title: Joint Time, Phase, and Amplitude Alignment of CIRMs for Accurate Sensing in UWB Systems
authors: Xi Hu, Xiaowei Cui, Ziyuan Sha, Mingquan Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Dual-function localization and sensing (DFLS) technology based on commercial communication and localization (CCL) UWB chips has attracted substantial attention, as it shares spectrum and hardware resources, enabling ubiquitous sensing without incurring additional hardware cost. In DFLS UWB systems, channel impulse response measurements (CIRMs) play a critical role in sensing tasks. However, non-ideal factors in UWB systems lead to time, phase, and amplitude misalignment among CIRMs, severely degrading sensing performance. Existing methods cannot achieve phase alignment, and rely on timestamps provided by CCL UWB chips for time alignment, which suffer from low accuracy in harsh environments. These shortcomings limit the applicability and functionality of DFLS UWB systems. This article investigates the CIRM misalignment issue in DFLS systems based on CCL UWB chips. Through an in-depth analysis of the DFLS architecture and UWB frame reception, we establish, for the first time, a mathematical model that characterizes the relationship between non-ideal factors in UWB systems and CIRM misalignment. Accordingly, we propose a joint time, phase, and amplitude CIRM alignment (JTPA-CIR) algorithm, Building upon the well-established bistatic synchronization methods, JTPA-CIR is tailored for DFLS UWB systems and extends this framework to multistatic cases. Exploiting the stability of the direct path in UWB propagation, JTPA-CIR estimates and compensates for the time delay, carrier phase, and amplitude discrepancies of the direct path across CIRMs that stem solely from CIRM misalignment. JTPA-CIR eliminates the reliance on chip-provided timestamps, and achieves CIRM alignment in time, phase and amplitude. Experimental results verify the effectiveness of JTPA-CIR and demonstrate its substantial improvement in sensing performance over existing methods.

title: A Robust Defect Detection Method for Vision-based Measurement System via Wavelet-guided Spatial-Frequency Prior Network
authors: Zhitao Wen, Jinhai Liu, Jianhua Tang, He Zhao, Lin Jiang, Qiannan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Robust defect detection is a crucial link in vision-based measurement systems. However, noise and lighting in complex industrial environments can weaken the structural and edge information of defects, leading to unsatisfactory measurement accuracy. Recent studies have employed discrete wavelet transform (DWT) to enhance defect features using multi-resolution frequency subbands. However, they exhibit a bias toward frequency branches that compromise spatial cues, resulting in inadequate feature enhancement. To address these challenges, this study considers enhancing measurement features from a joint spatial–frequency perspective and proposes a wavelet-guided spatial-frequency prior network (WSP-Net). At the structural level, a dynamic prior excavator and a dual-domain detail aggregator are constructed to adaptively mine and aggregate discriminative spatial-frequency defect priors. At the decision level, a frequency-assisted task-aware head (FT-Head) is customized to further enhance task-specific semantics and edges through decoupling DWT. In addition, joint supervision is introduced to constrain fine regression for complex defects with ambiguous boundaries. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance across various vision-based measurement systems (e.g., PCB: 95.7% mAP; steel plates: 82.1% mAP; pipelines: 98.7% mAP), while maintaining low computational cost (Parameters: 9.1M, FLOPs: 12.8G FPS: 235-284 imgs/s). It also achieves remarkable performance under strong noise and low-light conditions. Furthermore, generalization analysis using real-world pipeline data from MFL-based measurements indicates that the method holds strong potential for engineering applications in real-world measurement systems.

title: Polar Subarea-Aware Fusion Net for Posterior Eyeball Shape Reconstruction
authors: Jiaqi Zhang, Xiuzhe Wu, Jiahui Liu, Chunyu Zou, Fengze Nie, Zicheng Sun, Xiaojuan Qi, Jiang Liu
abstract: High-fidelity reconstruction of the Posterior Eyeball Shape (PES) is crucial for early diagnosis and timely intervention of sight-threatening diseases such as high myopia, diabetic retinopathy, and glaucoma. However, existing magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)- and optical coherence tomography (OCT)-based methods either provide only coarse scleral geometry or suffer from suboptimal PES representations due to limited field of view (FOV) and detail loss, hindering accurate assessment of intact retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) abnormalities. In this study, we propose the Polar Subarea-Aware Fusion Net (PSAFNet), a novel end-to-end framework that reconstructs complete and high-fidelity PES directly from a single local OCT scan, even under clinically common settings with only 6.25% FOV. To avoid information loss, we reformulate PES reconstruction as a 2D dense regression task and introduce the Ocular Shape Map (OSM), an innovative lossless 2D representation that encodes 3D coordinate attributes into corresponding image channels. PSAFNet then leverages three dedicated modules—Subarea Feature Embedding Module (SFEM), Channel- and Patch-wise Fusion Blocks (CFB/PFB), and Reassemble and Up-sample Module (RUM)—to enhance positional awareness, integrate local–global features, and achieve high-resolution OSM prediction. Furthermore, we construct two large-scale datasets, POSDiag and PESGen, comprising 794 ultra-widefield OCT scans from diverse health conditions and imaging devices, providing a comprehensive benchmark for PES reconstruction. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PSAFNet consistently outperforms existing methods (e.g., EMD=5.58, AAL=97.3%) and exhibits strong clinical relevance, validated by superior performance in downstream disease classification and ophthalmologist evaluations (Expert-Score=82.78%). The source code of the proposed PSAFNet is released at https://github.com/HKUZJ77/PSAFNet.

title: Semisupervised High-Order Graph Diffusion Network for Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis of Rotating Machinery
authors: Xiang Li, Jun Ma, Jiande Wu, Jing Na, Zhuorui Li
abstract: In recent years, the superiority of graph neural networks (GNNs) in the aspect of relational modeling has been confirmed in rotating machinery fault diagnosis field. However, most GNNs based intelligent diagnostic methods struggle to construct high-precision and low-complexity graph and perform poorly without efficient graph update strategies. To solve these problems, a semisupervised high-order graph diffusion network (SHGDN) for cross domain fault diagnosis is proposed in this study. First, the discriminative subsequences called Shapelets are sufficiently extracted by diffusion model. Thereafter, fast dynamic time warping and sparse strategy are leveraged to construct dynamic graph with semantic perception ability. Second, a high-order graph diffusion network based on approximate personalized propagation of neural predictions is put forward, which can implement dual-stream aggregation modeling for local first-order neighbors and global high-order neighbors. Then, the pseudolabel guided dynamic graph optimization and Leiden algorithm-based subgraph exchange enhancement is developed to reduce the cumulative propagation of pseudolabel errors. Finally, the explicit theoretical connection between graph construction and graph update is established, which can break the limitation of parameter isolation and provide a unified framework for model optimization. The proposed method is demonstrated on datasets from three types, and the experimental results indicate the SHGDN achieves the average accuracy of 97.29<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, surpassing other state-of-the-art methods.

title: Correcting Misperceptions at a Glance: Using Data Visualizations to Reduce Political Sectarianism
authors: Douglas Markant, Subham Sah, Alireza Karduni, Milad Rogha, My Thai, Wenwen Dou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Political sectarianism is fueled in part by misperceptions of political opponents: People commonly overestimate the support for extreme policies among members of the other party. These misperceptions inflame partisan animosity and may be used to justify extremism among one's own party. Research suggests that correcting partisan misperceptions-by informing people about the actual views of outparty members-may reduce one's own expressed support for political extremism, including partisan violence and antidemocratic actions. However, there remains a limited understanding of how the design of correction interventions drives these effects. The present study investigated how correction effects depend on different representations of outparty views communicated through data visualizations. Building on prior interventions that present the average outparty view, we consider the impact of visualizations that more fully convey the range of views among outparty members. We conducted an experiment with U.S.-based participants from Prolific (N=239 Democrats, N=244 Republicans). Participants made predictions about support for political violence and undemocratic practices among members of their political outparty. They were then presented with data from an earlier survey on the actual views of outparty members. Some participants viewed only the average response (Mean-Only condition), while other groups were shown visual representations of the range of views from 75% of the outparty (Mean+Interval condition) or the full distribution of responses (Mean+Points condition). Compared to a control group that was not informed about outparty views, we observed the strongest correction effects (i.e., lower support for political violence and undemocratic practices) among participants in the Mean-only and Mean+Points condition, while correction effects were weaker in the Mean+Interval condition. In addition, participants who observed the full distribution of out-party views (Mean+Points condition) were most accurate at later recalling the degree of support among the outparty. Our findings suggest that data visualizations can be an important tool for correcting pervasive distortions in beliefs about other groups. However, the way in which variability in outparty views is visualized can significantly shape how people interpret and respond to corrective information.

title: Expanding Access to Science Participation: A FAIR Framework for Petascale Data Visualization and Analytics
authors: Aashish Panta, Alper Sahistan, Xuan Huang, Amy A. Gooch, Giorgio Scorzelli, Hector Torres, Patrice Klein, Gustavo A. Ovando-Montejo, Peter Lindstrom, Valerio Pascucci
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: The massive data generated by scientists daily serve as both a major catalyst for new discoveries and innovations, as well as a significant roadblock that restricts access to the data. Our paper introduces a new approach to removing big data barriers and democratizing access to petascale data for the broader scientific community. Our novel data fabric abstraction layer allows user-friendly querying of scientific information while hiding the complexities of dealing with file systems or cloud services. We enable FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) access to datasets such as NASA's petascale climate datasets. Our paper presents an approach to managing, visualizing, and analyzing petabytes of data within a browser on equipment ranging from the top NASA supercomputer to commodity hardware like a laptop. Our novel data fabric abstraction utilizes state-of-the art progressive compression algorithms and machinelearning insights to power scalable visualization dashboards for petascale data. The result provides users with the ability to identify extreme events or trends dynamically, expanding access to scientific data and further enabling discoveries. We validate our approach by improving the ability of climate scientists to visually explore their data via three fully interactive dashboards. We further validate our approach by deploying the dashboards and simplified training materials in the classroom at a minorityserving institution. These dashboards, released in simplified form to the general public, contribute significantly to a broader push to democratize the access and use of climate data.

title: A spatial-temporal seamless evapotranspiration product based on TSEB-SM model and DNN-ETo method across China
authors: Gengle Zhao, Lisheng Song, William P. Kustas, Long Zhao, Shaomin Liu, Gaofei Yin, Rongqi Tang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate, seamless products of evapotranspiration (ET) are crucial for understanding the hydrological and energy cycles. Currently, there is no routinely available daily ET product based on the thermal infrared satellite data and two source energy balance (TSEB) models over China. In this study, we developed a seamless ET dataset (also including transpiration, T and evaporation, E) for China from 2001 to 2020, with spatial and temporal resolutions of 0.01° and daily, respectively. This dataset is generated through the two-source energy balance model coupled to soil moisture (TSEB-SM) and a novel reconstruction method (DNN-ETo) using deep neural networks and reference evapotranspiration. This dataset showed good agreement with ground measurements across various landcover types with a RMSE, bias, NSE and KGE of 1.02 mm day-1, -0.17 mm day-1, 0.51 and 0.73. Regarding spatial distributions and interannual variations, TSEB-SM ET exhibits similar performance to previous studies, while providing more reasonable values in the arid and semi-arid regions. The dataset has high potential in water resources management and climate change research. The TSEB-SM ET product is freely available at https://doi.org/10.11888/Terre.tpdc.301340.

title: DeepWavelet: A Multimodal Wavelet-Based Network for Sonar–Inertial Odometry in Underwater Robots
authors: Jibo Bai, Daqi Zhu, Mingzhi Chen
abstract: To effectively fuse multisource underwater sensor data and enhance the localization accuracy of underwater robots in complex environments, we propose a multimodal end-to-end sonar–inertial odometry deep learning network tailored for underwater environments, named DeepWavelet. The network jointly utilizes imaging sonar images and inertial measurement unit (IMU) sequence data to estimate the absolute trajectory of the underwater robot. Specifically, DeepWavelet converts interframe sonar images into point clouds to enrich the input representation. A spatial feature extraction module is applied to the sonar images to capture features rich in edges and textures, which are further decomposed into low- and high-frequency components via the Haar wavelet transform and then fused. Meanwhile, point cloud information is processed through feature extraction and grid mapping to obtain a structured spatial representation. In parallel, the IMU data are modeled using a network based on gated recurrent units to extract temporal features incorporating sensor biases. Moreover, to bridge the gap between cross-modal and cross-scale features, a multiscale dual-modal alignment filter is proposed, employing a dual cross-attention mechanism to achieve deep fusion of different modalities. Experimental results demonstrate that DeepWavelet achieves outstanding localization accuracy and generalization ability on both simulation and real-world data sets. Even in challenging scenarios characterized by large interframe intervals and severe data loss, DeepWavelet exhibits greater robustness compared to traditional methods.

title: 100 GHz-Carrier Broadband OFDM Radio Transmission enabled by Photonic Integrated Optical Clock Synthesizer
authors: Antonio Malacarne, Muhammad Imran, Alberto Montanaro, Antonio D'Errico, Vito Sorianello, Giuseppe Virone, Antonella Bogoni, Claudio Porzi
abstract: We report on the performance of a monolithically integrated silicon photonics <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim$</tex-math></inline-formula>100 GHz-carrier synthesizer, and its application in a radio transmission system. The photonic integrated circuit (PIC) includes an optical frequency comb generation stage driven by a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim$</tex-math></inline-formula> 20-GHz reference clock, followed by an innovative multi-resonant distributed feedback resonator-based optical filter for selecting the two comb components generating the target <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim$</tex-math></inline-formula> 100 GHz-carrier wave in an off-chip photodiode. Phase noise (PN) characterization of the synthesized W-band signal indicates operation in agreement with ideal frequency multiplication of the employed reference clock. In addition, the flat-tops spectral feature of the photonic integrated filter allows the output frequency to be tuned in the range 96 — 100 GHz without significant PN degradation. A 97-GHz optical local oscillator is then used to up-convert and succesfully transmit broadband wireless data signals with different complex modulation formats, including single-carrier and orthogonal frequency division multiplexed (OFDM) QPSK and 16-QAM, with net information rate up to 4 Gb/s.

title: Resilient Secondary Frequency Control in Distributed Renewable Energy Microgrids Under Cyber Attacks: A Double Replay Q-Learning Approach
authors: Yu Zhang, Minrui Fei, Dajun Du, Yukun Hu
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of resilient secondary frequency control in distributed renewable energy microgrids under False Data Injection Attacks. A rigorous Lyapunov based stability analysis is conducted, and a formal theorem is established that quantifies the maximum tolerable attack intensity under both actuator and sensor side intrusions. This theoretical tolerance boundary provides a principled and interpretable threshold for real time attack detection and secure control activation. Building upon this result, we propose a resilience framework that tightly integrates the derived physical safety boundary with an adaptive reinforcement learning controller. Specifically, a Double Replay Q-learning algorithm is developed, leveraging dual Q-tables and prioritized experience replay to enhance convergence speed and robustness under nonlinear REM dynamics. Simulation results conducted on both a real world experimental REM platform and a modified IEEE 9-Node test system validate the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed approach.

title: Analytical Solution for Electric Potential in a Homogeneous Anisotropic Spherical Head Model with Directional Conductivity
authors: Konstantina Bampali, Maria Hadjinicolaou, Gregory Kamvyssas
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Homogeneous anisotropic spherical model is employed to represent the human head, assuming uniform conductivity throughout the domain with directional anisotropy in both the radial and tangential directions. The internal anatomical complexity of the head, comprising distinct biological tissues such as brain matter, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skull, and scalp with varying electrical conductivities is not considered in this model. Analytical expressions for the electric potential generated by a dipolar source at varying depths within the head are derived, with particular emphasis on the role of anisotropy in the radial direction. Our findings show that anisotropic conductivity significantly influences the potential distribution, especially for deeper sources, as compared to isotropic models. For instance, at a source depth of 0.01 m, the electric potential in the anisotropic model is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0161315 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{V}$</tex>, while for a 0.06 m depth, the potential increases to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.17645 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{V}$</tex>. These results demonstrate that deeper sources experience a greater effect from anisotropic tissues, which underscores the importance of incorporating tissue-specific anisotropy into EEG modeling. Additionally, our study corroborates prior researches, highlighting the critical need to account for the anisotropy of cranial tissues, particularly the skull and white matter, to avoid significant source localization errors. By integrating anisotropic conductivity tensor, this work improves the forward problem solution and contributes to more accurate inverse source localization, with implications for both clinical and research applications in non-invasive brain mapping.

title: On Temporal Robustness & Brain-State Stability of Functional Connectivity in Mouse Primary Visual Area V1 Compared to Higher Visual Area AL
authors: Mario Alexios Savaglio, Christina Brozi, Stelios M. Smirnakis, Maria Papadopouli
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Understanding how the structure of functional connectivity in the visual cortex changes over time and across brain states is crucial for elucidating the mechanisms by which neurons coordinate to process information and support behavior. Higherorder visual areas in mice are known to exhibit more distinct, segregated functional roles compared to the primary visual cortex (V1) [1], and they maintain stimulus representations over extended time scales [2]. However, the stability of the architecture of their functional connectivity across time and brain states remains less understood. In vivo mesoscopic two-photon calcium imaging was used to simultaneously record activity from thousands of neurons across V1 and the extra-striate anterolateral area (AL) in mice, during both visual stimulation (optical-flow/motion) and at resting state (i.e., absence of stimulus). We then applied the spike time-tiling (STTC) coefficient [3] to estimate the pairwise correlations of the neuronal firing and form the functional connectivity at the cell resolution. We then comparatively analyzed the functional connections within area AL and V1 under both stimulus-driven and resting-state conditions. The functional connectivity within AL remains consistently more robust over time than in area V1. Moreover, the structure of the functional connectivity in AL exhibits a smaller change between these two conditions compared to V1, indicating that functional connectivity derived from spontaneous activity more faithfully reflects the functional network architecture elicited by visual stimulation in this higherorder area. Finally, during the resting state, AL activity and functional connectivity are less dependent on pupil size than those of V1, indicating that arousal exerts a weaker modulatory effect on AL compared to V1.

title: Coordinated Intra-Day and Seasonal Hydrogen Storage Optimization for a Wind–Solar–Hydro Integrated Energy System
authors: Xiongli Wang, Xiaoyi Ding, Chenyan Mao, Zhikun Shi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy, the volatility and seasonality of wind–solar–hydropower systems have become increasingly prominent. Hydrogen energy storage, with its capability for multi-time-scale regulation, has become a key approach to enhancing system stability and flexibility. This paper develops an optimization model for a multi-energy system integrating photovoltaics, wind power, hydropower, electrolyzers, fuel cells, and both short-term and seasonal hydrogen storage. The model incorporates three operating modes of electrolyzers to reflect differences in efficiency. Using real-world data from southwestern China, the study systematically compares three hydrogen storage strategies—short-term storage, seasonal storage, and dual-cycle coordinated storage—based on key indicators such as operating cost, energy consumption, and electricity purchases. Results show that the dual-cycle strategy reduces electricity purchases by 33.4%, limits start-up/shutdown energy consumption to within 1260 kWh, and lowers total operating costs to below 182 million CNY, significantly outperforming the single-mode strategies. Further analysis demonstrates that this strategy combines the rapid responsiveness of short-term storage with the large-scale balancing capability of seasonal storage, achieving a favorable balance between economic performance and operational reliability. It is well suited for optimizing hydrogen storage dispatch in high-renewable-penetration scenarios.

title: SOC Estimation of Energy Storage Lithium ion Battery Pack Based on GA-CNN
authors: Weikang Kong, Erhui He, Xinwei Wang, Huaizhao Liu, Xiaohui Li, Jiali Qin
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: This article uses the weights and thresholds of convolutional neural network (CNN) as chromosome in the Genetic Algorithm (GA), and the reciprocal of loss function of CNN as the objective function of GA, to construct the GA-CNN for predicting the state of charge (SOC) of energy storage lithium-ion battery groups. Using the charging and discharging data collected on-site from the energy storage system as samples, the algorithm proposed in this paper, the support vector machine (SVM) optimized based on GA, and CNN were used for training, and the prediction performance of the three algorithms was compared on the complete charging and discharging dataset. The results show that the algorithm in this article has good convergence and high prediction accuracy.

title: DTranIDS: A Two-Tiered Intrusion Detection System for RPL-based IoT Networks based on Decision Tree and Transformer Models
authors: Mohammad Fazeli, Mohsen Raji, Mohammad Mahdi Fazeli
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: RPL (Routing Protocol for Low-Power and Lossy Networks) has emerged as the de facto standard for IoT routing, offering robust, energy-efficient, and scalable communication. However, its susceptibility to unique cyber-security attacks demands robust security enhancements to ensure reliable deployment. Although Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) offer a proactive defense mechanism to mitigate RPL's inherent vulnerabilities, traditional IDS solutions are often too resource-intensive for IoT environments. Therefore, there is a critical need for lightweight-yet-accurate IDS frameworks specifically designed for RPL-based networks. In this paper, we propose a novel two-tier intrusion detection system, DTranIDS, designed to effectively identify and classify RPL-specific attacks in IoT environments. In the first tier, a Decision Tree classifier rapidly filters incoming data to determine whether a given instance is benign or malicious. In the second tier, a Transformer-based model is employed to precisely classify the specific type of detected attack. Unlike prior hybrid shallow-deep approaches that rely on heavy and computationally intensive models, DTranIDS leverages the Transformer for efficient deep feature extraction, making it significantly faster and lighter while maintaining high classification accuracy. This combination of cascading decision filtering and a lightweight deep model constitutes the core innovation of this work, enabling both real-time detection and detailed attack classification in resource-constrained IoT environments. The proposed model is evaluated using the ROUT-4-2023 dataset, which includes four common RPL routing attacks: Blackhole, Flooding, Version Number, and Decreased Rank. Experimental results demonstrate that DTranIDS achieves an overall accuracy of 97%, with precision, recall, and F1-score values all around 96%, significantly outperforming several state-of-the-art IoT intrusion detection methods (which typically achieve 88–91% accuracy). Moreover, DTranIDS shows its efficiency in fast intrusion detection (about 0.4 s), indicating that it is well-suited for real-world, resource-constrained IoT environments, offering both real-time intrusion detection and detailed attack classification capabilities to aid cybersecurity analysts.

title: Risk Assessment Method for Voltage Sags Considering Fluctuations in PV and ESS
authors: Shuaibin Shi, Yongli Liu, Xiaowei Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With deep integration of photovoltaic (PV) and energy storage system (ESS) systems introducing significant power fluctuations into modern grids, traditional voltage sag severity assessment becomes inadequate due to its static modeling assumptions. This study develops a novel probabilistic framework to accurately evaluate sag severity by explicitly incorporating PV-ES output variability. Key innovations comprise: 1) A joint scenario reduction technique generating representative PV-ES operational states to streamline computational processes; 2) A dynamic impedance-adaptive voltage divider model that modifies conventional sag magnitude calculations to reflect power fluctuation impacts; 3) A composite risk quantification index integrating sag characteristics under stochastic PV-ES outputs. The proposed methodology establishes a rigorous framework for voltage sag risk assessment in high-renewable-penetration power systems. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated using the IEEE 30-node system.

title: Study on Droplet Motion Mechanism in Microchannels of Marine PEM Fuel Cells
authors: Shikun Zhou, Guohua Pang, Bingju Lu, Yuhang Li, Chuang You, Jinsi Cai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: The application of fuel cells in underwater vehicles offers significant advantages, including depth-independent operation and wake-free performance. In this study, the Lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) was employed with a single-component multiphase Shan-Chen model to investigate droplet transport processes in the microchannels of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) for marine applications. The findings demonstrate that moderate inlet gas velocity and hydrophobic channel walls facilitate effective droplet removal.

title: Optimization of Low-Sidelobe Concentric Ring Antenna Arrays
authors: Xiuyu Wang, Yan Liu, Yurong Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: To address the peak sidelobe level (PSLL) suppression in thin concentric circular antenna arrays (CCAA), this paper proposes a collaborative optimization framework integrating the genetic algorithm (GA) and the dandelion optimizer (DGO).The proposed method improves the real-coded genetic algorithm (MGA) to generate the initial population and incorporates the Lévy flight diffusion mechanism of DGO to enhance global search capability, optimizing both the array radii and element distribution. The proposed method effectively suppresses the sidelobe level (SLL) of concentric ring arrays while demonstrating faster convergence compared to conventional algorithms. Experimental results validate both the accuracy and effectiveness of the hybrid optimization approach.

title: Mobile Ultraviolet Imaging for Intelligent Partial Discharge Identification
authors: Chunxiang Mao, Qingjie Zhao, Kangyu Pei, Yiyu Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: As high voltage converter station equipment and operating environments grow increasingly complex, automated and intelligent on-site inspection has become an urgent demand. Traditional partial discharge (PD) detection methods are constrained by field noise and sunlight interference, struggling to meet unattended inspection needs. Ultraviolet (UV) imaging-based PD detection, with its sensitivity to the "sun-blind" band (220–280 nm), exhibits superior performance in complex outdoor scenarios, as this specific wavelength range effectively avoids ambient light interference and enhances signal-to-noise ratio.This paper presents an intelligent detection system integrating UV imaging acquisition and a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) for PD recognition, deployed on a quadruped robot platform to enable stable operation and real-time data processing in field environments. The quadruped robot’s adaptive movement capability allows it to traverse uneven terrains common in converter stations, while the lightweight CNN model ensures efficient computation without compromising detection accuracy.

title: Towards Transparent and Accurate Story Point Estimation via Interpretable BERT-based Modeling
authors: Seyed Emad Baradaran Hosseini, Maryam Khodabakhsh, Alireza Tajary, Seyedehfatemeh Karimi
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: This study proposes a novel approach for estimating story points in agile software projects by leveraging advanced natural language processing (NLP) models combined with interpretability techniques. Task descriptions are first transformed into semantic embedding vectors, and then classified into four categories—Small, Medium, Large, and Huge—using a BERT-based classifier. To enhance model interpretability, the CLS embedding vectors are extracted, dimensionally reduced, and clustered via K-Means to clearly reveal class boundaries and overlaps. Experimental results demonstrate a high overall accuracy of 88.71% and an average F1-score exceeding 0.87, significantly outperforming baseline methods. Analysis of confusion matrices and semantic clustering indicates challenges in distinguishing between the small and medium classes, which could be alleviated by incorporating richer contextual features. The proposed framework, by providing interpretable insights alongside robust accuracy, represents an important step towards increasing transparency and trustworthiness in intelligent story point estimation systems for agile projects. Finally, recommendations for future work include employing more advanced language models, optimizing model performance, and expanding training datasets for improved generalizability.

title: Assist-as-Needed Control for FES in Foot Drop Management
authors: Andreas Christou, Elliot Lister, Georgia Andreopoulou, Don Mahad, Sethu Vijayakumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Foot drop is commonly managed using Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES), typically delivered via open-loop controllers with fixed stimulation intensities. While users may manually adjust the intensity through external controls, this approach risks overstimulation, leading to muscle fatigue and discomfort, or understimulation, which compromises dorsiflexion and increases fall risk. In this study, we propose a novel closed-loop FES controller that dynamically adjusts the stimulation intensity based on real-time toe clearance, providing “assistance as needed”. We evaluate this system by inducing foot drop in healthy participants and comparing the effects of the closed-loop controller with a traditional open-loop controller across various walking conditions, including different speeds and surface inclinations. Kinematic data reveal that our closed-loop controller maintains adequate toe clearance without significantly affecting the joint angles of the hips, the knees, and the ankles, and while using significantly lower stimulation intensities compared to the open-loop controller. These findings suggest that the proposed method not only matches the effectiveness of existing systems but also offers the potential for reduced muscle fatigue and improved long-term user comfort and adherence.

title: Effect of Flight Parameters on Solid Rocket Motor Plume Flow
authors: Ruyan Zhao, Qing Xin, Jingru Huang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Through an integrated numerical simulation study on the nozzle and plume flow field of a solid rocket motor for an aircraft, this research analyzes the effects of flight altitude and Mach number on the plume flow characteristics of the solid rocket motor. The ground numerical simulation results are consistent with the ground test results, and the calculation has high reliability. Numerical simulation results show that the plume boundary of solid rocket motor increases with the increase of flying height under the same flying Mach number. With the increase of flying Mach number at the same flying altitude, the plume boundary of solid rocket motor decreases accordingly. At the same time, the plume structure varies greatly with flight conditions.

title: Enhancement of Anterior Cruciate Ligament Tear Diagnosis using Optimized Hyperparameters in Deep Learning Models
authors: Pallikonda Rajasekaran M, Sivashankari T, Md. Jakir Hossen, Wai Kit Wong, Poh Kiat Ng, Kottaimalai Ramaraj, Arunprasath T, Rajesh K
abstract: Musculoskeletal disorders must be treated early, and an accurate diagnosis is very important. Among them Anterior Crucial Ligament (ACL) tears occur mostly in athletes (50%-70%), aged people (5%-10%) and people with previous injuries (20%-30%). ACL tears are complicated to identify, and segmentation is also a tedious process because of their complex morphological structures. Along with manual interpretation, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) diagnosis is essential in confirming the ACL tears. An automated decision support system aids medical professionals in detecting and confirming the ACL tears. Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models are efficient in feature selection as it recognizes textures with local connectivity and spatial hierarchy. Hyperparameter values vary depending on the dataset and neural network architectures. As manual tuning is performed unsystematically, it is time-consuming to identify the correct parameters. So, the proposed work trained CNN-based deep learning models to classify knee MRI into normal, partial torn and full torn ACL. Also, the hyperparameters are optimized efficiently by Bayesian optimization techniques. With the implementation of transfer learning, SqueezeNet, DarkNet-53 and DenseNet-201 are compared with the performance of optimized hyperparameters. After Bayesian Optimization, these models performed well with greater accuracy and less computational time. In conclusion, optimized SqueezeNet, DarkNet-53 and DenseNet-201 architectures provide an efficient decision support system to assist healthcare professionals in diagnosis of ACL tears.

title: Multi-Directional Car License Plate Detection Using MDYOLO
authors: A. Samatha, Madarapu Vasanth Rao, Rehaam Abdohwr, Bhogi Jayaram, Boi Rajesh, Yalla Jeevan Nagendra Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: This study presents a novel convolutional neural network (CNN)-based method for high-accuracy real time car license plate detection. Many modern methods of detecting a car's license plate are only good under very specific conditions or strong assumptions, such as when the captured image is clear and taken under good lighting conditions. However, they perform poorly if the assessed car license plate images have a degree of rotation due to the manual capture by traffic police or deviation of the camera. In order to detect car license plates in both directions, we propose a CNN based MD-YOLO framework. MD-YOLO is an extended version of YOLO framework which will be helpful for detecting the number plates from the images which are taken from the side view. Our method, which makes use of precise rotation angle prediction and a fast intersection-over-union evaluation strategy, effectively manages rotational issues in real-time scenarios. Several experiments have been conducted to show that the proposed method outperforms other current state-of-the-art methods in terms of better accuracy and lower computational cost.

title: A Real-Time Magnetic Positioning Algorithm Based on Simulated Annealing Algorithm
authors: Bowen Lv, Haijun Lin, Shijian Su
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: The potential applications of magnetic positioning technology extend across a broad range of disciplines, including medicine and industry. This study proposes a magnetic positioning method based on a simulated annealing (SA) algorithm, which has been evaluated through a series of 800 comparative experiments. In comparison to the whale optimization algorithm, genetic algorithm, and particle swarm optimization algorithm examined in previous research, SA has been shown to achieve the smallest objective function value, while also exhibiting the smallest standard deviation across all algorithms. These findings suggest that SA demonstrates better stability and superior positioning accuracy.

title: HKM-surg: A Hierarchical Knowledge-Guided Multimodal Surgical Instruction Tuning Method for Fine-Grained Surgical Action Prediction
authors: Ling Li, Zuxing Deng, Jingcheng Chen, Xiaojian Li, Qingyun Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: With the widespread application of minimally invasive surgery in modern healthcare, the demand for precise intraoperative operations and real-time decision-making continuously increases. Current research is largely based on coarse-grained data, making it difficult to achieve intelligent intra-operative decision-making.This paper proposes a novel hierarchical knowledge-guided multimodal surgical instruction tuning pipeline. This pipeline enhances the fine-grained surgical action prediction capabilities of multimodal large language models (MLLMs) in surgical environments. It does this by integrating visual temporal analysis with domain-specific surgical knowledge constraints. Experimental results demonstrate the substantial potential of hierarchical knowledge tips for specific phases, achieving optimal exact accuracy of 37.44% with 8 images and peak approximate accuracy of 57.85% with 5 images. The rise-then-fall pattern in performance indicates that increasing the number of images does not necessarily improve results, suggesting limitations in current models’ ability to effectively utilize sequential visual information. This work lays a foundation for further fine-grained surgical planning and decision-making.

title: Targetless Extrinsic Calibration of Fisheye Cameras Using Vehicle Detection and Monodepth Alignment in Cylindrical Image Space
authors: Gee Hoon Lee, Soon-Yong Park
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: We propose a novel targetless method for estimating the extrinsic parameters of multiple fisheye cameras mounted outside of a vehicle. Without using any artificial calibration target, we use image features in the detected road vehicles and depth data of the surrounding scenes. To solve the severe image distortion problem, fisheye images are first transformed into cylindrical image space. This enables the direct use of existing object detection and monocular depth estimation networks. After the image transformation, feature points in the detected vehicles are extracted and matched across multiple camera views. At the same time, the estimated depth from the monodepth network is used to convert the cylindrical images into 3D point clouds. To solve the inherent scale ambiguity in monocular depth, the depth information of the surrounding scene is rescaled using the assumption that the xz-plane of the front camera is parallel to the ground. Then, the point clouds were aligned to estimate the camera poses, and the scale was corrected accordingly. Video sequences from the fisheye cameras are used to collect sufficient image features and depth for this process. We validate our method through both real-world and simulation-based experiments. The evaluation results show that the proposed method outperforms COLMAP and DUSt3R even under conditions of wide baseline and low frame rate. These results indicate that the proposed method is effective in practical scenarios and can be applied without the use of calibration targets.

title: Enhancing Electricity Theft Detection: Optimized Model Calibration for Illicit Crypto Mining
authors: Milad Khani, Mohammad Pouyani, Mostafa Hoorzad
abstract: The unauthorized use of electricity for cryptocurrency mining in low-tariff countries is a growing issue, causing significant losses for utility companies. Existing studies focus only on preprocessing and model fitting but overlook postprocessing and uncertainty in theft detection. This article highlights the need for a complete model workflow, including postprocessing, to improve decision-making. We first explore post hoc calibration methods to enhance probability estimates. Then, we optimize probability thresholds to improve classification performance in imbalanced data. The proposed methodology is validated using real-world data from the Mashhad Electric Energy Distribution Company, demonstrating its effectiveness in accurately detecting illicit electricity use for mining.

title: Comparative Study of Machine Learning and Deep Learning Algorithms for Customer Support Ticket Classification: Evidence From Public and Enterprise Datasets
authors: Jittirat Boonklay, Supakpong Jinarat
abstract: The automation of customer support operations depends on proper ticket classification systems to achieve better operational efficiency and faster response times. The research evaluates eight algorithms including Naive Bayes and Decision Tree and Random Forest and Logistic Regression and Support Vector Machine and XGBoost and Convolutional Neural Network and Recurrent Neural Network for ticket classification tasks. The research utilized two datasets which included public Kaggle information and confidential enterprise data through twelve testing scenarios that analyzed both category and priority classification with three different text sources (title, description and full text). Most algorithms demonstrated exceptional performance in priority classification because this task proved simpler than category classification according to the results (Accuracy/F1 > 0.95). The enterprise dataset results showed that category classification proved more difficult than priority classification because enterprise-specific terminology decreased overall accuracy. The combination of title and description text in input data led to better model performance in all experimental runs. The performance of deep learning models was matched or exceeded by classical machine learning algorithms including Logistic Regression and SVM and XGBoost. The CNN achieved optimal results when processing complete ticket texts but RNN demonstrated poor performance especially when working with brief ticket titles. The research indicates that traditional machine learning algorithms should be considered for ticket classification systems because they deliver both strong performance and efficient computation. The research team plans to study transformerbased models together with multilingual datasets to boost real-world application robustness.

title: Tuning the Structural and Optical Properties of Graphene Quantum Dots via NaOH Concentration in Hydrothermal Synthesis
authors: Aida Zulia Zulhanip, Nor Shahanim Mohamad Hadis, Zurita Zulkifli, Afaf Rozan Mohd Radzol, Anis Diyana Rosli, Nur Atiqah Azman
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) concentration on the structural and optical properties of the synthesized graphene quantum dots (GQDs) via the hydrothermal cutting method. Graphene oxide (GO) is used as a starting material. NaOH concentration varied at 0.1 M, 0.5 M, and 1.0 M. The study’s comprehensive characterization, including UHR-SEM, EDX, TEM, XRD, FTIR, Raman, UV-Vis, PL, and zeta potential, revealed that 0.5 M NaOH yielded optimal GQDs with well-dispersed particles (~ 3.3 nm) and higher colloidal stability (-42.6 mV). In contrast, 0.1 M concentration resulted in a smaller average size (~1.3 nm) but formed aggregated particles while 1.0 M concentration led to excessive oxidation and structural degradation of the carbon material. These findings highlight the crucial role of NaOH concentration in tuning the structural and optical characteristics of GQDs and offer insights into optimizing their performance for practical implementation in future nanomaterial applications

title: Research on Automatic Identification Method of Downhole Casing Defects Based on VMD-CFAR Joint Detection
authors: Bo Dang, Yang Han, Ling Yang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: The structural integrity of oil and gas well casings is directly related to production safety and environmental risk prevention and control. However, under the coupled effects of high temperature, high pressure, chemical corrosion, and complex in-situ stress, it is highly prone to induce hidden damages such as pipe wall thickness reduction and microcrack propagation. Traditional damage detection methods based on fixed thresholds have significant limitations under complex downhole noise interference, often leading to an uncontrollable increase in the false alarm rate, which severely restricts detection reliability. To address this issue, this study proposes a variational mode decomposition-constant false alarm rate (VMD-CFAR) joint detection framework: First, the original logging signals are subjected to adaptive frequency band decomposition via VMD to suppress background noise interference; then, the optimally selected intrinsic mode function (IMF) components are input into multi-type CFAR detectors to achieve threshold decision-making with dynamic background perception. Through systematic simulation experiments, the combined performance of different IMF components and CFAR algorithms is quantitatively analyzed, and the optimal VMD-CFAR parameterization scheme is finally determined.

title:
Effect of Acidic Environment and Precursor Type on Hematite (α-Fe
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
