                    ) Growth via Hydrothermal Synthesis
authors: Wan Rosmaria Wan Ahmad, Mohamad Hafiz Mamat, Ahmad Sabirin Zoolfakar, Norhazlin Khairudin, Norfarariyanti Parimon, Mohamad Syahrir Suidan
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This study investigates the effect of acidic conditions on the structural and optical properties of hematite (Fe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) nanostructures synthesized via hydrothermal approach. Iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>·6H2O) was used as a precursor both with and without hydrochloric acid (HCl), denoted as FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl and FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, respectively. The results highlight the important role of acidity in the synthesis process, with HCl improving hematite nanostructure formation by enhancing precursor dispersion and light transmission. A comparison of chloride- and nitrate-based precursors showed that Fe(NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>)<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> combined with HCl leads to better hematite growth than FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> with HCl XRD analysis confirmed the presence of hematite in all samples, with FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> showing higher peak intensities but FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl producing thicker structures (1275.83 nm) compared to FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> alone (954.78nm). Fe(NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>)<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl exhibited distinct crystallinity and higher XRD counts relative to the chloride-based samples. VP-FESEM revealed that FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl leads to the formation of nanorods, while Fe(NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>)<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl generates spherical nanoballs, attributed to the influence of nitrate ions. Optical characterizations showed increased transmittance in the FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>+HCl sample due to its semiconducting nature, while absorbance spectra confirmed the presence of Fe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>. Overall, the findings offer valuable insights into how acidity and precursor selection influence the tailored growth of hematite nanostructures, presenting potential strategies for optimizing their hydrothermal synthesis.

title: Performance Evaluation of YOLO-based Models for Coral Species Detection
authors: Aung Hein Bo Bo, Karn Yongsiriwit
abstract: Coral reefs are vital for marine biodiversity but are increasingly endangered by climate change, pollution, and human activities. Therefore, monitoring these habitats is critical for conservation, yet conventional survey methods are time-consuming and lack stability. This study addresses these difficulties by evaluating the performance of recent YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection models-YOLOv8 through YOLOv12-for automatic coral species detection in underwater imagery. The project utilizes 646 annotated underwater images containing six coral species from the SCoralDet dataset, originally developed by the Coral Germplasm Conservation and Breeding Center at Hainan Tropical Ocean University, China. The dataset was pre-annotated and preprocessed using Roboflow and used for training and evaluation with the Ultralytics YOLO framework in Python. Models were evaluated based on key performance metrics: mean Average Precision (mAP@50), precision, recall, and inference speed. Among the models, results show that YOLOv9 achieved the highest detection accuracy (mAP@50 = 81.6%), while YOLOvl1 produced nearly comparable results (mAP@50 = 80.9%) with more consistent performance across evaluation metrics and faster inference. These findings illustrate the potential of recent YOLO models for precise, real-time detection of coral species and provide a comparative study that can inform future uses of deep learning in the monitoring of marine biodiversity.

title: Wide-Area Decentralized Energy Storage Station Clustering Method for Power System Dispatching
authors: Yunchao Sun, Yingqiang Han, Yu Dong, Jun Yang, Kexi Qian, Wei Hu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The integration of numerous multi-type energy storage stations complicates power system optimization scheduling. To maximize their regulatory potential, this article proposes a rapid clustering method for massive multi-type energy storage systems using an improved genetic algorithm. A comprehensive evaluation index system is established. It includes electrical distance, storage similarity, and demand matching degree. Subjective and objective weights are integrated to build the clustering framework. The improved genetic algorithm enables efficient large-scale storage clustering. Simulation results confirm that this method fully considers cluster structures and regulatory performance. It offers new insights for coordinated wide-area energy storage scheduling.

title: Triple-phase-shift-based Co-optimization of Current Stress and Soft Switching for Dual Active Bridge Converters
authors: Hongwei Xia, Xin Gao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Dual Active Bridge (DAB) DC-DC Converters, as critical interfaces in renewable energy systems, require efficiency optimization to ensure highly reliable power transmission. Traditional Single Phase Shift (SPS) control suffers from high current stress and limited soft-switching range under voltage mismatch conditions. To address these issues, this paper proposes a dual-objective optimization strategy for current stress and soft-switching compatibility based on Triple Phase Shift (TPS) control. By analyzing the operational modes and soft-switching constraints under TPS, normalized power and current stress models are established. The optimal phase-shift angle combinations are solved using the Lagrange Multiplier Method (LMM) combined with Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions, enabling minimum current stress and soft-switching compatibility across the full power range. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that, under a voltage ratio of k=2 and a power range of 0∼625W, the proposed strategy achieves a 32% reduction in current stress and improves overall efficiency by 5%–8%. This study provides theoretical support for multi-objective optimization control of DAB converters, with future research focusing on integrating dead-time effects and transient magnetic bias suppression strategies.

title: Long-Term Yearly Peak Load Forecasting, Using Artificial Intelligence, Time Series Analysis, and Trend Curve Techniques
authors: Hossein Aliyan, Seyed Hamid Khalkhali, Mohsen Taghizadeh Kejani
abstract: Long-term annual peak load forecasting is one of the critical issues in power system planning and development. Accurate prediction of peak load plays a vital role in capacity planning, energy resource management, and preventing potential crises in the electricity grid. Without precise peak load forecasting, planning for developing power plants, transmission lines, and related infrastructure will face significant challenges. Every country needs a clear understanding of its future energy consumption patterns to achieve its development goals and meet growing energy demands. This issue is particularly important in developing countries like Iran, which face increasing challenges in energy supply and demand. In this paper, the main objective is to forecast the long-term annual peak load in Iran. To achieve this goal, artificial intelligence methods such as LSTM, Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Decision Trees are utilized. Additionally, three curve-fitting models, including the Modified Exponential Curve, Logistic Curve, and Gompertz Curve, are employed for peak load forecasting. These methods are combined with time series modeling to enhance prediction accuracy. MATLAB software is used for implementing and testing all the proposed models, ensuring robust and reliable forecasting results. Finally, the performance of all these methods is compared, and the most suitable model for forecasting Iran's peak load is selected. This research not only provides an accurate method for peak load forecasting but also analyzes the strengths and weaknesses of each approach. The results demonstrate that combining artificial intelligence methods with time series modeling can serve as a powerful tool for long-term energy planning. This study can act as a practical guide for experts and policymakers in the field of power system management and development.

title: Tapered Optical Fibre Polarisation Control for Selective Whispering Gallery Mode Resonance Excitation
authors: Mohd Narizee Mohd Nasir, Zulfadzli Yusoff
abstract: The control of polarisation state of tapered optical fibre evanescent light wave is demonstrated with the utilisation of free-space optics polarisation resolved setup. Discrimination between TE- and TM-polarised light of > 20 dB could be achieved with the proposed setup on tapered optical fibre with waist diameter. Investigation on the performance of the proposed tapered optical fibre with whispering gallery mode (WGM) optical microresonators show distinguishable TE and TM group-mode families of sharp wavelength dip contrast.

title: Interactive Cyber-Physical System for ExoBrake: a Novel Drilling Collaborative Platform for Aerospace Manufacturing
authors: Erfan Dilfanian, Aghilès Yousfi, Seyedhossein Hajzargarbashi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: A cyber-physical system with digital twins is developed for the designed ExoBrake — a novel drilling collaborative platform capable of withstanding large clamping forces. Traditional robotic manipulators for aerospace drilling operations are huge, expensive, and lack safety, while cobots, which are more affordable and safer, cannot produce the required clamping force for the drilling process. However, we designed ExoBrake as an add-on kit for a cobot —currently under patent application— which can produce and withstand the required clamping force for drilling stacked metallic sheets in aerospace manufacturing. Moreover, an interactive Cyber-Physical System (CPS) with a graphical user interface is developed for ExoBrake, including online digital twins of ExoBrake, the workpiece, and the test bed. This CPS replicates digitally the assembly of the cobot-ExoBrake and enables the operator to configure the workpiece, define and execute drilling tasks. The main novelty of this CPS is the interactive drilling task definition from the workpiece geometry itself, rendered in the visualization panel. It also controls the entire system and drilling sequence. Experiments are conducted to ensure the CPS functions to apply a specific clamping force and control it during the drilling process.

title: Transforming Precision Agriculture through Deep Learning: CNN Encoder-Decoders and a Hybrid YOLOv8-SAM Solution for Advanced Grape Cluster Segmentation
authors: Sarish Gyale, Utkarsh Singh, Yashvardhan Tekavade, Parul Jadhav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: Accurate grape cluster segmentation is crucial for developing automated vineyard harvesting systems and precision agriculture applications. This paper presents a novel hybrid approach combining YOLOv8 object detection with Meta’s Segment Anything Model (SAM) for multi-cluster grape segmentation, alongside comprehensive evaluation of CNN encoder-decoder architectures for single-cluster scenarios. Using the GrapesNet dataset containing over 11,000 diverse vineyard images, we trained and evaluated various segmentation models including U-Net variants with pre-trained encoders, SegNet architectures, and fully convolutional networks (FCNs). The MobileNetV2-UNet achieved superior single-cluster segmentation with mIoU of 0.906 and Dice coefficient of 0.984, demonstrating computational efficiency suitable for resource-constrained agricultural environments. For multi-cluster scenarios involving overlapping grape clusters, our hybrid YOLOv8-SAM approach demonstrated exceptional performance with mIoU of 0.943 and Dice coefficient of 0.970, significantly outperforming traditional CNN-based methods by 4.1% in IoU scores. The hybrid methodology addresses key challenges in agricultural computer vision including variable lighting conditions, cluster occlusion, and complex vineyard backgrounds. Comprehensive ablation studies validate the contribution of each component, while computational analysis demonstrates practical deployment feasibility. The primary contribution lies in demonstrating that foundation models like SAM, when combined with robust object detection, can effectively handle complex agricultural scenes with overlapping grape clusters, advancing automated harvesting and real-time yield estimation technologies for precision viticulture applications.

title: Finite Element Simulation and Experimental Study on the Response of ZnO Varistors to $4 / 10 \mu$ S Current Impulses Before and After Aging Based on Measured V-I Characteristics
authors: Yuanzhi Wu, Yongxia Han, Yongcheng Guo, Leilei Ding, Taishan Hu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Mechanical fracture may occur in ZnO varistors when subjected to high-current impulses. This paper presents a finite element-based electro-thermal-mechanical multiphysics coupling model to simulate the behavior of ZnO varistors under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4} / \mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{\mu}$</tex> s impulse currents. The model incorporates experimentally obtained current-voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V$</tex> - I) characteristics of both aged and unaged samples. The study focuses on analyzing the temperature distribution and thermally induced mechanical stress within the varistor blocks under impulse conditions. It aims to provide deeper insight into the failure mechanisms of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{Z n O}$</tex> varistors under surge currents, particularly by examining the influence of aging through comparison of measured <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V-I$</tex> characteristics - on the resulting thermal and stress fields. Based on simulation results, conclusions are drawn to support condition assessment and optimized design of varistor devices.

title: Fast Person Tracking for Automated Monitoring of Child Occupation Therapy Using YOLOv8 and AlphaPose Algorithms
authors: Lim Yong Chuan, Zaid Omar, Vikrant Bhateja, Anwar P.P. Abdul Majeed, Uswah Khairuddin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an automated monitoring framework for child occupational therapy using the YOLOv8 and AlphaPose algorithms. The proposed system processes video footage to detect and track subjects, estimate gaze direction, and generate comprehensive session summaries. The performance evaluations yielded a mean mean precision (mAP) of 0.978, a recall of 0.967, and a gaze estimation accuracy of 92.88%, while maintaining a display speed of 15 frames per second (FPS) on a graphical user interface (GUI), providing a comprehensive overview that can aid therapists' assessment of the session.

title: An Optimal Pricing Approach for Time-of-use Tariff Mechanism Based on Hierarchical Clustering and Artificial Hummingbird Algorithm
authors: Xiejun Du, Junjie Li, Kun Wang, Yan Shen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of smart grid technologies and the growing penetration of renewable energy sources, traditional flat-rate electricity pricing models have become inadequate for addressing demand-side management challenges and improving energy efficiency. Time-of-use (TOU) pricing has emerged as a promising dynamic pricing mechanism to incentivize load shifting, mitigate peak demand, and enhance power system stability by aligning electricity prices with temporal variations in supply and demand. This study proposes an enhanced TOU pricing framework that overcomes the limitations of conventional models by explicitly accounting for seasonal load variations and differentiated consumption patterns across residential, commercial, and industrial users. A seasonal clustering-based method is adopted for time period segmentation, enabling user-specific period definitions. To solve the resulting multi-constraint nonlinear optimization problem, an Artificial Hummingbird Algorithm (AHA) is employed, which effectively explores the solution space through guided, territorial, and migratory foraging behaviors. Empirical analysis using real-world load data from a province in China validates the proposed method, demonstrating significant improvements in peak shaving, valley filling, and pricing fairness. The results underscore the framework's potential to support sustainable energy system development and offer practical insights for utilities and energy policy formulation.

title: Seven-Level T-Type Asymmetrical Multilevel Inverter of Minimum Leakage Current for Transformerless Grid–Tied Solar PV System
authors: Siva Asapu, Madasu Keerthika Lahari, Kotla Naga Sree Nehanvitha, Juttiga Harsha Vardhini, Jaladi Esther Grace, Chittimala Mrudula
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: This paper presents a seven-level T-type asymmetrical multilevel inverter (7L-T-AMLI) for a transformerless grid-tied solar photovoltaic (SPV) system aimed at improving power quality and minimizing leakage currents. Asymmetrical multilevel inverters enhance output voltage by producing near-sinusoidal waveforms with reduced harmonic distortion. In transformerless SPV systems, varying common-mode voltage can induce leakage currents through parasitic capacitance between the PV array and ground, leading to safety concerns and reduced system performance. The proposed 7L-T-AMLI grid-tied SPV system addresses these challenges by effectively balancing the inverter’s capacitor voltages, thereby suppressing leakage current and maintaining high power quality. Simulation results in MATLAB confirm the effectiveness of the design, achieving a negligible leakage current and a grid current with a low total harmonic distortion (THD) of 2.21%.

title: Approximate Circuits Versus Quantization for Energy Efficient Deep Neural Networks
authors: Jordi Fornt, Pau Fontova-Musté, Martí Caro, Jaume Abella, Josep Altet, Antonio Rubio, Francesc Moll
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: Deep neural networks dominate the landscape of artificial intelligence models and are used in many applications, but their high computational complexity makes executing them in real time very costly in terms of power. Hence, custom energyefficient accelerators have become a need in some domains. Lowprecision integer arithmetic and approximate compute circuits are two popular optimizations often contemplated for saving hardware resources and power consumption. These techniques are usually considered as separate and independent approximations, but in reality they are inextricably linked. In this work, we explore the interaction and trade-off between quantization and approximate circuits in the context of deep neural network acceleration by evaluating several circuits, including approximate multipliers, approximate adders, and combinations thereof, while using different integer precisions. Additionally, we study how approximate multiplier and adder circuits can be combined to further push energy efficiency. We use the YOLOv3 object detection network to assess the accuracy impact of the circuits in a state-of-the-art complex deep learning model. By combining approximate arithmetic circuits with low-precision quantization, we generate approximate MAD circuits with over 60% less power consumption and near identical accuracy compared to using only quantization. Nevertheless, we find that quantization plays a dominant role in the resulting energy efficiency, since the best design points are always found at the lowest bit precisions.

title: A Message from the Organizing and Program Committees
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: On behalf of the Organizing Committee and the Cantabria Chip Chair of the University of Cantabria, we warmly invite you to the 2025 40th Conference onDesign of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS 2025). It is a privilege and a pleasure to host the DCIS Conference in Santander, Spain, for this anniversary.

title: Continual Learning-Guided Adaptive Approximate Computing for Real-time MEA Spike Detection
authors: Mishal Fatima Minhas, Falah Awwad, Osman Hassan, Muhammad Shafique
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: We propose a novel Continual Learning (CL)-based adaptive Approximate Computing (AxC) framework for Micro-electrode array (MEA) spike detection on Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA), enabling adaptive precision control under key constraints in real-time. Our approach aims to continuously learn from incoming MEA data and configure computational precision in response to dynamic input characteristics and design constraints, i.e., latency and accuracy, which are more critical than power consumption in this case. Towards this, we investigate the accuracy-efficiency trade-offs of MEA spike detection, through precision scaling. Our evaluations at the algorithmic-level reveal that 32-bit floating-point (FP32) single-precision filtering operation performs 1.8× faster than 64-bit floating point (FP64) double-precision baseline, with minimal detection accuracy loss. Moreover, the hardware-synthesized fixed-point implementations demonstrated substantial resource savings and an 86.6% reduction in dynamic power when using 16-bit fixed-point (Fix16) compared to the 32-bit fixed-point (Fix32).

title: Dual-Band Reflective Metasurface Integrated Circularly Polarized Antenna for Sub-6 GHz 5G N77 and Wi-Fi 7 Applications
authors: Varsha Kheradiya, Ganga Prasad Pandey, Arpan Desai
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A dual-band opposite circularly polarized (CP) reflective metasurface integrated antenna for sub-6 GHz 5G (N77 band) and Wi-Fi 7 applications is proposed. The work addresses the critical need for polarization diversity in multi-band wireless systems. The proposed design achieves opposite-handedness CP operation—left-hand CP (LHCP) at one band and right-hand CP (RHCP) at the other, which helps in enhancing the interference mitigation and signal robustness. The system employs a compact, double-layer phase-change metasurface (DL-PCM) reflector integrated with a dual-band linearly polarized monopole antenna, enabling the independent control of the amplitude and phase of reflected waves at each frequency. The integrated antenna and DL-PCM configuration results in wide axial ratio bandwidths (27.3% and 25.3%) and high radiation efficiencies (90% and 87%), ensuring optimal performance across both bands. This approach offers the ability to achieve circular polarization when interfaced with any linearly polarized (LP) antenna system, which is a generic approach. Also, the opposite polarization at both bands helps in reducing the interference. This system has a potential for next-generation wireless networks requiring versatile broad impedance and axial ratio bandwidth, high efficiency, and CP operation, notably advancing multi-band antenna solutions for 5G and Wi-Fi 7 applications.

title: Subjective and Objective Quality Assessment of Display Content Videos
authors: Yijie Huang, Fangfang Lu, Huiqun Yu, Kaiwei Zhang, Wei Sun, Xiongkuo Min, Guangtao Zhai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Display quality assessment plays a crucial role in evaluating the performance of display devices. However, existing video quality assessment methods primarily target compression-related distortions, failing to capture display-specific degradations including definition loss, color distortions, and motion artifacts that critically affect user subjective experiences during video playback. To address these limitations, we develop a specialized video dataset, namely Video Displaying Quality Assessment Dataset (VDQA), constructed using a DSLR camera with standardized parameter optimization of exposure settings (aperture, ISO sensitivity, and shutter speed). VDQA comprises 250 high-resolution video clips covering diverse content categories, providing a robust foundation for evaluating display devices across multiple quality dimensions. Additionally, we propose a deep learning-based model specifically designed for display quality assessment that employs three complementary pathways to independently evaluate definition, color fidelity, and motion quality. The model integrates Canny edge detection for explicit sharpness measurement, a color attention mechanism to enhance sensitivity to display color reproduction characteristics, and temporal modeling for motion artifact assessment. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves superior performance in reflecting user subjective experiences for display content videos compared to state-of-the-art methods, with significant improvements in both color fidelity assessment and definition evaluation.

title: In Vivo Measurement of Passive and Active Rat Gastrocnemius Muscle Force Using a Miniaturized Fiber Bragg Grating Sensor
authors: Kejun Huang, Jingtao Lei, Junjun Zhu, Jiao Wang, Haonan Jia
abstract: Accurate in vivo muscle force measurement is essential in biomechanics, orthopedic surgical planning, and human–machine interaction design. However, most current method either require invasive instrumentation or only infer force indirectly from activation, which fails for passive loading conditions. This study presents a compact, implantable force sensor for rat gastrocnemius, utilizing a Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) sensor integrated into a custom tendon buckle. The system features a simple structure capable of accurately detecting force transmitted by a single muscle. The design converts tendon tension into measurable bending strain, with Finite Element Analysis optimizing placement and confirming force-strain linearity. A passive muscle–tendon unit (MTU) model was developed to theoretically estimate gastrocnemius force during externally loaded hindlimb motion. Ex vivo calibration and in vivo tests in rat cadavers and live animals demonstrated functionality. Under passive loading, peak tendon forces ranged from 0.5N to 0.63 N, aligning with model predictions (0.48N-0.74 N). Live rats exhibited peak forces near 0.6 N during spontaneous movement. The FBG buckle enables direct tendon force measurement—including passive loading—with optical readout for electromagnetic immunity, miniaturization for small animals, and biocompatibility for chronic implantation, offering advantages over existing strain-gauge, EMG, and imaging-based techniques.

title:

                    odulus Conversion and

authors: Ye Dong, Wen-jie Lu, Xiaoyang Hou, Kang Yang, Jian Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Secure two-party machine learning has made substantial progress through the use of mixed-mode protocols, but existing approaches often suffer from efficiency bottlenecks due to inherent mismatch between optimal domains of various cryptographic primitives. In response to these challenges, we introduce framework M&M, which features an efficient modulus conversion protocol. This breakthrough enables seamless integration of the most suitable cryptographic subprotocols within their optimal modulus domains with a minimal modulus conversion overhead. We further establish new benchmarks and practical optimizations for the performance of fundamental primitives, namely comparison and multiplication, across various two-party techniques.By incorporating these techniques, M&M demonstrates significant performance enhancements over state-of-the-art solutions: i) we report a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$6\times$</tex-math></inline-formula>-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$100\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> improvement for approximated truncations with 1-bit error tolerance; ii) an average of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> (resp. <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times$</tex-math></inline-formula>) reduction in communication (resp. runtime) for machine learning functions; iii) and a 25%-99% improvement in cost-efficiency for private inference of deep neural networks and 50% improvement in private training of gradient boosting decision trees.

title: Fusing Driving Behavior Features for Detecting Early Voltage Consistency Anomaly of Battery Pack in Electric Vehicles
authors: Shaopeng Li, Hui Zhang, Daniela Anna Misul, Federico Miretti
abstract: To prevent battery thermal runaway incidents in electric vehicles (EVs), it is crucial to detect faults on voltage consistency between cells (VCC) in the battery pack by a timely and accurate manner. This paper conducts a naturalistic driving experiment on 20 EVs to collect high-quality vehicle operation data, and proposes an early VCC anomaly detection method that integrates driving behavior features. For four types of micro-running segments of EVs, the model of genetic-algorithm-optimized back propagation neural network (GA-BPNN) is established to estimate the normal voltage variation coefficient between cells (VVCC) during vehicle running. The input features of models include related parameters of ambient temperature, state of charge (SOC), current, vehicle speed, acceleration, and pedal stroke. The GA-BPNN models are validated to exhibit a good robustness. The VVCC anomaly threshold is obtained using methods of Box-Cox transformation, 3σ rule, and box plot. The validation results indicate that the proposed method can effectively identify early abnormalities before VCC exceeds the conventional threshold. The average recall rate for 12 test EVs is 0.8746. This method overcomes the shortcomings of existing methods that cannot automatically adjust anomaly detection standard due to lacking consideration of driving behavior’s impact on voltage fluctuation.

title: A Novel Hybrid Strategy Based on MPPT for WPT EV Charging Station Powered by Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Karam Khairullah Mohammed, Irfan Hussain Panhwar, Saad Mekhilef, Marizan Mubin, Abdullah Albaker
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: The Electric vehicles (EVs) are widely recognized as eco-friendly devices. Consequently, the need for EVs is growing at a rapid pace daily, which has increased the need for charging stations. However, EV battery charging requires sustainable electrical energy sources. The wireless power transfer (WPT) system powered by photovoltaic panels is suggested in this paper as a clean energy source implementation. Although the PV system is exposed to various irradiance patterns, traditional approaches may not be able to capture the global maximum power point (GMPP). Consequently, various types of optimization techniques for adhering to the GMPP have been proposed. However, optimization algorithms lack the capability to differentiate between uniform shading and partial shading patterns. The paper proposes a novel hybrid MPPT method to overcome the limitation and avoid an unnecessary search region of the whole P-V curve through uniform shading conditions (USCs). When the system is exposed to USCs, a new method for determining the optimal power point is proposed. In addition, a modified parrot optimization (MPO) technique will be used to improve the convergence speed by mitigating the partial shading and load variation. The suggested approach was employed experimentally with a sample time of 0.05 s using dSPACE. An experimental prototype was used to test the suggested approach and present results. Consequently, power was transmitted from primary to secondary with 90% efficiency and 99.22% MPPT efficiency with an average convergence speed of 0.51 s. Moreover, the proposed method has been compared with recently published algorithms to illustrate the proposed method’s superiority.

title: Advancements and Insights in Assessing Cognitive Load During Driving: A Comprehensive Narrative Review
authors: Peijiang Zhang, Tao Cheng, Yuande Jiang, Wanying Liu, Xiaoming Chen, Xiaochuan Zou, Yixuan Sheng, Xiangmo Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: In the context of rapid advancements in the automotive industry and intelligent transportation systems, assessing cognitive load during driving has become a key factor for driving safety and user experience. This paper presents a comprehensive narrative review of theories, methods, and technological advancements in assessing cognitive load during driving. Rather than following a systematic review protocol,the structure of the review is organized around key research questions and critical gaps identified in the current literature. We assess the applicability and performance of major evaluation methods, including physiological indicators, behavioral measures, subjective self-report scales, and data-driven approaches, across various driving scenarios. The review also discusses the integration of multi-source information and propose a conceptual framework for holistic and adaptive cognitive load assessment. Furthermore, it highlights challenges in current practices, such as technical constraints, environmental variability, and individual differences. Special emphasis is placed on the relevance of cognitive load assessment for industrial informatics, particularly in the context of advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS), autonomous driving technologies, and driver training programs. This review aims to provide a structured synthesis of current approaches, offer practical insights for application and system design, and guide future research toward developing more robust, generalizable, and context-aware assessment tools. By analyzing the state of the art, we contribute a timely reference to support both academic development and industrial implementation for next-generation intelligent vehicle systems.

title: Clinically Generalizable Low-Dose CT Denoising for Pediatric Imaging via Enhanced Diffusion Posterior Sampling
authors: Hongmei Tang, Qianhao Chen, Qiyang Zhang, Zhaoting Cheng, Yang Wu, Shuang Song, Hairong Zheng, Dong Liang, Zhanli Hu, Xiaohua Zhu, Na Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: In total-body positron emission tomography and computed tomography (PET/CT) imaging, reducing the radiation dose of diagnostic CT scans is essential for minimizing overall radiation exposure, particularly in pediatric patients. Although deep learning-based denoising methods have shown promise in restoring low-dose CT (LDCT) to normal-dose CT (NDCT) quality, most approaches rely on structurally aligned paired data, which are difficult to acquire in clinical practice. Models trained on synthetic pairs often exhibit limited generalizability to real LDCT data. Unconditional diffusion models demonstrate outstanding generalizability, but fail to preserve structural fidelity. To address these challenges, we propose an enhanced diffusion posterior sampling (E-DPS) framework that combines a one-step denoiser U-Net with an unconditional diffusion model. Specifically, the U-Net estimator, trained on simulated LDCT–NDCT pairs, provides preliminary denoised outputs as structural constraints, whereas the diffusion model captures the prior distribution of NDCT images to enhance realism and generalizability. During inference, the U-Net predictions are integrated as constraints with tunable weights, thereby guiding diffusion posterior sampling. In addition, an intermediate-stage initialization strategy is introduced, significantly reducing the number of required sampling steps. Extensive experiments on simulated LDCT datasets across three dose levels demonstrate the superiority of our method, yielding average PSNR gains of +5.2% and +4.3% at unseen dose levels compared with state-of-the-art approaches. Moreover, on real LDCT images, E-DPS exhibits strong zero-shot generalizability, achieving better noise suppression while preserving anatomical detail. These results highlight the robustness and clinical potential of E-DPS for LDCT denoising.

title: ULNC: Universal Language-Guided Nuclei Classification Via Instance-Aware Prompting_supp1-3629394.docx
authors: Minghui Wang
abstract: Accurate classification of nuclei is a crucial step in advancing pathology image analysis for disease diagnosis and treatment. Recently, prompt learning has shown great promise in universal nuclei classification for multiple datasets, as it can harvest the common knowledge by representing nuclei semantics across different sources. However, remarkable intra- and cross-dataset variability in nuclei categories and their complicated semantic relationships with numerous nuclei are often observed in distinct image instances, leading to two key challenges of instance variability and semantics ambiguity. In this paper, we propose a universal language-guided nuclei classification framework (ULNC) that leverages prompt-based language supervision to overcome these obstacles at the instance level. To address the instance variability issue, we introduce an innovative prompt learning approach that fully exploits unique contextual information of each image instance and generates instance-aware text embeddings highly adaptable to the categorical semantics of varied data sources. Additionally, to tackle the problem of semantics ambiguity, we employ a local vision-language matching loss that explicitly reinforces semantic connections between localized image regions and text prompts for nuclei categories, thus promoting the universal model's ability to learn discriminative image features for generalized nuclei classification. Extensive experiments conducted on several public datasets demonstrate that ULNC outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and generalization to unseen domains, highlighting its potential for robust nuclei classification across diverse datasets.

title: Variable Transformation for sEMG Pre-Processing: Applications and Analysis in Predicting Human Upper Limb Motion Intentions
authors: Kuang Nie, Reza Langari
abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG) signals hold considerable promise for predicting upper limb motion, particularly in applications related to human-machine interaction and rehabilitation. While extensive research has been conducted on sEMG signal analysis and pre-processing techniques, relatively little attention has been paid to addressing inter-subject variability in motion prediction using deep learning models. This study presents a comparative evaluation of six distribution transformation techniques, applied during pre-processing to account for subject-specific differences in sEMG signal distributions for upper limb intention prediction. The experimental results indicate that normalization choice significantly affects model performance, with techniques such as Yeo-Johnson leading to the highest accuracy improvement of up to 12.05% in Bi-LSTM prediction models. These findings underscore the importance of selecting appropriate personalized distribution transformation (PDT) strategies to enhance the generalizability and effectiveness of sEMG-based motion intention prediction.

title: HPGS-SLAM: Hybrid Point-Guided Dense Visual SLAM with Online Mapping via Gaussian Splatting
authors: Xin Su, Xiaoang Zhang, Rastin Pries, Eckehard Steinbach
abstract: In this letter, we introduce HPGS-SLAM, a real-time RGB-D SLAM system guided by hybrid point features (combining traditional and learned point features), enabling high-precision tracking and online dense mapping with photorealistic reconstruction. HPGS-SLAM consists of two main components: (1) a lightweight feature-based frontend guided by hybrid points with adaptive learnable feature matching, aiming for accurate pose tracking and 3D landmarks generation; and (2) a backend that leverages 3D Gaussian Splatting for real-time dense mapping and photorealistic rendering, where the spawning of Gaussian primitives is guided by the 3D landmarks and hybrid keypoints shared from the frontend. HPGS-SLAM is designed in a distributed architecture to facilitate practical deployment. We evaluate HPGS-SLAM on the Replica, TUM-RGBD, and EuRoC MAV datasets. Both quantitative and qualitative results demonstrate that HPGS-SLAM outperforms existing systems in tracking accuracy and mapping efficiency, while achieving competitive visual quality for visual rendering.

title: A Simplified Cost-effective DuC-UPQC with Multi-Objective Optimization Design
authors: Weidong Fu, Qingsong Wang, Wei Hua, Ming Cheng, Giuseppe Buja
abstract: A simplified cost-effective dual-capacitor unified power quality conditioner (DuC-UPQC) is proposed. It could maintain sinusoidal standard load voltage and in-phase grid current, obtain reduced DC-Link voltage, improve modulation indexes, achieve active power balance between inside DVR and APF. Compared to existing methods, DuC-UPQC is cost-effective as less bipolar capacitors are required and external bidirectional DC power source could be removed. Besides, it exhibits robustness against grid voltage harmonics pollution and enables independent control for internal submodules. Next, two-dimensional multi-objective optimization strategy is developed through load voltage phase angle adjustment, so that multiple control objectives could be managed in buffer-capacitor-based topologies. Subsequently, phasor analysis is employed to derive the constraints and analytical solutions. Then associated control strategy can be designed. Finally, theoretical analysis was validated through simulation and laboratory experiments, with detailed results presented and discussed.

title: Multi-Link Enabled Reliable and Low Latency Transmission Design for Edge Estimation
authors: Siyu Qian, Xiaolin Wang, Fangfei Li, Yi'ang Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Edge computing enables real-time estimation for mission-critical Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems by processing massive data streams at the network edge. Existing methods struggle to balance estimation performance and energy efficiency under varying reliability and latency requirements. We investigate Multi-Link Operation (MLO) to improve adaptability under dynamic wireless conditions. However, existing schemes offer limited flexibility in transmission modes and rely on simplified network models, which restricts the potential for MLO-specific performance optimization. To overcome these challenges, we propose a novel flexible transmission mode selection mechanism called Synchronous-Asynchronous Co-existence Multi-Link Aggregation (SACMLA). Based on switchable MLO modes, we formulate a scheduling-estimation co-design problem that optimizes the trade-off between estimation error covariance and transmission energy consumption. Given the environmental complexity and the action space explosion caused by the joint optimization of transmission mode, packet-to-link mapping, and energy allocation, we design a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO)-based Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Link Co-optimization (HDRL-MLC), a two-tier architecture where a PPO-based outer loop dynamically adjusts scheduling, and an inner loop optimizes energy allocation in MLO. Simulation results demonstrate the necessity of the SACMLA mechanism and highlight the superior performance of the PPO-based HDRL-MLC algorithm over flat algorithms in balancing multiple communication metrics and adapting to varying traffic conditions.

title: Endoscopic Endonasal Stereoscopic Images of the Skull Base: From Creation to Automatic Evaluation
authors: Milton Manrique Rastelli Júnior, João Pedro Murback Wiedmer, Pedro Marochi, Rubens Alexandre De Faria, Elder Oroski
abstract: The study of neuroanatomy is an integral part of the education and training of neurosurgeons and aspiring professionals in this field, in which the use of images, videos, models, simulators, and virtual reality can fit into the pedagogy of this medical area. However, individuals who lack a solid understanding of three-dimensionality and proportion encounter challenges when interpreting two-dimensional images. Regardless of all the technology currently available, the stereoscopic images, a technique used by superimposing two images taken from the same region by moving a camera laterally, keeping the same horizontal plane and the same focal length, become valuable by presenting the viewer with the notion of depth and decreasing the learning time. However, when stereoscopic images are generated, many of them do not present the expected results, and could cause discomfort to the observer when analyzed, especially because their depth perception could be altered. In this study, a computational algorithm uses Pearson’s Correlation Coefficient, Angle between two vectors, and Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF (ORB) to analyze and compare the two stereo pair images. Thus, six parameters are described that best correlate the two images, classified in order using the Fisher Discriminant Ratio (FDR), and used to evaluate the quality of a set of 180 endoscopic endonasal stereo images of the skull base. This study evaluated stereo pairs to determine their suitability for accurate 3D pictures using digital image processing and classification methods. Six parameters tested were effective for class separation, with the most discriminative being the angle between column vectors in the red channel, determined by the highest FDR, and it can serve as a standalone classifier or be used in a multivariate discriminant function for automated quality assessment. This research also determines that existing quality metrics such as Unified No-Reference Quality Assessment via Monocular and the Binocular Local Visual Primitives and Top-Down JND Estimation were ineffective for this specific classification, highlighting the potential of the proposed methodology.

title: Trace doxycycline detection via molecular imprinting combined with fiber surface plasmon resonance
authors: Meijuan Jia, Xiaoyi Wei, Shu Fang, Yunchang Wang, Jie Dong, Jun Zhou, Dingyu Yang, Changyu Shen
abstract: Doxycycline (DOX) is one of the most widely used veterinary antibiotics in animal husbandry, and its residues may affect the health of humans and animals due to the in-creased bacterial resistance. Here we developed a trace DOX detection means based on molecular imprinting technology with tilted fiber Bragg grating surface plasmon resonance (TFBG-SPR). Sputtering a 50 nm thick gold film on the surface of TFBG to excite surface plasmon resonance, and coating a layer of molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs) on the surface of the gold film to capture DOX. Experimental results show that the proposed sensor shows a detection sensitivity of 1.89 dB/(μg/mL) for DOX in the concentration range of 0.1-1 μg/mL, with a detection time of about 5 minutes and a detection limit (LOD) of about 0.0323 μg/mL (0.0672 μM). The obtained LOD is half of that of the current similar DOX sensor. The proposed sensor is expected to provide technical support for real-time trace monitoring of DOX concentration in the environment and food.

title: Image classification of GMAW robotic weld bead images by MobileNetV2 neural network using Transfer Learning
authors: Erwin M. Davila-Iniesta, José A. López-Islas, Oscar Camacho-Nieto, Yenny Villuendas Rey
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: Robotic gas metal arc welding is widely used in industry due to its efficiency and quality in joining metal parts. However, environmental and mechanical variations during the process can cause defects that compromise the integrity of the final product. This work explores the application of the MobileNetV2 convolutional neural network using Transfer Learning for the automatic classification of weld bead images into two categories: GOOD’ and ‘REWORK’. Given the limited availability of images in the dataset, a Data Augmentation strategy was integrated to increase the variability of the training set. The results show that the use of Transfer Learning allows a first approach to solving the problem, although the performance of the model is still limited. It is also concluded that, although the proposed approach presents a solid foundation, a larger and more balanced dataset is required, as well as the possible exploration of more complex network architectures.

title: Machine Learning Approach for Discovering Titanium Alloys with a Low Young’s Modulus
authors: Carlos Edmundo Aguilar Hernández, Raúl Rivera Blas, Chinnapat Panwisawas, Emmanuel Zenén Rivera Blas, Luis Armando Flores Herrera
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This research proposes the use of machine learning (ML) to predict and optimise titanium alloys with low Young's modulus for applications in additive manufacturing of bone prostheses. From a database of 3,235 alloys, a predictive model integrating atomic and electronic descriptors was developed. The Artificial Neural Network achieved the best performance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.8448), predicting a minimum modulus of 36.75 GPa. This approach allows to reduce time and resources in costly experimental tests.

title: Recursive Neural Network POS Tagger
authors: Jasmeet Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: This project explores the application of recursive neural networks (RNNs) in natural language processing, specifically for part-of-speech (POS) tagging. Drawing on foundational work by Socher et al. (2010) for constructing sentence parse trees and Collobert and Weston (2011) for distributed word representations, we implemented a recursive neural network POS tagger. Utilizing Lua and the Torch7 neural network library, we developed two models: a basic RNN and a compositional vector tagger inspired by Socher et al. (2013). Both models leverage distributed word representations to capture contextual information essential for accurate POS tagging. Our basic RNN combines word and phrase representations, while the compositional vector tagger employs tag-dependent weight matrices for phrase representation. Despite challenges with capitalization in our dataset, our models demonstrate the potential of RNNs in capturing linguistic structures for improved POS tagging performance.

title: Multi-Stage Classification Approach for Heart Failure Disease Diagnosis and Reduced Ejection Fraction Prediction
authors: Ognjen Pavić, Lazar Dašić, Anđela Blagojević, Tijana Geroski, Nenad Filipović
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Heart failure (HF) is one of the most common medical conditions around the world in the modern age. Patients with HF struggle with reduced quality of life and have a greater risk of death. For these reasons it is important for HF to be diagnosed early before it starts to majorly impact patients and cause major concern for death. Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is one of the most important features which can be used to further classify HF patients into patients with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), mid-range ejection fraction (HFmrEF) and preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). In this paper we describe a machine learning based pipeline for multistage classification of patients according to presence of HF and degree of reduced ejection fraction. Two separate pipelines are created in the scope of our research. Both pipelines classify patients based on whether HF is present or not. The first pipeline classifies HF patients into 3 classes based on their ejection fraction into reduced, mid-range and preserved classes. The second pipeline conducts classification of patients into LVEF <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<50 {\%}$</tex> and LVEF <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>50 {\%}$</tex> based on available features, followed by a second classification of HFrEF and HFpEF classes. HF classification model achieved 97% accuracy and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8 \%} \mathbf{F 1}$</tex> score for the confirmed HF class. The 3-class classification model achieved an overall prediction accuracy of 82% with F1 scores of 90%, 51% and 86% for HFpEF, HFmrEF and HFrEF respectively. The final two stage classification model achieved an overall accuracy of 96% and 87% for LVEF <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>50$</tex>% versus LVEF <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<50$</tex>% and mid-range versus reduced ejection fraction respectively. In the case of the twostage classification model F1 scores of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2 \%, 9 5 \%}$</tex> and 97% were achieved for HFpEF, HFmrEF and HFrEF respectively.

title: A Multidimensional Framework for Data Quality Assessment in Heart Failure: Integrating IEEE 2801-2022 and Fairness Metrics
authors: Marina Georgoula, Grigorios G. Kotoulas, Konstantina-Helen Tsarapatsani, Dimitrios G. Boucharas, Ioannis Kyprakis, Dimitrios Manousos, Andrej Preveden, Lazar Velicki, Amy Groenewegen, Frans Rutten, Borut Flis, Matej Pičulin, Peter Vračar, Zoran Bosnić, Maria Tafelmeier, Lars S. Maier, Fausto Barlocco, Iacopo Olivotto, Marta Jimenez-Blanco, Jose Luis Zamorano, Duncan Edwards, Prithwish Banerjee, Nduka C. Okwose, Sarah Charman, Djordje G. Jakovljevic, Manolis Tsiknakis, Dimitrios I. Fotiadis
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Heart failure (HF) affects over 64 million people globally and poses complex diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. Reliable clinical research in HF hinges on high-quality data. This study presents a novel data quality assessment (DQA) framework tailored to retrospective HF datasets. It adapts the IEEE standard 2801-2022 criteria—originally for general medical data—to HF's clinical and multimodal structure and introduces a fairness-aware dimension to assess demographic representativeness. Applied to a real-world dataset of 6,039 patients and over 110,000 records across 11 clinical domains, the framework evaluates six dimensions: Completeness, Accuracy, Consistency, Compliance, Timeliness, and Fairness. Initial completeness was low <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(48.82 \%)$</tex>, but improved to 61.04% after cleaning via outlier correction, imputation, and schema normalization. Accuracy and compliance reached 100%, and consistency improved to 99.61%. Fairness, measured via JensenShannon Similarity across age, sex, and BMI, remained at 87.35%, highlighting demographic imbalance remained unresolved by technical cleaning. This is the first standards-aligned, domain-adapted, and fairness-extended DQA pipeline for HF, producing a robust dataset suitable for machine learning and clinical decision support.

title: A Generalized Aggregation Modeling Method for High-Dimensional Impedance Networks in Renewable Energy Clusters
authors: Yan Li, Ye Zhang, Wangqianyun Tang, Ziqian Yang, Lei Huang, Tian Hou, Ying Huang, Guoteng Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The large-scale integration of renewable energy sources, such as wind and photovoltaic power, into weak grid areas has led to sub/super-synchronous oscillations and resonance issues, severely threatening the safe and stable operation of power grids. To address the challenges of the curse of dimensionality and limited universality in existing impedance analysis methods when applied to complex renewable energy clusters, this paper proposes a generalized impedance aggregation method based on network equivalence. First, the impedance network model of renewable energy clusters, considering the characteristics of multiple types of converters, is analyzed, and resonant modes are accurately identified through eigenvalue analysis of the nodal admittance matrix. Subsequently, a generalized impedance aggregation method based on network equivalence is proposed, employing dimensionality reduction techniques for the nodal admittance matrix to transform the high-dimensional network into an equivalent low-dimensional matrix, significantly reducing computational complexity. To validate the effectiveness of the method, a grid-connected system of a renewable energy network is constructed on an electromagnetic transient simulation platform, and simulation analysis is conducted to verify the accuracy of the proposed approach.

title: Design and motion analysis of a space-borne array antenna deployment mechanism
authors: Yifan Xiong, Guanghui Wang, Wenxu Yao, Rufei Ge, Mingli Liu, Wei Hu
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: This paper describes a space-borne multi-folding expandable array antenna. The antenna can be unfolded from a folded state of 1 row, 2 columns and 8 layers to a $4 \times 4$ planar antenna. Firstly, the overall design and deployment scheme of the deployable array antenna are introduced; secondly, the deployment motion of the antenna is analyzed, and the speed and acceleration of the two deployment motions are determined; then the detailed design and analysis of the actuator of the deployment mechanism is carried out; finally, the development A set of principle prototype of deployable array antenna was built, and the deployment function test was carried out on the microgravity device. The test results show that the unfolding mechanism developed according to the design scheme has a gentle and smooth unfolding process, and can be locked smoothly after unfolding in place, which verifies the correctness and feasibility of the design. The proposed structure mechanism and design and analysis methods of the deployable array antenna can provide a reference for the design and research of other types of deployable antennas.

title: Research on Target Missile Equivalence Evaluation Based on Fuzzy Membership Degree and Combined Weighting Model
authors: Weixiao Wu, Changxing Shao, Mengcheng Zhu, Mohan Zhao, Qi Yu, Long Qian, Xueqing Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Equivalence assessment plays a crucial role in target missile design, as the degree of realism achieved in simulating operational targets directly impacts the credibility of weapon system verification tests. To enhance the simulation accuracy of target characteristics, research on target missile equivalence evaluation has become imperative. Existing methodologies primarily include Fuzzy Comprehensive Evaluation, Bayesian Networks, and Grey Relational Analysis. These approaches typically determine indicator weights through weighting methods to complete assessments. However, conventional single-weighting techniques often fail to balance expert experience with battlefield data characteristics and rarely incorporate weapon system kill probability for weight adjustment, leading to assessment results that deviate from actual combat requirements. This paper proposes an innovative target missile equivalence evaluation method based on fuzzy membership degrees and hybrid weighting models. By integrating game theory principles, the method balances Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) with Entropy Weight Method (EWM), optimizing combination coefficients through the minimization of deviation sums. This ensures weight distribution reflects both expert expertise and battlefield data features of weapon system kill probabilities. To address the differences between qualitative and quantitative indicators, the study combines fuzzy membership functions with G.A. Miller’s Quantification Theory to resolve challenges in precisely quantifying qualitative attributes. By treating weapon system kill probability as the objective attribute in EWM, the approach overcomes traditional limitations of entropy-based methods that rely solely on data distribution, significantly enhancing battlefield adaptability. Through constructing an algorithmic model based on this evaluation framework, the research demonstrates the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed method using two types of target missiles to simulate BrahMos missile threats and obtain equivalence composite values. The results provide theoretical support for target missile design optimization, weapon system test validation, and dynamic battlefield threat assessment, offering significant practical value for military applications.

title: Research on Bus-Aggregated Distributed Photovoltaic Power Prediction Technology Based on Intelligent Algorithms
authors: Fei Xia, Qiwei Peng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: This study investigates bus-aggregated distributed PV power prediction technology employing intelligent algorithms to mitigate grid integration challenges from PV intermittency and variability, driven by meteorological factors. The proposed framework integrates algorithms like MLP, SVR, GBRT, LightGBM, and Transformer, combined with a phased clustering method using output characteristics for PV site partitioning and aggregation. Case study validation highlights Transformer's excellence, utilizing self-attention to capture spatiotemporal dependencies and dynamic variations, yielding superior accuracy and adaptability over alternatives. By innovatively merging dynamic clustering with advanced AI, this research enhances grid reliability, supports renewable energy integration, and offers key value for intelligent monitoring in new energy systems.

title: Better Learning to Drive Autonomously with Proximal-Policy Reinforcement Learning and Visual Perception Representations
authors: Jirasak Sittigorn, Racha Tungtrakool, Jirayu Petchhan
abstract: This study presents an approach based on a deep reinforcement learning framework for vision-based autonomous driving in the CARLA environment, focusing on urban driving tasks. Our study implements a sub-policy Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm, demonstrating its effectiveness in navigating complex scenarios including lane following, straight driving, and left/right turns, and outperforming a single-policy approach for intersection maneuvers. To enhance learning efficiency, our representation learning leverages a deep mobile network for state representation, which significantly reduces image feature complexity. Furthermore, the integration of a single-shot multi-box detector enables the agent to perform realistic tasks such as responding to traffic lights and maintaining safe distances from leading vehicles, without compromising training speed. While the system demonstrates stable driving in various scenarios, current limitations include handling highly complex decisions and adapting to diverse speed limits due to environmental constraints. Future work will focus on expanding training environments and exploring more advanced network architectures to improve real-world applicability and learning efficiency.

title: Classification and Identification of Potato Leaf Disease Using Ensembling of Attention-Aided Deep Neural Networks Through Feature Fusion
authors: Shreyan Kundu, Nirban Roy, Rahul Talukdar, Semanti Das, Souradeep Mukhopadhyay, Biswadip Basu Mallik, Swarnamouli Majumdar, Sonny E. Kirkley, Soumik Basu
abstract: In terms of production, the potato is the most grown crop after wheat and rice in India. Foliar diseases, most notably Late Blight and Early Blight, expose the yields to risk. These diseases, if left undiagnosed, can pose grave economic losses along with a severe drop in productivity. Early and accurate detection, therefore, is important. This paper presents a deep learning-based technique that uses the fusion of features from multiple Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models enhanced with attention mechanisms for refined disease classification. By distinguishing healthy leaves and leaves suffering from Early and Late Blight, the system provides timely advice to farmers. The proposed method, which outperforms others, achieves a remarkable 97 % classification accuracy.

title: Innovation of Information and Communication Technology Supervision in Power Grid Companies
authors: Qingyun Hao, Zongtao Li, Si Chen, Xuan Li, Jingnan Xu, Bingxin Liu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Since its introduction into China in the 1950s, the power technology supervision management mode has been enriched with the development of the power industry, and has become an inseparable part of the safe production of power and the progress of power technology. Compared with the primary specialty of power, the technology supervision of information and communication specialty starts later, the foundation is relatively weak, the system is not sound enough, and the fault analysis is too dependent on the equipment manufacturers. Through the innovative introduction of testing and simulation technology means, improve the whole process of technology supervision system, realize the independent gate-keeping of information and communication equipment admittance, operation and maintenance, and decommissioning and scrapping, laying the foundation for the construction of a safe, reliable, technologically advanced and future-oriented electric power information and communication network, and also providing strong technical support for the professional management of power grid companies.

title: SHACL-Prolog Collaborative Validation Method for Digital Handover of Substation Secondary Systems
authors: Yu Rong, Hui Zhang, Di Wang, Qiumiao Cheng
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Data quality is the decisive factor for the success of digital handover in smart substations. Existing manual or relational-rule - based checks struggle to guarantee model completeness, compliance, and multi-model consistency simultaneously. This paper presents a graph-database validation framework that couples SHACL with Prolog: SCD, SDD, and GIM are first unified into an RDF graph stored in Neo4j; SHACL enforces structural constraints while Prolog performs complex logical reasoning. The result is a closed-loop workflow of “validate - alert - auto-repair - reject”, which markedly improves the reliability and automation of handover data.

title: Adaptive Cross-Layer Resource Allocation for BPLC-OFDM Systems Using Hybrid FEC Techniques
authors: Ghaith A. Mukhlif, A.Z. Yonis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: Broadband Power Line Communication (BPLC) utilizing Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) is a highly anticipated approach for data transfer over pre-existing electrical networks. Typically, BPLC systems rely on standard, static resource allocation methods with a single tier, which fail to adapt to the changing Quality of Service (QoS) requirements and unpredictable channel conditions. Our study introduces a novel, multi-layer resource allocation framework that incorporates a blend of Hybrid Forward Error Correction (FEC) schemes—specifically, Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC), Turbo, and Reed-Solomon coding into a utility-based scheduling model that encompasses the application, medium access control (MAC), and physical layers. The paper's unique focus is on a mid-band frequency span of 2.4 to 5.6 MHz, which is a practical segment of the total BPLC spectrum, capped at 28 MHz. This specific range was chosen to lessen computational complexity and adhere to the commonly simulated PLC channel properties under the Zimmermann model. The experimental outcomes reveal that our proposed technique results in decreased Bit Error Rates (BER), increased overall system performance, and enhanced proportional fairness, outperforming traditional algorithms in scenarios with weak as well as strong channels. By integrating adaptive FEC into the cross-layer model, we ensure superior QoS satisfaction for both real-time and non-real-time data consumers.

title: Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality, an Innovative and Interactive Tool in Technical Training in the Electrical Industry: Case Study "Implementing Cable Termination" in Great Tehran Electric Power Distribution Company
authors: Ali Mighi, Kourosh Apornak
abstract: For the first time in Iran’s power industry, the training department of the Great Tehran Electric Power Distribution Company has introduced Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) for cable termination training. This new approach, never used before in the country's energy sector, has the potential to transform technical training in distribution companies and beyond. This study compares different training methods for cable termination, including theoretical instruction, traditional hands-on training, AR-based training, and VR-based training. The results show that AR and VR offer a more interactive, effective, and cost-efficient learning experience than conventional methods. These technologies accelerate learning, reduce errors, and improve overall training efficiency. Additionally, they lower operational costs and provide a safer environment, making them an excellent choice for practical education.
