title: Research on Optimizing Fire Evacuation Routes in Large Industrial Plants Based on an Improved Ant Colony Algorithm
authors: BoQi Wu, Zhengyan Dong, HaoNan Zhang, BingYi Wu, Bao Jia, Sen Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved ant colony optimization(ACO) method to address the complexity and urgency of fire evacuation planning in large industrial facilities. By combining the A-star algorithm's fast, deterministic search with ACO's global optimization, the method uses A-star to quickly generate an initial path and enhance it with a local adjustment strategy, solving common ACO issues like slow convergence and local optima. A simulation based on real factory layouts compares A-star, traditional ACO, and the improved algorithm in path length, convergence, and stability. Results show A-star is fast but less adaptable, while ACO offers global search but is unstable early on. The improved method balances both, delivering shorter, more stable routes with fewer iterations. This approach provides an effective solution for fire evacuation and other emergency route planning.

title: Time-Based Observation System for Real-Time Learning Analytics During Lessons Using Time-Series Cross-Sections
authors: Konomu Dobashi, Catherine P. Fulford, Christina Higa, Kris Hara, Curtis P. Ho
abstract: Learning management systems (LMSs) are used in many educational institutions, and accumulate learning logs for each learner, including attendance records, access to online learning resources, and information on quiz responses. The multifaceted analytics of these learning logs enables an understanding of learners' engagement in class. This paper describes a method for analyzing learning logs in real time, in which the learning log accumulation function of a Moodle LMS is integrated with Excel. The system was built by seamlessly integrating Moodle and Excel pivot tables, and is currently used in weekly classes. Moodle learning logs are analyzed using timeseries cross-sections and process mining, and the results of the analysis are visualized in real time using Excel pivot tables. This paper describes a new system integration framework for realtime learning analytics, and discusses the effectiveness of the developed application in supporting classes. The app developed here can help teachers provide more effective feedback to learners and give them more confidence in their evidence-based interventions and advice.

title: A Repository-First Framework for Democratizing Chatbot Development
authors: Rashan Boonsri, Utharn Buranasaksee
abstract: Teams often require chatbots that integrate with business systems; however, existing options involve trade-offs: hosted platforms enable quick setup but impose vendor lock-in, whereas custom frameworks preserve control but exclude non-developers. This study evaluated whether combining a repositoryfirst framework with an AI coding agent can lower development costs and time without reducing reliability or usability. In a within-subjects experiment of eight matched chatbot app microtasks with nine developers and 144 runs, the framework plus agent condition completed tasks 56 percent faster with an agent-to-framework ratio of 2.29 and 95 percent confidence interval from 1.40 to 3.63, and at 43 percent lower cost with an agent-to-framework ratio of 1.76 and 95 percent confidence interval from 1.12 to 2.58 compared to the agent-only condition. Reliability signals improved with fewer human interventions and comparable error rates, token efficiency, and latency. A separate 50-user study reported a System Usability Scale mean of 70.6 with a 95 percent confidence interval from 68.6 to 72.6, exceeding the common benchmark of 68. These results support repositoryfirst, agent-assisted development as a practical approach to democratize chatbot creation while maintaining portability and code ownership.

title: YOLOv8-Based Grape Leaf Disease Classification with Feature Enhancement
authors: Papangkorn Pidchayathanakorn, Panthita Prayoonchan
abstract: Grapevine diseases threaten crop yield and fruit quality, creating the need for fast and reliable detection. This study proposes a lightweight deep learning framework for grape leaf classification across four conditions: Black Rot, Esca (Black Measles), Leaf Blight, and Healthy. A Kaggle dataset was processed using contrast enhancement, multi-scale Laplacian of Gaussian filtering, and morphological top-hat transformations to emphasize disease-specific patterns. The YOLOv8n-cls model was employed due to its high efficiency and accuracy. Experiments achieved 99.77% Top-1 accuracy, 100% Top-5 accuracy, and a 99.67% overall F1-score, with consistently high precision and recall across all categories. These results demonstrate the capability of lightweight deep learning models to provide reliable decision support in vineyard management, enabling timely detection and effective control of grape leaf diseases in real-world agricultural practice.

title: Dynamic Fire Spread-Based Cooperative Path Planning for UAV Swarms in Forest Fire Suppression
authors: Yalan Shi, Dezhen Yang, Dongming Fan, Yue Zhang, Shanshan Yan, Quan Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium - Europe (RAMS-Europe)
abstract: SUMMARY & CONCLUSIONSThe rapid spread and dynamic behavior of forest fires in complex environments challenge multi-UAV firefighting systems, as traditional isolated strategies often fail to balance global fire boundary prioritization with real-time adaptive path planning, leading to delays and inefficiency. This study proposes a hybrid framework integrating a genetic algorithm (GA) to dynamically identify high-priority fire boundaries based on spread velocity and an ant colony optimization (ACO) algorithm to generate collision-free suppression paths. The model focuses on minimizing extinguishing time and total fire spread area, tested under scenarios simulating wind-driven spread and irregular boundary expansion. Results demonstrate the hybrid strategy ensures timely intervention and effective containment of fire spread. Future work will involve simulating complex forest fire scenarios, taking into account factors such as terrain slope, heterogeneous vegetation flammability, and dynamic wind patterns. This will aid in studying more realistic phenomena of forest fire spread.

title: End-to-End Wrist PPG Generation Using Radial Artery Hemodynamics and Light Transport Simulation
authors: Supun Kuruppu, Biyon Fernando, Dakshina Tharindu, Dumindu Bandara, Ajith Pasqual
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Photoplethysmography (PPG) has emerged as a critical non-invasive technique for cardiovascular health monitoring through wearable devices, yet the physiological mechanisms underlying PPG signal formation are not completely understood. This affects the development of accurate diagnostic tools and personalized health monitoring systems. To overcome it, analysis of how cardiac output and other physiological factors are reflected in PPG, especially at the wrist, is required, and end-to-end PPG simulation methods have been developed for this purpose. However, these methods have limitations in either accuracy or computational efficiency. To address this gap, we present a comprehensive end-to-end framework for simulating wristbased PPG signals by integrating radial artery hemodynamics with optical light transport modeling through skin. In our approach, first, cardiac parameters are used to generate the cardiac output. This is passed into an upper left limb artery simulation, which produces arterial pressure, flow, and crosssectional area variation at each location. These waveforms at the radial artery are used by a novel, computationally efficient light transport simulation through the skin to generate the PPG signal. The morphological features of the PPG waveform generated by our method are closer to those of real PPG data compared to simulations that utilize a deterministic method as an alternative to light transport simulation. Furthermore, our light transport simulation method is significantly faster than the Monte Carlo method used for more accurate simulations. Therefore, our approach provides a balance of both computational efficiency and accuracy in wrist PPG simulation, aiding the development of personalized cardiovascular monitoring systems.

title: Low-Order Induction Machine Model with Saturation and Air-Gap Flux Harmonics
authors: MohammadSadegh Khajuee Zadeh, Arash Safavizadeh, Navid Amiri, Juri Jatskevich
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The computational efficiency of induction machine models is crucial for the simulation of large-scale power systems. In this paper, a reduced-order qd0 model of the induction machine is proposed to explicitly account for magnetic saturation and its adverse effects on the air-gap flux, which emerge as higher-order distortions. Capturing the saturation and harmonic effects leads to higher-order models and thus increased computational complexity. However, neglecting dynamic states of harmonics that play a minor role in the general system’s behavior and replacing them with algebraic solutions results in a lower system order. The eigenvalue analysis shows that the full-order and low-order models share almost the same dynamics. This confirms that the proposed low-order model may offer similar transient performance but with higher computational efficiency. The model’s performance is evaluated against the full-order model and experimental measurements, verifying its accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Analysis of the Influence of Permanent Magnet Shape on the Electromagnetic Characteristics of Halbach Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Yu Cao, Jin Wang, Jian Xiao, Junhao Yang, Libing Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Radial permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM) magnetized using halbach arrays show great promise due to their high efficiency and high torque density. However, they also impose higher demands on the processing and cooling of permanent magnet (PM). They require magnet structures that are easy to process and efficient cooling structures to ensure reliable motor operation. This paper takes an 85kW radial PMSM as an example. Based on the characteristics of PM and finite element analysis, a two-dimensional model of a motor using rectangular magnets is established to study the impact of the rectangular magnet structure on the motor's electromagnetic performance and losses. The research results indicate that motors with rectangular PM structures can reduce magnet losses without significantly affecting torque density, while also reducing the risk of magnet demagnetization within a certain range.

title: Dynamic Route Planning for Electric Vehicle Charging and Discharging Based on Road-Network and Power-Grid Coupling
authors: Yifan Pan, Liangyin Shen, Qiangqiang Wang, Xuanchen Li, Yuhan Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the rapid development of electric vehicles (EVs), their charging demands pose significant challenges to the security and stability of power grids. The spatiotemporal randomness of EV charging behavior tends to exacerbate the peak-valley load difference of the grid, degrade power quality, and increase network losses. However, as distributed energy storage units, EVs can utilize vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology to mitigate fluctuations in renewable energy, provide frequency regulation services, and participate in grid load shifting, thereby promoting the coordinated development of energy and transportation systems. Existing path planning methods often rely on simplistic integration of static road and grid information, failing to reflect dynamic coupling characteristics and multiagent interactions, which limits their real-time applicability. To address this, this paper proposes a dynamic path planning method that holistically considers users ’ travel time, energy consumption, and economic costs. By designing dynamic road network and electricity price models, the method dynamically responds to real-time road network conditions and grid load variations, updating path weight parameters through the fusion of road and grid information. This approach not only meets users ’ charging/discharging needs but also achieves grid load balancing and road network traffic optimization, maximizing overall system benefits. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method alleviates grid peak-valley differences, balances traffic flow, enhances user benefits, and optimizes comprehensive system interests.

title: Research on the Application of Sparrow Search Algorithm Based on Evolutionary Strategy in MPPT
authors: Xiaotong Mi, Yong Zhu, Shuangxin Zhu, Bo Geng, Qinglong Feng, Jinpeng Han
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: In order to address the issue of inaccurate maximum power point tracking (MPPT) under partial shading conditions in photovoltaic (PV) systems, an improved sparrow search algorithm-evolutionary strategy (ISSA-ES) is proposed in this paper. To enhance diversity and prevent premature convergence, the population is initialized using Tent chaotic mapping first. Then, an adaptive mutation mechanism is incorporated to improve the global search capability. Additionally, a restart mechanism is introduced to prevent the algorithm from falling into local optima. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves faster convergence and higher tracking accuracy compared with the PSO and SSA with chaotic mapping(ISSA).

title: Analysis of Emergency Metering Device Configuration Strategy Based on Simulated Annealing Algorithm
authors: Tao Liao, Huiyong Luo, Qiang Yao, Guohui Wang, Bingyang Li, Xiaojie Liu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Under the background of frequent natural disasters, the stability of power system is severely challenged, and the emergency metering device is very important to ensure its reliable operation under the emergency state. At present, the configuration of emergency metering devices is interfered by complex environmental factors, and faces the problems of dynamic change of power system characteristics and difficult balance of multi-objective optimization requirements. In this paper, a configuration strategy based on simulated annealing algorithm is designed, where the deployment location and quantity of devices are optimized by establishing an objective function considering the coverage, configuration cost and measurement reliability. The actual case analysis shows that with proper initialization of algorithm parameters and iterative adjustment of solutions, the configuration scheme based on simulated annealing algorithm meets the requirements in terms of coverage, configuration cost and measurement reliability, and the algorithm is reasonable and effective.

title: Joint Compression Based on Tensor Ring Decomposition and Structured Pruning
authors: Pengfei Liu, Zhijun Li, Yihao Ma, Yanming Wu, Weirong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) typically involve a large number of parameters, leading to increased computational and storage demands during training, inference, and deployment. Tensor decomposition can effectively reduce redundant parameters and FLOPs in DNNs, facilitating deployment on edge devices. In the context of Tensor Ring (TR) decomposition, two challenges arise: (1) redundancy in input and output channels during the TR decomposition process; (2) significant oscillations in the gradient magnitudes of remaining channels during iterative training. Joint compression based on tensor ring decomposition and structured pruning (TR-SP) method is proposed to address these issues. The proposed approach consists of three steps: (1) structured pruning, (2) rank selection, and (3) fine-tuning to recover accumulated accuracy loss. Experimental results demonstrate that, for a given network, TR-SP achieves the best performance in terms of Top-1 accuracy and parameter efficiency across various compression levels. Furthermore, TR-VB achieves state-of-the-art performance on the CIFAR 10 and CIFAR 100 public benchmark.

title: IoTide: A Smart Underwater Monitoring System for Aquatic Life and Debris Detection Using AI and IoT
authors: Soham Walimbe, Chaitanya Abhyankar, Ayush Deshmukh, Prajakta Pardeshi, Anuradha Phadke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: There is an urgent need to help the marine pollution which we humans cause. Constantly throwing waste into water bodies, industrial waste, and in general trash which automatically gets into water bodies is a major concern. Our solution to that is IoTide. IoTide is an intelligent IoT-based device that monitors trash and marine life in real time using ESP32-CAM and YOLOv8 visual model. Best suited for small scale uses such as pond level garbage detection, fish culture, fish farming, etc. IoTide achieves a high accuracy in detecting such examples and is reliable as a device which detects trash and aquatic life easily. Just a device which goes underwater and a ground unit which makes the detections. With further improvements based on integrating the processing unit into the underwater device itself, IoTide becomes future ready to tackle marine issues.

title: YOLOv5 with SVM-Aided Post-Classification for High-Precision Skin Lesion Detection
authors: R Srividhya, Vaibhav C. Gandhi, Anitha D, Sudha Rajesh, Soham Biren Katlariwala, Krunal Panchal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: Skin cancer ranks among the most common health conditions across the world, and the decision to treat it effectively hinges on its early diagnosis. The research presented herein introduces a hybrid deep learning approach that complements YOLOv5's real-time lesion localization ability with the robust post-classification ability of a Support Vector Machine (SVM). The model was tested and trained on the ISIC2018 and HAM10000 datasets. Both datasets include a mixture of skin lesions including melanoma, nevus, basal cell carcinoma, and other types. We made sure we balanced the split dataset of 70% training, 15% validation, and 15% testing to reflect the real-world distribution of classes. This is particularly important to avoid overfitting, especially for rare lesion types like melanoma. Preprocessing steps such as contrast enhancement and data augmentation were applied to improve feature representation and model generalization. A multi-stage pipeline including preprocessing, contrast augmentation, and data augmentation is utilized for enhancing the quality of features and generalization of models. Experimental results show that the YOLOv5-SVM model has a 96.8% classification accuracy and surpasses baseline models for F1-score (0.93), AUC (0.981), and IoU (0.86). Comparative analysis, ablation tests, and visual feature projections validate the effectiveness of the hybrid approach in reducing false positives and enhancing diagnostic accuracy. The suggested model also preserves real-time inference speeds, hence appropriate for deployment in tele dermatology and mobile healthcare applications. These findings highlight the potential of integrating object detection with scalable machine learning to develop efficient and accurate AIpowered dermatological tools. These results highlight the potential of the proposed YOLOv5-SVM system as a scalable, interpretable, and highly accurate solution for AI-based dermatological screening.

title: SAIMNet: Object Detection Based on Semantic Alignment of Infrared Image and Microwave Non-image Information Fusion
authors: Xiaoyu Li, Zuopeng Zhao, Maocai Ning, Jianfeng Hu
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Due to the inability of unimodal data to provide comprehensive information and its poor environmental adaptability, which fails to meet the detection accuracy requirements, this paper proposes an object detection algorithm that integrates infrared images and microwave non-image information based on semantic alignment, leveraging their complementary characteristics. We improve radar image quality by converting radar point cloud data into radar range Doppler(RD) images and introducing a hierarchical wavelet-thresholding denoising technique. Subsequently, to address the noise issue in infrared images, we design an adaptive median filtering algorithm to effectively remove salt-and-pepper noise while preserving edge details. Furthermore, we propose the Adaptive Convolutional Context Attention (ACCA) module, which dynamically adjusts convolutional-kernel sizes, enhancing the model's ability to perceive features across different image regions. To further improve feature representational capacity, we design the Adaptive Feature Enhancement (AFE) module, which strengthens the model's ability to capture and integrate semantic information across channels. Experimental results demonstrate that SAIMNet improves object detection accuracy.

title: Smart Grid Resilience: The Key Role of Machine Learning in Crisis Management
authors: Kamran Taghizad-Tavana, Mohsen Ghanbari-Ghalehjoughi, Mehrdad Tarafdar-Hagh, Hossein Shahinzadeh, Hamed Nafisi, Hossein Askarian-Abyaneh
abstract: The present article examines the role of emerging technologies in enhancing the resilience of power distribution networks against natural disasters and cyberattacks. Given the increasing challenges posed by the penetration of renewable energy sources, the growth of nonlinear loads, and security threats, this study emphasizes resilience as a key metric for evaluating the system's ability to maintain optimal performance under critical conditions. Resilience improvement strategies are categorized into hardware-based (e.g., vegetation management and undergrounding lines) and operational (e.g., utilizing emergency energy resources and managing repair teams) approaches. Additionally, the role of machine learning in damage prediction, anomaly detection, cyberattack identification, and outage forecasting is explored. Moreover, the combination of robust optimization and reinforcement learning is proposed as a comprehensive solution for managing uncertainties and enhancing the resilience of smart grids. The results indicate that integrating these technologies can reduce system recovery time and increase stability under critical conditions.

title: A Medium-Long Term PV Generation Forecasting method based on installed capacity decoupling
authors: Juan Yan, Xudong Wang, Cungang Hu, Shaokun Zou, Peiyang Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper presents a medium-to-long-term photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting method based on capacity decoupling. The proposed approach decomposes PV power into two key factors: installed capacity and decoupled PV output per installed capacity. For installed capacity forecasting, an improved linear rolling prediction method is developed, which incorporates historical capacity data and monthly characteristics for correction. The decoupled PV output, which represents the normalized power generation efficiency, is predicted by the XGBoost regression model that leverages meteorological data (e.g., surface solar radiation) and temporal features. By decoupling the capacity influence from the actual power generation, our method effectively handles the impact of dynamic capacity changes on long-term forecasts. Experimental validation using real-world data from Shandong province in China demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method for monthly and 10-day predictions. Comprehensive evaluation metrics (including CR, MAPE, MAE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) confirm its superior accuracy and robustness compared to traditional approaches.

title: Digital Preservation and Archival Practices Integrating AI and History: a case study at the Campos Gerais Museum-Brazil
authors: Julia Graciela Machado, Gabriel Lacerda De Souza, Giovana Ferreira, Lucas V. Kaspzack, Karine De F. Almeida, Vitor Bomfim Lopes, Gliceu F. De Camargo, Cloter Migliorini Filho, Edson A. Silva, Robson Laverdi, Ilton C. Martins, Niltonci B. Chaves, Renê Wagner Ramos, Marcella Scoczynski
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive case study on the integration of digital technologies and artificial intelligence in archival practices at the Campos Gerais Museum (MCG), a university museum in Brazil. It highlights the methodology developed by the Multiuser Laboratory for Digital Humanities and Innovation (LAMUHDI), responsible for digitizing, describing, and disseminating historical collections. Through a combination of archival principles and digital tools—including OCR technologies, metadata standards (Dublin Core, NOBRADE), and platforms like Omeka S—the lab ensures both the preservation of documentary heritage and its accessibility to researchers and the public. Moreover, the adoption of AI tools, such as the LLaVA model, supports the automated generation of image descriptions and metadata enrichment, improving scalability and minimizing manual effort. Experiments conducted with historical newspapers, including Diário dos Campos, demonstrate OCR accuracies above 90% for well-preserved editions. The transition from physical to digital repositories is guided by strict archival protocols, ensuring provenance, authenticity, and semantic interoperability. This initiative not only fosters academic research but also promotes democratic access to cultural memory through open-source systems and standardized processes. As a broader goal, this work proposes an integrated, state-level network of interconnected digital collections, enabling dynamic cross-referencing of historical data across institutions over the world.

title: Investigating Simulation for Safety Analysis of Battery Systems in an Active Solar Car Project
authors: Sebastian Daag, Johan Cederbladh
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: In the design of Electrical Vehicles (EVs) there are often many trade-offs to consider during system design. When considering safety aspects, these needs are further increased due to counter-acting incentives in design. Model-based tools and methods present a means of providing analytical capabilities through modeling of complex systems, possibly assisting in the analysis and design of EVs. In this paper we detail the experiences of using model-based methods in the design and analysis of a thermal management system for battery systems in solar cars. We use the context of the challenger class vehicles in the Bridgestone World Solar Challenge (BWSC) and discuss insights from applying a model-based method. The paper further reports on feedback from an active solar car project at a Swedish University. Our findings indicate that a model-based approach for safety analysis can provide meaningful tools for students to reason about safety during early system design stages.

title: Twin2Clouds: Cost-Aware Digital Twin Engineering and Deployment Across Federated Clouds
authors: Philipp Gritsch, Deniz Pierer, Luca Berardinelli, Michael Felderer, Sashko Ristov
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: CONTEXT: Digital Twins (DTs) undergo a rapid shift from monolithic cyber-physical systems to distributed, cloud-native stacks. While the elasticity of public cloud providers benefits this transition—opaque, provider-specific pricing renders economically viable deployment, especially across federated clouds, difficult.OBJECTIVES: This work aims to enable cost-aware deployment of Digital Twins across federated cloud providers by modeling DTs as multi-layered architectures and optimizing service selection per layer to minimize operational expenses.METHODS: We introduce Twin2Clouds, a cost-driven DT engineering framework that (1) organizes DT functionality into five cloud-oriented layers to help engineers map twin components to suitable cloud services, (2) offers cloud-agnostic cost and pricing primitives that capture heterogeneous pricing schemes across providers and services, and (3) integrates these elements in a cost-aware deployment model that predicts cloud costs and prescribes a reproducible deployment plan selecting the lowest-cost services for each layer.RESULTS: A quantitative evaluation of three real-world scenarios, ranging from a large smart building (30,000 devices) to a smart home (100 devices), demonstrates that Twin2Clouds consistently outperforms single-provider baselines. Depending on scale and workload, monthly costs decrease by an average of 24.6% and up to 79% compared with single-cloud alternatives.CONCLUSION: Twin2Clouds equips DT engineers with a practical, vendor-neutral method for navigating today’s complex cloud landscape and for realizing scalable, sustainable, and economically viable Digital Twins.

title: Privacy-Aware Fall Detection with LSTM and Differential Privacy
authors: M. Ali Fauzi, Bian Yang, Yati Sri Hayati, Budi Darma Setiawan, Irawati Nurmala Sari, Eko Sakti Pramukantoro
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Intelligent Technology and Embedded Systems (ICITES)
abstract: Falls are a significant health risk among elderly populations, necessitating effective detection systems. Vision-based methods, particularly pose estimation combined with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, have shown promising accuracy but raise privacy concerns due to the use of sensitive visual data. This paper proposes a privacy-aware fall detection system that leverages pose-based skeletal data and integrates Differential Privacy (DP) into LSTM training, providing formal guarantees of data privacy. We evaluate our approach using a publicly available dataset, comparing standard LSTM models against those trained with DP at various privacy levels (privacy budgets, ε). Our results indicate that incorporating DP introduces a measurable performance trade-off: higher privacy protection (smaller ε) leads to reductions in accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, particularly affecting the detection of minority-class events (falls). Nevertheless, moderate privacy settings ($\varepsilon \approx 2$ to 5) still achieve acceptable performance (approximately $85-87 \%$ accuracy), balancing privacy and practical utility effectively. This work underscores the importance of carefully selecting privacy budgets to maintain model efficacy while ensuring rigorous data protection, offering a robust approach suitable for sensitive environments such as elderly care facilities.

title: From Diagrams to Code: An Exploration into Automated Cloud Template Creation
authors: Varun Chandrashekar, Vikas Paul Menezes, Thaksha Ganesh, Isha Sudheer Prabhu, Chandrashekhar Pomu Chavan
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: Infrastructure as Code is the ability to provision and manage cloud infrastructure through code instead of manual and error-prone processes. Despite its benefits, the initial creation and maintenance of Infrastructure as Code templates remains tedious. Manual template creation may lead to security vulnerabilities and inconsistencies between design and implementation. Furthermore, cloud architecture complexity makes it harder to prevent configuration drift, where infrastructure deviates from its intended use case. Moreover, a lack of automation in template creation hinders rapid deployment and leads to inefficiencies. This paper presents an automated system for converting Amazon Web Service cloud architecture diagrams into CloudFormation templates. Using deep learning models and image processing techniques accompanied by a deterministic rule set, the system detects Amazon Web Services’ service components and their relationships from the input architecture diagram. The system detects the various icons (depicting services) present in the diagram with an accuracy of 98.40%. Simultaneously, a group detection module recognises various logical and physical boundaries such as Virtual Private Clouds or Security groups that define network and security segmentation. Rule-based suggestions are made on the extracted information to infer services that are not explicitly illustrated. Finally, the CloudFormation template is generated based on the aggregated output. Through this pipeline, the solution streamlines the automatic creation of CloudFormation templates with a latency under 15 seconds, minimising errors and development effort.

title: Multi-Scale Feature Aggregation Module for Drone-based Wind Turbine Defect Detection
authors: Wei Li, Shenwang Li, Yuyang Zhou, Yunwei Zhang, Junlong Deng, Zhenkang Zhang, Li Liu, Thomas Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Detecting small-scale defects on wind turbine components remains a major challenge due to issues such as motion blur, surface glare, occlusion, and complex backgrounds during drone-based inspections. To address this issue, we propose a lightweight detection framework enhanced by a novel Multi-Scale Feature Aggregation (MSFA) module, which effectively captures and fuses local detail and global context through deformable convolutions and an adaptive gated mechanism. This enables the network to focus on subtle defects even in noisy environments. We also introduce the Wind Turbine Visible Dataset (WTVD), containing 4,467 high-resolution images with pixel-level annotations across seven fault types. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in both accuracy and speed, achieving an mAP@0.5 of 91.57% and supporting real-time inference at over 30 FPS on edge devices, making it highly suitable for efficient, drone-based wind turbine inspection in real-world scenarios.

title: Fine-Tuning Thai Language Model for Sentiment Analysis of Restaurant Reviews Using WangchanBERTa
authors: Korawit Orkphol, Kathawach Satianpakiranakorn, Warintorn Jampasee, Aissariya Thongpang, Jidapa Chaihuadjaroen
abstract: This research focuses on developing a sentiment analysis system for Thai restaurant reviews, aiming to classify opinions into a five-star rating scale. The primary goal is to provide a tool that reflects customer satisfaction trends, offering valuable insights for business owners to enhance their services. We collected 7,200 reviews from Wongnai and Google Maps. After cleaning the data, a subset of reviews with lengths between 80 and 510 characters was used, with 6,000 entries for training and 1,200 for testing. The model we fine-tuned, WangchanBERTa, is a pre-trained Thai language model based on the BERT architecture. The fine-tuned WangchanBERTa model demonstrated a significant improvement in performance for star rating classification, achieving an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F} 1-score$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 0. 4 5 \%$</tex>, a substantial increase over the 65.28% F1-score of the baseline model. Although some minor misclassifications occurred between adjacent ratings, the overall performance was deemed satisfactory. Furthermore, the developed sentiment analysis system was integrated into a web interface, which allows users to input review text and receive real-time sentiment summaries. This system not only assists consumers in making more informed decisions when selecting restaurants but also helps restaurant owners understand and respond to customer feedback.

title: Optimization of Security in IoT with Stacked Ensembles for High-Precision Predictions
authors: Osman Salem, Jiahui Xiang, Ahmed Mehaoua, Santichai Wicha, Pradorn Sureephong
abstract: As the Internet of Things (IoT) continues to grow rapidly, safeguarding the security and privacy of these systems has become a critical challenge for organizations across various sectors. This paper proposes a comprehensive strategy to IoT safety, taking into account potential threats and effective defense mechanisms. We begin by reviewing existing methodologies for IoT security and highlighting their limitations. Subsequently, we present our methodology, detailed through this paper, which involves searching for an optimal Stacked Ensemble (SE) model that can effectively detect attacks. Our strategy combines several Machine Learning and Deep Learning techniques. To gauge the efficacy of our proposed approach, we conducted an experimental study using an IoT dataset. Our findings indicate that the best-performing models are Random Forest (RF) and an SE model combining RF, AdaBoost and a Deep Neural Network. These two algorithms exhibit very similar performances and both exceed 98.27 % and 98.26 % accuracy respectively in detecting 15 classes. However, in contrast to RF, the SE model achieves flawless Area Under the Curve (AUC) values for 14 classes and 0.99 for the last one. Our study underscores the need for a comprehensive contribution to IoT security and identifies the most promising techniques for fortifying these systems against potential cyber threats. In this article, we provide great insights into the challenges and solutions related to the protection of IoT devices within industrial settings. Organizations can use our proposed approach and the information gained from our study to enhance the security and privacy of their IoT systems.

title: Prediction of rTMS Treatment Response in Depression Using a Frequency-Based EEG Biomarker
authors: Ali Asadi Zeidabadi, Saeid Rashidi
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a leading cause of disability worldwide, and a significant proportion of patients do not respond to standard pharmacological and psychotherapeutic treatments. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) provides a non-invasive neuromodulatory therapy for treatment-resistant depression (TRD); however, the absence of reliable biomarkers limits its precision. In this study, resting-state EEG was recorded prior to treatment from 80 MDD patients undergoing a 20-session rTMS protocol. Spectral features across canonical frequency bands were extracted from 19 scalp electrodes, and a regularized feature selection technique identified a single high-frequency component at electrode F4 as the primary discriminator between responders (R) and non-responders (NR). This feature was normalized relative to an empirically derived reference cohort of optimal R to create a differential index. Combined with Support Vector Machine (SVM) and k-Nearest Neighbor (k-NN) classifiers under leave-one-out cross-validation, this index separated R from NR with 100% accuracy. These findings indicate that a succinct, interpretable spectral marker can predict individual rTMS outcomes and may inform personalized neuromodulation strategies in future studies.

title: Low-Frequency Oscillation Analysis with Interactions of Photovoltaic and Distributed Vehicles Based on Frequency Domain Modal Analysis Method
authors: Zeyu Zhang, Xiaoru Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: After the photovoltaic power generation system is connected to the traction power supply system, it will interact with the distributed vehicles in operation, making the stability analysis of the system more complex. The parameters of the inverter in actual systems are often unknown, and traditional state space methods cannot be used. Meanwhile, the frequency impedance method requires the system to be divided into active and passive sides for analysis. For complex systems containing multiple inverters, the frequency impedance method is also difficult to apply. The frequency domain modal method can be used to analyze the interactions between inverters in complex systems. This paper uses the impedance measurement method to obtain the impedance model of the vehicle and photovoltaic power generation, and analyzes and studies the impact of photovoltaic power generation system access on the low-frequency oscillation stability of traction power supply system based on frequency domain modal analysis method. Finally, the theoretical analysis results are validated through Matlab/Simulink time-domain simulation model.

title: Exploring a Hybrid Feedback Model: The Impact of Teacher and AI Feedback on Sixth-Grade Students' Reflective Writing in Mathematics
authors: Mitsushiro Ezoe, Masanori Takagi
abstract: This research proposes and evaluates an instructional support cycle model where teachers and generative artificial intelligence (AI) collaboratively offer feedback on elementary school students' reflective writing in mathematics. The framework aims at addressing the gap between the “ideal” of individualized learning support and the “reality” of teachers' heavy workloads by exploring (1) whether AI feedback can be evaluated on par with teacher feedback and (2) how feedback content interacts with the quality of student reflections across distinct achievement levels. A feedback support system was developed utilizing multiple large language models in an agentic workflow according to Hattie and Timperley's feedback model. The system was implemented in a sixth-grade mathematics unit on ratios (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=14$</tex>, eight lessons), with teacher and AI feedback alternating. Quantitative analyses displayed no significant difference in perceived usefulness ratings between teacher and AI feedback across achievement levels. Content analysis exhibited that teacher feedback highlighted task and self-regulation levels, while AI feedback depended more on self-level comments, with variation across achievement groups. Case studies affirmed that alignment between feedback content and learners' implicit needs determined perceived usefulness. Overall, the findings propose that AI can complement teachers by delivering immediate, affective feedback, thereby freeing teachers to focus on context-sensitive, high-expertise instructional support.

title: TransEF: Transform-Domain Enhanced Features for Lightweight Image Matching
authors: Shunlong Zhou, Gongjian Wen, Peiyao Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Intelligent Technology and Embedded Systems (ICITES)
abstract: Current deep learning-based image matching methods generally face a trade-off between computational efficiency and matching accuracy: although existing approaches have significantly improved matching precision through complex network architectures, their high computational costs severely limit realtime applications. To address this challenge, we propose TransEF, a lightweight local feature extraction network that achieves synergistic optimization of efficiency and performance through two key innovations. Firstly, we design self-enhanced feature descriptors by integrating the Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) with convolutions to construct parameter-efficient descriptor enhancement modules. Secondly, we develop a structure-aware detection branch through an independent feature detection network. By leveraging knowledge distillation guided by an ALIKE teacher network, this branch forces the model to focus on underlying geometric structures. Experimental results on MegaDepth and HPatches datasets demonstrate that compared to baseline methods, our approach achieves better balance between runtime efficiency and network performance in downstream tasks, making it more suitable for practical applications.

title: Linear Optimization Strategy for Stability and Economics of High Renewable Penetration Grids
authors: Yalong Sun, Dongliang Deng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of distributed photovoltaics (PV) in distribution networks and the enhanced interaction between source, grid, and load, the requirements for voltage stability are becoming more stringent. Traditional static voltage stability indicators, due to their high nonlinearity, cannot effectively guide the optimal operation of distribution networks. In response, this paper proposes a linear static voltage stability index, which offers the potential for voltage security optimization in distribution networks. First, analogous to the traditional L-index, and based on reasonable assumptions combined with the impedance characteristics of distribution networks, a linear voltage static stability indicator is proposed based on solvable power flow equations. Second, the Sobol' method is employed to quantitatively analyze the impact of input variable uncertainties and correlations on the voltage stability indicator through global sensitivity analysis. Then, based on the sensitivity analysis results, an optimization operation model for distribution networks is established, balancing economic efficiency and stability, with constraints linearized using second-order cone optimal power flow. Finally, the proposed stability indicator and optimization operation model are tested on the IEEE 33-bus system, demonstrating the accuracy of the indicator and the superiority of the optimization operation model.

title: Security Analysis of MiniApps: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and a Tailored Mitigation Framework
authors: Keyhan Mohammadi, Arman Moradi, Reza Ebrahimi Atani
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Telegram MiniApps and WeChat Mini Programs represent two leading implementations of the superApp sub application paradigm, each combining centralized backend services with lightweight, embedded client interfaces. While both platforms enable rich user experiences, they also introduce significant security risks through architectural and implementation flaws. In this paper, we present a comparative analysis of vulnerabilities in Telegram MiniApps and WeChat Mini Programs, drawing from documented exploits and empirical testing. For WeChat, prior studies reveal widespread issues including sensitive data leakage, weak permission enforcement, and cross MiniApp request forgery, affecting millions of deployed apps. For Telegram, we identify unproxied frontend–backend communication leaking IPs and server endpoints, insecure HTTP defaults in the Bot API enabling man in the middle attacks, and inadequate auditing of TON blockchain smart contracts. We further analyze adversarial MiniApps exploiting WebView sandbox weaknesses for malware delivery, cryptomining, and cryptocurrency phishing. Building on these findings, we propose a comprehensive mitigation framework tailored to Telegram but informed by lessons from WeChat’s vulnerabilities. Our approach includes mandatory HTTPS, Telegram-hosted proxying, sandbox isolation, automated malicious activity detection, and AI-assisted code auditing. The results highlight the urgent need for platform level reforms across superApp ecosystems to align rapid feature growth with strong user privacy and security guarantees.

title: A Novel Dynamic Reconfiguration Method for Photovoltaic Arrays Based on Gene Pairing
authors: Jiangjin Zuo, Feng Li, Xiaokang Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) arrays are often subject to the negative impacts of partial shading conditions (PSCs), such as non-uniform irradiance caused by surrounding objects, cloud shadows, and dust accumulation. Such PSCs can significantly reduce power generation efficiency, potentially damage PV cells, and lead to complex multi-peak characteristics in P-V curves. To address the multi-peak power output issues induced by PSCs, this study explores dynamic array reconfiguration as a solution. Specifically, a 10×10 PV array model is constructed, and a novel Gene-pairing Configuration Strategy (GCS)-based dynamic reconfiguration algorithm is proposed for real-time optimization under shaded conditions. The core objective is to mitigate PSC-induced power losses and enhance total power output. Simulations demonstrate that under a specific short-wide partial shading pattern, the proposed GCS reconfiguration optimization achieves over 30% improvement in maximum power point output compared to the pre-reconfiguration baseline.

title: RSM 2025 Commentary
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)

title: Design and Implementation of 1200W VPX Server Power Based on High Speed Serial Bus
authors: Tao Wang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: A new generation of server power product called 1200 W VPX power supply based on high speed serial bus is introduced in this paper. It has the characteristics of high efficiency, high power density and high electromagnetic compatibility. The power supply adopts discrete devices to solve many problems caused by module integration scheme. The electrical performance indicators of the power supply meet the design requirements. The experimental results show that this product is feasible and reliable.

title: An LSTM-SVM hybrid framework for thermal fault diagnosis in SOFC systems: single and multi-fault analysis
authors: Xiaolong Wu, Zhuxun Li, Yushui Huang, Xi Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC), celebrated for its high-power generation efficiency and environmentally friendly attributes, holds significant promise in the domain of green energy. However, the high-temperature operating conditions of SOFC frequently trigger various heat management-related faults, which severely compromise system reliability and operational lifespan. Consequently, developing high-performance fault diagnosis methods enables the timely detection and localization of faults, allowing for the implementation of measures to prevent further escalation and potential damage. In this study, a phased hybrid fault diagnosis approach combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) is proposed, where LSTM extracts temporal features while SVM performs precise classification based on the extracted features. Utilizing data from three representative thermal fault types within SOFC systems, the method is evaluated under both single-fault and multi-fault diagnostic scenarios. Moreover, five conventional data-driven methods are introduced for comparison to validate the diagnostic performance of the LSTM-SVM model in terms of Hit Rate (HR), False Alarm Rate (FAR), Correct Rate (CR) and response time. The experimental results demonstrate that in single-fault diagnostic scenarios, the LSTM-SVM model exhibits optimal performance, achieving an impressive accuracy of 99.99%, with a false alarm rate as low as 0.06% and a notably fast response time. In multi-fault diagnostic tasks, the LSTM-SVM model achieves the highest precision of 99.71% and the best hit rate of 99.59%, while also demonstrating faster response speeds. These advantages establish LSTM-SVM as the most effective method. This study provides a valuable foundation for selecting and optimizing fault diagnosis strategies for thermal management challenges in SOFC systems, offering meaningful insights and guidance for future research efforts in the field.

title: A Data-Driven Simulation Platform for Harmonic Source Localization
authors: Yuyao Wu, Yinhui Li, Yangguang Zhang, Qingxin Shi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of nonlinear loads and distributed energy resources, harmonic distortion has become a critical challenge in modern distribution systems. The accurate localization of harmonic sources is crucial for maintaining power quality and enhancing grid reliability. To enable such localization, this paper presents a data-driven harmonic source localization simulation platform developed in Matlab. The platform comprises three primary components. The first component is a data preprocessing unit that integrates harmonic power flow computation and multi-order harmonic extraction using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). The second is a localization algorithm module that employs Partial Least Squares (PLS) regression to identify the locations of harmonic sources and quantify their contributions based on measured voltage and current waveforms. The third is a visualization module that presents the localization results through tabular data and graphical outputs. The platform provides an effective tool for harmonic analysis, detection, and mitigation in smart distribution systems.

title: Transient Overvoltage Cooperative Control Strategy Based on Energy-Consuming Devices and Supply-Side Voltage Reduction
authors: Jianbo Zhou, Zun Wang, Yuxiang Geng, Yifan Wang, Li Luo
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Flexible DC transmission technology based on modular multilevel converters offers flexible control and no commutation failures, making it an effective means of transporting renewable energy. However, when faults occur in the AC grid at the receiving end of the system, power surpluses can arise, leading to transient overvoltage on the DC side and posing a serious threat to system stability. This paper addresses this issue by analyzing the power imbalance mechanism under receiving-end faults. It proposes a coordinated control strategy combining energy dissipation devices with voltage reduction at the sending end to address excess power and suppress transient overvoltage. This strategy leverages the temporary energy storage characteristics of converter stations to increase their equivalent capacitive storage capacity, thereby temporarily suppressing DC-side overvoltage, and utilizes the power dissipation capability of energy dissipation devices to dissipate overall excess power. Finally, simulations were conducted using the PSCAD/EMTDC platform to validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: Simulation of Serpentine Microfluidic Channel for Portable Virus Detection System
authors: Ahmad Akmal Jazmi, Muhammad Khairul Faisal Muhammad Atan, Rosminazuin Ab Rahim, Aliza Aini Md Ralib, Ahmad Fairuzabadi Mohd Mansor, Anis Nurashikin Nordin
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive simulation study of a 3D-printed microfluidic system designed for virus detection using Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) at a constant temperature of 65°C for a duration of 35 minutes. To enhance portability and reduce the dependency on bulky thermal cycling equipment required in conventional PCR methods, a serpentine microchannel geometry was designed using AutoCAD and analyzed in finite element simulation. The simulation integrates laminar flow and heat transfer physics to evaluate critical parameters including velocity distribution, volume flow rate, pressure drop, Reynolds number, and temperature profile. Results show stable laminar flow with a low Reynolds number (Re = 0.175), minimal secondary flow effects (Dean number = 0.107), and consistent volume flow rates around 262 μL/hr within 35 minutes. Thermal analysis indicates effective heat transfer with uniform temperature distribution along the channel. These findings validate the model’s suitability for isothermal nucleic acid amplification and support its application in low-cost, point-of-care diagnostic devices. The simulated design can be fabricated using 3D-printing technology for a portable virus detection system.

title: Player Perceptions of Path-First Procedural Content Generation Level Design for 3D Platformer Games
authors: Matthew Jakeman, Matan Yosef, Hugh Parsons, Jia Tee, Jordan York, Dominik Lange-Nawka, Steffan Hooper, Burkhard C. Wünsche
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Video game development faces increasing challenges from higher player expectations and expanding budgets. Procedural Content Generation (PCG) addresses these issues by reducing developer resource requirements. For platformer games, PCG methods often require time-consuming post-generation validation. Path-first PCG, designed for 2D platformers, first creates a playable path and then constructs the level around it. Existing path-first PCG techniques solve resource and playability concerns in 2D platformers, but no guarantee exists that these levels are perceived the same as manually designed levels, and few have attempted to apply path-first to 3D platformers. This paper prototypes a game to assess the effectiveness of a rhythm-based path-first PCG level design for 3D platformers. Empirical evidence from a controlled user study (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{n}=\mathbf{1 8}$</tex>) reveals minimal differences in perceptions between path-first PCG and manually designed levels, showcasing promise for the automated PCG technique.

title: Robust DTMOS Schmitt-Trigger Circuits in 130 nm SOI CMOS for Sub-100mV Supply Voltage
authors: Muhammad Umer Khalid, Trond Ytterdal, Snorre Aunet
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This work proposes to utilize a dynamic thresholdvoltage MOSFET (DTMOS) technique for Schmitt-Trigger-based circuits that significantly enhances the Ion/Ioff ratio while improving robustness against process variations and mismatch. We designed and validated DTMOS Schmitt Trigger (DST) inverter and NAND gates in a commercial 130nm SOI CMOS technology. Comprehensive post-layout simulations compared noise margins, power dissipation and propagation delay against standard Schmitt-Trigger implementations. Monte Carlo analysis demonstrates that our proposed circuits achieve 99.9% yield at an ultra-low supply voltage of 60 mV. Evaluation of 11-stage inverter- and NAND-based ring oscillators revealed that the DST-based circuits deliver <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24-27 {\%}$</tex> improved energy efficiency and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-37 {\%}$</tex> reduced delay at 90 mV operation, with only a small area overhead. Furthermore, the minimum operating voltage is reduced by 12.5%, with the DST inverter demonstrating functionality at voltages as low as 40 mV.

title: Towards Safer E-Healthcare: BWM-Based Cybersecurity Risk Prioritization
authors: Melike Erdoğan, Ertugrul Ayyildiz, Busra Kesici, Elissa N. Madi
abstract: As more patient information is stored and shared electronically with developing technology, cybersecurity risks and threats in e-healthcare applications have become a notable problem. To mitigate these risks, it is essential to implement measures such as strengthening security protocols, regularly updating systems, and collaborating with IT experts. Along with identifying security measures, determining which risks pose a threat to cybersecurity and their relative importance is also a crucial step in managing risk. This study aims to investigate cybersecurity risks in e-healthcare applications and rank them. Therefore, it will identify which risks are most critical and, accordingly, which risks should be combated first. For risk prioritization, the Best Worst Method (BWM), which has been frequently used in the literature recently, has been adopted. Among the nine main risks identified as a result of literature research and expert opinions, it has been successfully determined which ones should be addressed with priority.

title: Impact of Temperature, Doping, and Device Geometry on the Electrical Performance of 4H-SiC MOSFETs
authors: Fahim Shahriar, Nurul Ezaila Alias, Michael Loong Peng Tan, Yasmin Abdul Wahab, Hanim Hussin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: To address the limitation of silicon (Si) and germanium (Ge), SiC has gained huge importance as a high-performance semiconductor material for high-power, high-frequency, and high-temperature applications. However, the performance and reliability of 4H - SiC MOSFETs are affected by challenges such as high temperatures, higher doping concentrations, and high bias voltages, which lead to stress and degrade performance. In this paper, the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of 4H-SiC MOSFETs were analyzed to enhance understanding and improve device performance. A 3D device structure of 4H - SiC MOSFET was simulated, and I-V characteristics was used to extract critical electrical parameters, including threshold voltage (Vth), on-current (Ion), off-current (Ioff), subthreshold swing (SS), and Drain Induced Barrier Lowering (DIBL). The influence of physical dimensions such as epilayer thickness (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{W}_{\text{Drift}}$</tex>), and gate length (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{L}_{G}$</tex>) on electrical characteristics was investigated by varying device parameters for power applications, focusing on ON-state behavior, such as on-resistance. It was found that Ron had a significant effect below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> of width, while for gate lengths from 1.2 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.8 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>, Ron remained almost constant. Furthermore, stress testing was conducted to evaluate degradation effects in terms of breakdown voltage and electric field under variations in doping concentrations, temperature, and biasing voltage. It was found that temperature had very little impact on breakdown voltage, but increasing the doping concentration by 2 times resulted in 3 times decrease in breakdown voltage.

title: Method for State Classification and Probability Evaluation of Security and Stability Control Devices Based on Historical Statistical Data
authors: Manli Li, Haibo Xu, Xijian Dong, Jianbing Xu, Qitao Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Security and stability control devices (SSCDs) serve as critical components in the second line of defense for power-system security, and their reliability is paramount. This study analyzes key factors influencing the reliability of SSCDs based on historical data and elucidates the mechanisms through which these factors impact the functions. Building upon this foundation, the research examines the introduction process of latent faults in SSCDs from the perspective of their design lifecycle. It classifies typical operational states of SSCDs and proposes a Markov-based probability assessment model. Furthermore, calculation principles for key model parameters are derived based on historical statistical data, and the effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through a numerical case study.

title: A Novel High Voltage Gain DC-DC Boost Converter
authors: Vishrut Karangale, Manisha Ingale, Nathrao B. Jadhav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: DC - DC converters play a vital role in the functioning of renewable energy systems, microgrids and electric vehicles. The quest for converters that delivers high gain with the reliable performance in this domain is no history. Majorly there are three DC-DC converters classified based on their gain with respect to input as boost converter, buck converter and buck-boost converter. This work focuses on novel DC-DC high gain boost converter topology which can boost input voltage with a gain of about 11.76 at 70% duty cycle. The circuit is simulated in MATLAB and performance is analysed considering duty cycle, settling time and peak voltage as the parameters for verification of novelty. The comparative analysis is carried out with the existing standard DC-DC boost converter topology. While boosting the input DC voltage of 150 V by the gain of 5 for a 2000W system, the duty cycle required was reduced by 63.29%, settling time being reduced by 50%, peak voltage being reduced by 49.8% than that of the standard DC-DC boost converter topology, which ultimately results in reduction of component stress.

title: Dual Time Scale Prescribed-Performance Tracking Control Strategy for Underactuated Surface Vessels Based on Singular Perturbations
authors: Duanhua Bao, Yujie Xu, Yan Wang, Lijing Dong, Mingyu Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: To address the issue of dual prescribed performance (convergence speed and accuracy) control for underactuated surface vessels (USVs) under multi-time scales, this paper proposes a new simplified tracking control approach founded on singular perturbation. To resolve the underactuation constraint, a dynamic feedback coordinate transformation is employed. This transformation maps the velocity composite variable and the position variable into the fast and slow subsystems respectively, thus establishing a singular perturbation model suitable for USVs. Then, the singular perturbation system is decoupled in time scale to obtain non-coupled fast and slow subsystems. For the fast subsystem, the corresponding control law is designed using a predefined-time convergence method. To govern tracking error dynamics in the slow subsystem, a performance function enforces both transient and steady-state performance. Further fortifying robustness, a nonlinear disturbance observer provides continuous estimation and real-time compensation for unknown environmental disturbances. The effectiveness of the proposed control strategy was verified through Lyapunov stability analysis.

title: A Non-Invasive Cross-platform Supported Pocket ECG Device for Heart Monitoring
authors: Md Razu Miah, Octavian Adrian Postolache
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) pose a significant global health challenge that requires innovative solutions for continuous monitoring and early intervention. Different solutions are part of healthcare digital transformation through mobile implementations. In this paper, presented a lead electrode-based and cross-platform-supported ECG device called CorSeg, which is suitable for monitoring heart activities in home and outdoor environments. Additional functionalities are body temperature measurement and movement detection for removing motion artifacts and calculating heartbeat rate. An ESP32-PICO-D4 integrated microcontroller board called ESP32 PICO KIT D4 has been used to obtain and process the ECG data. A cross-platform supported software has been developed with a.NET MAUI framework to store and visualise the ECG data. To send and receive data between the CorSeg device and the cross-platform software, Universal Serial Bus (USB) and Bluetooth communication protocols have been used. The activation of the protocols depends on the device where the software is installed. For mobile devices, the CorSeg ECG device uses Bluetooth communication, while it uses USB for desktop devices. The CorSeg device has been tested with the FLUKE ECG simulator in a laboratory environment, where the simulation and real-life test on volunteers suggest that the device's performance is good enough to monitor heart rhythm. The device is fabricated with a 3D-printed box so that the user can put the box in their pocket during walking.

title: A Dual-Mode Flapping-Wing Robot Capable of Water-Surface Sliding and Take-Off
authors: Yang Qiu, Zhidong Xu, Jihong Yan, Jie Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Multiple-mode motions enhance the flexibility, adaptability and motion efficiency for water-surface robots in complex water environments. Owing to the unstructured and perturbable properties of water, the task of water-surface take-off remains profoundly challenging. Furthermore, at the microscale, there persists a notable scarcity of a rapid, stable, and lightweight attitude adjustment mechanism. So it is challenging for robots to achieve water-surface sliding and take-off dual-mode motion. To handle this problem, this paper optimizes the shape of the support feet to significantly reduce the drag force during takeoff, and designs a rapid, stable, and lightweight attitude adjustment mechanism based on a linear servo with a self-locking function. On this basis, a flapping-wing robot capable of continuous water-surface sliding and take-off is designed. Experiment shows that continuous water-surface sliding and takeoff motion is achieved, with a motion mode switching time of 0.03 s.
