title: A Dense U-Net Framework for Speech Enhancement with Channel-Sequence Attention
authors: Areefa Begam Shaik, Sunny Dayal Vanambathina
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: This paper presents a new deep learning framework that aims to improve speech quality in noisy environments. The model is built on a U-Net structure and enhanced with two key components: a channel-sequence attention (CSAtt) module and a Densely Connected Multi-Dilated Convolution (D3) block. The CSAtt module enables the model to emphasize the most informative regions of the speech signal by capturing both channel-wise (frequency) and time-based patterns in the spectrogram. The D3 block is used as the central layer in U-Net, which utilizes dilated convolutions with dense connections to comprehend the broader context while preserving detail. The model takes spectrograms as input and is trained using Huber loss, making it more robust to noise and better at preserving sound quality. Tests show that this combination of attention and dilation techniques produces significantly better quality and more comprehensible speech, making the model suitable for real-world applications, such as phone calls, hearing aids, and voice assistants.

title: Mitigating Negative Energy Pricing through Cryptocurrency Mining as a High Flexible Load
authors: Omidreza Heydaritafreshi, Mehran Hajiaghapour-Moghimi, Ehsan Hajipour, Mahmud Fotuhi-Firuzabad
abstract: In recent years, countries have increasingly promoted the deployment of renewable energy sources (RESs) to leverage their environmental and economic benefits. These incentives often take the form of power purchase agreements (PPAs), which guarantee fixed electricity prices regardless of market fluctuations. While PPAs provide steady profits for RES owners and encourage investment, they also introduce challenges within power systems. A key issue arising from these agreements is that RES owners may submit excessively low or even negative bids to secure market commitments, thereby activating PPA benefits and feeding electricity into the grid. As a result, regions with high shares of RESs may experience market clearing at negative prices. Meanwhile, cryptocurrency mining loads (CMLs) have become a significant energy consumer, accounting for nearly 1% of global electricity consumption, a share that is expected to grow. While the increasing presence of CMLs poses challenges for power grids, they can also offer valuable services, particularly in terms of demand-side flexibility. This paper proposes CMLs as highly flexible loads to counteract negative pricing. To evaluate the effectiveness of this approach, case studies were conducted, indicating that CMLs can mitigate the instances of negative prices without causing price spikes. Furthermore, the results showed that integrating CMLs into the electricity grid can reduce the curtailment of the RESs.

title: Comparative Study of Building Detection from Satellite Images using Deep Learning
authors: Yong Loong Yap, Wisnu Jatmiko, Kurniawati Azizah, Muhammad Hafizhuddin Hilman, Sin Liang Lim
abstract: In this paper, the performances of various deep learning models, including YOLOv8, ResNet, and VGG across a spectrum of configurations and training scenarios are studied. The aims of this study are (i) to develop and implement a deep learning model for accurately detecting building damage in satellite images and (ii) to develop methodologies for quantifying and analysing building damage level. By comparing with various Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models, this research aims to improve the accuracy and efficiency of building detection and damage assessment, ultimately aiding in urban planning and disaster response efforts. This comparative analysis not only highlights the relative advantages of each model but also guides the selection of appropriate deep learning techniques for enhancing building detection accuracy. By optimizing these deep learning models, we aim to advance the capabilities of satellite image-based monitoring systems, thus supporting more efficient urban planning and more responsive disaster management strategies.

title: A Constant Bandwidth Oversampling PLL Enabled by a Constant-Gain Oversampler Composed of Double-Edge and Sampling Single-Edge Capacitive Charging and Discharging Phase Interpolators
authors: Xueke Cai, Tong Zhang, Deyong Li, Yang Zhao, Yongfu Li, Honglan Jiang, Patrick P. Mercier, Hui Wang
abstract: This work introduces a constant bandwidth oversampling PLL (CBW-OSPLL) that eliminates the noise degradation and stability limitations of conventional oversampling phase-locked loops (PLLs) caused by sampling gain fluctuations. The proposed CBW-OSPLL utilizes a constant-gain oversampler composed of double-edge capacitive charging and discharging PIs (DE-CCDPIs) and sampling single-edge capacitive charging and discharging PIs (SSE-CCDPIs) with embedded reference sampling functionality. The DE-CCDPIs provide eight clocks with phases uniformly distributed within a reference cycle, which are further evenly split into 16 phases through SSE-CCDPIs. The intrinsic sampling functionality embedded in the proposed SSE-CCDPI ensures a constant sampling across all sampling locations, enabling improved noise and stability. To further improve the linearity of the DE-CCDPIs and SSE-CCDPIs, direct-gating transition and voltage clamping techniques are proposed, collectively reducing the differential nonlinearity of the DE-CCDPIs and SSE-CCDPIs to 0.001 LSB. Fabricated in a standard 0.18-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m CMOS, the proposed integer-N CBW-OSPLL occupies an active area of 0.44 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. When operating at 2 GHz, it achieves an rms jitter of 444 fs and consumes 7.6mW, yielding an FoM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">JIT</sub> of −238.2 dB and an FoM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">REF</sub> of −240.2dB, while measurements across supply variation, temperature variation, and multiple samples are performed, demonstrating the robustness of the proposed CBW-OSPLL.

title: ZSTT: A Zero-Shot Time-Series Prediction Model Based on Transformer and Its Application to Hydraulic Actuator Performance Degradation Prediction
authors: Jiashan Gao, Shaoping Wang, Rentong Chen, Chao Zhang, Enrico Zio, Yuwei Zhang, Yaohui Lu
abstract: Most of the existing time-series prediction methods depend on large training datasets, which restricts their applicability in industrial applications with limited or no target-system data. This occurs in various instances of performance degradation prediction based on multisource sensor data. To address this issue, this article proposes a zero-shot time-series prediction (ZSTT) model based on the transformer framework, referred to as ZSTT. It enables multisource time-series prediction without requiring pretraining on the target dataset. Approximate Bayesian inference is first considered to increase the generalization ability of the model. A learnable pattern module, which employs a Gumbel-distribution-based dynamic masking mechanism, is then introduced to optimize joint training across multisource datasets. Finally, a real degradation test of the hydraulic actuator is conducted to assess the performance of ZSTT. Its validation through comprehensive experiments is also conducted on benchmark datasets. A comparison with state-of-the-art methods is conducted, demonstrating the performance of ZSTT in terms of higher accuracy and robustness of prediction. Furthermore, ablation studies were performed to validate the contribution of each individual module. The case study demonstrates the high performance of ZSTT in multisensor data prediction and performance degradation prediction.

title: Efficient LLM Deployment in Consumer Electronics Applications via Resource-Aware and Salience-Guided Quantization
authors: Tianfu Pang, Yingchi Mao, Zhenxiang Pan, Rongzhi Qi, Benteng Zhang, Xiaoming He, Jie Wu
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) can stimulate intelligent functions on mobile devices in the applications of consumer electronics. However, it is challenging to deploy LLMs on mobile devices due to limited memory and computational resources that fluctuate as devices execute multiple AI tasks concurrently. Quantization is a widely adopted compression technique, but faces two major difficulties in practical deployment: 1) Existing quantization methods are unable to select suitable models for deployment according to the resource limitations of mobile devices; 2) Mixed-precision quantization-based methods utilize reinforcement learning and element-level quantization, which incurs substantial computational and memory costs on mobile devices. To this end, we propose Resource Awareness-Based Salience-Weighted Mixed-Precision Quantization (RAS-MQ). Specifically, RAS-MQ constructs a memory and latency computation incorporating model parameters and device constraints, then RAS-MQ employs integer linear programming for optimal per-layer bit-width allocation. Weight matrices are partitioned into groups with bit-widths assigned based on average saliency ranking. Furthermore, RAS-MQ applies training-free quantization range clipping to salient weights, which can improve representational capacity while reducing quantization error. Experiments on five zero-shot inference datasets, for the 2-bit quantization of LLaMA2-13B, RAS-MQ outperforms the state-of-the-art baseline (SqueezeLLM) by 0.85% in accuracy and reduces weight memory consumption from 24.5 GB to 4.1 GB, achieving a 5.98× compression ratio.

title: FreMamba: A Frequency Domain Mamba Model for Hyperspectral Image Change Detection
authors: Pengyuan Lv, Peng Cheng, Feilong Shan, Yune Cao, Yanfei Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The task of hyperspectral image change detection (HSI-CD) is to identify the subtle category changes of land surfaces by utilizing the rich spectral information of bi-temporal hyperspectral images (HSIs). Recent advanced deep learning methods have improved the performance of HSI-CD. However, HSIs have the mixed-pixel phenomenon, which affects the ability of HSI-CD models to discriminate land-cover changes. In this paper, a frequency domain Mamba (FreMamba) model is proposed to precisely capture the details of the spatial and spectral changes in bi-temporal HSIs, with consideration of the abovementioned problem. The proposed FreMamba model utilizes the capability of the Mamba model to adaptively filter the critical change information in long-range feature sequences. This is combined with frequency domain information to enhance the low-frequency global information and high-frequency spatial detail representation, based on a dual-branch network structure. A low-frequency spectral-guided attention (LSGA) module is proposed for the low-frequency Mamba branch, where it is embedded within the Mamba block via residual connections. Global low-frequency features are aggregated by the LSGA module with noise suppression, while the spectral change discriminability of ground objects is adaptively enhanced via the subsequent Mamba blocks. In the high-frequency Mamba branch, a high-frequency spatial geometric enhancement (HSGE) module is proposed that preserves edge details by spatial frequency domain decomposition to extract high-frequency geometric features. Experiments on three public HSI-CD datasets demonstrate that the proposed FreMamba model can accurately capture detailed change information and can outperform the existing state-of-the-art HSI-CD methods.

title: SS-VIO: A Novel Cross Modal State Space Visual Inertial Odometry
authors: Wenyuan Qin, Zhi Lin, Lu Bai, Shaojun Yao, Hao Xu, Xiwang Dong
abstract: Visual-inertial odometry (VIO) is fundamental to autonomous driving, embodied navigation, and robotics. While geometry based methods dominate the field, learning based approaches are still in their infancy despite promising progress. Current deep learning based VIO methods usually fuse visual images and inertial measurements directly, neglecting intra modal frequency heterogeneity, cross modal dependencies, and temporal continuity in state estimation. We propose a State Space Visual-Inertial Odometry (SS-VIO) framework that fuses modalities through a Mamba-based time-frequency modeling module. The first is a time frequency interaction module with Mamba that captures joint temporal and frequency representations and performs adaptive selection. The second is a cross modal fusion module that integrates inertial cues into visual features through learned weighting. Experiments on the KITTI dataset show that SS-VIO outperforms state of the art methods in both accuracy and efficiency. Additional tests on RealSense D435i quadruped robot data confirm the generalization ability of the framework across different platforms.

title: Gentle Object Retraction in Dense Clutter Using Multimodal Force Sensing and Imitation Learning
authors: Dane Brouwer, Joshua Citron, Heather Nolte, Jeannette Bohg, Mark Cutkosky
abstract: Dense collections of movable objects are common in everyday spaces-from cabinets in a home to shelves in a warehouse. Safely retracting objects from such collections is difficult for robots, yet people do it frequently, leveraging learned experience in tandem with vision and non-prehensile tactile sensing on the sides and backs of their hands and arms. We investigate the role of contact force sensing for training robots to gently reach into constrained clutter and extract objects. The available sensing modalities are (1) “eye-in-hand” vision, (2) proprioception, (3) non-prehensile triaxial tactile sensing, (4) contact wrenches estimated from joint torques, and (5) a measure of object acquisition obtained by monitoring the vacuum line of a suction cup. We use imitation learning to train policies from a set of demonstrations on randomly generated scenes, then conduct an ablation study of wrench and tactile information. We evaluate each policy's performance across 40 unseen environment configurations. Policies employing any force sensing show fewer excessive force failures, an increased overall success rate, and faster completion times. The best performance is achieved using both tactile and wrench information, producing an 80% improvement above the baseline without force information.

title: Phase-Compensated Multi-Carrier Modulations for Common-Mode Voltage Suppression in MMC
authors: Zuoxing Wang, Hong Li, Yanjun Li, Zhaoyi Chu, Wenzhe Su, Tiancong Shao
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Multi-carrier modulation has been widely employed in medium-voltage modular multilevel converters (MMCs) due to its implementation simplicity. Nevertheless, typical modulations usually ignore the effects of common-mode voltage (CMV), while recent low CMV modulations (e.g., pulse-edge reconstruction and edge-triggered pulse sequential connection) can lead to increased switching frequency or reduced DC-link voltage utilization ratio, thereby limiting their applicability in medium- and high-power scenarios. To address these challenges, this paper proposes two phase-compensated (PC) multi-carrier modulations for MMC, namely PC carrier phase-shifted (CPS) sinusoidal pulse width modulation (SPWM) and PC carrier disposition (CD) SPWM. First, a waveform-decomposition-based universal CMV model for MMC is developed by accessing the mechanisms and characteristics of CMV fluctuations under typical CPS SPWM and CD SPWM. Following that, the proposed modulations are analytically derived, realizing effective CMV suppression without increasing the switching frequency or reducing the DC-link voltage utilization ratio. Moreover, the electrical performance of the proposed modulations for MMC is systematically evaluated using seven key performance indicators and compared with that of existing modulations. Finally, the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed modulations are validated through simulation and experimental results.

title: Constrained Conditional Denoising Diffusion for Hyperspectral-Multispectral Fusion
authors: James E. Fowler
abstract: Diffusion models have recently risen to prominence for a variety of inverse-imaging problems. Many such models use what is commonly known as conditional diffusion which effectively samples from the distribution of the desired image conditioned on some known side information, often a degraded or lower-resolution version of the target image. However, an alternative paradigm has recently emerged in the form of constrained diffusion in which explicit constraints between the target image and the side information are iteratively incorporated into the diffusion reconstruction during inference. While prior literature has considered conditional and constrained diffusion to effectively be mutually exclusive, a diffusion algorithm is proposed to combine the two within the widely-used denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) framework. The resulting approach—constrained conditional denoising diffusion—inputs both the target and side information into the diffusion network during both training and inference similar to conditional diffusion but also applies explicit constraints during inference like constrained diffusion. The proposed approach is evaluated for the task of fusing a hyperspectral image, possessing high spectral resolution, with a multispectral image, having high spatial resolution, to yield an image with high resolution both spatially and spectrally, an inverse-imaging problem called hyperspectral-multispectral fusion. Experimental results demonstrate that, not only can constrained and conditional diffusion operate complementarily and achieve performance superior to either used alone, but also that the proposed constrained conditional denoising diffusion outperforms other state-of-the-art approaches for hyperspectral-multispectral fusion.

title: DANG: Data Augmentation based on NIR-II Guided Diffusion Model for Fluorescence Molecular Tomography
authors: Qiushi Huang, Chunzhao Li, Anqi Xiao, Jie Tian, Zhenhua Hu
abstract: Fluorescence molecular tomography (FMT), particularly within the second near-infrared window (NIR-II, 1000-1700 nm), is a sophisticated imaging technique for numerous medical applications, enabling reconstruction of the three-dimensional (3D) distribution of internal tumors from surface fluorescence signals. Recent studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of deep learning methods in FMT reconstruction tasks, however, their performance heavily relies on large-scale, diverse labeled datasets. The existing researches primarily focused on datasets with static tumor characteristics, including fixed tumor numbers, locations, and sizes, which shows an insufficient pattern diversity, limiting neural networks' generalization ability for complex real-world scenarios beyond the training dataset. To address this limitation, we draw inspiration from the similarity between Monte Carlo photon simulation and sampling process of diffusion model, to propose a diffusion model-based data augmentation strategy. Further, we introduce a novel NIR-II-specific guidance mechanism to enhance sample fidelity and diversity by incorporating NIR-II spectral optical properties. Quantitative analysis validated that high-quality NIR-II fluorescence signal samples are synthesized, where the proposed NIR-II guidance achieved a 56.7% reduction in Fréchet Inception Distance(FID) and a 21.5% improvement in Inception Score (IS), covering a broad spectrum of patterns. Since the synthetic samples are unlabeled which cannot be used for neural network training, these samples are integrated with the original dataset as augmented samples and train FMT neural networks by semi-supervised learning. By combining pattern-diversifying strengths of diffusion models with semi-supervised learning, the proposed strategy maximizes the utility of limited datasets. Both simulative and in vivo experiments confirmed that data augmentation significantly enhances the network's reconstruction performance in precisely localizing tumor sources and reconstructing complex morphologies. title: Vision-Assisted Chest Wall Localization for Microwave Vital Sign Monitoring
authors: Yingjie Gou, Yuyong Xiong, Wenjie Lin, Sicheng Hong, Zhike Peng
abstract: Microwave-based vital sign monitoring offers non-contact sensing capabilities but face challenges in human target localization, especially in cluttered environments with strong interference from non-human reflections. In this article, we propose a novel vision-assisted method for precise human chest wall localization in microwave vital sign detection. This approach identifies the chest wall region of interest (ROI) using human pose key points detection, aligns visual and microwave domains through a coordinate transformation framework, and employs a robust Chest Wall Peak Extraction (CWPE) algorithm to suppress non-human targets clutter and detect heatmap peaks within ROIs. Experimental results show the method can accurately locate human targets in various scenarios, including single-person, cluttered multi-person, and challenging case with complex spatial arrangement. The max measured respiratory rate and heart rate achieve errors of only 0.48 bpm and 1.64 bpm respectively compared to chest strap references, demonstrating the method’s effectiveness and robustness in positioning and measurement. This integration of vision and microwave sensing advances non-contact monitoring in complex real-world environments.

title: Foot Contact Detection for Motion Capture via Physics-Based Simulation and Temporal Graph Networks
authors: Weichao Yan, Yifan Liu, Hao Ma, Zaiyue Yang
abstract: Foot–ground contact detection is essential for analyzing human motion and supporting balance control in humanoid and wearable robotic systems. This paper proposes a physics-informed framework that integrates motion simulation with graph-based learning to achieve robust contact detection across complex terrains. The method combines physics-based motion synthesis with a Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (TGCN), which models human joints as nodes and bones as edges, capturing both spatial coordination and temporal evolution. To generate diverse and physically consistent training data, we simulate locomotion scenarios using the PyBullet physics engine with Adversarial Motion Priors (AMP). These simulations span flat, inclined, and composite terrains. Real-world motion data are collected using a commercial inertial motion capture suit equipped with 17 IMUs (sampling at 96 Hz) from 13 volunteers performing walking, running, and complex movements. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed TGCN achieves accurate frame-wise contact detection across various terrains and motion types, outperforming sequential baselines such as LSTM. With 1.72 million parameters and a memory below 100 MB, the TGCN model enables real-time inference with less than 10 ms inference time. This scalable and physics-grounded approach provides strong potential for deployment in real-time motion analysis, gait evaluation, and humanoid locomotion control.

title: Transformer Network-based Gait Identification using WiFi
authors: Oliver Custance, Saad Khan, Simon Parkinson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biometrics, Behavior, and Identity Science
abstract: Wireless sensing has become a prominent choice for human activity recognition, valued for its non-intrusive operation and privacy-conscious design. However, it grapples with environmental challenges, especially from static (e.g., furniture) and dynamic objects (e.g., people walking), as well as how demographic factors such as BMI and sensor quantity affect accuracy. This paper addresses these gaps through a focused experiment on gait-based participant identification. Our methods and techniques encompass variance exploration for movement detection, Channel Power Distribution (CPD) analysis, and polynomial fitting to determine walking direction.We present a novel model for gait recognition, using a hybrid architecture that combines convolutional layers, LSTM blocks with residual connections, and multi-head self-attention mechanisms. We conducted a comprehensive evaluation of our gait identification system using two datasets: MultiEnvironment and HWDD. Both consist of data from 10 volunteers. We achieved 96.1% and 96.66% accuracy for MultiEnvironment and HWDD, respectively. To benchmark our system, we selected four state-of-the-art pre-trained models: Transformer, LSTM, CNN and SVM. Finally, we benchmark our technique against a dataset that we collected for 25 individuals, demonstrating an accuracy better than other state-of-the-art techniques of 97.9%.

title: Digital Supplier Quality Chargeback System for A Case Study Automotive Supply Chain Process Automation
authors: Attakan Pratumrat, Tanyaporn Kanignant, Sarayut Nonsiri
abstract: The Supplier Quality Chargeback (SQCB) process has long depended on manual tasks-taking photos, renaming files, entering data, and sending emails-resulting in inefficiency and excessive workload. This study presents an automated SQCB system that integrates these steps into a single digital workflow. Focusing on automation rather than web interfaces, the system eliminates redundant activities and minimizes manual work. A case study at a motorcycle manufacturer demonstrates a 31.23% reduction in processing time (from 134.5 to 92.5 minutes per incident) while significantly reducing administrative burden. The system decreases total manhours from 6.7 to 4.6 hours per day across six staff. The approach enhances real-time visibility, enforces standardized workflows, and optimizes workforce utilization. The results highlight how process automation supports digital lean manufacturing and strengthens efficiency in supplier quality management.

title: Sentiment Analysis on Flipkart Reviews Using Aspect-Level Attention and Fuzzy Logic
authors: S. Sowmyayani, Anitha Rajakumari P, Krishnammal N, S. Maheshwari
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Sentiment analysis has become an important tool in e-commerce for extracting useful information from customer reviews and feedback. This information can be used to track customer satisfaction, detect emerging product issues, personalize recommendations and guide business strategy. This paper presents a hybrid sentiment analysis for Flipkart reviews combining Aspect-level Attention and Fuzzy Inference System (A2FIS). Unlike other classifiers that provide coarse polarity labels, this work extracts fine-grained aspect-based sentiment insights. A Bi-LSTM with attention mechanism is employed to emphasize contextually relevant tokens. Additionally, a Mamdani-style fuzzy inference system is used to refine review ratings and model predictions. Experiments are carried out in the benchmark dataset and evaluated using a few standard metrics. The proposed method achieves 91.8% accuracy and 91.2% F1-score. The contribution of each component is analyzed in detail. The method can be further extended by not only using text but also with emojis, images, etc.

title: Sliding Mode Control of Robotic Manipulators with a Fixed-Time Disturbance Observer
authors: Wenbin Su, Qingcheng Wang, Jiangqiao Wang, Haochen Zhang, Chaorong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: In recent years, robotic manipulators have developed rapidly and achieved results in multiple fields. However, their performance is restricted by uncertain factors, affecting the accuracy and reliability of the system. This paper investigates the trajectory tracking problem of robotic manipulators subject to internal uncertainties and external disturbances, and proposes a novel global fixed-time sliding mode control strategy. First, a fixed-time disturbance observer (FTDO) is adopted to address the adverse effects of model uncertainties and external disturbances in the manipulators system. To enhance the system's robustness, a new non-singular fast terminal sliding mode (NFTSM) surface is designed, which effectively overcomes the singularity problem. Based on the estimated disturbances from the observer, a fixed-time non-singular fast terminal sliding mode controller (FTNFTSMC) is developed to ensure that the trajectory tracking error converges to zero rapidly within a fixed time. Finally, simulation experiments are conducted on a two-link robotic manipulator to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme. A comparison with other existing sliding mode controllers confirms its superior control performance.

title: Fake Job Detection using Statistical and NLP Based Analysis
authors: Alan Joji Veliyath, Ambar Ahmad, Ashish Binoy Abraham, Sree Hema Hasmita Kancharla, Chandrashekhar Pomu Chavan
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: Detecting fraudulent job postings is a critical challenge for online recruitment platforms. This study integrates statistical analysis and natural language processing (NLP) to enhance detection accuracy. Structured features such as company reputation, job titles, and salary ranges are analyzed using machine learning models, including Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), XGBoost, and Naïve Bayes. To address data imbalance, the Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique (SMOTE) is applied, ensuring model reliability. Additionally, NLP-based detection leverages linguistic features such as word usage, sentence structure, and tone to identify deceptive job postings. For this task, KNN, Logistic Regression, and SVM are employed, demonstrating strong classification performance. This hybrid approach significantly improves fraudulent job detection, offering a robust and scalable solution for real-world applications.

title: Seeing Beyond the Airways: Asthma Prediction via Cross-Attention on Dual Retinal Modalities
authors: Umar Farooq, Matt Trinh, Angelica Ly, Asif Ameer, Imran Razzak, Sonit Singh
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Asthma's systemic effects and chronic underdiagnosis trigger avoidable exacerbations and a heavy healthcare burden. Effort-dependent spirometry and specialist-only tests block population-scale screening. We propose a cross-modal attention framework for non-invasive asthma classification from dual retinal modalities, colour fundus photographs (CFP; Type 1: posterior pole view; Type 2: optic nerve head view) and optical coherence tomography (OCT) measurements, where systemic changes manifest in retinal structure and vasculature. Fundus images are encoded by a CNN backbone followed by multi-head self-attention (MHSA); OCT metrics are embedded by a lightweight feed-forward encoder; cross-modal attention (CMA) then fuses the two streams to capture intermodal dependencies. Trained and evaluated on a novel dual-modality dataset curated at UNSW Centre for Eye Health (CFEH), the model achieves an AUC of 0.97 and offers improved interpretability via attention-weight visualisations. These results support retinal biomarkers as a scalable pathway for early asthma detection and open a window to population-level oculomic screening for other systemic diseases (e.g., neurodegenerative and cardiovascular diseases), highlighting the promise of CMA for ocular imaging.

title: A Diffusion Model for Virtual Try-On Systems
authors: Yuchao Zhang, Kien Tran, Minh Nguyen, Wei Qi Yan
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: We present a modular virtual try-on (VTON) system that integrates natural language control, efficient diffusion-based image synthesis, and lightweight garment classification. User intent is parsed by a large language model (LLM) into structured visual prompts. A LoRA-tuned diffusion model generates tryon images conditioned on pose and segmentation maps, while a compact classifier, LightClothNet, handles five-category clothing recognition and pre-filtering. The pipeline is built using ComfyUI nodes and orchestrated via Dify. Compared to the existing methods, the proposed system offers improved realism, garment-pose alignment, and controllability. Our evaluations on the DressCode and VITON-HD datasets show that LoRA fine-tuning enhances fidelity under limited data, while LightClothNet achieves up to 91.76% precision and 0.91 F1-score with low latency. This result demonstrates how multimodal control, lightweight classification, and diffusion generation are unified for fast, flexible, and userdriven VTON applications.

title: FPGA-Based Implementation of sEMG Feature Extraction and Movement Classification with MLP
authors: Rubén Nieto, Silvia Iniesta, Santiago Murano, Pedro Rafael Fernández, Susana Borromeo
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: Determining movement intention in patients with partial spinal cord injury or stroke remains challenging, requiring efficient frameworks to decode muscle activity for assistive and rehabilitation technologies. Surface electromyography (sEMG) provides a non-invasive way to monitor muscle activation, but its analysis is affected by noise and the complexity of extracting discriminative features for robust classification. This work proposes a complete pipeline for sEMG feature extraction and lower-limb movement classification using a multilayer perceptron (MLP) implemented on an FPGA-based System-on-Chip (SoC). sEMG signals from eight muscles were processed to distinguish sitting, standing up, remaining still, and walking. Four computationally efficient time-domain features-Average Power (AP), Mean Absolute Value (MAV), Integrated sEMG (IEMG), and Simple Squared Integration (SSI)-were extracted and fed into the network. The system achieved 92.5% accuracy and sub-millisecond inference latency, demonstrating a practical trade-off between accuracy, latency, and hardware efficiency. Unlike most state-of-the-art approaches that rely on offline GPU processing, our design enables real-time operation on a compact, low-power SoC platform. These results confirm the feasibility of deploying machine learning models for portable rehabilitation devices, paving the way for intelligent, resource-efficient human-machine interfaces in clinical environments.

title: A Programmable, Negative, and Dynamically Biased Sampler for Ultra-Low Power Body-Bias Generators in 18nm FD-SOI
authors: Tom Bergmann, Joel Damiens, Alfonso Hildebrand Rueda, Stephane Lacouture, Remy Cellier, Nacer Abouchi
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for Ultra-Low Power (ULP) circuits increased, making power management circuits a critical need. In this context, Fully Depleted Silicon on Insulator (FD-SOI) technology is indicated thanks to an enhanced body biasing possibility's. An Adaptive Body-Biasing (ABB) circuit is therefore needed and must meet the ULP constraints. To address this challenge, a programmable negative sampling solution optimized for ABB circuit in 18 nm FD-SOI technology is proposed. The sampling rate ranges from 10 kHz to 100 MHz and introduces specific design techniques to enhance power consumption and area efficiency. The circuit is composed of a modified 6-bit binaryweighted Capacitive Digital to Analog Converter (CDAC) coupled with a dynamic comparator. This solution exhibits only dynamic power consumption, making it a suitable solution for frequency regulation of the ABB circuit. This implementation can achieve a power reduction up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 460$</tex> at 10 kHz and a silicon area reduction by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x 7.5$</tex> compared to a previously implemented design that relies on statically biased functions in the same technology.

title: Robust SOSM Based Current Sensorless Control Design for Buck Converters with Disturbances
authors: Zhongding Zhang, Weile Chen, Zuo Wang, Shihua Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: In this article, a robust current sensorless control approach via second-order sliding mode (SOSM) is proposed for disturbed DC–DC buck converters. In converter systems, conventional current sensors lack reliable measurements and the demands for high-precision sensors lead to increased circuit costs. In such scenarios, current states are often reconstructed by state observers to ensure tracking performance. However, general state observers are incapable of independently estimating the internal system states when coupled with mismatched terms and disturbances. It indicates that the observer design cannot be separated from the controller. To this end, this paper aims to develop a SOSM synthesis controller based on the "non-separation principle". The current sensorless finite-time SOSM control scheme demonstrates attractive properties in faster convergent speed, higher control accuracy, and strong robustness against multiple disturbances. The rigorous global finite-time stability of the closed-loop system is given based on Lyapunov design approach. Simulation results verify the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed control approach.

title: Research on Key Technologies for Return Capsule Landing Search and Navigation Positioning
authors: Guanyu Chen, Zhongwang Wu, Zhen Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: The Beidou-3 Global Navigation Satellite System has been fully established and is widely applied across various fields such as the economy and power sector. According to publicly available information, GPS beacon positioning technology remains the primary method internationally. Therefore, this paper focuses on leveraging the advantages of the BeiDou-3 system to optimize GPS beacon positioning using BeiDou beacon positioning technology in the context of manned landing return capsule search and rescue recovery scenarios. It conducts a detailed study of the entire search and rescue recovery process, the ballistic characteristics of manned return capsules, and establishes a MATLAB experimental environment for simulation to verify the feasibility of applying BeiDou-3 beacon positioning technology in challenging search and rescue recovery scenarios involving manned landing return capsules.

title: Automated Glaucoma Classification in Fundus Images Using Multi-Backbone Feature Fusion
authors: Juhee Han, Soo Min Oh, Hee Jo, Bengie L. Ortiz, Yifan Li, Jo Woon Chong
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Glaucoma is one of the leading causes of irreversible blindness worldwide, underscoring the need for accurate and accessible diagnostic solutions. In this study, we propose a scalable glaucoma classification pipeline that leverages deep features extracted from sensor-acquired retinal fundus images using pretrained architectures-Swin Transformer V2, ConvNeXt V2, and EfficientNet V2. These models are employed as fixed feature extractors, and the concatenated representations are subsequently used to train and evaluate classical classifiers, including Random Forest, Multilayer Perceptron, and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Among these approaches, the SVM achieved the most balanced performance, which was further improved through hyperparameter optimization. Experiments conducted on the public RIM-ONE DL dataset demonstrated that the optimized SVM attained an accuracy of 0.957, an F1-score of 0.938, and an AUC-ROC of 0.978. These results highlight the effectiveness of integrating transformer-based and CNN-based deep representations with conventional machine learning models, offering a practical and resource-efficient framework for automated glaucoma classification.

title: Coordinated Operation of Integrated Power, Natural Gas, and Hydrogen Systems with Detailed Modeling of Electrolyzers
authors: Yingyin Gong, Sheng Chen, Zhinong Wei, Manyun Huang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The integrated energy systems (IESs), composed of electricity, gas, and hydrogen, effectively enhances renewable energy consumption, enabling efficient energy utilization and supporting sustainable development. This paper investigates the optimal operation of electricity-gas-hydrogen integrated energy systems. First, A comprehensive model is developed, including DC power flow, steady-state gas flow, detailed power-to-hydrogen conversion, and hydrogen blending based on energy balance. Then, a day-ahead dispatch model is formulated to minimize total operating cost under electricity and gas system constraints. Finally, simulation results validate the model’s effectiveness, revealing the coupling characteristics between the electric and gas networks considering hydrogen integration.

title: Phishing Email Classification Using Few-Shot Learning with a Lightweight LLM (Llama 3.2)
authors: La Min Ei, Karn Yongsiriwit
abstract: Phishing attacks are a major threat to cybersecurity. They use fake emails to get people to give up private information. This study shows a model for classifying phishing emails that is based on LLaMA 3.2, a lightweight large language model (LLM), and few-shot learning to make it better. By converting email content into semantic embeddings, the model distinguishes phishing from safe emails with minimal labeled data. Our model gets 99% accuracy and a 99.01 % F2-score using a Kaggle dataset with 1,000 phishing and 1,000 safe emails. This is a lot better than a zero-shot baseline. The model was fine-tuned using Ollama's Modelfile and evaluated for robustness, showing that it can adapt to new phishing tactics.

title: Noise Suppression in ECG Signals Based on Izhikevich’s Spiking Neuron
authors: Gonzalo Sebastián Torres-Chávez, Luis Alberto Vallejo-Mora, Jorge Alejandro Juárez-Lora, Herón Molina-Lozano
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: In recent years, neural networks have been widely used for signal classification through spatial frequency filtering in EEG signals. Gao et al. in 2021 or Tan, Wang, and Wang in 2022 proposed an approach that combines multichannel complex spectral mapping with deep neural networks, achieving significant improvement in interference suppression and signal quality preservation. Their study demonstrates the ability of neural networks to adapt to different environments and their computational efficiency compared to other methods. We propose exploring the possibility of using a spiking neural network (SNN) for noise suppression in EEG signals. Neurons based on the Izhikevich model were employed due to their biological similarity and computational efficiency (Izhikevich, 2004). Additionally, the use of PopSan encoding, the network architecture, and the RSTDP method with reinforcement learning were analyzed. Finally, its decoding through a system of two second-order differential equations based on the Maxwell-Kelvin-Voigt model was analyzed.

title: Automatic Classification of Driving Maneuvers via Supervised Learning
authors: Isay Zamora, Ilse Cervantes, Amadeo Argüelles, Marco A. Hernandez-Nochebuena, Mauricio Cruz-Acevedo
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This study presents a supervised learning approach for the automatic classification of driving maneuvers using only vehicular dynamics data collected through a Racelogic VBOX 3i logger at 100 Hz. The methodology involved (1) spatial segmentation of a test track via GPS to label five maneuver types—curve with banking, curve without banking, straight line, roundabout, and slalom; (2) training classical (Random Forest, KNN, MLP) and sequential (RNN, LSTM) models; and (3) comparative performance evaluation. Among all tested algorithms, the bidirectional LSTM achieved the highest average F1-score of 95.9%, outperforming the best classical model (MLP) by more than 1.5 percentage points. The classification of roundabout maneuvers reached an F1-score of 95.5%, while slalom was the most challenging with 94.8%. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of temporal modeling in maneuver classification and support its application in intelligent driving assistance, usage-based insurance, and behavioral profiling—without requiring multimodal sensor fusion.

title: Generating Software Architecture Description from Source Code using Reverse Engineering and Large Language Model
authors: Ahmad Hatahet, Christoph Knieke, Andreas Rausch
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Software Architecture Descriptions (SADs) are indispensable for navigating the complexity of modern software systems. They enable high-level reasoning, guide design decisions, and facilitate communication among diverse stakeholders. Yet in practice, SADs are frequently missing, outdated, or poorly aligned with the system’s actual implementation. As a result, developers are forced to derive architectural insights directly from source code—a time-intensive task that increases mental effort, slows onboarding, and contributes to the gradual degradation of architectural clarity over a system’s lifetime. To address these challenges, we propose an automated generation of SADs from source code by combining reverse engineering (RE) techniques with Large Language Model (LLM). Our approach recovers both static and behavioral views by extracting a comprehensive component diagram, filters architecturally significant elements—core components—via prompt-guided LLM analysis, and generates state machine diagrams to model component behavior based on code logic. This dual-view representation offers a scalable and maintainable alternative to manual architectural documentation. This approach, demonstrated with C++ examples, showcases the potent capability of LLMs to: 1) find abstract component diagram, lowering the reliance on human expert involvement, and 2) represent complex software behaviors, especially when enriched with domain-specific knowledge through few-shot prompting. These findings suggest a viable path toward reducing manual effort while enhancing system understanding and long-term maintainability.

title: Short Term Load Forecasting Based on BP Network Model
authors: Huafeng Su, Zhiqi Li, Junhui Li, Jinping Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: With the development and wide application of new energy technology, the complexity and uncertainty of the load on the power side of the power system have increased, which has brought great challenges to the power dispatching. In view of the difficulty and low accuracy of short-term load forecasting, this paper proposes a short-term load forecasting method based on BP network model. By analyzing the historical load data, the multi-dimensional input feature set is constructed, and the dynamic relationship model between load and influencing factors is established by using the adaptive learning ability and nonlinear mapping characteristics of BP network. The experimental results show that, compared with the traditional time series method and support vector machine model, the proposed BP network model reduces the mean square error (MSE) and average absolute percentage error (MAPE) by about 15% and 12%, respectively, which verifies the effectiveness and robustness of the method in complex load fluctuation scenarios, and provides reliable technical support for the refined dispatching of power grid. Specifically, in high proportion wind and photovoltaic integration scenarios, this model exhibits stronger adaptability to load fluctuations caused by intermittent new energy sources, effectively assisting dispatchers in developing rolling scheduling plans and reducing wind and solar curtailment rates.

title: Thermal Simulation and Analysis of The Small Unmanned Aerial Vehicle in The Launch Tube
authors: Mayi Guo, Zhipeng Meng, Xiaoqing Chen, Bo Wang, Dejian Li
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Miniaturization is an important trend in the development of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). However, the dense arrangement of electronic devices in small UAVs also brings difficulties in heat dissipation. Especially when the UAV needs to conduct self-checks or be preset within the launch tube, the more demanding conditions create new challenges for heat dissipation. This paper performed a thermal simulation of the small UAV within the launch tube and analyzed the influence of environmental temperature, solar irradiation, and airflow on the temperature of electronic devices. This research can provide a reference for the heat dissipation design of small UAVs within the launch tube.

title: A RA-based Deep Neural Network for Predicting Fretting Fatigue Life
authors: Tianxiang Wang, Qiyuan Chen, Chaojie Zhang, Junwei Yan
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Fretting fatigue is one of the most significant causes of aero engine failure. Accurately predicting fretting fatigue life is of paramount importance for ensuring the safety of aero engine. However, existing fretting fatigue life prediction methods suffer from insufficient accuracy and poor generalization ability. To address these problems, a deep learning neural network based fretting fatigue life prediction method is proposed, taking into account cracks, wear and their interactions, which is called RADNN. The experimental results show the 92% of the prediction results of the RA-DNN given by this work are distributed within the $1.5 \times$ limit band, and all the prediction results are within the $2 \times$ limit band, which meets the engineering requirements and surpasses previous works. It is demonstrated that the proposed network RA-DNN can serve as an effective option to realize aero engine fretting fatigue life prediction.

title: Predefined-Time Hierarchical Cooperative Control for SOC Balancing of Multiple Energy Storage Units in DC Microgrids
authors: Jipeng Gu, Guohui Deng, Jianxiao Wang, Weijie Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper addresses the state of charge (SOC) imbalance problem among multiple parallel-connected energy storage units (ESUs) in DC microgrids, which arises from inherent battery discrepancies. To overcome the limitations of existing distributed consensus algorithms, a novel hierarchical control strategy is proposed. Conventional methods suffer from slow convergence speed, particularly as the number of ESUs increases or under sparse network topologies, which severely compromises control accuracy and system stability. To this end, the proposed strategy employs a dual-layer control architecture. The lower layer utilizes conventional droop control to achieve autonomous, communication-less load sharing, thereby ensuring fundamental system robustness and plug-and-play capability. The upper layer innovatively introduces a predefined-time consensus algorithm. Through the synergistic design of a time-varying gain function and an acceleration factor, this layer significantly enhances the speed and accuracy of current and SOC balancing among the ESUs. The correctness and effectiveness of the proposed hierarchical coordinated control method are validated through simulations in Matlab/Simulink.

title: Multi-Fusion Ensemble CNN for Drug–Target Binding Affinity Prediction Using Transformer-Based Molecular and Protein Representations
authors: Betsabeh Tanoori
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Accurate prediction of drug–target binding affinity (DTA) is essential in computational drug discovery, yet many deep learning models exhibit limited generalization to unseen drug–target pairs. To address this, we propose a novel Multi-Fusion Ensemble Convolutional Neural Network (MF-CNN) framework that leverages transformer-based embeddings—ChemBERTa for drug molecules and ProtBERT for protein sequences. These high-level representations are integrated using five complementary fusion strategies, each generating independent affinity predictions to capture diverse interaction perspectives. A final adaptive combination module aggregates these outputs to exploit their complementary strengths. We evaluated MF-CNN on both the widely used Davis dataset and the KIBA benchmark. Ablation studies confirm the contribution of each fusion strategy and the ensemble module. These results showcase the potential of multi-fusion ensemble architectures in advancing reliable and generalizable DTA prediction.

title: Simulating Human Visual Cortex and Recall System with Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Sina Saadati, Abdolah Sepahvand
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Artificial neural networks (ANNs) are mathematical representations inspired by biological neurons, the foundational units of the human and animal brain. While ANNs are extensively applied in tasks such as image processing, classification, semantic segmentation, localization, and image generation, they also offer potential for simulating psychological and cognitive processes. In this research, we examine whether convolutional neural networks (CNNs), commonly used in image processing tasks, can mimic the visual recall mechanism of the brain. A deep CNN was trained to associate a series of input images with a specific output image, referred to as the “memory image.” After training, we fed the network new input images and observed the generated outputs. In repeated trials, the CNN consistently produced images that were visually similar to the last memory image. These results suggest that CNNs may offer a viable model for exploring how the brain recalls and reconstructs recent visual memories. Consequently, the artificial neural networks have the potential to simulate psychological behaviors caused by the brain.

title: Leveraging Uncertainty Estimates for Improving RUL Prognosis of Lithium-ion Batteries
authors: Ting Tang, Quan Xia, Yi Ren, Dongming Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium - Europe (RAMS-Europe)
abstract: Accurately predicting the remaining useful life (RUL) of lithium-ion batteries is crucial for their reliability and safety. Conventional methods rely on mean regression models, which fail to capture variability and quantify uncertainty. While some methods express uncertainty when predicting RUL, they have not been effectively leveraged to improve prediction accuracy and enhance model robustness. To meet this gap, this paper proposes a two-stage model combining convolutional neural networks (CNN), gated recurrent units (GRU), multi-head attention mechanisms (MHAM), and deep neural networks (DNN) for integrating uncertainty information. Firstly, the health indicator (HI) representing capacity degradation is extracted. HI and capacity are then fed into the 1st-DNN to produce the mean and uncertainty of capacity. Next, these outputs, along with HI, are processed by CNN and GRU to extract shape and time-dependent features, respectively. The extracted features capture the complex dependencies between the three by MHAM, while focusing on the diversity of input sequence from different perspectives, forming a multivariate feature representation. Finally, the obtained multivariate feature representation is input into the 2nd-DNN to obtain the RUL prediction results, including the prediction mean and uncertainty. The model’s feasibility is validated on NASA and Oxford battery datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that it not only outperforms traditional models, but also significantly enhances prediction reliability.

title: Voltage and Frequency Regulation of Parallel Inverters via Consensus-Based Secondary Control in AHO-VOC Microgrids
authors: Zihao Li, Lamei Xu, Wenchao Zhu, Changjun Xie
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: To mitigate issues such as frequency drift, voltage inconsistency, and power-sharing inaccuracies that arise in multi-inverter islanded microgrids due to impedance mismatches and load fluctuations, this study reformulates the power-loop dynamics of the Andronov–Hopf virtual oscillator control (AHO-VOC) into a droop-equivalent structure. This simplification retains the essential grid-forming characteristics while streamlining the controller design process. Consensus-based distributed secondary controllers are implemented in both the frequency–active power and voltage–reactive power loops, allowing each inverter to share local state information via a sparse communication network and collaboratively correct voltage and frequency deviations in real time. To validate the proposed strategy, a simulation model comprising four parallel inverters is constructed in MATLAB/Simulink and benchmarked against conventional AHO-VOC control. The results indicate notable enhancements in dynamic performance and power-sharing precision, supporting the practical deployment of coordinated virtual oscillator–based microgrid control.

title: Research on Long-Term Prediction Methods for Solar Irradiance Based on Multidimensional Decomposition and Deep Learning
authors: Quanliang Zhou, Tiejun Zhang, Shuanghe Liu, Jiajun Xu, Yue Mi, Junyong Zhao, Liang Ma, Liyan Li, Ruhui Song
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: In the context of the “dual carbon” goals and the rapid development of photovoltaic insurance, precise long-term predictions of global solar irradiance (GHI) have become a core requirement for power plant risk assessment and insurance product pricing. The paper proposes a GHI long-term prediction method tailored for insurance applications, combining STL-EMD-VMD multi-dimensional decomposition with SARIMA+LSTM-Attention. This is in response to the challenges of single models struggling to account for multiple temporal patterns and prone to overfitting. Firstly, STL is utilised to decompose GHI data from photovoltaic power plants into seasonal, trend, and residual components. Secondly, based on the Hurst index, frequency, and sample entropy of each component, the trend component undergoes improved EMD (Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition) decomposition, while the residual component undergoes VMD (Variable Mode Decomposition) decomposition based on whale optimization, achieving a secondary fine decomposition. Finally, the SARIMA+LSTM-Attention model is applied to jointly forecast different sub-components, and the results are automatically optimized and integrated using multiple metrics such as MSE, MAE, MAPE, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}}$</tex>. Experimental findings demonstrate that, in comparison with the absence of decomposition, single decomposition, and single models, the proposed algorithm reduces mean squared error (MSE) to 0.0991, mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) to 4.74 %, and increases <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> to 96.23 %. The research findings can provide reliable theoretical support for insurance companies in developing photovoltaic power generation index insurance.

title: FinTNet: From Tweets to Trades
authors: Dorsa Tavakoli, Saman Haratizadeh
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Recent research indicates a correlation between textual information, media sources, and stock price movements. Additionally, studies have highlighted the influence of inter-stock relationships on their respective behaviors. In this study, FinTNet is introduced as a novel graph neural network model that integrates financial text data, price information, and stock relationships for enhanced stock price prediction. Three text-based graphs, derived from Twitter text analysis and the exploration of stock relationships, are presented for prediction using a semi-supervised graph convolutional model. The predictive model concurrently incorporates textual data, stock prices, and indicators. For in-depth tweet content analysis, Large Language Models (LLMs), including Financial Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (FinBERT) and Gemini Pro, are employed. FinBERT transforms tweets into embedding vectors, yielding a dataset of approximately three million tweets with vectors of size 768. Additionally, about 85,000 are getting four different labels (trend direction, discussed time, amount of change in price, and sentiment), using the Gemini Pro model, forming an accessible labeled dataset. Experiments demonstrate that FinTNet achieves superior accuracy compared to baseline models by leveraging LLM-extracted textual features within carefully designed graph structures.

title: User Perceptions of Code and Model Generation with Simulink in Industrial Settings - A Survey
authors: Johan Cederbladh, Jakob Norin
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Model-Based Development (MBD) has become an expectation in several industries to support testing & verification during system design. Specifically, MBD reduces the need for physical resources and promotes re-usable digital development frameworks. At the same time, there are still several challenges that exist with using (primarily graphical) MBD tools in industrial settings which are hindering a mature integration for collaboration in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs) design and development. In this paper we provide an experience report about using Simulink for code generation & automated testing in industrial settings and discuss the implications for wider model-based adoption. The paper also supports these experiences through results from an internal survey at a company with 23 participants in relation to user experiences of using Simulink. The survey findings highlight concerns in collaboration, particularly from a software engineering perspective.

title: Optimal Dispatch of Distribution Networks Considering Battery Swapping Cabinets Based on a Stackelberg Game
authors: YuJie Li, Qi Qi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: The widespread deployment of electric scooter battery swapping cabinets (BSCs) offers significant dispatchable potential for distribution networks (DNs). To better leverage this potential, this paper proposes an optimal DN dispatch method incorporating BSCs participation using a Stackelberg game framework. First, the dispatch capability of BSCs is analyzed considering battery swapping demand. Then, a Stackelberg gamebased model is developed to coordinate interactions between the DN and BSCs. Finally, multi-scenario simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Automatic Verification of Grid-Related Protection Configuration for Generators in Heilongjiang Power Grid Based on Time-Domain Simulation
authors: Xinghua Mu, Jiazheng Xie, Wanlin Guan, Sanen Du, Jiapeng Cui, Guoyang Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: In the Heilongjiang Power Grid, certain power plants exhibit incomplete and suboptimal configurations in their gridrelated protection systems, lacking proper coordination with the grid infrastructure, which poses significant threats to system security. To address these issues, this study proposes an automatic verification method for generator grid-related protection settings based on time-domain simulation. This approach adapts to diverse grid operating conditions, conducts batch time-domain simulations for multiple fault scenarios, evaluates the impact of protection settings on grid stability, identifies operational risks, and facilitates timely configuration adjustments. Simulation results using actual operational data demonstrate that the proposed method can accurately simulate cascading dynamic processes following system faults, effectively harness power source regulation capabilities, and substantially enhance resilience against contingencies in the Heilongjiang Power Grid.

title: Collaborative LLM Reasoning for Vulnerability Detection in Smart Contracts
authors: Amirreza Samari, Parsa Hedayatnia, Seyyed Javad Bozorgzadeh Razavi, Mohammad Allahbakhsh, Haleh Amintoosi
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Smart contracts play a pivotal role in decentralized applications but are subject to security vulnerabilities often difficult to detect. Traditional static and symbolic analysis tools cannot handle intricate logic and are limited in adaptability and explainability. Recent development of large language models (LLMs) provide new opportunities for vulnerability detection, but single-model methods often suffer from inconsistency and prompt sensitivity. This paper introduces a collaborative LLM-based model that enhances detection robustness through semantic similarity-based few-shot prompting and multi-LLM reasoning. Our model integrates diverse LLMs (ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok) as worker nodes, along with an aggregator model to resolve disagreements via justification analysis and final prediction consolidation. Experimental evaluations on the SmartBugs benchmark demonstrated a remarkable enhancement in detection accuracy (96.25%) and response time compared to other models. The proposed model provides a scalable and explainable solution for smart contract auditing, illustrating the strength of LLM collaboration in security-critical applications.

title: Improved Deadbeat Predictive Current Control of PMSM Based on Disturbance-Estimated Parameter Identification
authors: Fan Yang, Hua Cai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Deadbeat Predictive Current Control (DPCC) is widely used in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs) due to its excellent tracking performance and low computational burden. However, its performance is sensitive to the accuracy of motor parameters, and parameter mismatches can significantly degrade control effectiveness. To enhance the parameter robustness of DPCC, an improved DPCC method based on disturbance-observer-based parameter identification is proposed. First, the impact of parameter mismatch on the control performance of conventional DPCC is analyzed. Then, an Extended State Observer (ESO) is introduced to compensate for the one-step prediction delay, enabling simultaneous prediction of the current and observation of the total disturbance. Based on the disturbance estimated by the ESO, a method is developed to compute the inductance and flux linkage errors, which are then used to update the model parameters of both the DPCC and ESO in real time. The proposed method requires minimal control parameter tuning and can accommodate a wide range of parameters mismatches. Finally, a simulation platform is developed to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Comparative simulations with conventional DPCC and ESO-based DPCC demonstrate that the proposed method effectively suppresses the adverse effects of parameter mismatches and significantly improves the robustness of motor control.

title: Social Media Post Categorization and Engagement: Insights from a Japanese Car Brand on Twitter
authors: Mathupayas Thongmak, Anuwat Chaiwongyen, Nuchjarin Intalar
abstract: This study investigates how different types of social media posts influence user engagement (likes and retweets) on Twitter, drawing on a content categorization framework from prior research. The dataset consists of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{3, 1 7 4}$</tex> firm-generated tweets from Toyota, collected through the Vicinitas analysis tool. After excluding replies, retweets, and non-English posts, 2,555 tweets were organized into 12 categories and examined for recurring themes with the assistance of ChatGPT. Hierarchical regression analysis revealed both control factors and specific post types that significantly affect engagement, while word cloud visualizations offered further insights into categories with positive effects. Findings suggest that Toyota could refine its content strategies, as posts emphasizing brand resonance, functionality, emotional appeal, and experiential aspects were associated with higher engagement. The research supports the relevance of applying content categorization models to an automotive brand's Twitter activity. Nevertheless, its scope is limited to a single company within one industry and one platform, highlighting the need for future studies to consider multiple brands and alternative social media channels. Moreover, little prior work has evaluated the influence of emerging post categories on engagement, and this framework has not been extensively tested on Twitter.

title: Research on Energy Management Strategy of Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle Based on Improved Double Delay Depth Deterministic Strategy Gradient
authors: Wei Wang, Zekun Jia, Fufan Qu, Yiwen Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Aiming at the optimal control of power source energy for fuel cell vehicles, this paper focuses on the development of intelligent energy management strategy for fuel cell vehicles, and builds an energy management algorithm (TD3+BC) model with double delay depth and deterministic strategy gradient, which takes the hydrogen consumption of fuel cells and the change of state of charge (SOC) of batteries as the optimization objectives. Taking vehicle speed, acceleration, SOC and fuel cell power at the last moment as state variables, selecting fuel cell system power as the action quantity of the algorithm, setting reward functions in different SOC ranges, simulating and training the agent under combined standard working conditions, and optimizing the configuration parameters. The simulation results show that compared with DDPG algorithm, TD3+BC algorithm converges faster, the output of selected action is more stable, the estimation of action value is more accurate, and the energy consumption is reduced. TD3+BC algorithm can consider the action value in the future time domain to a certain extent, the trajectory of vehicle SOC is more flexible, and the energy efficiency of power battery is higher. Under the combined working condition and random working condition, compared with DDPG algorithm, TD3+BC algorithm has the best economic performance, which is promoted by 1.15％ and 0.92% respectively.

title: The Academic Community's Influence on Global Cybersecurity
authors: Vedran Mihalj, Mario Tomiša, Tomislav Volarić
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive overview of the academic community's profound and multifaceted impact on cybersecurity. It explores the dual role of academia, both as a critical source of cybersecurity innovation and talent and as a vulnerable target for cyber threats. The paper examines key contributions from universities and research institutions, including the development of foundational security protocols, the cultivation of a skilled cybersecurity workforce, and the influence on public policy and government regulation. Furthermore, it addresses the challenges and unique vulnerabilities faced by academic networks, such as open access cultures, legacy systems, and the tension between academic freedom and stringent security measures. By analyzing modern examples from the last five years, this paper demonstrates how the symbiotic relationship between the academic community and the cybersecurity landscape is shaping the future of digital defense and resilience.
