title: Practical Framework for Privacy-Preserving and Byzantine-robust Federated Learning_supp1-3642546.pdf
authors: Tong Li
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) allows multiple clients to collaboratively train a model without sharing their private data. However, FL is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks, where adversaries manipulate client models to compromise the federated model, and privacy inference attacks, where adversaries exploit client models to infer private data. Existing defenses against both backdoor and privacy inference attacks introduce significant computational and communication overhead, creating a gap between theory and practice. To address this, we propose ABBR, a practical framework for Byzantine-robust and privacy-preserving FL. We are the first to utilize dimensionality reduction to speed up the private computation of complex filtering rules in privacy-preserving FL. Additionally, we analyze the accuracy loss of vector-wise filtering in low-dimensional space and introduce an adaptive tuning strategy to minimize the impact of malicious models that bypass filtering on the global model. We implement ABBR with state-of-the-art Byzantine-robust aggregation rules and evaluate it on public datasets, showing that it runs significantly faster, has minimal communication overhead, and maintains nearly the same Byzantine-resilience as the baselines.

title: Exploring Waste-to-Energy Solutions for Sustainable Waste Management and Environmental Impact Reduction: The Case of Yangon, Myanmar
authors: Aung Ko Ko Hset, Min Thu Soe, Aung Zaya Myo, Nann Myint Myat Aye, Khin Yadanar Oo, Chan Myae Khin
abstract: As Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, continues to urbanize rapidly, the generation of municipal solid waste (MSW) is increasing at an alarming rate. The city’s uncontrolled waste dumping and improper disposal methods, particularly at poorly managed sites such as the Htain-Bin Waste Dump, pose severe health and environmental challenges. These sites release significant amounts of greenhouse gases and leachate, exacerbating the situation. This research explores Waste-to-Energy (WTE) technologies as a viable solution to address both waste management and energy shortages in Myanmar. The study evaluates various WTE conversion options, including incineration, biogas recovery, and others, to assess their potential in reducing the environmental impact of waste disposal. By examining the WTE policies and practices of other developing countries, the research identifies strategies that could be effectively adapted to Myanmar’s context. The findings highlight that, with proper implementation, WTE projects can significantly reduce reliance on landfills, decrease carbon emissions, and mitigate excessive methane production, offering a sustainable and environmentally friendly solution to the challenges posed by waste management in Yangon.

title: An Attention-Based Deep Learning Model for Multi-Horizon Prediction of Load, Price, and Wind Power Generation in Smart Grids
authors: S. Mozhgan Rahmatinia, Seyed-Amin Hosseini-Seno
abstract: Accurate forecasting of critical parameters in power grids, such as electricity load, price, and renewable energy production, plays a pivotal role in implementing demand response strategies and maintaining grid stability within smart grid systems. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach based on an encoder-decoder architecture with an attention mechanism to simultaneously predict these essential parameters. To enhance the model's ability to capture complex patterns and long-term dependencies in time series data, we incorporate a preprocessing step using the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), which transforms the data into the frequency domain. This transformation aids in reducing noise and extracting latent patterns, thereby improving the model's predictive performance. The proposed model is evaluated on real-world electricity consumption datasets from multiple regions, including Austria, Italy, Sweden, and the UK. It is compared against several state-of-the-art time series forecasting models, such as LSTM, CNN-LSTM, LSTM-Attention, and a basic encoder-decoder structure. The results demonstrate that our approach achieves significantly higher accuracy in most cases, particularly for short- to medium-term predictions (12 to 48 hours ahead). Additionally, visualizations of the predictions reveal that the proposed method closely follows the actual trends, confirming its effectiveness in capturing both short-term fluctuations and long-term dependencies. This study contributes to the field by introducing a flexible and robust framework that integrates attention mechanisms and frequency-domain preprocessing to improve time series forecasting in the electricity domain. The proposed approach not only enhances prediction accuracy but also provides valuable insights into the underlying patterns of electricity consumption and production, making it a promising tool for smart grid applications. The source code and implementation details of the proposed model are publicly available on GitHub <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.

title: Design and Performance Evaluation of Electrically Doped Tunnel FETs with $S i_{(1-x)} G e_{x}$ Source for Improved ON Current
authors: Chitrakant Sahu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Herein, we propose a new architecture for tunnel field effect transistor (TFET) where source and drain regions are formed by a mechanism of electrical doping, with boosted ON current <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(I_{O N})$</tex> employing a low energy bandgap compound binary material (SiGe) in the source region. The heterojunction formed at the source-channel interface aids tunneling by improving charge carrier tunneling efficiency. The properties of SiGe, including low energy bandgap <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E_{g}$</tex> and high mobility <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mu)$</tex>, improve the tunneling rate depending on the mole fraction <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{x})$</tex> of germanium in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S i_{(1-x)} G e_{(x)}$</tex>. Polarity gates (PG) and control gates (CG) provide electrostatic control over charge concentration variation over the entire semiconductor film. The appropriate potential at polarity gates creates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N^{+}$</tex> drain and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P^{+}$</tex> source regions in the low-doped semiconductors. The device performance has been observed for a mole fraction 0.5, which tunes the energy bandgap to 0.85 eV. The 2D Atlas simulations analyze and compare the proposed device with similar conventionally doped TFET for DC and analog performance metrics. A drain current of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$27 \mu ~\mathrm{A} / \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> is obtained in the proposed device, three times more than conventionally doped TFET for similar device dimensions with a significant reduction in OFF current <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(I_{O F F})$</tex>. The improvement in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(I_{O N}\right) /\left(I_{O F F}\right)$</tex> current ratio improves subthreshold swing to 15 mV/dec. Due to increased transconductance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(g_{m}\right)$</tex>, the proposed device's cut-off frequency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(f_{T})$</tex> of 16.2 GHz is observed.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Driven Enhancement of Classification and management the quality of Service in Satellite Communications
authors: Wahiba Belgacem, Youcef Benabdellah
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: Modern satellite communication (SATCOM) systems require intelligent strategies to ensure high Quality of Service (QoS) and efficient resource utilization. Key challenges include accurate channel state classification and dynamic optimization of Forward Error Correction (FEC) and Adaptive Coding and Modulation (ACM) under varying signal conditions. This paper proposes an AI-based approach using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for real-time channel state prediction and adaptive FEC/ACM parameter optimization. By analyzing metrics such as Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) and Bit Error Rate (BER), the model enables proactive transmission adjustments. Simulation results show significant improvements in signal reliability, bandwidth efficiency, and QoS compared to conventional methods. This work establishes a foundation for intelligent, self-adaptive SATCOM systems, enhancing robustness and efficiency in dynamic environments.

title: Promotion Path of Photovoltaic Carrying Capacity of Distribution Network Under the Coordination of Market Mechanism and Grid Constraints
authors: Jieyi Sun, Zhen Hu, Jingya Liu, Ruoqi Liu, Shu Zhu, Junfei Zhu, Min Xu, Xiaoliang Deng
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: With the advancement of the “dual carbon” goals, the high proportion of photovoltaic (PV) grid integration poses dual challenges to the stable operation and economic benefits of regional power grids. This study focuses on a specific region, aiming to quantitatively analyze the PV load-bearing capacity of its distribution network under the current architecture, and explore the collaborative optimization path for enhancing this capacity through the mechanism of the electricity spot market. Firstly, based on the actual grid topology, load characteristics, and solar resource data of the region, a probabilistic power flow calculation model considering temporal characteristics and randomness is constructed. This model evaluates key technical constraints such as node voltage violations and line overloads caused by PV integration under different penetration rates, thereby determining the physical load-bearing limit of the grid. Furthermore, the study introduces the price signals of the electricity spot market and constructs a “investment-operation” bi-level optimization model: the upper level aims to maximize the net income of PV and energy storage system investors for capacity planning, while the lower level simulates spot market clearing to determine real-time electricity prices and dispatch schemes.

title: Development of a Cybersecurity Framework for Cloud Environments Adapted to the Retail Sector
authors: Tomás Tátá Isidoro, Carlos Coutinho, Carlos Serrão
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Retail companies are increasingly targeted by cyber threats that are becoming more complex and difficult to deal with as technologies evolve, particularly due to the complexity and volume of information involved in this type of business. Traditional solutions such as antivirus/antimalware are becoming insufficient to deal with mass attacks that are increasingly sophisticated given current computing power. The retail business, due to its characteristics, is becoming a greater target, due to the large number of transactions and potential points of intrusion, from employees to partners.This article proposes a cybersecurity framework to support the migration of on-premises systems to the cloud. This framework consists of controls aimed at increasing confidence in migration, which have been defined through the analysis of internationally recognized frameworks and the author's practical experience. The focus of this document is mainly on the retail sector and data protection.

title: End-to-End Automated Screening of Lordosis-Kyphosis-Scoliosis and Vertebral Compression in Salmon X-Ray Images
authors: Loc Nguyen, Bach Hoai Nguyen, Seumas P. Walker, Jane E. Symonds, Binh P. Nguyen
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Automated health assessment is important for efficiently managing spinal deformities, such as lordosis-kyphosisscoliosis (LKS) and vertebral compression, in farmed salmon. In this study, we present a multi-stage deep learning pipeline for vertebral detection and severity classification in salmon X-ray images. Following initial image preprocessing and segmentation via a U-Net model, vertebrae are detected and localized using an enhanced YOLOv12 object detection framework. YOLOv12 has high accuracy, stable convergence, and a faster inference compared to the prior YOLOv10 version. LKS severity is then assessed through a rule-based strategy using Cobb angle measurements derived from the detected vertebrae, enabling objective anatomical characterization across different regions of the vertebral column. For compressions, statistical and morphological features are extracted and classified using a suite of machine learning models, with performance optimized by feature selection and class balancing techniques. The proposed system achieves robust detection and disease classification across both normal and pathological regions, showing reliable performance even in anatomically challenging cases. Designed for integration into industrial aquaculture workflows, the pipeline enables highthroughput, automated screening of large fish populations to support timely, data-driven health management at scale. This integrated approach enhances the scalability and accuracy of disease monitoring in aquaculture, and thus fish welfare and farm productivity.

title: Low Carbon Oriented Energy Dispatch of Multi-Energy Microgrid with Flexible Demands
authors: Yuxin Zhou, Junwu Qian, Qiang Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of multi-energy microgrid (MEMG), the aggregation techniques of distributed resources have been widely adopted. However, it still poses challenges for the operation of MEMG to balance economic and low-carbon indicators. In this regard, this work proposes a low-carbon oriented dispatch strategy that accommodates multiple types of flexible demands. Firstly, the flexibility of electric and heat demands is analyzed, which incorporates shiftable, transferable, and curtailable electricity demand. Especially, the heat demand is modelled flexibly considering comfort constraints based on the predicted mean vote (PMV). Further, the optimal operational model of MEMG is established with diverse energy devices, aiming at minimizing both economic cost and carbon emissions. Finally, a case study is conducted and the numerical results confirm that the proposed solution can effectively reduce economic costs and carbon emissions while maintaining user comfort.

title: Research on Collaborative Optimization Strategies for Grid-Connected Operation of Grid-Forming Energy Storage Systems
authors: Jie Guo, Zilei Zhang, Peihong Yang, Xuefeng Wu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: The low inertia and low-damping characteristics of “double high” power systems exacerbate the risk of freq uency and voltage instability, and the connection of new ene rgy sources to the grid is particularly prone to slow dynami c response and poor stability issues. To this end, a photovolt aic hybrid energy storage system (HESS) is proposed, which focuses on the use of grid-forming energy storage (GFM-ES) technology and introduces an improved adaptive virtual syn chronous generator (VSG) control strategy to significantly en hance the system's equivalent inertia (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$J$</tex>) and damping (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D$</tex>). The DC side of the system is primarily powered by photovo Itaics, supplemented by batteries and supercapacitors workin g in tandem. The photovoltaic system operates in MPPT mo de, and the hybrid energy storage system stabilizes the DC output through power and voltage control strategies. Simulat ion verification confirmed its effectiveness in maintaining DC and grid stability during load changes. based on the relatio nship between photovoltaic output and load, the charging an d discharging power of the hybrid energy storage system is adjusted in real time to ensure power balance and voltage st ability. Compared with traditional VSG, adaptive VSG furth er optimizes grid characteristics.

title: Robust Load Management Modeling for Outage Management and Energy Imbalance Reduction in Distribution Networks Based on Technical and Economic Indicators Considering Solar Energy
authors: Kourosh Apornak, Ali Mighi
abstract: In electrical distribution networks, managing imbalances and reducing peak loads during the summer is a critical operational challenge that directly impacts system resilience and efficiency. The increasing consumption of commercial and industrial customers, coupled with infrastructure limitations, has further emphasized the importance of optimizing consumption and utilizing renewable resources. This research presents a comprehensive model for load management and distribution network performance optimization. By integrating GAMS software and employing a robust approach, the model ensures the stability of decisions under uncertainty. The proposed model is evaluated in two case studies: the first study assesses peak load reduction strategies for 10 major industrial and commercial customers, considering outage and transformer repair costs. The second study analyzes the load management of a shopping center through a 100 kW solar system, resulting in a 25% reduction in peak load. The results demonstrate that asset management and the combination of load management strategies with renewable resources, while reducing operational costs, improve network resilience and stabilize the voltage profile. This model, with its flexible and robust approach, can be applied to other distribution networks and is an effective step in optimizing energy management.

title: Power Swing Detection in Distance Protection Schemes Using Impedance Angle Rate Evaluation
authors: Elahe Salari, Mehrdad Mahmoudian, Mokhtar Torabi, Hamid Arab
abstract: Power swing (PS) conditions can cause distance protection relays to malfunction, potentially jeopardizing power system stability. This paper presents an enhanced algorithm for power swing detection using the Rate of Impedance Angle Change (RIAC) method, introducing several key improvements over traditional approaches. The proposed algorithm features dynamic thresholds, real-time impedance trajectory analysis, and swing frequency adaptation to more accurately differentiate power swings from short-circuit faults. An adaptive Maximum Rate of Impedance Angle Change (MRIAC) is developed to handle fast swings, high-loading conditions, and asymmetrical faults, such as those occurring during single-pole tripping (SPT). This approach enhances relay performance without requiring extensive dynamic stability studies, making it ideal for heavily loaded transmission lines. Simulation results demonstrate superior accuracy and dependability in various system conditions, with faster and more reliable fault detection during power swings. The novel features significantly improve system security and protection reliability, addressing key limitations of existing methods.

title: Anomaly Detection Method for Metering CT Errors Using Sum-Current Vector Analysis
authors: Cheng Zhao, Xuecheng Li, Jinjun Xie, Fengming Lv, Yuqi Wang, Xin Jin, Chao Wang, Pengshen Cheng, Yang Jin, Quancheng Pan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: To address the challenges of precise extraction of current transformer (CT) error characteristics and accurate identification of abnormal states, this paper proposes an anomaly detection method for metering CT errors using sum-current vector analysis. The method constructs a KCL-based multivariate vector linear regression equation and employs a regularized iterative algorithm to calculate the regression coefficients as feature indicators for CT anomaly detection. Subsequently, the Q statistic is established using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), enabling state discrimination of CTs based on this metric. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves accurate CT error identification and localization, proving to be an effective approach for online CT error detection.

title: ASC-USID: Axial Spatial Coordinate-based Object Detection in Underwater Sonar Images
authors: Yuhao Shi, Zongyuan Li, Feihu Yin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: With the deepening of marine resource development and scientific research, the importance of underwater sensing and monitoring technology has become more and more prominent. By virtue of its non-contact characteristics and strong penetration ability, sonar imaging is widely used in the fields of target identification and terrain mapping. However, the complexity of the underwater environment and noise interference pose a serious challenge to the accurate detection and identification of targets in sonar images. To address this challenge, a novel object detection framework for underwater sonar images, called ASC-USID, is proposed in this paper, which firstly introduces a Laplace Pyramid Detail Enhancement Module, which can amplify high-frequency details by multi-scale decomposition of the sonar images, and effectively suppresses noise and enhances the key target regions by combining with a gating mechanism. Further, an axial spatial coordinate feature extraction network is designed, which utilizes axial compression as well as self-attention and cross-attention mechanisms to model long-range dependencies, and generates spatial coordinate attention maps to enhance position-sensitive information, thereby significantly improving the accuracy of target localization and classification. Extensive experiments on the UATD dataset show that the proposed ASC-USID framework significantly outperforms baseline methods and other mainstream object detection models in terms of detection accuracy.

title: Energy-Efficient Smart Composting IoT System for Sustainable Food Waste Management
authors: Yang Fatin Syahira Binti Mior Mohammad Hairol, Azwan Mahmud, Noor Lindawaty Md Jiziat, Azlan Abd Aziz, Syamsuri Yaacob
abstract: This paper presents the development of a smart composting machine that integrates IoT, sensor-based automation, and machine learning to enhance the decomposition process of food waste. The system features real-time monitoring of temperature, gas emissions (methane and air quality), and pH levels, along with automated environmental controls to maintain optimal composting conditions. An actuator assists in mixing the compost, while a heater maintains the temperature using an energy-efficient battery. The sensor data is transmitted to a mobile Blynk dashboard via ESP8266, enabling remote monitoring and user alerts. We proposed development of a fully automated smart composting system that integrates automated pH adjustment through acid/alkaline dosing, and a linear regression-based machine learning model that predicts the maturity stage of compost. The system was tested using five categories of food waste—fruits, vegetables, meat, dairy, and bread—demonstrating stable operation and accurate predictions. The system shows that a combined approach significantly optimizes decomposition conditions and reduces the composting cycle to under 12 hours, a reduction by a third in comparison to commercial composting machine.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Quantum Internet Modeling: Concepts, Implementation, and Future Directions
authors: Abdulmohsen Alsaui, Sunish Kumar Orappanpara Soman, Bradley D. E. McNiven, Hyundong Shin, Octavia A. Dobre
abstract: The classical Internet faces increasing limitations as data generation and device interconnectivity expand at unprecedented rates. In recent years, this has highlighted the need for communication frameworks that surpass classical limitations. The quantum Internet (QI), composed of multiple layers of quantum communication networks (QCNs), holds promise for remarkable capabilities in secure transmission, distributed quantum computing, and quantum-enhanced sensing. Accurate and scalable modeling of QCNs is essential for designing, analyzing, and optimizing QI protocols under realistic physical conditions. To model such open quantum systems under Markovian noise, the Lindblad master equation is widely used, but its modeling complexity grows exponentially with the system size. In this work, we introduce a learned approach that utilizes a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to model the dynamics of open quantum systems, which embeds the Lindblad formalism directly into the neural network's loss function. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by simulating the entanglement fidelity decay of a two-qubit Bell state under energy damping and phase decoherence noise, which is a relevant scenario for entanglement-based QI protocols. Preliminary numerical results show that the PINN-based solver aligns with conventional partial differential equation techniques while offering improved scalability. These findings suggest that PINNs could serve as an efficient approach for accelerating the analysis of future quantum networking solutions. Finally, we conclude by outlining key future directions for scaling the framework to support QCN-level optimization.

title: Adaptive Weighted Zonotopic Particle Filter and Its Application to SOC and Polarization Voltage Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Yi-Kun Qu, Zi-Yun Wang, Yan Wang, Ju H. Park, Zhen-Hua Wang
abstract: To solve the problem of state estimation for systems with unknown but bounded noise, this article proposes an improved particle filtering algorithm based on an adaptively weighted zonotopic space. First, the estimated state is considered as the center of a zonotope, which is then scaled to form a particle zonotope that encloses the particles and characterizes their distribution region. Furthermore, the adaptive weighting parameters are determined based on the proportion of particles covered by the zonotope and a decay factor over iterations. Two zonotopes are then fused through adaptive weighting to generate a new particle-feasible domain. This domain enhances both the robustness and estimation accuracy while maintaining particle diversity. Subsequently, a vector scaling method is used to determine whether each particle lies within the feasible domain, and particles outside the domain are discarded and replaced with newly generated ones to maintain a constant population size. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm was verified through a state-of-charge estimation case for lithium-ion batteries.

title: Fano Resonance of Fiber Bragg Grating for Liquid Sensing
authors: Vinícius Piaia, Mario R. Alves, Paulo Robalinho, Susana Silva, Orlando Frazão
abstract: The decoupling of temperature and refractive index measurements was achieved by exploiting the properties of the asymmetric spectrum generated by Fano resonance, resulting from the interference between the Bragg reflection of the grating and the Fresnel reflection at the fiber tip. This spectral asymmetry enabled the implementation of a combined wavelength-based and intensity-based interrogation scheme. By separating the influence of each parameter in the spectral response, it was possible to measure the refractive index independently, without interference from temperature variations. A refractive index sensor with a minimum detectable change of δ = 1.2 × 10⁻⁴ RIU was demonstrated. In addition to introducing a novel structure that leverages Fano resonance, the sensor was also applied as an evaporation rate sensor. The results demonstrate its potential for a wide range of applications, serving as a foundation for the development of future optical sensing technologies.

title:
A Novel Compact Circular Waveguide TM
                    <sub>01</sub>
                    –TE
                    <sub>11</sub>
                    Mode Converter for High-Power Microwave Applications
authors: Qiang Liu, Min Zhao, Yingguo Li, Guangxing Du, Guolin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: We propose a novel compact circular waveguide (CWG) TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub>–TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sub> mode converter. The design combines an axial CWG input supporting TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub> mode, two-way radial short-circuited rectangular waveguides (RWGs) that guide TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sub> mode and an axial CWG output for TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sub> mode. A tailored phase shift mechanism that is inside the radial RWGs yield a competitive axial length, while stretched and trapezoidal RWG profiles improve power-handling capacity (PHC) and widen the bandwidth. Two metal rods in the input CWG further increase the conversion efficiency. These features reconcile structure compactness with gigawatt (GW)-level PHC demanded by high-power microwave (HPM) systems. A design at 2.4 GHz was simulated, fabricated, and measured. The conversion efficiency exceeds 90% across the operating band and peaks at 99.1%. The computed PHC is 2.3 GW for a radio frequency breakdown field strength of 50 MV/m in vacuum. Compared with existing linear GW-level works, the proposed mode converter achieves the shortest axial length, the lowest peak electric field (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$E_{\mathrm {peak}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of 1054 V/m for 1 W input power, and a simple, lightweight geometry that is easy to manufacture and low cost. These characteristics make the design a strong candidate of mode converter for miniaturized, removable HPM application systems.

title: Oxygen-Engineered TeOₓ for Cryogenic p-Channel Thin-Film Transistors
authors: Wunan Wang, Enlong Li, Yu Liu, Yanqiu Wu, Caifang Gao, Fan Wu, Kaichen Zhu, Wenwu Li, Junhao Chu
abstract: The advancement of cryogenic electronics for space exploration and quantum computing is critically limited by the absence of reliable p-channel transistors, which often suffer from low on-off ratios and significant hysteresis at low temperatures. Here, we report high-performance, wafer-scale p-type tellurium oxide (TeOₓ) thin film transistors (TFTs) fabricated via e-beam evaporation and low-temperature annealing (<150 °C). Through precise modulation of oxygen content, we achieve a high field-effect mobility of 30 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>V<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup> and a record-high on-off ratio of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup> at 10 K, with negligible hysteresis and high reliability. The exceptional performance is attributed to bandgap engineering via oxygen composition—which effectively suppresses the off-state current—and to enhanced crystallinity achieved through optimized annealing. This breakthrough underscores the potential of oxygen-modulated TeOₓ for energy-efficient and highly reliable CMOS integrated circuits in extreme cryogenic environments.

title: Unveiling Fine-grained Deceptive Patterns in Multi-modal Fake News: An Explainable Neuro-Symbolic Framework with LVLMs
authors: Dongxiao He, Yiqi Dong, Xiaobao Wang, Meng Ge, Carl Yang, Di Jin, Witold Pedrycz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The widespread proliferation of fake news on the Internet, especially in multi-modal formats, poses a substantial threat to society. Most deep learning-based approaches for fake news detection yield accurate predictions but lack explainability. Existing models focusing on explainability visualize key components from results or generate surface causes via Large Language Models. However, they can hardly provide the deep rationale behind the fabrication of fake news, which is indispensable for misinformation mitigation. Thus, we approach explainability from a different perspective, focusing on explaining how fake news is fabricated, which we term deceptive patterns, at its very source. First, four types of deceptive patterns are pre-established, namely Image Manipulation, Cross-modal Inconsistency, Image Repurposing and Others. Based on this, we propose GE-NSLM, a General Explainable Neuro-Symbolic Latent Model that integrates the power of Large Vision Language Models, which not only provides accurate judgments but also offers insights on deceptive patterns. Specifically, each deceptive pattern is represented as a binary learnable latent variable, obtained through amortized variational inference and weak supervision guided by logical rules. Experiments show GE-NSLM achieves competitive performance. More importantly, it provides interpretable insights into the underlying reasons why specific news items are fake. Our code is available at https://github.com/hedongxiao-tju/GE-NSLM.

title: DualFocus-CapNet: A Dual-Stream Network for Real Change and Inter-Scale Relationship-Aware Change Captioning in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Xianqi Meng, Yuefeng Zhao, Kaifa Cao, Qifei Wang, Junjie Wang, Nannan Hu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing image change captioning (RSICC) aims to generate textual descriptions of changes between bitemporal images. However, accurately describing fine-grained changes while capturing inter-scale relationships as well as distinguishing real changes from spurious changes (e.g., illumination, seasonal variations) are still major challenges for current methods. To address these issues, we propose DualFocus-CapNet, a novel model tailored for RSICC. DualFocus-CapNet employs a dual-stream architecture, where each stream is dedicated to processing a distinct pair of bitemporal features. Crucially, we introduce a Scale-wise Progressive Convolution (ScalePro Conv) that employs a progressive scale-specific approach to decompose remote sensing features into pixel-level variations, regional continuities, and linear structures. Unlike conventional parallel multi-scale processing methods, ScalePro Conv adopts a serial progressive structure to establish inter-scale relationships, thereby avoiding the fragmentation of feature information. Then, the Bi-Directional Difference Guided Transformer (BDiGTrans) is proposed to eliminate interference from spurious changes by dynamically masking invariant regions and extracting bidirectional differential features. Furthermore, the Cross-Temporal Adaptive Fusion Module (CTAF) is introduced to dynamically balance bitemporal features using learnable gating to enhance change discrimination and robust caption generation. Comprehensive experiments on the benchmark datasets LEVIR-CC and WHU-CDC show that our DualFocus-CapNet surpasses state-of-the-art change captioning methods in various evaluation metrics.

title: A topography-attentional network for ground filtering from ALS point cloud in forest environments
authors: Wenxia Dai, Wanmin Wu, Yuqi Hao, Qingfeng Guan, Wenyou Fan, Zhen Dong, Ningning Zhu, Xiaoxin Mi, Bisheng Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Ground filtering (GF) from Airborne Laser Scanning (ALS) data is a fundamental and critical task in forestry applications, which has remained an extensively researched but not yet fully resolved issue, due to the abrupt topographic changes and intricate forest configurations. This study presents a topography-attentional GF network (TAGF-Net) consisting of three modules. First, the topography aware representation introduces topography distribution to drive abstraction of higher-order landform representations, resulting in discriminative topography awareness. Second, the captured topography-aware features are further processed using the elevation attentive aggregation to stress the significance of elevation information in GF. Finally, the global feature homogeneity is introduced to analyze the long-range interactions and contextual information in the network. The performance of the TAGF-Net is evaluated on a GF benchmark, which was collected in California, USA and encompassed varied topographic settings and forest ecosystems. Compared with representative traditional and deep-learning methods, the TAGF-Net attains cutting-edge performance with total error of 1.16%. Additionally, TAGF-Net trained on the above California dataset can also achieve a better result on the NEWFOR dataset and OpenGF dataset than the representative methods without retraining, which verified its generalization ability and robustness

title: From Sparse to Dense: Toddler–inspired Reward Transition in Goal–Oriented Reinforcement Learning
authors: Junseok Park, Hyeonseo Yang, Min Whoo Lee, Won–Seok Choi, Minsu Lee, Byoung–Tak Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents face fundamental challenges in balancing exploration and exploitation, particularly when sparse or dense rewards bias learning toward sub–optimal behaviors. Biological systems, notably human toddlers, naturally navigate this balance through developmental transitions from free exploration to goal-directed behavior. Inspired by this progression, we propose the Sparse-to-Dense (S2D) reward transition for goal-oriented RL tasks. Our approach transitions from sparse rewards encouraging broad exploration to dense rewards guiding efficient exploitation, while preserving optimal policies via potential-based reward shaping throughout. Through extensive experiments on robotic manipulation and egocentric 3D navigation tasks, we demonstrate that S2D transitions significantly enhance sample efficiency, and generalization compared to static reward schemes and intrinsic motivation baselines. Using a novel Cross-Density Visualizer, we reveal that S2D transitions smooth the policy loss landscape, resulting in wider minima associated with improved generalization. Furthermore, reinterpreting Tolman’s maze experiments in modern RL contexts, we show that early sparse-reward exploration establishes robust initial parameters analogous to cognitive maps, facilitating stable learning under subsequent dense rewards. Our findings bridge developmental psychology and machine learning, offering a principled framework for designing adaptive reward structures in complex RL environments.

title: Advances in Deep Visual Intelligence: A Review of High-Performing Models, Hybrid Architectures, and Regional Perspectives in Medicinal Plant Identification
authors: S. Nilofar Banu, U. Rahamathunnisa
abstract: Herbs are natural plants known for their healing, aromatic, and nutritional benefits. Herbs are also called medicinal plants. Medicinal Plants can be used to treat various illnesses. People have been using them for centuries in traditional medicine systems, especially in Siddha and Ayurveda. It is essential to identify the proper herbs, as incorrect usage can lead to fatal consequences. Accurate identification helps doctors, farmers, companies, and people use and develop safe drugs. Medicinal plant identification and classification represent a critical computer vision task necessary for biodiversity conservation, safeguarding Indigenous Medical Practices, and pharmaceutical discovery. Proper Plant identification requires time and precise knowledge, but there are not enough experts. Many plants appear similar, which can lead to identification errors. To address these issues, approaches such as computer vision, machine learning, hybrid models (combining ML and DL), and deep learning provide opportunities for automating plant recognition from images. This paper discusses modern deep learning methods for medicinal plant recognition, exploring 153 articles and proceedings published over the past years. After a careful analysis of these studies, the paper presents frequently used datasets for plants, especially for herbs and flowers, along with deep learning methods, multi-part with hybrid techniques, regional plant classification, advanced methods, and complex datasets used for classification, as well as the accuracies of top-performing models in plant classification. The paper also discusses the primary challenges faced by the researchers and proposes suggestions for future studies for young researchers in this area.

title: Plasma-Activated Liquid Modulated the Efficacy and Resistance of Targeted Therapy Agents in Melanoma Cells With BRAFV600E Mutation
authors: Cong Yan, Zhaowei Chu, Xi Wang, Xueshan Du, Delu Che, Songmei Geng, Kun Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Targeted therapy is the first-line treatment for melanoma patients harboring the BRAFV600E mutation. However, the development of drug resistance significantly limits its clinical efficacy and long-term patient survival benefits. Cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) has emerged as a promising adjunctive oncotherapy. Plasma-activated liquid (PAL), the indirect application of CAP, exhibits superior tissue penetration capabilities and has been extensively investigated in animal models. Previous study from our group indicated that PAL can sensitize melanoma cells to targeted therapeutic agents in vitro. However, therapeutic efficacy has not yet been evaluated in animal models. This study aimed to evaluate the combined effect of PAL and targeted therapy in BRAFV600-mutant melanoma both in vitro and in vivo. Results demonstrated that PAL enhanced the efficacy of targeted therapy and sensitized A2058 cells to the BRAF inhibitor GSK2118436. Furthermore, the combination of intratumoral PAL injection with targeted therapy significantly inhibited the growth of subcutaneous melanoma tumors in vivo. In conclusion, our findings suggest that PAL represents a novel and promising combined strategy for melanoma treatment.

title: Exploring Real-Time Gesture Recognition Through Chipless RFID Technology
authors: Zeshan Ali, Etienne Perret
abstract: This research paper introduces a system engineered to detect hand gestures utilizing a depolarizing chipless RFID tag held by an individual positioned in front of a monostatic radar. The system ascertains the location of the chipless RFID tag within a three-dimensional space by employing the backscattered phase from each resonator in conjunction with multilateration. Through the assessment of the tag’s location in three-dimensional space, a range of hand gestures can be recognized employing uncomplicated processing techniques based on the similarity metric of turning distances. This renders the proposed technique suitable for real-time applications, eliminating the necessity for machine learning or training. The system was evaluated by detecting six basic hand gestures while the tag was affixed to a Styrofoam arm positioned on a 3D position table and held in a human hand within an office environment. Statistical analyses showed that the proposed gesture recognition works well within a 3D volume of 10 × 10 × 10 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The suggested gesture recognition system shows promise for real-world applications, as it may function effectively even when the reader antenna is concealed beneath materials such as wood, gypsum, and chipboard. This paper is accompanied by two videos demonstrating the proposed gesture recognition system.

title: UZSDD: Universal Zero-shot Deepfake Detection via Domain-Invariant Meta-Learning
authors: Qin Wang, Xiaofeng Wang, Ningning Bai, Zinian Liu, Jianghua Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Existing zero-shot deepfake detection methods are often constrained to specific scenarios and struggle in diverse, complex scenarios. To address this limitation, we propose a universal zero-shot deepfake detection method. This method models the common forgery traces across different domains as domain-invariant features and introduces a novel domain-invariant meta-learning strategy. This strategy embeds the mechanism of domain-invariant learning into a meta-learning framework, enabling the model not only to extract specific domain-invariant features from certain domains, but also to leverage the meta-learning mechanism of fast adaptation to new domains. As a result, the model is capable of effectively capturing the intrinsic domain-invariant characteristics of deepfake images, thereby achieving universal zero-shot deepfake detection. Extensive comparative experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves the highest average detection AUC (86.96%) across 28 unseen datasets, representing an improvement of 8.02% over the second-best method (78.94%). Moreover, it is the only method that is effective in all four zero-shot scenarios, which strongly validates its superior zero-shot detection performance and universality. Code is released at https://github.com/QinQin741/DIML.

title: Cross-domain Class Context Optimization for Universal Domain Adaptation
authors: Bo Zhou, Long Liu, Chenyue Fan, Zhipeng Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Universal Domain Adaptation (UniDA) aims to achieve cross-domain knowledge transfer without label set assumptions. UniDA primarily faces two challenges: domain alignment under label shift and identifying unknown class samples in the target domain. We propose a cross-domain class context optimization method for UniDA to address these two challenges, leveraging a contrastive language-image pre-training model containing learnable prompts. First, we develop a domain context-guided feature augmentation technique, which augments source domain features based on textual features related to the target domain style, improving the consistency of feature distributions between the source domain and target domain. Subsequently, we learn a set of class contexts suitable for the target domain using the augmented source domain features. Furthermore, to improve the ability of the class context to filter unknown class samples, we propose a local known-unknown entropy optimization strategy, which effectively reduces the interference from class-irrelevant semantic information in the images, thereby mitigating erroneous class matching under label shift. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves competitive results compared to advanced UniDA approaches. Additionally, experimental results show that our entropy optimization strategy can serve as a general optimization component for prompt tuning, enhancing the generalization performance of existing methods when applied to downstream tasks with label shift.

title: MDepth: Wavelet-Enhanced Depth Estimation on Mars via Mutual Boosting of Dual-Modal Data_supp1-3642761.pdf
authors: YU LIU
abstract: Depth estimation plays a great potential role in obstacle avoidance and navigation for further Mars exploration missions. Compared to traditional stereo matching, learning-based stereo depth estimation provides a data-driven approach to infer dense and precise depth maps from stereo image pairs. However, these methods always suffer performance degradation in environments with sparse textures and lacking geometric constraints, such as the unstructured terrain of Mars. To address these challenges, we propose M<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>Depth, a depth estimation model tailored for Mars rovers. Considering the sparse and smooth texture of Martian terrain, which is primarily composed of low-frequency features, our model incorporates a convolutional kernel based on wavelet transform that effectively captures low-frequency response and expands the receptive field. Additionally, we introduce a consistency loss that explicitly models the complementary relationship between depth map and surface normal map, utilizing the surface normal as a geometric constraint to enhance the accuracy of depth estimation. Besides, a pixel-wise refinement module with mutual boosting mechanism is designed to iteratively refine both depth and surface normal predictions. Experimental results on synthetic Mars datasets with depth annotations show that M<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>Depth achieves a 16% improvement in depth estimation accuracy compared to other state-of-the-art methods in depth estimation. Furthermore, the model demonstrates strong applicability in real-world Martian scenarios, offering a promising solution for future Mars exploration missions.

title: Deep Neural Network and Feature Extraction Approach for Anomaly Detection and Classification in Infrared Images of Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Leandro H. Formigoni Aggio, Rafael Krummenauer
abstract: This work presents a solution based on a deep neural network for detecting and classifying faults in photovoltaic modules using thermographic infrared images comparing the performance of different machine learning techniques. Three scenarios were evaluated, those being the identification of the presence of faults, whether the faults are permanent or not and finally a classification of the type of fault. The core of the proposed methodology utilizes a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for classification. Initially, a relatively deep CNN is developed as a standalone system for fault detection and classification. Subsequently, the feature extraction layers from the proposed CNN are employed to convert dataset images into more straightforward vectors of attributes, which are then used to train other more general classifiers. This approach aims to create easier and promising learning conditions for any classifier, especially those that are not intrinsically devised to operate directly with digital images as input data. The results emphasize the strengths and weaknesses of the evaluated models and encourage further research investments on the proposed feature extraction approach.

title: PPS-DMIA: Directed Mating with Infeasible Solution Archive in Push and Pull Search for Constrained Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Ryo Takamiya, Minami Miyakawa, Keiki Takadama, Hiroyuki Sato
abstract: This paper proposes PPS-DMIA (Push and Pull Search with Directed Mating and Infeasible Archive), a novel evolutionary approach for constrained multi-objective optimization, which commonly arises in real-world optimization problems characterized by multiple conflicting objectives and practical constraints. Push and Pull Search (PPS) provides a promising framework by improving objective values while ignoring constraints in the push phase and searching for feasible solutions in the pull phase. PPS-DM (PPS with Directed Mating) accelerates the pull phase by directed mating, which guides the search by mating infeasible solutions in the search population with feasible non-dominated solutions in the archive. However, its effectiveness is limited by the infrequent occurrence of directed mating, the current solution generation method, and the strategy for selecting guiding solutions. To overcome these limitations, the proposed PPS-DMIA introduces four key mechanisms: (i) it comprehensively updates the archive with all solutions generated during the search, thereby increasing opportunities for directed mating; (ii) it introduces an additional archive of infeasible solutions, which facilitates directed mating when feasible solutions are scarce; (iii) it uses the direct difference vector between a focal solution and a selected archive solution to generate a new solution; and (iv) it selects guiding solutions from the archive by considering the search direction of the focal solution, enhancing the directional bias of directed mating. Experimental results on the LIR-CMOP benchmark suite show that the proposed PPS-DMIA enhances directed mating effectiveness and achieves superior search performance, outperforming PPS-DM and other state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Wideband Tri-Band Negative Group Delay Circuit With Flatness Enhancement
authors: Yuwei Meng, Aixia Yuan
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: A novel wideband tri-band negative group delay (NGD) circuit with flat-NGD characteristic is proposed, and the complete closed-form design equations are presented. Meanwhile, the group delay (GD) ripple and flat-NGD bandwidth (BW) can be set according to design requirements to further constraints on the values of circuit parameters. For verification, an NGD circuit is designed, fabricated, and measured at the center frequency of 1.0 GHz. From the measured results, the NGD time of −0.5 ns at the center frequency is obtained with insertion loss (IL) of 16.3 dB. The flat-NGD BW reaches 43.8%, 21.9%, and 11.2% with 12% GD ripple, and the variation of IL is less than 1.8 dB. The proposed NGD circuit can be potentially applied to multiconstellation GNSS and multiband 5G/4G MIMO systems, enabling significant advantages in multiband transceiver systems and NGD application integration.

title:
Numerical Modeling and Design Optimization of a MgB

                    Bulk Superconducting Undulator
authors: Dabin Wei, Yimin Tong, Chan Liu, Zhuangwei Chen, Marco Calvi, Alexandre Arsenault, Jacques Noudem, Yiteng Xing, Pierre Bernstein, Kai Zhang, Haixiao Deng
abstract: In 2023, researchers from the University of Cambridge and the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) successfully demonstrated the feasibility of employing second-generation high-temperature superconducting (HTS) RE-Ba-Cu-O(REBCO) materials for undulator applications, achieving a magnetic field of 2.1 T with a 10 mm period and a 4 mm magnetic gap. This remarkable performance is primarily attributed to the high critical current density (Jc) of REBCO. However, REBCO also presents several challenges, including high production cost, complex fabrication procedures, and limited machinability. In contrast, although MgB₂ exhibits a lower Jc, it offers advantages such as ease of synthesis and machining, making it a promising candidate for undulator development. This study presents the design, preparation fabrication, and assembly of short-period MgB₂ bulk undulators, utilizing spark plasma sintered (SPS) MgB₂ bulks with a 16 mm period and a 4 mm magnetic gap, after 2D size optimization and 3D simulation, it is estimated that an undulator magnetic field of 1.75 T will be generated.

title: Analyzing Linux System Call Variability: Real-Time Patch Impact and System Call Monitoring
authors: Markel Galarraga, Charles-Alexis Lefebvre, Jon Perez-Cerrolaza, Jose A. Pascual
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: State-of-the-art safety-critical systems are increasingly integrating advanced functionality that requires high computational power, such as the pedestrian detection required by autonomous vehicles. Consequently, high-performance embedded platforms are becoming increasingly necessary. In this context, the use of Linux is highly attractive to industry due to its extensive ecosystem (platform support, AI libraries, etc.) and its opensource development model. However, Linux was not designed to comply with strict safety standards, which complicates its use in safety-critical systems. Previous works have studied the nondeterminism of Linux kernel system calls regarding their execution paths and execution times, and proposed alternative approaches to justify its use in such systems. In this work, we continue those efforts with two main contributions. First, we compare a regular Linux kernel with the kernel patched with the PREEMPT_RT real-time patch, and show how the patch reduces the variability of system calls, both in terms of timings and execution paths. Then, we propose an additional layer of assurance in the form of a trie-based monitor implemented in hardware, which ensures that the variability measured and estimated during testing holds when the system is fielded, both for execution paths and execution times. We implement a software prototype of the monitor to demonstrate its feasibility and discuss our plan to migrate it to hardware.

title: A Configuration Optimization Method for Distribution Network Fault Monitoring Devices Based on GA-GNN Neural Network
authors: Yingdong Xu, Qiulin Ding, Ming Xiao, Yuheng Fan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimization method for the configuration of distribution network fault monitoring devices based on the GA-GNN neural network. The Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) is adopted to screen the key indicators of configuration influencing factors, and a typical network frame model is established to determine the device configuration limit distance for different types of lines. The network frame layout information, configuration influencing factors and their weights, configuration limit distance and requirements are input into the GA-GNN neural network algorithm to optimize the device configuration scheme. This method can effectively improve the scientificity and rationality of device configuration, providing reliable technical support for the optimal configuration of distribution network fault monitoring devices.

authors: Neng Tao, Ru Zhao, Qianyi Chen, Honghao Wu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Ammonia, as a clean energy carrier, has the potential to be used as a hydrogen energy source. Methaneammonia co-combustion technology involves mixing ammonia (NH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) with methane (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>) in a specific ratio and then burning the mixture, combining the advantages of both to enhance combustion performance as a clean energy technology. This study employs a combination of experimental and computational methods to measure and simulate the flame stretch extinction limit and flame structure of non-premixed counterflow flames containing ammonia/methane/nitrogen mixtures with ammonia concentrations of 10%, 20%, 30%, and 40%, as well as air, to assess their potential as clean fuels. The results show that as the ammonia concentration increases, the flame stretch extinction limit of the non-premixed counterflow flame decreases, the maximum flame temperature decreases, and flame stability decreases. At the same time, CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions are significantly reduced, achieving a certain emission reduction effect.

title: Research on a Multi-Feature 1D-CNN-Based Composite Fault Diagnosis Method for Gearboxes
authors: Yanlong Wang, Antao Wang, Fanbin Kong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: To address the challenges of strong feature coupling and low diagnostic accuracy in gearbox composite faults, this study proposes an intelligent diagnosis method based on multi-feature parallel 1D-CNN. By constructing a multi-branch feature extraction network, the automatic decoupling and fusion of time-domain features from multiple signals are achieved. Firstly, an 8-channel parallel convolutional architecture is designed to process features from different sensors, employing large 64×1 kernels to enhance local feature extraction. Secondly, a feature fusion module is developed using depthwise separable convolutions, where 1×1 convolutions facilitate cross-channel information interaction. Finally, batch normalization is incorporated to effectively mitigate overfitting. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average diagnostic accuracy of 97.66% on a gearbox dataset covering eight composite fault types. This study provides a novel technical approach for composite fault diagnosis under complex operating conditions.

title: Analysis of Coordination Strategies between Large-Scale Power Users' Direct Participation in Inter-Provincial Spot Markets and Grid-Agent Electricity Procurement
authors: Bo Zhou, Shunfu Lin, Zhiqiang Luo, Shuyan Zhang, Guodong Huang, Jianzhang Qu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This study focuses on analyzing coordination strategies between Large-Scale power users' direct participation in inter-provincial spot markets and Grid-Agent electricity procurement. It aims to provide theoretical support and practical guidance for the stable operation of the electricity market during the reform transition period. We begin by deconstructing the mechanisms of these two distinct markets: the inter-provincial spot market and the Grid-Agent electricity procurement market. Following a comprehensive analysis of both markets and identification of their respective challenges, we propose the concept of "leveraging complementary advantages and fostering synergistic development". This approach seeks to fully utilize the comparative strengths of each market, mitigating weaknesses while optimizing their coordinated operation. Through this research, we strive to maximize the potential of the novel inter-provincial spot market, significantly enhance resource allocation efficiency, and ensure power supply security. The ultimate goal is to facilitate "smooth reform progression, healthy market development, and mutual benefit for all stakeholders", thereby achieving a win-win outcome for market participants.

title: Mode Switching Method of Three-port Converter Based on Neural Network Fitting Explicit MPC
authors: Peng Luo, Yili Li, Lei Guo, Zhaohong Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Three-port converters (TPCs) have recently become increasingly popular in sustainable energy systems, such as wind, solar, and energy storage systems. In order to solve the oscillation problem caused by TPC mode switching, this paper proposes a strategy based on neural network fitting explicit model predictive control (EMPC) to solve the mode switching problem of TPC. This control strategy not only ensures the stability of TPC mode switching, but also maintains stability when the load changes. To verify this control strategy, a simulation model of TPCs is established, and the simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Research on Scheduling Method of Aerospace TT&C Network Resources Based on Improved DQN Algorithm
authors: Shuai Li, Xucun Yan, Jianfeng Ye, Tao Wu, Zixin Si, Si Chen, Guixin Li
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Space tracking and control resource scheduling is a highly complex, dynamically constrained combinatorial optimization problem. To address the challenges posed by the large number of satellites, diverse types, and high likelihood of tracking and control time window conflicts, this paper proposes an improved Deep Q-Network (DQN) algorithm incorporating a dual-branch gated neural network architecture to address the resource scheduling problem in large satellite constellations. First, a mathematical model of the task is constructed, considering multiple constraints, including the task time window, priority, release time, and resource demands. Second, by introducing a shared feature extraction layer and a task scoring branch, the priority and temporal urgency of each task are modeled separately. A gating mechanism is employed to fuse the scores and improve the strategy’s capability in identifying critical tasks. This paper selects three representative algorithms that employ distinct solution strategies-the Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), and the standard DQN algorithm -to compare against the proposed improved DQN algorithm. A unified simulation environment and a consistent evaluation metric system are established to ensure fair comparison. The experimental results indicate that the improved DQN algorithm achieves a higher scheduling success rate, improved resource utilization, and demonstrates strong stability and robustness under complex task scenarios. In Scenario 1, the scheduling success rate, high-priority task completion rate, resource utilization rate, and average scheduling lead time are $95.00 \%, 92.86 \%, 28.10 \%$, and 9.47. In Scenario 2, these metrics are $77.50 \%, 80.65 \%, 29.31 \%$, and 8.87. In Scenario 3, they are $\mathbf{7 3. 3 3 \%, ~} \mathbf{8 0. 0 0 \%, ~} \mathbf{2 3. 5 3 \%}$, and $\mathbf{8. 4 1}$.

title: Designing Higher Education Exam Schedules with Multiobjective Evolutionary Algorithms
authors: Manuel Freire, Ema Soboredo, Martín Pedemonte
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: Defining an academic assessment calendar, particularly for midterm and final exam periods, is a complex challenge faced by many universities, including the Universidad de la República (UDELAR) in Uruguay. The large number of courses and the diversity of student trajectories, with many students simultaneously taking courses from different years of their degree programs, lead to conflicting interests when scheduling exams. Additionally, there are various logistical constraints, such as limited classroom availability, and academic restrictions, such as the requirement to avoid scheduling exams for courses in the same semester on the same day. Moreover, faculty members generally prefer the evaluation period to be as short as possible, as regular classes are suspended during this time.In this work, we present a strategy that employs evolutionary algorithms to generate examination timetables, aiming to maximize student satisfaction while minimizing the duration of the evaluation period. We formulate the problem as a multiobjective optimization problem and explore different approaches by varying the criteria used for initializing the population. We evaluate our approach on a real-world instance from the School of Engineering, and the numerical results suggest that this is a promising approach to this problem.

title: Genetic Algorithm-Based Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Path Planning in Dynamic Environments for Disaster Management
authors: V. R. Wijerathne, W. G. P. Theekshana, K. G. B. Prabhanga, K. P. C. De Silva, Sanika Wijayasekara, Ishara Weerathunga, Mahaadikara M.D.J.T. Hansika
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) hold immense potential in disaster management by enabling rapid response, real-time aerial reconnaissance, and improved situational awareness without endangering human lives. This research proposes a real-time UAV path-planning system based on a Hierarchical Recursive Multiagent Genetic Algorithm (HR-MAGA). Unlike traditional methods that struggle with adaptability in dynamic 3D environments, our system employs localized waypoint updates to reduce the computational cost of full-path recalculations. A multi-objective fitness function guides the optimization process by balancing safety, energy efficiency, altitude smoothness, turbulence resistance, and travel time. Additionally, the system integrates a decoupled real-time collision avoidance module for immediate response to sudden threats. While obstacle detection is abstracted in this study, the framework is designed to be easily integrated with real-time sensing technologies such as LiDAR for dynamic obstacle awareness. Experimental evaluations show a 20–30% improvement in path efficiency and a 40% increase in convergence speed compared to conventional genetic algorithms, highlighting the system’s adaptability and robustness in disaster response scenarios.

title: MBF-Net: Multi-stage Bilateral-feature Fusion Network for EEG-Based Emotion Recognition
authors: Debam Saha, Asfak Ali, Diego Oliva, Ram Sarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: Mental health conditions are increasingly affecting populations across the world. While audio, video, and image-based emotion recognition methods are widely used, they are susceptible to intentional emotion masking by individuals. In contrast, Electroencephalogram (EEG)-based emotion recognition offers a more reliable and direct insight into a person’s emotional state, making it valuable for applications in human-computer interaction, medical diagnostics, military systems, and mental health monitoring. However, existing EEG-based models often struggle with limited accuracy and generalizability. This paper introduces a Multi-stage Bilateral-feature, Fusion-based deep learning framework, called MBF-Net, that integrates parallel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) streams through a multi-stage feature fusion strategy. The model is further enhanced by attention mechanisms, including Multi-Head Attention (MHA) and the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM), effectively capturing both spatial and temporal dependencies. The proposed model demonstrates superior performance on four benchmark EEG datasets, namely SWELL, WESAD, Brainwave EEG, and SEED, achieving classification accuracies of 99.99%, 99.99%, 99.00%, and 99.99%, respectively. These results underscore the proposed model’s robustness, interpretability, and real-world applicability in affective computing and brain-computer interface domains. Code is available at : https://github.com/DebamSahaCS/BFFAMechanism.
