title: Conflict Management for Multi-Level Models in Collaborative Modelling Environments
authors: Yuhong Fu, Georg Grossmann, Karamjit Kaur, Matt Selway, Markus Stumptner
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Multi-level modelling supports multi abstraction levels and enhances reusability. Multi-view modelling enables customised view tailored to different stakeholders, thereby separating concerns and fostering collaboration. Because multi-level modelling approaches have more complex semantics, and views represent subsets of a model - conflicts may not be obvious or explicitly visible to end users. There is no conflict management framework currently applicable for multi-level and multi-view modelling approach. In this paper, we propose a conflict management framework which can detect and resolve overlapping changes and semantic conflicts. We present algorithms that support the framework and the conflict resolution, which leverages priority-based and rule-based strategies to restore consistency across the model and views.

title: Amplitude Optimization in Linear Antenna Arrays using CEAO Algorithm
authors: Yurong Yin, Yan Liu, Xiuyu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on Electronics Information and Emergency Communication (ICEIEC)
abstract: This paper describes the synthesis method of linear array with minimum sidelobe level using a hybird algorithm called CEAO algorithm. To enhance the global search capability and accelerate convergence of the algorithm, we employed the CEAO algorithm, which is an optimization approach that utilizes the CVX toolbox to optimize the random initialization of the Enzyme Action Optimization (EAO) algorithm. This method aims to identify the optimal current amplitude distribution for achieving the desired radiation pattern with minimal sidelobe levels. To validate its efficacy, the paper presents simulation experiments. The results demonstrate that the CEAO algorithm effectively enhances the performance of linear antenna arrays by mitigating the broadening of the first-null beamwidth (FNBW) and simultaneously reducing the peak side lobe level (SLL). This approach serves as a valuable reference for addressing similar model optimization challenges in the field of antenna array design.

title: Prediction of Steam Turbine Rotor Temperature Field Using Physics-Informed Neural Network
authors: Mengen Xu, Zhenhao Tang, Guanglei Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Steam turbines are critical to modern industry and energy systems. Accurate rotor temperature field prediction is critical for safe and efficient turbine operation. To address the limited physical interpretability of existing models, this paper proposes a physics-informed deep neural network based on grid continuity for steam turbine rotor temperature field prediction. A dataset of 30 typical operating conditions during the rapid load increase phase is constructed from operational data and finite element simulations. Baseline condition relationships are analyzed to correct prediction biases. A physics-informed neural network incorporates continuous temperature distributions from adjacent simulations, integrating physical and temperature loss functions for model optimization. Experiments validate the model's accuracy in predicting rotor temperature fields during startup, providing theoretical and technical foundations for stable turbine operation.

title: Study on Low-Carbon Data Centre Cooling Configuration Based on Hydrogen Internal Combustion Engine Waste Heat Recovery Refrigeration Technology
authors: Jin Qian, Hui Chen, Jian Wang, Chunyang Gong, Zhixin Wang, Shousong Jin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: In the current context of rapidly increasing computing power, new data centres are subject to strict requirements that at least 80% of their energy must come from green sources. It is therefore urgent to optimise the internal energy supply structure of data centres to meet load demands while further achieving energy conservation and carbon reduction.To address this, this paper proposes an integrated wind-solar-hydrogen hydrogen-electric coupling system based on electrohydrogen-cold synergy. By incorporating hydrogen internal combustion engine waste heat recovery cooling technology and considering the energy consumption of the cooling system, the architecture for renewable energy hydrogen production, hydrogen storage, and zero-carbon cooling is optimised. Ultimately, the capacity configuration of the hydrogen internal combustion engine waste heat cooling system in the data centre is optimised. The scheme employs a PSO optimisation algorithm to jointly optimise the power of the electrolyser, hydrogen storage capacity, and the output of the hydrogen internal combustion engine within a 72-dimensional solution space. Finally, simulations were conducted for a national-level data centre in China. The results indicate that a 5 MW hydrogen internal combustion engine waste heat cooling system can achieve zero carbon emissions during the operational phase, with instantaneous cooling capacity reaching 897.7 kW, representing a 64%-166% improvement over traditional air-cooled and water-cooled systems, thereby validating the feasibility of low-carbon data centres and the synergistic application of waste heat cooling.

title: Deep Learning for Lung Cancer Detection in Chest Radiographs: Evaluating YOLOv8 in Clinical Practice
authors: Patricia Anelis Donisan, Maria Iuliana Dascălu, Seifaldien Haytham A.M, Dan Gârlaşu, Ioan-Alexandru Bratosin, Diana-Alexandra Ciungan, Stefan Dumitrache-Rujinski, Alexandra Pop, Filip Radu, Cristian Ștefan
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: This study employs transfer learning with the YOLOv8 model to evaluate its effectiveness in detecting pulmonary nodules on chest radiographs within real-world clinical environments. The model was trained using the publicly available NODE21 dataset, comprising 1,134 chest X-rays annotated with 1,476 nodules. Performance assessment was conducted on an independent dataset consisting of 64 radiographs from the “Marius Nasta” Institute of Pneumology (Bucharest, Romania), involving patients with biopsy-confirmed lung cancer. To ensure dataset consistency, images exhibiting extensive disease, atelectasis, pleural effusion, or more than three nodules were excluded. The trained model attained an accuracy of 65% on the NODE21 dataset; however, its performance declined to 32% on the independent clinical dataset, highlighting challenges in generalizing to real-world cases—particularly those involving large pulmonary masses (>3 cm), which were underrepresented in the training data. Nevertheless, the YOLOv8 model effectively detected smaller nodules (<3 cm) and those overlapping mediastinal structures, which are often difficult for radiologists to identify. These findings indicate that, despite limitations in detecting larger lesions, the model may offer utility in preliminary screenings or as a supplementary tool for radiologists, especially in identifying subtle or obscured nodules during routine chest X-ray evaluations.

title: Study on the Design of Driving Circuit Based on Silicon Carbide Devices
authors: Tao Liu, Chuanyu Sun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Driven by rapid advances in power electronics, silicon carbide (SiC) power devices are now widely adopted in renewable-energy systems, electric vehicles, high-frequency switch-mode power supplies and other applications, thanks to their superior switching performance, high voltage rating and low conduction losses. However, SiC devices impose more stringent requirements on gate-drive circuits, rendering traditional MOSFET drivers inadequate in terms of switching speed, high-voltage isolation, accurate protection and other critical functions. Therefore, developing a highly reliable, wide-bandwidth SiC gate-driver with comprehensive protection features is of significant research value. This thesis presents a gate-drive solution for highspeed SiC MOSFETs that centers on Texas Instruments' isolated gate-driver chip UCC21710. The design methodology is elaborated from the perspectives of driving principles, circuit implementation, signal integrity and protection strategies, supported by detailed schematics; Ultimately realizing reliable gate control for both high- and low-voltage sides.

title: Model Consistency Management of a Brewery Digital Twin
authors: Hossain Muhammad Muctadir, Yanyifan Liao, Loek Cleophas
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) are often defined as a pairing of a physical entity (PE) and one or more virtual entities (VEs) where the latter mimics certain behaviors of the former to provide specific services. VEs are typically model-based software systems that incorporate a variety of multi-domain, multi-tool models that are essential throughout the DT’s lifecycle. Any inconsistency among these models, which occurs rather frequently, directly affects the performance, reliability, and effectiveness of a DT. In this paper, we present a system for managing the consistency of VE models contained within a DT of a microbrewery, which encapsulates the fermentation process to optimize beer production.

title: Synchronization of Wearable Sensor Data for Vital Sign Monitoring
authors: Joshua C Y Lai, Pushpendu Kar
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Wearables are increasingly popular and are being accepted in healthcare applications, such as monitoring activity and heart rate. Like other wireless sensors, time synchronization is an important issue to ensure the credibility of data. While studies in this area are not uncommon, most methods try to synchronize the clock on individual devices and require access to the hardware and modification to the firmware. We consider a case for consumer wearables, where there is zero access to both firmware and hardware of the devices, except listening to the streaming data passively, and all synchronization can only be done on the receiving end. We present a two-part approach to synchronize streaming data received from wearable sensors. First, the fixed time offset due to device processing time is corrected by a one-time calibration. Second, the random time offset due to wireless communication is corrected by finetuning the sampling rate. Instead of adjusting the time on separate devices, the method attempts to align data from different devices to the accuracy of one sample time. The synchronization method also considers situations of data loss, congested Bluetooth channels, and multiple receiving hubs. With further interpolation on the received data, a synchronization accuracy of 1 ms is achieved. Unlike existing methods that rely on embedded timestamps, synchronized start events, or firmware modifications, our technique operates entirely on the receiver side, achieving single sample accuracy even under packet loss and clock drift.

title: A Deep-Learning Approach Based on Graph Network Model for Recognizing Receptor-Odor Interaction and Perception
authors: Fei Wang, Junfei Liu, Zihao Liu, Huihao Wang, Yunwei Xiong, Xiaoya Xie, Xing Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Olfactory perception arises from the synergistic activation of multiple receptors, each exhibiting distinct affinity for recognizing specific odors. However, accurately identifying the olfactory receptor corresponding to particular odors, i.e., receptor-odor interactions, remains a significant challenge due to incomplete understanding of the underlying biological mechanisms. To address this problem, we propose a novel deep learning approach that integrates graph neural network with attention mechanism-based fusion strategy. This approach models the spatial structure feature among olfactory receptors, and aims to construct a receptorodor interaction mapping using the curated dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively identify the receptor-odor interaction relationship, achieving an accuracy of 93.5 %, and significantly outperforming existing deep learning models and recognition method. Additionally, the method exhibits robust on external real-world samples, and accurately recognize receptor interactions involved in odor perception, with substantial improvements across all performance metrics. Finally, we construct an odor-receptor space distribution to elucidate the structural organization of diverse odors, highlighting receptor clustering patterns for each odor. The proposed method offers valuable insights into the biological mechanisms of olfaction, provides a promising framework for odor-related disease diagnosis, and delivers practical guidance for the design of electronic nose systems.

title: Real-time Implementation of Fuzzy Visual Servoing for a Delta Robot via Shape and Color Detection
authors: Nooshin Najafian, Alireza Ashrafi Majd, Abbas Ansaroudi, Sahar Aghazadeh, Manizheh Zakeri, Mohammad-Reza Sayyed Noorani
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: This paper implements a real-time fuzzy-based visual servoing system for a Delta robot. The end-effector and target object are detected using a monocular camera via their color (white and blue, respectively) and circular shape. The designed fuzzy logic controller effectively manages the kinematic coupling between the robot's axes by considering the error in both directions simultaneously. The robot is controlled by solving the inverse kinematics to move the end-effector toward the target. A key contribution is a Mamdani-type Fuzzy Inference System (FIS) that dynamically adjusts the proportional control gain based on the x and y position errors, overcoming the speed-accuracy trade-off of a fixed-gain controller. Real-time experimental results confirm the superiority of the proposed fuzzy adaptive controller, showing faster and more precise convergence compared to conventional proportional .

title: A Bi-object Optimization Algorithm for Topology Reconfiguration on Tiled Many-core Architectures
authors: Zhidong Qin, Shaoyu Wang, Junyin Wei, Wei Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Intelligent Technology and Embedded Systems (ICITES)
abstract: This paper proposes a topology reconfiguration algorithm to optimize the trade-off between performance and reliability of many-core processors. By innovatively incorporating the clustering characteristics of defect distribution, a core-level reliability calculation method is developed to accurately evaluate system reliability under defect clustering effects. A bi-objective optimization problem model is further constructed, and a topology reconfiguration algorithm for many-core processors is presented based on the NSGA-II framework. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm effectively balances reliability and time performance.

title: Machine Learning for Teenager Diabetes Prediction
authors: Zichen Peng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Biomedical Engineering and Bioinformatics for Health (ICBEBH)
abstract: Diabetes is a growing global health concern, increasingly affecting children and teenagers. The primary method for diabetes detection in current clinical practice is blood sample analysis, which minimizes the uncertainty of invasive tests. Monitoring daily behaviors can identify at-risk groups early for intervention before clinical symptoms develop. This approach increases testing convenience and captures vital moments for disease management. This study aims to use machine learning to enable pre-diagnosis for potential teenage diabetes patients prior to blood tests. Logistic regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Classification (SVC), and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) models are utilized to assess the connection between diabetes and lifestyle habits. Results show that the XGBoost model is the most effective, failing to identify 20.34 % of diabetes cases and misdiagnosing 26.67 % of patients. Additionally, General Health, Body Mass Index, and High Blood Pressure emerge as the most significant factors linked to diabetes in teenagers. All models achieved convergence, ensuring the accuracy of the results. By using machine learning, healthcare professionals can pre-diagnose teenage diabetic patients, significantly reducing costs associated with blood tests.

title: Spiral Curriculum Optimization (SCO): Spiral Curriculum-Inspired Search Unifying Multi-Scale Oscillatory Micro-Cycles and Long Jumps for Robust Constrained Engineering Design
authors: Jakkrin Srihajak, Sirapat Chiewchanwattana, Khamron Sunat, Poomin Duankhan, Patchara Nasa-ngium
abstract: Many engineering design problems are nonconvex, high-dimensional, and constrained, where derivative-free meta-heuristics are often preferred. We introduce Spiral Curriculum Optimization (SCO), a population-based algorithm that operationalizes Bruner's spiral-curriculum idea-revisiting topics with increasing depth-into four mechanisms: (i) micro-cycles with a per-iteration randomized sine driver and stepwise decay to orchestrate exploration-exploitation at multiple scales; (ii) a prior-knowledge schedule <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E(t)=\sqrt{t / T}$</tex> that progressively gates per-dimension updates toward the current best; (iii) occasional long jumps via <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\log (1 /$</tex> rand) (exponential-tailed) to escape attraction basins; and (iv) soft boundary projection that mitigates bouncing and edge locking. Greedy acceptance yields a monotonically non-increasing best-so-far curve. We benchmark SCO on 12 constrained engineering design problems (F1-F12) against eight competitive methods (GA, ABC, GWO, WOA, JAYA, SNS, RIME, DOA) under identical budgets (population <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=30$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T=10,000$</tex> iterations) with 50 independent runs per problem. Using feasible-only statistics, convergence curves, violin plots, and a CEC-style aggregate score, SCO achieves the best overall rank and exhibits tight dispersion. Collectively, the findings show that embedding a curriculum-style schedule together with multi-scale oscillatory micro-cycles and soft-boundary handling delivers a stable, effective balance between exploration and exploitation in constrained optimization.

title: Comparative Analysis of Single-Phase and Dual-Phase Interleaved Flyback Converters for Micro-EDM Applications
authors: Yahya Mohammed Sinjab, Azli Yahya, Abd Rahim Mat Sidek
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Micro-EDM expands the capabilities of Electrical Discharge Machining (EDM) to sub <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> to be implemented not only in advanced materials prototyping and machining, but also in applications related to nanotechnology. However, providing consistent, low ripple, discharged energy to ensure consistent Material Removal Rate (MRR), along with high quality surface finishing, is one of the major challenges that Micro-EDM faces. This paper presents a comparative simulation study between conventional single-phase and a dual-phase interleaved Flyback design, both simulated in a semi-ideal environment. Both converters target <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{0}=60 \mathrm{V}, I_{0}=0.2 \mathrm{A}, \mathrm{D}= 50 \%, \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{o}}=0.33 \mu \mathrm{F}, \mathrm{R}=300 \Omega$</tex>, and a 5% ripple ratio. The interleaved version <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{m} 1}=\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{m}}=1.25 \text{mH}$</tex> per phase, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{m} 2}=5 \text{mH}$</tex> total) achieves >89% ripple reduction with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta \mathrm{I}_{\text{pp}} \approx 1.15 \text{mA}(<1 \%$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{0}$</tex>) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta V_{p p} \approx 0.5 \mathrm{V}\left(<1 \% \text{of}\ V_{0}\right)$</tex>, outperforming the conventional single-phase design and demonstrating the improvements of the interleaving technique, when implemented in Flyback converters for Micro-EDM power supplies.

title: Task-Oriented Context Engineering for Pedagogic Agent Powered by Large Language Model
authors: Mukhamad Angga Gumilang, Ridi Ferdiana, Indriana Hidayah, Muhammad Ismail Azmi, Shafira Annisa, Fuad Adhim Al Hasan
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are widely used in education; however, the responses frequently fail to capture learners' real-time progress or task context. This paper presents a Kanban-driven context engineering framework for LLM prompts that incorporates structured workflow data, including task states, deadlines, and activity logs, to improve pedagogical alignment and feedback accuracy. Using the RAGAS assessment pipeline, the framework was tested across three LLMs (OpenAI/gpt-oss-120b, deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b, and gemma2-9b-it) to evaluate semantic similarity and response efficiency. The results demonstrate that OpenAI/gpt-oss-120b achieved the best balance of accuracy and latency, with an average similarity of 0.68 and a response time of 5.1 s, above the others. A usability test conducted with fifty graduate students provided an average System Usability Scale (SUS) score of 84.4, suggesting high acceptance and interaction quality. The findings show that a structured Kanban context enhances response relevance, interaction, and user satisfaction while being computationally efficient. This paradigm provides a scalable framework for creating context-aware pedagogical agents, connecting workflow analytics and adaptive learning, and directing future research on multimodal and self-regulated learning support.

title: A UAV Routing Strategy For Distribution Network Post-disaster Recovery Considering Energy Consumption Calculation For Returning
authors: Yu Gong, Gang Wang, Wende Teng, Chuanzhang Yan, Fudong Lu, Zihao Wang, Chao Wu, Jianfeng Fu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper proposes a post-disaster unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) routing strategy for power system restoration. The UAV routing strategy we proposed before considering the uses of UAVs on damaged component inspections, transmission line monitoring, and traffic monitoring together uses a fixed threshold of remaining energy as the judgmental condition. A fixed threshold cannot accurately reflect the energy consumed for UAVs returning to the depot. Therefore, this paper proposes a routing strategy considering the calculation of the energy consumed for returning, so that the UAV can implement more inspection or monitoring tasks. The calculation method is based on the analysis of the influence of wind speed on energy consumption. Afterwards, we test the proposed strategy using a real-life case calculation of energy in an area within Northeast China. The testing results show that using our proposed strategy, UAVs can perform more inspection and monitoring tasks in the post-disaster restoration cases.

title: Design and Implementation of a Compact Vector Network Analyzer Using a Voltage-Controlled Oscillator
authors: Sneha Shrikant Salvekar, Rajesh Ghongade
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: A Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) is an essential tool for analyzing the frequency response of RF and microwave circuits. However, commercial VNAs are often expensive and bulky. This paper presents a compact and cost-effective VNA design using a Voltage-Controlled Oscillator (VCO) as the primary signal source. The proposed system is capable of measuring S-parameters, making it suitable for small-scale RF circuit characterization. The design includes a microcontroller for signal processing and data visualization, along with a directional coupler for signal separation. Simulation results validate the performance of the proposed system.

title: Heart Rate Variability-Based Driver Drowsiness Detection Using Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Riadul Islam Rabbi, Em Poh Ping, Jakir Hossen
abstract: Driver drowsiness contributes significantly to road accidents, necessitating the development of effective real-time monitoring systems. Traditional drowsiness detection systems utilize behavioral or vehicular parameters but consistently lack real-time monitoring of actual physiological indicators. Heart Rate Variability (HRV) exhibits a great potential physiological marker to detect drowsiness because it shows how the autonomic nervous system operates while revealing changes in fatigue and alertness. The research analyses the application of real-time HRV data through different recurring neural network (RNN) architectural designs for driver drowsiness detection levels. The objective aims to identify driver drowsiness states, which include alert, early drowsiness, and severe drowsiness. The methodology incorporates three RNN architectures—Simple RNN, Bi-Directional RNN, and Deep RNN—alongside a preprocessing approach using a band-pass filter on heart rate data. Additionally, the Lomb-Scargle Periodogram method is applied in the frequency domain to extract features. Experimental findings show that a simple RNN achieves 86% of the accuracy through Adam optimizer training, and a bidirectional RNN reaches 87.00 % accuracy with the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) optimizer. Deep RNN demonstrated the most promising performance, achieving a classification accuracy of 95.68%. These findings reveal the potential of deep learning-based methods to detect drowsiness in real time through physiological signals. The study underscores that deep RNNs are highly effective in extracting temporal patterns from HRV data, enabling advances in driver monitoring systems with enhanced road safety benefits.

title: Sentence-based Sign Language Recognition using CNN and NLP
authors: Salma Jahan Nisha, N. D. Salih, Wan-Noorshahida Mohd-Isa
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive real-time sign language gesture recognition framework using a combination of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Natural Language Processing (NLP). Although individual letter level sign recognition has seen considerable advancements, interpreting sign language sentences remains a challenging and underexplored area. Our proposed approach utilizes a CNN-based model to capture both spatial and temporal features from real-time inputs, transforming dynamic sequences of hand gestures into coherent short textual sentences using NLP. Leveraging key Python libraries such as Tensorflow, OpenCV, LLM and LabelImg, the system efficiently extracts important key point features to recognize gestures and convert them into sentences in sign language. Experimental evaluations demonstrate the potential of our framework as possible means to reduce communication barriers and expand the beneficial possibilities in technologies for individuals with hearing impairments.

title: LSTM-Aided Speech Enhancement with Wiener Filter Adaptation & Learned Loss Function
authors: V. R. Prakash, S. Sasikumar, Thangavel Bhuvaneswari, Krishna Bharath G, Srikanth V S, Balaji Ganesan
abstract: Voice augmentation is the process of strengthening voice signals that have been affected by background noise. This work presents a deep learning-based speech signal augmentation model that is innovative. The proposed model consists of two phases: Training (i) and Testing (ii). In the training phase, the noisy input signal is processed using a Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) to estimate the signal and noise spectrums. The Wiener filter's features are then extracted using the Empirical Mean Decomposition (EMD) method. The Fractional Delta AMS characteristics are retrieved, the de-noised signal is obtained from the EMD, and the bark frequency is evaluated. Here, in this paper we’re using "Learning with Learned Loss Function", for improving PESQ score. The key contribution of this study is the precise estimate of the tuning factor η for the Wiener filter using the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model for each input signal. The extracted features (EMD), which were trained on the LSTM using a modified wiener filter to break down the spectral input, provide the denoised improved speech signal. A comparative analysis is carried out between the proposed and existing models with respect to error metrics.

title: Progressive Distillation Attention for Robust Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Estimation
authors: Shubham Basak, Nushrat Hussain, Ujjwal Bhattacharya
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Near accurate estimation of left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) from echocardiography is essential for the assessment of cardiovascular risks, but remains highly dependent on expert interpretation. We propose a lightweight encoder-decoder architecture with attention-guided skip refinements for robust left ventricle segmentation and automated LVEF computation from echocardiogram video and image samples. Unlike conventional U-Net models, our approach integrates dense connections, feedback loops, and Progressive Distillation Attention Blocks (PDABs). The PDAB modules selectively refine shallow encoder features before fusion with decoder representations, enabling progressive distillation of fine spatial details and deeper semantic cues. This refinement strategy ensures the precise delineation of ventricular boundaries even in low-quality echocardiographic frames, directly improving the reliability of the estimation of ejection fraction. With only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 4 M}$</tex> parameters, our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods. In the EchoNet-Dynamic dataset, it achieves a 15.85 % improvement in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> with 69.4 % and 4.6% reductions in MAE and RMSE, respectively. In the CAMUS dataset, it reduces MAE by 79.06 % while improving Pearson's correlation coefficient and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> by 19.51 % and 1.02 %, respectively. These results demonstrate that the PDAB-enhanced method provides a compact and accurate solution for automated LVEF estimation from echocardiography.

title: Hardware Implementation of the Hungarian Algorithm for Optimum Task Assignments
authors: Lluís Ribas-Xirgo
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: Optimal solutions of task assignment problems like, e.g., subcarrier allocation for OFDM, are solved in polynomial time with the Hungarian algorithm. The sequential nature of the related procedure makes it difficult to accelerate its execution. In this work, several hardware implementations of a state version of the algorithm are presented and compared. Results show that the single-memory architecture delivers similar energy consumption than the software version, but multi-block memory systems can significantly cut execution times as well as hardware resources.

title: A Lightweight AES Peripheral for RISC-V Cores and IoT Applications
authors: Carlos Fernández-García, Carmen Baena Oliva, Pilar Parra Fernández, Carlos. J. Jiménez-Fernández
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: In this article, we present a lightweight peripheral of the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm suitable for its implementation as a memory mapped peripheral in RISC-V cores. The peripheral is based on an 8-bit serial implementation of AES, which achieves a drastic reduction in the time required to encrypt a message with a reduced increase in resource consumption. The peripheral is compared in terms of resource utilization and timing with a software implementation of AES, tinyAES-c, and a hardware implementation that employs a more common 128-bit datapath using the Series-7 FPGA technology of the manufacturer AMD-Xilinx. The results show that the system using the peripheral achieves a speed 71.84 times faster than the software implementation, with a 46.37% increase over the logic used to implement the RISC-V processor.

title: Prototyping a Traceability System for Coffee Value Chain: A Case Study of Local Farmers in Pangkhon, Chiang Rai
authors: Phusanee Surarityothin, Damrongpol Kamhangwong, Santichai Wicha
abstract: The coffee industry plays a crucial role in the global agricultural sector, and the demand for traceability and value-added products has increased. This research focuses on prototyping a traceability system for the coffee value chain in Pangkhon, Chiang Rai, to improve transparency, enhance quality, support sustainability, and add value to the coffee produced in this region. The research methodology consists of data collection, design and prototypes, and prototype evaluation. In the data collection phase, information is gathered on objectives, regulatory requirements, products/ingredients, position in the food chain, the flow of materials, information requirements, procedures, documentation, and feed and food chain coordination. Based on the collected data, prototypes of the traceability system are designed and developed, incorporating the principles and requirements of ISO 22005: Traceability in the Feed and food chain. The prototypes are then evaluated through a survey of local stakeholders in the Pangkhon coffee supply chain, utilizing the User Acceptance Model and statistical analysis techniques. The expected outcomes of this research include increased transparency in the coffee supply chain, value addition to the coffee from Pangkhon, and insights into the acceptance and usability of the traceability system prototypes. The findings from this research will contribute to developing effective traceability systems in the coffee industry, promoting sustainability, trust, and consumer confidence in coffee products.

title: Research on the Integrated Form of Source-Grid-Load-Energy Storage in Industrial Parks and Grid Transaction Coordination Strategies
authors: Hongrong Fu, Xiangxiang Liu, Limin Deng
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: This paper explores the challenges posed by renewable energy grid integration to grid stability and proposes a solution that enables industrial parks to operate in synergy with the grid through an integrated source-grid-load-storage approach. The solution optimizes distributed generation, energy storage, and flexible loads to construct a multi-subject interaction model, achieving peak shaving and valley filling, increasing electricity consumption during off-peak hours, and thereby enhancing economic benefits. This solution not only improves the energy efficiency and power supply reliability of the industrial park but also provides flexibility to the power grid, contributing to the development of a more stable and efficient energy system.

title: Improved Wind Power Prediction based on Privacy Protection and Federated Transfer Learning
authors: Qishan Xu, Fengliang Xu, Peng Wang, Jianghua Hua
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Addressing the issue of data privacy leakage faced by wind turbine clusters during knowledge transfer, a federated transfer learning method consisting of global model training based on federated learning and personalized adaptation based on transfer learning is proposed to achieve wind power prediction. In terms of model structure, a serial network composed of a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) is proposed to extract temporal variation patterns from wind power data. In terms of knowledge transfer, a federated learning mechanism is introduced to learn shared knowledge among multiple wind turbines while protecting data privacy, thereby addressing the issue of insufficient samples. A parameter fine-tuning strategy is utilized to achieve personalized adaptation of shared knowledge, thereby improving the prediction accuracy of the model on the target wind turbine. Experiments show that compared to traditional local training frameworks, the accuracy improvement of the federated transfer learning framework can reach up to 43.32%.

title: Real-Time Nuclei Classification and Allred Scoring in PR-IHC Stained Breast Cancer Histopathology Images
authors: Hasanul Bannah, Mohammad Faizal Ahmad Fauzi, Sarina Binti Mansor, Md Serajun Nabi, Md. Sabbir Hossen, Istiyak Amin Santo, Seow Fan Chiew, Lai Meng Looi
abstract: Progesterone receptor immunohistochemistry (PR-IHC) of breast cancer tissue requires precise nuclei classification and Allred scoring for biomarker quantification and clinical decision-making. However, these tasks are still difficult because of overlap, heterogeneous nuclear morphology, and variations in diaminobenzidine (DAB) staining. Using auto-calibrated DAB-intensity thresholds, we propose a real-time, lightweight framework for classifying individual nuclei into Strong, Moderate, Weak, and Negative categories. The pipeline separates the DAB signal, extracts nuclear contours, aggregates per-nucleus intensity, and uses calibrated, intensity-driven decision-making to assign a single label. By combining the percentage of positive nuclei with their dominant staining intensity, we calculate ROI-level Allred scores, building on the nucleus-level outputs. The University of Malaya Medical Centre (UMMC) provided the primary dataset, and a hybrid automated-manual workflow with expert validation was used to create pixel-based ground truth for 250 PR-IHC images. This approach consistently performs well on a held-out test split (macro-F1 = 0.948; overall IoU = 0.906). The results demonstrate the usefulness of intensitydriven, computationally efficient techniques for Allred scoring and nucleus classification in digital pathology workflows. Instant Allred scoring without sophisticated computation is made possible by the lightweight design, which makes it appropriate for overloaded hospitals and clinics with limited resources.

title: Parameter Optimization Design of Bidirectional CLLC Resonant Converter
authors: Haoyu Shi, Zhihua Li, Nan Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper proposes a parameter optimization design method based on an accurate efficiency model of the converter to address the inadequacy of solely qualitative efficiency analysis in traditional parameter optimization designs for the bidirectional CLLC resonant converter. Firstly, the working principle and characteristics of bidirectional CLLC resonant converters are elaborated in detail. The efficiency model of the converter is accurately constructed using the parameters K and Q. Additionally, the mathematical expressions related to the design constraints of the converter concerning the parameters K and Q are proposed. The optimal design of the converter is found based on the efficiency model in satisfying the constraints, and the specific design flow is given. Finally, through simulation and experimental verification, it is demonstrated that the proposed design method can realize the soft switching of the device and ensure the stable operation of the system while satisfying the high efficiency and high power density.

title: Using Gamification for Creating A Cyber Scam Awareness
authors: Xin Lyu, Arthorn Luangsodsai, Pattarasinee Bhattarakosol
abstract: With the growing use of internet technology and mobile payments, online scams have become increasingly prevalent, particularly during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. While law enforcement continues to intensify efforts against cybercrime, relying solely on punitive measures is insufficient. Enhancing public awareness and promoting preventive education are essential complements. This study introduces a gamified educational game designed to improve users' ability to recognize and respond to online scams. A practical cybersecurity training model using gamification to support scam prevention has been proposed. The game simulates five common scam scenarios, allowing users to acquire anti-scam knowledge through interactive decision-making. A preliminary study shows that gamified learning enhances motivation, engagement, and knowledge retention compared to traditional methods.

title: Design and Development of a Review-Target Knowledge Map Application for Mathematics Learning: Visualization Using Subjective Comprehension and Answer Accuracy
authors: Miruri Tada, Masanori Takagi
abstract: In recent years, with the advancement of the GIGA School Initiative in Japan, the need to support students in understanding their own learning status and enabling self-regulated learning through the use of learning logs has grown increasingly important. In mathematics education in particular, acquiring new knowledge often depends on a solid understanding of prerequisite concepts. A lack of mastery in these foundational areas frequently leads to learning difficulties. Nonetheless, it is not easy for learners to identify which prerequisite knowledge needs to be reviewed, nor to independently select the next problem to tackle. This study proposes a Review-Target Knowledge Map (RTK Map) application, which utilizes subjective comprehension status (SCS) and binary scoring, recorded during problem-solving, to support learners in identifying their own review-target knowledge (RTK) and selecting which problems to work on. This system allows learners to record their SCS after solving each problem, then visualizes the knowledge and problems that require review based on that information and binary scoring. As a result of an implementation of this method in junior high school mathematics classes, SCS was recorded for approximately 17.7% of the problems, and positive responses were observed, such as students recognizing their areas of weakness and developing a motivation to review. In the future, we plan to apply this approach to physics learning and verify the effectiveness of the application through practical implementation at a high school.

title: Numerical Simulation Study on Pressure Drop and Heat Transfer Characteristics of Packed Bed Thermal Energy Storage Tank
authors: Zhonghua Zhao, Zhijie Zheng, Xinguang Dong, Pu Zhao, Chunxiao Tian, Limeng Zhang, Yuetao Shi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Against the backdrop of an increasing share of wind and solar power generation, packed bed thermal energy storage technology is regarded as a highly promising solution for addressing the intermittency and variability inherent in power production. This study employs computational fluid dynamics (CFD) based on a local thermal non-equilibrium model to numerically investigate the resistance and heat transfer characteristics of a packed bed thermal energy storage tank. This paper focuses on the impact of particle diameter (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-4 ~\text{cm}$</tex>) and heat transfer fluid velocity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{0. 0 0 0 2 - 0. 0 0 0 8 ~ m} / \mathrm{s})$</tex> on system performance. The results indicate that: (1) In terms of resistance characteristics, the pressure drop decreases non-linearly with increasing particle diameter (from 15.08 Pa at 1 cm to 4.07 Pa at 2 cm, and further to 1.16 Pa at 4 cm), while it increases almost linearly with fluid velocity; (2) Regarding heat transfer characteristics, increasing the particle diameter leads to a thicker thermal stratification layer and a significant reduction in charging and discharging efficiency (with a 31.3% drop in discharging efficiency), although it shortens the overall thermal storage and release time. In contrast, increasing the fluid velocity reduces the operation cycle, slightly increases the thermal layer thickness, but results in a relatively minor efficiency decline <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\leq 4 \%)$</tex>; (3) The influence of particle diameter on efficiency is more pronounced than that of fluid velocity. Smaller particles (1 cm) yield higher charging and discharging efficiencies (0.94 and 0.83, respectively). From the perspective of balancing flow resistance and heat transfer performance, it is recommended that the diameter of the solid packing particles should not exceed 2 cm. The study demonstrates that the synergistic optimization of particle size and flow velocity is crucial for achieving high efficiency and low resistance, providing a theoretical foundation for the engineering application of packed bed thermal energy storage systems.

title: Wireless Attack Simulation of WiFi Threats: A Real-Time Scenario
authors: Abhyudaya Tiwari, Piyush Bafna, Anuj Baheti, Ayush Pareek, Archana Ratnaparkhi
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Wireless networks are more and more susceptible to numerous types of cyber attacks because they are open and shared. This work addresses the simulation in real time of four prominent wireless network attacks: Packet Sniffing, Deauthentication Attack, Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) Attack, and Evil Twin Attack. Utilizing Python and its networking libraries, we create an interactive system that simulates these attacks with randomized parameters to simulate real-world variation. The simulation provides dynamic feedback on attack success, detection probability, and possible data loss, enabling real-world analysis of each technique's effect. Our approach closes the gap between theoretical security models and real-world network contexts and offers an educational and research-based environment to study wireless vulnerability. Performance outcomes identify attack patterns under varied network settings and the capability of the framework to represent attacker strategy and network resilience.

title: Inverse Modeling of 2D Lubrication Film Using Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Haoyang Huang, Zhengjia Ji
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: To accurately evaluate the working conditions of the lubrication film under point contact scenarios, an inverse modeling framework composed of a Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)-based encoder and a ResNet-based decoder is proposed. The model achieves a prediction accuracy exceeding 0.99 for key parameters including the load w, velocity u, and the relative elastic modulus $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}$. Furthermore, computational result analysis demonstrates that the proposed model is suitable for resource-constrained or edge-computing environments. This enables its potential application in intelligent condition monitoring and real-time lubrication evaluation for mechanical systems.

title: Evaluation of Ester Dielectric Liquids for Sustainable Nanosecond Pulsed Power Systems
authors: Chris Williamson, Martin J. Given, Scott J. MacGregor
abstract: The breakdown and degradation characteristics of ester-based dielectric liquids subjected to nanosecond impulses have been investigated and compared with those of conventional mineral oil. Experiments were performed using a ten-stage Marx generator delivering impulses across electrode configurations with varying field utilization factors. Two complementary studies were undertaken. First, a breakdown study was conducted, in which breakdown voltage, time to breakdown, and peak breakdown current were measured under both positive and negative polarities. Following this, a degradation study, where each liquid was subjected to 500 consecutive impulses prior to reevaluation under 25-kV ac partial discharge (PD) diagnostics, was undertaken. Results confirm the strong polarity dependence of nanosecond impulse breakdown, with higher breakdown voltages and longer time to breakdown observed under negative polarity. Ester liquids exhibited breakdown voltages comparable to mineral oil, but with consistently shorter delay times, indicating faster streamer initiation. In degradation tests, electrode conditioning produced apparent increases in breakdown voltage; however, PD measurements revealed that mineral oil experienced significantly greater deterioration, with larger increases in both peak and average PD. In contrast, both natural and synthetic esters showed more moderate degradation, with synthetic ester demonstrating the highest stability. The findings support the use of ester liquids as technically viable alternatives to mineral oil for pulsed power insulation applications.

title: High-energy chirped nanosecond pulsed laser system for particle diagnostics and manipulation
authors: Stefan Karatodorov, Marios Kounalakis, Gabriel M. Flores Alfaro, Yingjie Zhao, Atulya Kumar, Ashwini Vaishnav, Jeremy Ramos, Alexandros Gerakis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Direct measurement of the particle velocity distribution function (VDF) of neutral gases and plasmas allows for their thermodynamic characterization (temperature, density, and velocity vector) and is of crucial importance for fields such as aeronautics, aerospace, microelectronics, etc. In recent years, the mechanical probes that have formed the state of the art — Pitot tubes, hot wires, Langmuir probes, etc. — are steadily being replaced by laser-based diagnostic techniques. Among the latter, single-shot coherent Rayleigh-Brillouin scattering (CRBS), a four-wave mixing technique, has been demonstrated to perform VDF characterization of atomic and molecular species within a single laser shot (∼ 100 ns). CRBS requires the use of highly specialized laser systems capable of generating laser beams with controllable chirps, variable pulse duration, controllable pulse shaping, and high pulse energies. However, the characterization of environments exhibiting fast flows, such as gas boundary layers, or low particle number densities, such as low-temperature glow discharges, have proven extremely challenging with current state-of-the-art laser systems mainly due to the need for pulse energies beyond 1 J. In this work, we report on the improvement of a custom nanosecond-pulsed laser system tailored for optical particle diagnostics and manipulation, and which is capable of pulse energies exceeding 2 Joule/pulse. In addition to the notable output energy, the laser system is capable of generating laser pulses with customizable temporal profiles and variable durations (10 ns to 1 μs), with a chirping range of several GHz over the pulse duration. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the highest reported energy per pulse generated by a lab-scale frequency-chirped laser source at nanosecond timescales. The expanded output energy range is anticipated to greatly broaden the laser system’s application potential via CRBS for thermodynamic diagnostics of both supersonic/hypersonic gas flows in wind tunnel and shock-tube facilities, as well as plasma species in space-like conditions, e.g. ion thrusters.

title: Automated Pneumonia Detection with Transformer-CNN Architecture
authors: M. Uma Maheshwari, R. Tamilselvi, M. Parisabeham, K. Shanmugapriya, C. Senthilpari, Lee Chu Liang
abstract: Pneumonia detection from chest X-rays remains a challenging task due to variations in image quality, overlapping features, and the need for precise localization of affected regions. Traditional CNN-based models, while effective, often struggle with capturing long-range dependencies and global contextual information. Transformer models, on the other hand, excel in self-attention mechanisms but require extensive data and computational resources. To address these limitations, we propose an improved hybrid Transformer-CNN model that integrates the local feature extraction capability of CNNs with the global attention mechanisms of Transformers. Multi-scale feature fusion enhances representation learning, while contrastive learning improves model robustness. Additionally, a Bayesian segmentation approach refines the localization of pneumonia-affected lung regions, improving interpretability. Knowledge distillation is employed to enable lightweight deployment without compromising performance. Experimental results on benchmark chest X-ray datasets show that our proposed model achieves a classification accuracy of 94.8%, outperforming traditional CNNs by 6.5% and standalone Transformers by 4.2%. The segmentation precision is improved by 7.3%, enabling more accurate identification of pneumonia-affected areas. These advancements contribute to a more reliable and interpretable AI-driven pneumonia detection system.

authors: N/A

title: Hybrid Feature-Based Machine Learning for Real-Time Biometric Facial Liveness Detection
authors: Md Farman Ali, Jahid Hassan Noor, Md Serajun Nabi, Hezerul Bin Abdul Karim, Sadia Afrin Samia, S M Nadim Mahmud
abstract: Face recognition is now the most used biometric mode; however, it is vulnerable to spoofing. Spoofing attacks include image-printed attacks, video replay attacks, 3D mask attacks, and so on, necessitating the implementation of appropriate anti-spoofing methods. Previous methods for early liveness identification used handcrafted techniques such as Local Binary Patterns (LBP) or Histogram of Orientated Gradients (HOG) to analyze texture variations between real and synthetic faces. Without a doubt, these methods were computationally efficient, but they proved ineffective against sophisticated attacks such as high-resolution printouts or 3D masks. Aside from the methodologies used in the referred models, researchers interested in improving face identification presented CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks) solutions. However, despite their high accuracy in terms of outcomes, deep-learning methods are computationally expensive, require large amounts of data, and are not generalizable when compared to other spoofing approaches. As a result, the paper suggests a lightweight strategy that does not use deep learning but integrates security, efficiency, and scalability into the output. It distinguishes between authentic, and spoof faces by utilizing handmade extraction techniques such as histograms of orientated gradients (HOG), local binary patterns (LBP), and Gabor. These collected characteristics are identified using machine learning-optimized ensemble models such as Support Vector Machines (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and XGBoost, which ensure high generalization while requiring minimal CPU resources. This model is up to 99% efficient in terms of accuracy and processing resources. This is one of the first experiments to achieve more than 99% accuracy in facial recognition using a lightweight, non-deep learning technique. Unlike prior research, which concentrated on CNNs or specialized customized techniques, our hybrid system combines LBP, HOG, and Gabor features with ensemble machine learning classifiers (SVM, RF, XGBoost) to provide real-time, scalable security suitable for low-resource applications. Keywords: Facial Liveness Detection, Biometric Security, Anti-spoofing, Digital Identity.

title: Lithium Battery Energy Storage Packaging: Innovative Precise Sorting Technique
authors: Amirhossein Rahimian Zarif, Yasser Mafinejad
abstract: Lithium batteries (LIBs) have gained significant attention in the global research community due to their high energy density and efficient power delivery. This study addresses the persistent challenges associated with accurately measuring the resistance of LIBs, a critical issue in the grading and sorting processes. The primary objective of this research is to increase measurement speed, enhance accuracy, and minimize errors by leveraging key battery charge and discharge parameters. Major gaps have been identified in the processes of measuring internal resistance and sampling, particularly in terms of accuracy, speed, and cost, within the battery energy storage manufacturing industry. To overcome these challenges, a novel hybrid methodology is proposed, combining advanced curve fitting technique with precise internal resistance measurement. The effectiveness of the proposed method was validated through a comparative analysis with traditional measurement approaches. The findings reveal a significant accomplishment, achieving an accuracy of approximately 0.2 milliohms, marking 90.00 percent improvement compared to traditional methods. Additionally, another test revealed 90.99 percent improvement in the accuracy and reliability of sampling parameters, further confirming the efficacy of the proposed method. Practical outcomes indicate that the proposed approach excels in measurement accuracy, speed, error reduction, and overall efficiency. These findings emphasize the method's potential as a significant advancement in the field, highlighting its ability to improve measurement precision, speed, and operational efficiency.

title: SVM-LSTM with SHAP for Dynamic API Security Whitelisting in AWS
authors: Wei Pin Chow, Chee Yong Lau, Sek Kit Teh, Chun Lim Siow
abstract: Ensuring robust security for API Gateways is critical as they remain vulnerable to sophisticated cyber threats. This paper proposes a hybrid SVM-LSTM model to enhance anomaly detection for dynamic whitelisting and blacklisting in API security. The model leverages SVM for static classification and LSTM for temporal pattern recognition, significantly improving detection accuracy. Additionally, SHAP analysis enhances model interpretability by identifying key contributing features. Evaluated on publicly available CloudTrail logs, the proposed SVM-3LSTM model achieves 99.865% accuracy, 99.440% precision, 92.116% recall, and 95.638% F1-score, demonstrating superior performance in threat detection and mitigation. Notably, "eventname" was identified as the most influential feature, ensuring a more transparent and reliable API security system.

title: High Voltage Gain DC-DC Converter for Enhanced Efficiency in Renewable Energy and Electric Vehicle Systems
authors: Abbas Seif, Hamid Radmanesh
abstract: DC-DC converters are essential components in various applications, including renewable energy systems, electric vehicles, and industrial power supplies. Traditional hard-switching converters, however, suffer from significant switching losses and electromagnetic interference (EMI) at high frequencies, limiting their efficiency. This research explores soft-switching techniques to overcome these limitations, enabling high-frequency operation with reduced switching losses and component stress. The primary objective is to develop novel soft-switching DC-DC converter topologies that enhance voltage gain and overall efficiency while maintaining simplicity and cost-effectiveness. This study proposes a novel soft-switching converter topology integrating coupled inductors and switched capacitors to achieve high voltage gain, continuous input current, and reduced voltage stress on components. 1 A detailed design methodology, encompassing both theoretical analysis and simulation, is employed to evaluate key performance parameters, including voltage gain, efficiency, and switching stress. The proposed converter demonstrates a significant efficiency improvement, reaching up to 95%, and a 20% reduction in switching losses compared to conventional hard-switching converters. Furthermore, the single-switch design simplifies control circuitry and lowers implementation costs. 2 This work presents a practical and cost-effective solution for high-efficiency power conversion, particularly beneficial in applications constrained by space and thermal management considerations.

title: PA-Boot: A Formally Verified Authentication Protocol for Multiprocessor Secure Boot under Hardware Supply-chain Attacks
authors: Zhuoruo Zhang, Rui Chang, Mingshuai Chen, Wenbo Shen, Chenyang Yu, He Huang, Qinming Dai, Yongwang Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Hardware supply-chain attacks are raising significant security threats to the boot process of multiprocessor systems. In this paper, we investigate critical stages of the multiprocessor system boot process and identify a new, prevalent hardware supply-chain attack surface that can bypass secure boot due to the absence of processor-authentication mechanisms. To defend against such attacks, in this paper, we present PA-Boot, the first formally verified processor-authentication protocol for secure boot in multiprocessor systems. PA-Boot is proved functionally correct and is guaranteed to detect multiple adversarial behaviors, such as processor replacements and man-in-the-middle attacks. The fine-grained formalization of PA-Boot and its fully mechanized security proofs are carried out in the Isabelle/HOL theorem prover with 348 lemmas/theorems and ~7,100 LoC. We further implement in C an instance of PA-Boot. Experiments on the proof-of-concept implementation indicate that PA-Boot can effectively identify boot-process attacks with a minor overhead (4.98% on Linux boot process) and thereby improve the security of multiprocessor systems.

title: A Secure Multimodal Retrieval Framework for Consumer Electronics under AI-driven Attacks
authors: Guodong Wang, Dongyang Ma, Luo Zhou, Asma Hassan Alshehri, Wenhao Li
abstract: In the field of consumer electronics, multimodal retrieval systems are increasingly employed to support intuitive product search based on a combination of reference images and natural language queries. However, such systems are vulnerable to AI-driven attacks, including adversarial prompts and manipulated inputs that can mislead retrieval outcomes. To address this, we propose SHRC-Net, a secure and robust multimodal image retrieval framework that integrates Semantic Harmonization and Region Composition. The architecture comprises three core modules: a Semantic Harmonization Unit (SHU) that aligns textual semantics with fine-grained visual regions, an Adaptive Region Composer (ARC) that captures region-level dependencies under semantic guidance, and a Unified Training Objective (UTO) that incorporates alignment, attention regularization, and compositional classification losses. SHRC-Net builds target-aware representations that faithfully reflect user intent while enhancing resistance to adversarial manipulations. The framework is trained end-to-end without requiring additional annotations. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that SHRC-Net achieves state-of-the-art retrieval performance, while also exhibiting strong robustness against ambiguous or malicious queries. These results underscore its potential for secure deployment in AI-powered consumer electronics systems.
