title: Optimum Portfolio Weights and Hedge Ratios between Conventional and Non Conventional Assets
authors: Vaibhav Aggarwal, Sudhi Sharma, Parul Bhatia, Mahender Yadav, Shashank Sharma
abstract: There is growing interest in cryptocurrency as an asset class for investors in the emerging market of India. This study aims to identify the optimal portfolio weights and hedge ratio for long-only investors and long-short investor, in emerging Indian stocks and Bitcoin. We have used the BEKK-GARCH (1, 1) to investigate the volatility spillover. The daily closing price data for Sensex and Bitcoin has been taken for the period January 2020 to October 2024. The findings indicate the potential benefit of adding small proportion of bitcoin to a portfolio alongside stocks for investors in India. The results can help investors make better risk adjusted portfolio.

title: One-dimensional Residual Shrinkage Network for Electromechanical Actuator Fault Diagnosis
authors: Yunxiao Lian, Ni Li, Yong Zhou, Changyin Dong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: Electrical faults are widely found in motors and electromechanical actuators. However, existing machine learning diagnostic methods are unable to specifically extract current fault features. To solve this issue, an improved one-dimensional residual shrinkage network algorithm is proposed to diagnose inter-turn short circuit and permanent magnet demagnetization faults. Specifically, the threshold-fitting network module is first designed to extract three-phase current fault features. This allows it to automatically adjust the threshold size according to current amplitude, ensuring effective extraction of fault features and achieving data compression. Additionally, a shrinkage module is embedded within the convolutional residual network to suppress noise, aiding in enhancing fault diagnosis accuracy. The proposed method is tested based on electromechanical actuator experimental platform. By comparing the proposed algorithm with the traditional convolutional network and residual network algorithms, it is verified that the proposed algorithm has stronger feature extraction capability and exhibits higher accuracy.

title: Hybrid Active Damping Control Algorithms for LC-Filtered Motor Drive with Two Rotating Masses
authors: Xiong Liu, Zhifeng Huang, Zhenhua Liang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: High dv/dt of voltage source motor drive inverter can be problematic for machine winding insulation, create severe EMI problems and machine bearing current issues. To address these problems, the common solution is to add the LC sine filter, forming the LCL topology with the stator winding inductance, thereby generating machine-friendly stator voltage waveform which requires active damping control. Meanwhile, the mechanical load is flexibly connected to the rotor, constituting a spring-mass elastic drivetrain that can generate torsional vibrations during transient condition. In the LC-filtered motor drive with mass-spring-mass system, both electrical and mechanical resonances coexist. This paper proposes the hybrid active damping scheme for such system. On this basis, hybrid active-damping algorithms are incorporated into the motor drive field-oriented control (FOC) framework, and the stabilities of both the electrical and the mechanical subsystems are analyzed. Furthermore, it proves that the LCL current control loop can be represented as a pure delay element, and demonstrates that speed-difference feedback active damping is equivalent to a virtual damping and a virtual stiffness, thereby providing a design guideline for oscillation suppressing of both electrical and mechanical resonances within a unified framework. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy is validated through simulations.

title: Fast Calculation of Electromagnetic Vibration of Hydro Generator Accounting for Pole-Slot Structure
authors: Xiaolong Zhao, Jianjun Liu, Jian Xiao, Yong Yang, Jin Wang, Libing Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper presents a fast and accurate analytical method for calculating electromagnetic vibration in hydro-generators accounting for pole-slot structure. A stator magnetic motive force (MMF) model is established using a complex phasor approach, enabling accurate representation under complex winding arrangements. For the rotor, a boundary element method (BEM) is developed to precisely model the rotor pole geometry and calculate both the MMF and air-gap permeance spectra. On the stator side, the Schwarz–Christoffel conformal mapping is employed to characterize the slot geometry and derive the harmonic components of air-gap permeance. Additionally, the influence of the damper winding is quantified through an equivalent asynchronous induction circuit model, improving the accuracy of harmonic MMF estimation. The synthesized air-gap flux density is used to derive electromagnetic force waves via Maxwell stress analysis. Comparisons with finite element analysis (FEA) results confirm the method’s accuracy. Furthermore, the natural frequencies and vibration responses of the hydro-generator are calculated analytically and validated against measurements from a large-scale machine, demonstrating strong agreement and practical applicability.

title: An Alternative Cardinal Spline for Cubic B-Spline Interpolation
authors: Juanjuan Chen, Qiumei Li, Junjuan Chen, Wei Qi Yan
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: This paper aims at introducing a special cubic cardinal spline from the GMK-splines, which is able to obtain almost the same interpolation results of the cubic B-spline, but without solving the system of equations for getting control vertices, and exploring its applications in geometric modeling and image processing. The spline involved can be obtained by using a linear combination of several shifted B-splines of the same degree. The spatial and frequency domain comparison demonstrates its superior local support and frequency domain performance. In addition, a number of examples are involved in geometric modeling and digital image processing, compared with a few conventional methods. As shown in this paper, the cubic cardinal spline is an alternative choice instead of the cubic B-spline in the interpolation procedure in order to avoid solving the system of equations over and over again.

title: Safety Compliance Assessment of Fibre Distribution Panel Installations Using Computer Vision
authors: Azib-Jazman Azmawi, Wan-Noorshahida Mohd-Isa, Abdul Aziz Abdul Rahman
abstract: The telecommunication industry in Malaysia plays a pivotal role in providing essential Internet and communication services. Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are increasingly adopting on Fibre Distribution Panels (FDPs) to deliver high-speed Internet to homes and businesses. Each new FDP installation requires an assessment to ensure safety and readiness of these setups. However, current methods rely on manual measurements, making the process inefficient and resource-intensive. While automated safety assessment systems are common in other industries, their application in the telecom sector remains largely unexplored. This study addresses the hap by introducing a computer vision-based approach to automate the safety distance assessment for FDP installations. With deep learning models, the system detects components and applies low-level image processing, the Line-Line intersection algorithm and Euclidean Distance to extract object width in pixel units. The system then checks for violations by determining whether other components violates the minimum required spacing set by the company. Experimental results using real-world data demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 0.6 accuracy in component width retrieval at almost 12s per installation. Our overall installation quality assessment error rate is less than 0.35, mostly owing to object detection errors in identifying essential components. The system also cuts assessments time in half compared to traditional methods. This research enhances efficiency safety and service quality in the telecom industry, offering a scalable solution for reliable and timely FDP installation inspections.

title: Design and Comparative Analyses of Programmable Frequency Divider using mGDI Technology for Modern Electronics
authors: Bhavya Doshi, Aunja Askhedkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: This work analyzes the design and creation of a programmable frequency divider circuit at the 45nm technology node using Modified Gate Diffusion Input (mGDI) logic. By reducing propagation latency, dynamic power consumption, and area, this design aimed to solve the drawbacks of conventional CMOS technology. The design is made up of fundamental digital building pieces, such as multiplexers, logic gates, and D flip-flops, which were all created using the mGDI design flow and principles. The design was verified using schematic simulations in the Cadence Virtuoso environment. In comparison to the CMOS divider, the mGDI divider has a 90.78% lower power consumption and near about same latency as of CMOS design. This design is especially appropriate for wearable electronics because of its little power consumption, rendering it highly pertinent for contemporary, portable, and energy-limited applications. According to the results, mGDI provides a competitive alternative to CMOS in the creation of compact, powerful, and energy efficient VLSI architectures. Its improved efficiency, scalability, and appropriateness for next generation semiconductor systems are confirmed by comparison with conventional CMOS implementations.

title: Chaos-Enhanced Approach To Audio Fingerprinting for Robust Music Identification
authors: Vishnudasan K, Sitadevi Bharatula, B. Naresh Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: Audio fingerprinting is a leap in music identification, copyright protection, and content-based retrieval. Existing methods rely primarily on spectral peaks and hash-based approaches, which are sensitive to noise, distortion, and temporal variations. In this paper, the introduction of a chaos-based audio fingerprinting system providing improved robustness and accuracy using chaotic transformations. The system derives spectral peaks from the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) and applies a chaotic map transformation for feature hashing to ensure robust and unique fingerprint generation. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves 99.72% confidence in matching audio segments even in the presence of temporal variations. The proposed method demonstrates improved performance compared to existing methods in managing time shifts, Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) and is a good candidate for real-world applications in music retrieval, audio forensics, and content recognition.

title: Leveraging Multi-Channel Image Representations to Enhance Robustness in Tabular Data Classification
authors: Zengshuai Wang, Peter Xiaoping Liu, Minhua Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: This paper presents TabImgF, a novel deep tabular data modeling architecture designed for classification tasks involving categorical features. The method adopts a dual-branch strategy to process categorical and continuous features separately. Specifically, categorical features are first transformed into multi-channel image representations using an ImgEncoding module, followed by a convolutional neural network that captures combinatorial patterns and high-level semantic representations. Continuous features are encoded using a fully connected network. The outputs of both branches are concatenated and passed into a classification head, enabling end-to-end training and prediction. Experimental results on five public datasets show that TabImgF achieves at least a 1.8% improvement in average AUC over state-of-the-art deep learning methods and outperforms leading tree-ensemble models. Robustness experiments further demonstrate that TabImgF maintains strong performance in the presence of missing or noisy categorical inputs, confirming its stability and applicability in complex scenarios.

title: A VLM Framework for Crack Segmentation and Description with Hierarchical Switching Mechanism
authors: Aohan Li, Shuo Ma, Teng Li, Yuxin Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: The precise monitoring of cracks is of great significance for the maintenance of infrastructure safety. However, the current crack detection methods and monitoring approaches mainly focus on the contour segmentation of cracks, lacking specific descriptions of the condition of the cracks. To tackle this problem, we propose a framework based on a vision-language model (VLM) with hierarchical switching mechanism (HSM), which has both contour segmentation and semantic description tasks. To improve the monitoring accuracy of crack analysis and optimize the fine-tuning process of the model, we also introduce a contrastive loss function involving both image and text inputs. The verification experiments conduct on the real crack dataset show that this architecture has higher accuracy and reliability for the contour segmentation of cracks compared with the traditional methods.

title: Confidence-Aware SSD Ensemble with Weighted Boxes Fusion for Weapon Detection
authors: Atharva Jadhav, Arush Karekar, Manas Divekar, Shachi Natu
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: The safety and security of public spaces is of vital importance, driving the need for sophisticated surveillance systems capable of accurately detecting weapons, which are often hampered by issues like partial occlusion, varying lighting, and cluttered backgrounds. While single-model detectors are advanced, they often lack robustness in these challenging conditions. This paper presents the hypothesis that ensemble of Single Shot Multibox Detector (SSD) models with diverse feature extraction backbones can significantly enhance detection robustness. To leverage diverse feature representations, individual SSD models were trained using a selection of backbone networks: VGG16, ResNet50, EfficientNet, and MobileNetV3. The study is conducted on a dataset consisting of images of three distinct weapon classes: guns, heavy weapons and knives. The predictions from these models are combined using the Weighted Boxes Fusion (WBF) method, an ensemble technique designed to optimize bounding box accuracy. Our key finding is that the fusion strategy is as critical as the ensemble's diversity, a WBF approach using a ‘max’ confidence scoring strategy achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.838. This represents a 2.948% relative improvement over the best-performing single model and consistently outperforms other fusion heuristics. This research offers a robust approach to enhancing real-time weapon detection capabilities in surveillance applications by demonstrating that confidence-aware fusion is a key mechanism for improving accuracy metrics of ensembles.

title: Evaluating Online Content Accessibility Using WCAG 2.1: A Case Study of University Platforms and an e-Learning System for Students with Visual Impairments
authors: Piyarat Thammachokmongkol, Werapat Lapawong, Worasak Rueangsirarak
abstract: This study validated the use of Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 to evaluate online content accessibility across three platforms: the University's Official Website, the University-LMS, and the Foundation for Children with Disabilities' e-Learning system. This paper adopted the Level A and AA standards to ensure access for visually impaired students. Evaluation methods combined automated tools (WAVE) with manual checks of key pages, including Homepage, Course, Assignment, and Examination functions. Findings showed that the University-LMS posed the most accessibility challenges, notably missing alternative text, weak keyboard navigation, and low color contrast. In contrast, the University's Official Website nearly met all AA standards and served as a reliable benchmark. An online survey was conducted with 18 participants (four lecturers, two teaching assistants, and twelve visually impaired students) to confirm the evaluation results and gather feedback based on real-world usage. Survey responses reinforced experimental findings, highlighting LMS issues such as unclear navigation, missing form labels, and insufficient link descriptions. These barriers created greater difficulties for visually impaired users than the University's Website, which was more compliant with WCAG standards. Although limited in scope, the study underscores the pressing need to improve LMS accessibility. It suggests expanding future research to include a broader range of users, higher WCAG levels, and more inclusive design guidelines.

title: Cloud Platform Computing Resource Allocation Strategy for Multi-Controllable Load Regulation
authors: Siwei Li, Xiaoming Wang, Xirun Zhang, Wenguang Zhao, Zhaoqing Chen, Lishi Du
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: This article proposes a cloud-edge collaborative load resource allocation strategy for the regulation of controllable loads such as electric vehicles and air conditioners. The results of the case study analysis show that the completion time of the computing task is the shortest under the same computing task but different numbers of resource nodes, and the completion time of the computing task is the shortest under the same number of resource nodes but different computing tasks. Therefore, in the process of allocating computing resources on the cloud platform, the limited cloud computing resources can be fully utilized, reducing the task completion time. It can efficiently manage and schedule computing resources, avoiding the high latency and network congestion problems that exist in the cloud control center when handling high-concurrency computing tasks.

title: Implicit Sentiment Classification in Hotel Reviews: A Comparative Analysis of Embedding Representations
authors: Jantima Polpinij, Benjawan Intara, Chunpong Chan, Dolsun Singhakam, Thananchai Khamket, Anirut Chothanom
abstract: Sentiment analysis of implicit sentiment in hotel reviews is quite challenging, as no explicit opinion words are present, so the model has to rely on context to determine the sentiment of the text. The research is about recognizing the implicit sentiment of the mentioned hotel aspects, i.e., staff service, cleanliness, value for money, and location, four critical areas of a hotel. To examine embedding representations, we have taken Word2Vec with TF-IDF, SciBERT, BERT, RoBERTa, and XLNet as examples and combined them with six different machine learning and deep learning models such as Logistic Regression, SVM, Random Forest, and CNN, etc. The performance was measured by using 10-fold cross-validation, and the evaluation metrics were F1-score, Accuracy, MCC, and AUC. The results show that embeddings derived from transformer-based models, especially RoBERTa and BERT, are more consistently better than those from classical methods, not only they achieve higher predictive stability but also are more robust when dealing with implicit sentiment. The best performance among non-neural methods was achieved by Word2Vec with TF-IDF, but the result was less stable. The evidence suggests that the deployment of contextualized embeddings is a very efficient way of capturing the subtle linguistic patterns that are required in an implicit sentiment field of research. This paper is a significant step forward for the romance of sentiment analysis in the hotel domain and opens up the field to reliable customer feedback systems development.

title: ANN-Assisted Compact Model of GaN HEMTs Across Wide Temperature Ranges
authors: Wei Zhao, Ziyue Zhao, Ting Feng, Yang Lu, Yilin Chen, Xuan Su, Zexiang Li, Chong Wang, Chupeng Yi, Xin Liu, Xiaohua Ma, Yue Hao
abstract: A temperature-dependent compact model for gallium nitride high-electron-mobility transistors (GaN HEMTs) based on artificial neural networks (ANNs) is presented. The model incorporates a novel analytically invertible transformation function to preprocess drain current and intrinsic capacitances, enabling accurate modeling across a wide dynamic range while maintaining a lightweight ANN architecture. Ambient temperature ( ${T}_{\text {amb}}\text {)}$ is explicitly incorporated as an input to capture the scaling of current and capacitances under different thermal conditions. The large-signal model is implemented in Verilog-A and validated using a 0.25- $\mu $ m SiC-based GaN HEMT with a $6\times 75~\mu $ m gate width. Measurements including dc-IV and small-signal S-parameter data at ${T}_{\text {amb}}$ from $25~^{\circ }$ C to $150~^{\circ }$ C are well reproduced. More importantly, large-signal load-pull experiments at 3.6 GHz confirm that the model reliably predicts output power, gain, and power-added efficiency (PAE) under different ${T}_{\text {amb}}$ conditions. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ANN-based compact model in addressing the temperature-dependent nonlinear behavior of GaN HEMTs for circuit design applications.

title: Modelling and Simulation of Heteromaterial Dual-Gate Dopingless TFET (HTDGDL-TFET) and its Application as Digital Inverter
authors: Suhana Mohamed Sultan, Fahim Shahriar, Wei Ting Teoh, Michael Loong Peng Tan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Tunnel Field-Effect Transistor (TFET) has been known as one of the promising devices which will be replacing conventional Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistor (MOSFET) as a future low-power and high-speed logic application. This is because as the size of MOSFET reduces decade by decade, to achieve better speed and lower power, and currently moving towards the nanometer regime, it has led to the limitation of the performance of MOSFET and faced a few bottlenecks. Therefore, TFET, which works on the principle of the tunnelling phenomenon, has been proposed as one of the devices to replace MOSFET, which works on the principle of thermionic emission that limits the device's sub-threshold swing to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60 \text{mV} /$</tex> decade. This work has been simulated using Silvaco TCAD tool. Single-Gate and Double-Gate heteromaterial dualgate dopingless TFET (HTDGDL-TFET) have been successfully modelled. Four simulation test cases have been done to select the best structure of the proposed TFET. Several important parameters such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text{th }}, S S, I_{\text{on }}, I_{\text{off }}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{\text{on }} / I_{\text{off }}$</tex> ratio, are used to measure the performance of TFET. Among all the 4 test cases, the best TFET structure is with Ge as source region material, source and drain region carrier concentration of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1} \times \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{1 9}} \mathbf{c m}^{-\mathbf{3}}$</tex> and channel carrier concentration of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 10^{17} ~\text{cm}^{-3}$</tex>. This is because the device shows <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text{th }}$</tex> value of 0.97 V, SS value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15 \text{mV} / \text{dec}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{I}_{\text{on }} / \mathrm{I}_{\text{off }}$</tex> ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \times 10^{11}$</tex>. The propagation delay for the designed TFET inverter is 75 times shorter than the inverter from published data and is 29 times shorter than the inverter in the market.

title: Security Threat Detection Method for Optical Transmission Equipment Carrying Power Dispatching Data
authors: Gang Xu, Erbo Shang, He Huang, Zhiyan Ning
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Optical transmission equipment, as the core of power dispatch networks, directly affects grid command execution and data security. Traditional centralized detection strains network resources and risks data privacy, while localized methods lack global threat awareness. This paper introduces a collaborative framework integrating semi-supervised federated learning and Transformer models. By leveraging distributed training, it updates global threat detection parameters while preserving data privacy. This approach reduces communication overhead and enables cross-domain/regional collaboration, providing an innovative solution for power system communication security.

title: Enhancing BOTDR SNR using Learned-Dictionary Sparse Reconstruction of Brillouin Gain Spectrum Matrix
authors: Qing Bai, Mingyuan Yang, Hongyu Guo, Wei Zan, Yu Wang, Li Liu, Baoquan Jin
abstract: A method of enhancing signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in Brillouin optical time domain reflectometer (BOTDR) is proposed using sparse reconstruction of the Brillouin gain spectrum (BGS) matrix. In the sparse reconstruction process, the measured raw BGS matrix is treated as a noisy image, which can be represented as a linear combination of sparse basis and reconstructed by iteratively solving the optimal sparse coefficients. During the iterative operation, the random noise is suppressed as residuals and hence enhance the SNR. The basic principle, flow chart and solving algorithm are presented and further verified by numerical simulation. In the experiments, the temperature sensing is implemented by BOTDR to evaluate the denoising performance of BGS sparse reconstruction over 24.14 km fiber with 3m spatial resolution. Under 65°C, the fluctuation range and the root mean square error (RMSE) in the heating region are reduced from 13.9 MHz to 5 MHz and from 5.47 MHz to 1.65 MHz, respectively, with only 200 average counts. According to the calculation of distance-window RMSE, the SNR enhancement of 6.19 dB at the fiber end is achieved. Both simulation and experimental results show good performance in noise suppression.

title: Robust Detection of Underwater Target Against Non-Uniform Noise With Optical Fiber DAS Array
authors: Siyuan Cang, Cong Liu, Xueli Sheng, Xiaoming Cui, Chao Li, Changxin Fa, Jiantong Chen, Chaoran Yang, Huayong Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The detection of underwater targets is severely affected by the non-uniform spatial characteristics of marine environmental noise. Additionally, the presence of both natural and anthropogenic acoustic sources, including shipping traffic, marine life, and geological activity, further complicates the underwater acoustic landscape. Addressing these challenges requires advanced underwater sensors and robust signal processing techniques. In this paper, we present a novel approach that leverages an optical fiber distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) system combined with a broadband generalized sparse covariance-fitting framework for underwater target direction sensing, particularly focusing on robustness against non-uniform noise. The DAS system incorporates a newly developed spiral-sensitized optical cable, which significantly improves sensitivity compared to conventional submarine cables. This innovative design enables the system to capture acoustic signals with greater precision. Notably, the sensitivity of the spiral-wound sensitized cable is around - 145.69 dB re:1rad/(μPa · m), as measured inside the standing-wave tube. Employing simulations, we assess the performance of the algorithm across diverse noise levels and target configurations, consistently revealing higher accuracy and reduced background noise compared to conventional beamforming techniques and other sparse techniques. In a controlled pool experiment, the correlation coefficient between waveforms acquired by the DAS system and a standard hydrophone reached 0.973, indicating high fidelity in signal capture. Moreover, during a lake field experiment, the DAS system equipped with a sensitized optical cable was deployed on the lakebed to consistently track a non-cooperative speedboat. These results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach in practical scenarios involving complex, non-uniform noise environments.

title: A Novel Measurement Method of Electromechanical Coupling in Portable Electromagnetic Vibroseis
authors: Yuda Chen, Jingru Wang, Xuan Cao, Genyuan Xing, Yan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Developing electromagnetic vibroseis is an important approach to achieving portable seismic sources for shallow seismic exploration. As an electromechanical device, the performance of the portable electromagnetic vibroseis is determined by its internal electromechanical coupling. Obtaining the force factor distribution curve BL(x) is the basis of studying the electromechanical coupling. Existing methods, such as finite element method and quasi-static method, suffer from reliance on prior information, operational complexity, or limited accuracy. Aiming at these disadvantages in the process of obtaining the BL(x), a novel indirect measurement method is proposed. The proposed method relies solely on acquisition data, including acceleration, displacement, and induced electromotive force (EMF) of the internal driving coils moving in the air gap magnetic field. This approach enables the acquisition of the full-stroke BL(x) in a single, rapid measurement, offering advantages in operational convenience and measurement accuracy. To suppress the noise in motion signals and induced EMF signal, Kalman and Savitzky-Golay (S-G) filtering methods were respectively used. The motion velocity was obtained by integrating filtered acceleration signal, followed by a two-stage calibration process. The BL(t) was obtained by solving the motion velocity and induced EMF. The filtered displacement signal was used to map the BL(t) to full-stroke BL(x). Experiments were carried out based on a portable electromagnetic vibroseis platform. The experimental results show that the average root mean square error (RMSE) of the 12 repeated experiments is 0.3139. Compared to other measurement methods, the proposed method achieves both accuracy and operational convenience in portable electromagnetic vibroseis.

title: Synergistic Effects of Infrared and Microwave Radiance in All-sky Data Assimilation for a Heavy Precipitation Case over the Korean Peninsula
authors: Jiwon Hwang, Hearin Park, Dong-hyun Cha, Yonghan Choi, Sang Seo Park
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: This study investigates how the integration strategy of infrared (IR) and microwave (MW) brightness temperatures (TBs) influences precipitation forecasting within an all-sky radiance data assimilation (DA) framework using a three-dimensional variational method. To improve heavy rainfall forecasts over Korea, we propose an asynchronous assimilation approach in which, when both IR and MW observations are available, only MW TBs are assimilated, and IR TBs are intentionally excluded to reduce redundancy and potential inconsistencies in cloud representation. The case study, focusing on a heavy precipitation event over the Korean Peninsula, employs IR TBs from the Himawari Imager (AHI) on Himawari-8 and MW TB from the Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) Microwave Imager (GMI) and the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer 2 (AMSR2) aboard the Global Change Observing Mission (GCOM-W). For comparison, two conventional synchronous strategies are conducted as baselines: one integrating clear-sky IR with all-sky MW, and the other integrating all-sky IR with all-sky MW. Results show that the asynchronous approach achieves the best balance between upper-level solid and lower-level liquid hydrometeors, leading to the most accurate precipitation forecasts. In contrast, with synchronous approaches, the all-sky IR with MW strategy enhances upper-level clouds but reduces low-level moisture, potentially resulting in localized heavy rainfall. Meanwhile, the clear-sky IR with MW approach underestimates upper-level cloud structures, which contributes to underestimation of stratiform rainfall. These findings highlight the importance of optimally designed IR–MW integration strategies for this specific heavy precipitation event and provide insights for future improvements in satellite-based precipitation assimilation systems.

title: The Effect of Depth on the Generalization of Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Mora-Guerrero León S., Alarcón-Paredes Antonio, Menchaca-Méndez Ricardo
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: With the advent of Deep Learning, artificial neural networks have become the standard for classification and prediction tasks. They are now among the most popular and widely used machine learning models in various fields, including education and finance, among others. This trend is further driven by the development of technologies and architectures based on classical Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), and Transformer models.The term "Deep" refers to the use of multiple sequential layers, which allows to perform several transformations of the input data. This approach helps to extract relevant hierarchical knowledge, allowing the model to deliver better results in its target tasks. According to the Universal Approximation Theorem, a sufficiently large ANN composed of a single layer can approximate any mathematical function. However, in practice, it is commonly more effective to distribute network complexity across multiple layers. In this paper the not-so-discussed topic of comparing the performance of Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs), which consist of multiple layers, versus Shallow Neural Networks (SNNs) composed of only a single layer, while keeping the number of parameters constant across different datasets is addressed. Moreover a discussion of the theoretical and mathematical reasons regarding why one type or ANN may outperform the other in terms of generalization is presented.

title: Simulation Research on Enhanced Charge/Discharge Protection Strategy for Hybrid Energy Storage Systems in Building PEDF System
authors: Tian Mao, Qiang Wei, Jianqi Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper introduces the characteristics of hybrid energy storage systems and proposes an improved charging/discharging control strategy for lithium -ion battery/supercapacitor hybrid energy storage systems. The strategy introduces transitional correction regions (overcharged/overdischarged correction zones) in the State of Charge (SOC) partitioning, enabling dynamic power adjustment to prevent abrupt transitions and enhance system stability. A simulation model of a PEDF system incorporating the improved hybrid energy storage is established on the Matlab/Simulink platform. The effectiveness and superiority of this approach are verified through case analysis, demonstrating its practical application potential in enhancing renewable energy integration and grid stability.

title: Auto-EIS: Automated Discovery of Equivalent Circuit Models from Impedance Spectroscopy via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Chen Chen, Xiaowen Jiang, Kai Huang, Wei Xi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) is a powerful non-destructive analytical technique increasingly vital for battery state monitoring. However, constructing its Equivalent Circuit Model (ECM) is a complex task that has traditionally depended on expert experience. Current automated approaches often frame this as a classification problem, which requires pre-training on large-scale datasets and limits their generalization ability to pre-defined topologies, thus failing to handle unknown structures in practical applications. To address this bottleneck, we propose Auto-EIS, a framework for automated ECM discovery based on deep reinforcement learning. The framework requires no extensive pre-training and can autonomously explore the optimal circuit topology as well as its precise parameters directly from a single impedance measurement. Our method was validated on typical ECMs, including those with Warburg and CPE elements. In all tests, Auto-EIS can correctly identify the circuit topology while achieving near-perfect parameter fits, evidenced by extremely low chi-squared error on the order of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−4</sup>. Moreover, a test on the real-world battery dataset where model parameters vary across the entire State of Charge (SOC) range shows that Auto-EIS can achieve an average Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of just 1.55% across all key parameters. Auto-EIS replaces the traditional, manual ECM construction with a fully automated process, thereby paving the way for large-scale electrochemical data analysis and online model updating in Battery Management Systems (BMS) during long-term operation.

title: Research on FPGA based Digital Correlation Receiver System
authors: Jing Zhang, Chao Feng
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Based on the imaging principle of the integrated aperture radiometer, in order to obtain the visual function inversion imaging, it is necessary to obtain the correlation between the two channels. The correctness of the data received in order to get the desired correlation results, so the digital correlator data reception becomes the key to imaging. A calibration algorithm is designed for $\mathbf{6 4}$-channel $\mathbf{1 G H z}$ data reception, so that the capture clock edge is in the middle of the data eye. The rate of FPGA interface logic resources is much higher than the rate of internal logic operation. In order to realize multi-channel high-speed data deceleration, the realization of serial and parallel conversion is designed. Through the correction algorithm and data deceleration to FPGA internal logic to low-speed parallel data operations, to achieve the relevant operations, access to accurate visual function, which inversion imaging.

title: Usage Variability Impact on Field Reliability Expectations
authors: Michael Leighton
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium - Europe (RAMS-Europe)
abstract: This paper presents an approach to defining and validating the reliability of automotive components through detailed usage definition. Usage definition involves assessing the stresses that a system is expected to encounter throughout its lifetime by evaluating probable user behaviors and environmental conditions. High-level system requirements are established, dictating reliability targets, such as less than 10% failure probability at the end of life, and these must be translated into suitable targets for the development and validation teams. The methodology includes the consideration of the usage definition as a distribution, rather than a single value, and the resultant expected reliability validation impact that results.The novelty of this approach lies in enabling validation results to be considered as a failure probability versus expected damage accumulation. By evaluating the failure probability and usage probability distributions through convolution, a cumulative failure distribution is obtained. This distribution is compared to reliability targets to ensure compliance. The methodology supports an agile validation process, allowing for tailored validation strategies that enhance validation accuracy while reducing costs.The results demonstrate that the component meets reliability targets throughout its operational life, with cumulative failure distributions remaining below acceptable thresholds. The approach also considers extreme users with an appropriate level of rarity, reducing conservatism and promoting efficient resource use. The conclusions highlight the benefits of this methodology in providing a realistic and comprehensive understanding of component reliability, supporting robust and reliable automotive component development.

title: Optimal Energy Management in a Microgrid with Renewable Sources, Fuel Cell, Electric Vehicles, and Demand Response Programs for Operational Cost Reduction
authors: Milad Farhadi, Mohammad Reza Fatehi, Amir Mohammad Sharifi, Fatemeh Panahi, Mohammad-amin Mohseni
abstract: This study presents an advanced framework for optimal energy management in a smart microgrid incorporating diverse energy sources, electric vehicles (EVs), and thermal storage. The objective is to minimize operational costs through a two-stage stochastic programming approach that accounts for uncertainties in key parameters such as electricity price, load demand, wind speed, and solar irradiance. To enhance demand-side efficiency, a combination of price-based and incentive-based demand response programs is implemented, analyzing their impact on load profile smoothing and reducing dependence on the upstream grid. EVs function as dual-purpose assets within the system, serving as both electricity consumers and energy storage units capable of injecting power into the grid, thereby improving microgrid operational flexibility. Uncertainty modeling is performed using scenario generation through probability distribution discretization, followed by scenario reduction via mixed-integer linear programming. The proposed model is implemented and solved in the GAMS software environment, and the obtained results indicate that integrating EVs and demand response programs significantly reduces operational costs while enhancing grid stability and sustainability.

title: Optimal Stochastic Scheduling of Virtual Power Plant with Distributed Energy Resources and Demand Side Management for Supplying Electrical and Thermal Loads in Distribution Network
authors: Hossein Kiani, Mohammad Hassan Nazari, Seyed Hossein Hosseinian
abstract: Given the climate change crisis, power grids are transitioning towards greater sustainability through distributed energy resources (DERs), energy storage systems, and smart loads. Virtual Power Plants (VPPs) emerge as a novel solution, enabling the flexible management of DERs, maintaining grid balance by controlling both generation and consumption. This study presents a stochastic scheduling model for a VPP, comprising conventional generators (CG), photovoltaic panels (PV), wind turbines (WT), CHP systems, battery energy storage systems (BESS), and boilers. The model incorporates uncertainties related to electrical and thermal loads, wind speed, solar irradiation, and market prices. Random scenarios are generated using a Monte Carlo method and reduced with a K-means clustering algorithm. Additionally, Demand Side Management (DSM) programs are employed to optimize VPP performance. The model is implemented on a standard IEEE 33-bus network and solved using the CPLEX solver in the GAMS environment. Simulation results indicate a 24% discrepancy between revenues and costs, yielding a net profit of 1659.16 $. Furthermore, electrical revenue increased by 60% compared to thermal revenue, and electricity sales were 61.4% higher than the cost of purchasing from the upstream grid. These findings demonstrate that the proposed model can enhance the net profit of the Virtual Power Plant over a 24-hour period.

title: Multi-Microgrid Operation Optimization Method Based on Coordination of Multi-Flexibility Resource
authors: Feifei Fan, Shijia Duan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: In response to the characteristics of zonal operation in power grids and the uneven distribution of multi-flexibility resources, a multi-microgrid operation optimization method based on the coordination of multi-flexibility resources is proposed. This method integrates various flexibility resources, including distributed generation (source side), transferable/interruptible loads (load side), and energy storage (storage side), into the operation optimization model of multi-microgrids. It not only focuses on the scheduling of a single type of resource but also comprehensively considers their synergistic effects in peak shaving, fluctuation smoothing, reducing wind curtailment, and ensuring load supply. This approach achieves a transition from “single microgrid internal optimization” to “interaction among multiple microgrids and coordinated optimization of multiple types of resources.” The method is validated using a case study of three interconnected microgrid systems, and the results demonstrate improved overall system economy and energy utilization efficiency.

title: Benchmarking Large Language Models for Root Cause Analysis in Train Control Software Testing
authors: Rahmanu Hermawan, Alessio Bucaioni, Eduard Enoiu, Wasif Afzal
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Software quality assurance is critical in safety-critical domains like railway systems, where failures can have catastrophic consequences. In this context, train control and management systems play a central role, and their software must undergo rigorous validation. Alstom Rail Sweden AB employs a digital twin infrastructure to simulate and validate train control and management systems software. While this setup significantly improves system-level testing, the root cause analysis of test failures remains a manual and time-consuming bottleneck.This study explores the potential of large language models to automate root cause analysis by interpreting execution logs generated during digital twin-based testing. We benchmark seven state-of-the-art large language models, Aion-1.0, DeepSeek R1, DeepSeek V3 0324, Mistral Small 3.1 24B, GPT o3-mini, Gemini 2.5 Pro Experimental, and QwB 32B, using zero-shot chain-of-thought prompting to assess their ability to reason about fault patterns in real-world industrial test execution logs. The logs, sourced from Alstom’s digital twin-based testing environment, capture complex operational behaviour typical of embedded, safety-critical systems.Our results show that Gemini 2.5 Pro Experimental achieved the best performance with 66.7% accuracy and strong reasoning quality in this domain, contributing to the future research agenda to improve the accuracy prediction.

title: On the Generalization Capabilities of LLMs for Reverse Engineering Sequence Diagrams
authors: Sandra Greiner, Judi Abdullah, Timo Kehrer
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Reverse engineering models from source code is a crucial activity for facilitating program comprehension and supporting software modernization. Existing reverse engineering tools are typically tailored to specific programming languages and often lack the flexibility to be easily extended or adapted to others. While sophisticated support exists for some languages such as Java, many other languages remain poorly supported. Motivated by the recent success of large language models (LLMs) in code understanding and translation tasks across heterogeneous programming languages, we aim to explore whether LLMs can mitigate this imbalance. We envision LLMs to easily transfer reverse engineering capabilities between programming languages once understanding the reverse engineering task. As step towards this vision, this paper presents an experiment in which we finetuned CodeT5, an LLM pretrained on code translation tasks, on the task of generating sequence diagrams from Java methods. We systematically evaluate its generalization capabilities by applying the finetuned model to generate sequence diagrams for Python methods. Our quantitative results are promising but not without limitations. The finetuned model achieves almost perfect accuracy on Java methods. The transfer performance for Python input reaches approximately 80% accuracy, consistently measured across different evaluation metrics. In a qualitative analysis, we find that the good results stem from similar Java and Python code structures but the model fails, for instance to transfer keywords. Building on our experimental infrastructure and datasets, we lay the groundwork for future research on examining the generalization capabilities.
