title: Transformer-Based Approaches to Description Sequence Generation for Chinese Characters
authors: Zheng-Yuan Lin, Hsiang-An Wang, Li-Ling Hung
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: A Chinese character has multiple decomposition methods, which can be represented by breaking it down into units such as strokes and components, or further expressed as ideographic description sequences through structural symbols. However, when expanding to new characters, existing methods mostly rely on manual processing, and due to the existence of multiple decomposition methods, the description sequence generation of newly included or rare characters often consumes a large amount of time, resulting in delays in data updates and limiting database applications. Although existing automated models are able to generate description sequences from glyph images, most of them lack the ability to learn the spatial positions and structural relationships of components within a glyph, thus making predictions prone to errors when dealing with complex characters. To overcome these limitations, this study explores Transformer-based models and incorporates spatial information into both stroke and component datasets. The findings provide evidence that the integration of spatial information within the stroke dataset achieves the most favorable performance in generating structural description sequences.

title: A RRT based Path and Gait Planning Framework for Humanoid Robots in 3D Complex Environment
authors: Shiyu Miao, Jiajie Yu, Wenzheng Chi, Lining Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Different from wheeled robots, humanoid robots should have the ability to cross and step on obstacles, and in order to realize autonomous navigation of humanoid robots in three-dimensional (3D) environments, the robots must be able to achieve efficient path planning and collision-free gait generation in all kinds of 3D environments. This paper proposes a 3D environment navigation and real-time gait planning framework for humanoid robots based on traditional motion planning methods, Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT). The framework adopts an ellipsoid approximation to characterize the swing leg motion envelope space for efficient collision detection. Within the 3D environment, a terrain adaptive mechanism is employed, wherein planar support analysis and local terrain complexity assessment are combined to enable differential filtering of dense RRT-generated path nodes. This filtered path planning is integrated with a gait controller to fully exploit the motion capabilities of the robot while enhancing planning efficiency. The challenge of humanoid robot navigation has been addressed by this framework, and its efficacy has been validated through experiments.

title: Robust Contactless Detection of Respiration and Heart Rate using Millimeter-Wave Radar during Continuous Body Movement
authors: Tianyi Wang, Wenxu Sun, Keisuke Shima
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: This study proposes a robust, contactless method for simultaneously detecting respiration and heart rates using frequency–modulated continuous wave (FMCW) millimeter– wave radar under continuous body movement. While radar– based biosignal monitoring offers the advantages of comfort and privacy, its reliability during motion remains limited. To address this, we build upon our previous work by extending a signal processing framework that employs non–negative matrix factorization (NMF) and template matching. Eleven participants were tested under a structured protocol involving static sitting and controlled body movements. Radar data were analyzed from multiple reflection points to extract micro–motions correlated with physiological signals. Temporal features were decomposed and matched to synthetic respiration and heart rate templates across defined frequency bands. Experimental results show strong correlation with ground truth signals, with heart rate detection achieving up to 100% accuracy under static conditions and over 80% during motion. Bland–Altman and correlation analyses further validate the method’s reliability. This approach offers promise for practical, privacy–preserving health monitoring, though future work is needed to extend measurement duration and enable real–time implementation.

title: Quantum–Classical Hybrid LSTM Model for PM2.5 Forecasting in Bangkok
authors: Rajasurang Wongkrasaemongkol
abstract: Air pollution is a serious environmental and health concern in Bangkok. This research proposes a hybrid quantum-classical model for forecasting fine particulate matter (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{P M}_{\text{2} \cdot \text{5}}$</tex>) by using Quantum Long Short-Term Memory (QLSTM) architecture that embeds a variational quantum circuit within the recurrent gating pathway to construct a compact, nonlinear feature map in Hilbert space. Daily concentrations of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PM}_{2 \cdot 5}, \text{PM}_{10}, \mathrm{O}_{3}, \text{NO}_{2}, \text{SO}_{2}$</tex>, and CO are used to train and evaluate the models on a held-out test set. The QLSTM improves from the LSTM baseline in both RMSE and MSE evaluation metrics. The method utilizes quantum superposition and entanglement to enhance feature representation, enabling faster convergence and reduced initial error. The findings underscore the integration of quantum computing into machine learning models to achieve high predictive accuracy with compact parameterizations for environmental time-series forecasting.

title: Fairness-Driven Growth Algorithms for Multi-Sided Digital Platforms
authors: Durga Krishnamoorthy, Raghu Para
abstract: Multi-sided digital platforms, such as e-commerce, ride-sharing, and social media, face increasing regulatory and societal pressure to ensure growth strategies uphold fairness and trust. This paper proposes a novel fairness-driven growth optimization framework that integrates algorithmic fairness constraints into AI-driven models for user acquisition, retention, and engagement. Leveraging machine learning techniques, including fairness-aware contextual bandits and NSGA-II multi-objective optimization, the framework balances key performance indicators (KPIs) with equitable opportunity distribution across diverse user segments, particularly underrepresented groups. An explainable decision pipeline, using SHAP values and counterfactual fairness, ensures transparency and compliance with regulations like the EU Digital Markets Act. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world e-commerce datasets demonstrate a 12% reduction in systemic bias with only a 3% KPI drop. This scalable, regulation-ready solution enhances stakeholder trust and monetization potential, offering a robust framework for sustainable platform expansion in dynamic, multi-sided ecosystems.

title: Wind Power Prediction Based on GJO's TCN-BiGRU-Attention
authors: Yulong Li, Dongrong Jiang, Huimin Huang, Yuyang Ao, Zhenze Yang, Sheng Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of poor prediction accuracy caused by intermittent and fluctuating wind power. In this paper, a hybrid power prediction model of TCN-BiGRU-Attention based on Golden Jackal Optimization algorithm (GJO) is constructed. Firstly, GJO is used to globally optimize the key hyperparameters of the prediction model to obtain the optimal parameter combination. Secondly, Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) is used to extract the temporal and spatial characteristics of wind power historical data. After sequence reconstruction, it is input into the BiGRU network to capture the temporal dependence and enhance the ability of the current state to represent future information. Finally, Attention is introduced to adaptively weight the BiGRU output, highlighting the contribution of key features to the prediction results, and obtaining the optimal spatio-temporal feature representation. The experimental results show that the prediction model is significantly better than the traditional prediction method in prediction accuracy, which verifies the effectiveness of the model.

title: Assessment of Charging Station Impact on Grid Loading Capability Considering Economic Optimization Coefficient
authors: Yuechao Wang, Junchi Gao, Jinjin Liang, Lei Xie, Xiaoming Gu, Kunqi Jia, Qi Wei
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: considering the impact of electric vehicle (EV) charging stations on distribution network Loading Capability and various influencing factors, this paper develops an evaluation model framework and indicators from three dimensions. A novel evaluation model for assessing the impact of charging stations on grid Loading Capability, incorporating an economic optimization coefficient, is proposed, along with a scheme for implementing this economic optimization coefficient within the model. Finally, an evaluation study is conducted on a real case of commercial and public bus charging station integration. The evaluation results show that this model can precisely characterize the Loading Capability profile of each switching station and estimate the accessible capacity value for integrating charging stations. Compared to the traditional "cost-distance linear model," this model can more accurately capture the "short-distance sensitivity effect." Regression analysis of 312 actual cases shows that the designed extended model’s goodness-of-fit R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> is 0.91, significantly higher than the ordinary exponential model’s 0.76. Moreover, the attenuation coefficient (0.018~0.022/km) remains stable within the 95% confidence interval, thereby providing theoretical guidance for charging station planning.

title: Research on the Forced Oscillation of Power System Based on Energy Functions
authors: Lei Yun, Fangze Wu, Yiying Gao, Yuhong Zhang, Yilang Jiang, Jingqi Yang, Lining Su, Zeyu Zhang, Dan Huang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Forced power oscillation differs from traditional weak damping power oscillation. Sustained periodic disturbances can trigger forced power oscillations in power systems. From their generation mechanism to their oscillation characteristics, forced power oscillations differ significantly from classical weakly damped free oscillations. The energy characteristics of forced power oscillations from the perspective of kinetic-potential energy conversion are analyzed. First, the dynamic response mechanism of the power system under persistent periodic disturbances is analyzed, then the rotor angular kinetic and potential energies of a disturbed power system are defined, response characteristics of the generator rotor angle under the action of a forced disturbance source are analyzed from the point of view of energy conversion, energy variations corresponding to generator rotor angles at different frequencies of forced oscillation source are compared, Finally, the operating characteristics of the power system at three energy resonance states are analyzed on the basis of the kinetic-potential energy conversion mechanism.

title: Optimal Scheduling Method of Cascaded Hydropower Plants Considering the Contradiction Between Supply Guarantee and Flood Prevention
authors: Yonglong Zhao, Quan Qing, Yuxuan Xiao, Tu Xu, Xiangyi Chen, Lingyun Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Hydropower resources exhibit strong seasonality, with flood season inflows accounting for about 70% of the total annual volume. To achieve optimal allocation of water resources, it is necessary to rely on the regulatory reservoirs in each basin to conduct "storage during wet seasons and replenishment during dry seasons" adjustments, redistributing the natural inflows. This paper proposes a joint operation scheduling method for cascaded hydropower plants that takes into account the supply guarantee security and flood Prevention. Firstly, considering the supply guarantee security and flood Prevention, a joint operation optimal model for cascaded hydropower plants is developed, Then, an optimal scheduling method to control the concentrated drawdown of centralized drainage before flood is proposed. This method aims to regulate the extent of pre-flood water level drawdown while addressing the power supply and flood Prevention requirements of cascaded hydropower plants. Finally, through the simulation in the middle and lower reaches of the Yalong River Basin, the effectiveness of the proposed scheduling method is finally validated. The results indicate that reservoir water levels can be effectively regulated under different inflow conditions by the optimal scheme, water spillage can be reduced, power generation efficiency can be enhanced, and stable water supply can be ensured. This demonstrates that the method is scientifically rational and feasible in practical applications.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Personalized Lifestyle Recommendations in Colorectal Cancer Prevention
authors: Christos Androutsos, Traianos Tsiokris, Zheshen Jiang, Nicolas Gillain, Ioannis S. Papanikolaou, Eleni Koukoulioti, Constantina Cloconi, Antria Savva, Sisse H. Njor, Susanne F. Jørgensen, Maja Ravnik, Sergej Černčič, María González Oter, Raquel Alcaraz Ortega, Vasilis Giannakopoulos, Dimitrios Kypreos, Dimitrios Dimitroulopoulos, George K. Matsopoulos, Dimitrios I. Fotiadis
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a largely preventable disease influenced by modifiable behavioral risk factors such as diet, smoking, alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, and chronic stress. This study proposes a machine learning-based framework that generates personalized lifestyle recommendations aimed at CRC prevention. The system consists of two components: the Behavioral Recommendation Mapping Engine, which maps behavioral questionnaire responses to expertvalidated recommendations, and the Risk Assessment Module, which classifies participants into specific recommendations using supervised learning models. Eight domain-specific classifiers were developed, each targeting a key behavioral risk factor. Random Forests consistently outperformed Decision Trees, achieving high macro-averaged F1 scores even in imbalanced categories such as smoking <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(F 1=0.88)$</tex> and stress <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(F 1=0.80)$</tex>. The system also identifies the most influential behavioral variable per domain to highlight actionable risk factors. This framework will be integrated into the DIOPTRA mobile application to support realtime, personalized prevention.

title: Integrating New Energy Storage into China's Optimal Pathway for Carbon-Neutral Power Expansion
authors: Ye Yi, Zhenwei Tang, Nan Gui, Wenping Hu, Xintuan Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: This study explores the integration of new energy storage technologies into China's long-term carbon-neutral power system planning. By applying a high-resolution Dynamic Optimal Power Expansion Model (DOPEM), we assess the cost-effectiveness, deployment potential, and system impacts of multiple storage technologies. Two scenarios-one with conventional technologies and one with a broad mix of new storage-are compared through 2060. Results indicate that diversified energy storage can effectively replace natural gas for grid flexibility, reduce system costs by 6.3 %, and play a critical role in achieving carbon neutrality.

title: On the Challenges of Integrating Digital Twins
authors: Benoit Combemaleo, Jörg Kienzle, Gunter Mussbacher, Pascal Archambault, Jean-Michel Bruel, Lola Burgueño, Betty H.C. Cheng, Loek Cleophas, Gregor Engels, Damien Foures, Stefan Klikovits, Vinay Kulkarni, Judith Michael, Sebastien Mosser, Houari Sahraoui, Eugene Syriani, Andreas Wortmann
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) are a key technology for smart ecosystems to provide accurate digital representation of their constituents, e.g., smart buildings, farms, transportation, and citizens, as well as synchronization between the digital and the real subject, and the exploration of what-if scenarios and tradeoff reasoning. To cope with emerging complex socio-technical ecosystems, we need to bring DTs together, which is a challenging endeavor. After giving a historical overview of system adaptation, we review the many enabling technologies that can help with DT integration. Using a smart city as an illuminating example to highlight scenarios that require integration of DTs, we discuss a model-based conceptual framework that identifies DT integration strategies and elaborate on nine key integration challenges that still need to be addressed. We call on the DT community to investigate these challenges.

title: YANG-APR: Towards Supporting Evolution in Model-driven Network Management Systems
authors: Hesham Elabd, Juergen Dingel, Robert Lee, Ali Tizghadam
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: In model-driven network ecosystems, high-level specifications such as YANG data models define APIs that engineers extend with custom code and handlers. When the model evolves, it can become misaligned with its API implementation, which typically requires manual, costly, and error-prone realignment, highlighting the need for automated repair. This paper presents our ongoing work on an automated repair approach to resynchronize evolving YANG models with their API implementations, using a four-stage pipeline: (i) localize compatible-vs-breaking diffs between the current and updated models, (ii) enrich each diff record with contextual information, (iii) instantiate precise transformation rules for every change, and (iv) apply those rules to generate a repaired version of the code, complete with a reviewable change log for engineer validation. To explore the feasibility of this approach, we have developed an initial prototype-YANG-APR-that targets five common model evolution scenarios: datatype change, node rename, endpoint URL rename, endpoint removal, and endpoint addition. We illustrate the approach through two representative cases: a breaking datatype modification and a non-breaking endpoint addition. These early results show promising potential to facilitate model-implementation coevolution, providing a foundation for continued development and broader evaluation.

title: Incorporating Pitching Moment Observation in Reinforcement Learning for Enhanced Thermal Updraft Exploitation by Fixed-Wing UAVs
authors: Chengju Zhang, Hongfei Wu, Guanquan Wei, Wenjuan Li, Jiayang Wang, Haobo Liu, Ke Li, Biao Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Fixed-wing UAVs can extend endurance by exploiting atmospheric thermals. Prior reinforcement learning (RL) methods used vertical acceleration and roll moments as state inputs. However, when flying straight through a thermal core, roll cues are weak, making it hard for RL agents to anticipate circling. This can delay thermal centering and waste potential energy gain. We propose adding pitching moment as an additional observation. Pitching moment reflects vertical airflow gradients along the fuselage, providing early cues of strong up-drafts. We design a deep RL agent with three-layer neural network and discrete bank angle actions. Simulations use a stationary Gaussian thermal model and glider dynamics. Results show that the pitchaugmented agent recognizes thermals earlier and begins circling sooner. Compared to baseline models, it gains up to $\sim 8 \%$ more altitude in head-on approaches and achieves better centering stability. This confirms that pitching moment sensing enhances autonomous soaring. Future work will explore moving thermals and real-world flight tests.

title: Electromagnetic Vibration Analysis of Doubly-Fed Induction Machines for Variable-Speed Pumped Storage
authors: Haoyu Kang, Tao Lei, Yiming Ma, Lu Sun, Zequan Li, Libing Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The doubly-fed induction machine (DFIM) serves as the core component of variable-speed pumped storage power plants, with its vibration characteristics directly impacting operational safety. To investigate the influence of motor-pump-turbine coordinated control strategies on unit vibration, this paper proposes a method for analyzing vibration characteristics of DFIMs under various operating conditions. A mathematical model of radial electromagnetic forces under variable-frequency excitation is established. Using a control-electromagnetic-mechanical co-simulation platform, the vibration characteristics of a 300MW DFIM under power-dominant control strategy are analyzed. Results demonstrate significant variations in vibration distribution across different operating conditions. Under high-power commands, vibration acceleration peaks exhibit greater magnitudes, with predominant low-frequency vibrations manifesting as breathing-mode oscillations.

title: Frequency-domain Stability Analysis Based on Immittance with SimuNPS
authors: Dengke Gao, Linlong Shi, Hongbiao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the continuous penetration rate growth of power electronic equipment in power generation, transmission and distribution, the trend of power electronicization in power systems has become increasingly obvious. In the meantime, oscillation problem in these new-type power systems is turning into a major challenge to the grid security and stability. The frequency-domain stability analysis based on immittance has been proved to be an important method to solve oscillation problem. As a new-type power systems modeling and simulation software, SimuNPS has frequency-domain modeling and stability analysis function by adopting this method. Firstly, the frequency-domain model of modified IEEE 39 bus system was built in SimuNPS. Then, the operating condition of oscillation, oscillation frequency and oscillation dominant power stations were revealed with Generalized Nyquist Criterion. Finally, the accuracy of these frequency-domain analysis results from SimuNPS was verified by a corresponding system time-domain simulation and FFT analysis results in MATLAB/Simulink.

title: Analysis of Ferromagnetic Resonance Influencing Factors of 10kV Electromagnetic Voltage Transformer Based on ATP-EMTP
authors: Tang Li, Pulong Geng, Yonggang Xu, Lijun Zheng, Dongdong Yang, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Aiming at the existing ferromagnetic resonance protection measures have the disadvantage of after-the-fact remediation, this paper analyses the influence factors of ferromagnetic resonance, determines its key influencing factors, and studies its influence law.. Based on ATP-EMTP, a simulation model of electromagnetic voltage transformer(PT) ferromagnetic resonance is constructed, and the influence of system capacitance to ground, PT excitation characteristics and fault point grounding resistance on the ferromagnetic resonance of electromagnetic voltage transformer is studied. Simulation results show that the study analyzes the key influencing factors of ferromagnetic resonance and provides a theoretical basis for the prevention and inhibition of ferromagnetic resonance faults.

title: Balanced Learning with Optimized Extra Trees Classifier for Reliable Lithology Identification in Imbalanced Well Log Data
authors: Ali Daneshpour, Behnam Yousefimehr, Mehdi Ghatee
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Accurate lithology identification is crucial for subsurface characterization in hydrocarbon exploration, yet conventional methods often fail to capture the complex, nonlinear relationships in well log data. To address this challenge, we propose a robust machine learning framework based on an optimized Extra Trees Classifier, enhanced by a hybrid resampling strategy to mitigate severe class imbalance. Our approach combines random oversampling of minority lithologies (e.g., coal and dolomite) with strategic undersampling of dominant classes, ensuring balanced representation while preserving critical geological patterns. Hyperparameter tuning via optimization further refines model performance, achieving an accuracy of 83.91% with a penalty score of -0.4087, demonstrating superior reliability, particularly for underrepresented facies. A comparative computational analysis confirms the efficiency of our framework, which outperforms complex models, such as GrowNet and Blender, as well as baselines, in both speed and scalability. To promote reproducibility, we provide the complete implementation, including preprocessing scripts and trained models, at https://github.com/alidaneshpour/ICCKE-2025.

title: Optimization of CZTS Solar Cells with $\text{ZrS}_{2}$ and $\text{Cu}_{2} \mathrm{O}$: A Numerical Simulation using SCAPS-1D
authors: Zhihao Miao, Yuming Xue, Luoxin Wang, Hongli Dai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: This study focuses on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{2} \text{ZnSnS}_{4}$</tex> (CZTS) solar cells, aiming to enhance photovoltaic performance by proposing a novel configuration through SCAPS-1D software. To reduce toxicity and improve band discontinuity, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{Z r S}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> is selected as an effective buffer layer to replacing CdS. Subsequently, the thickness and acceptor concentration (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{N}_{\mathbf{A}}$</tex>) of CZTS are optimized, and an efficiency of over 22.14 % is achieved. Moreover, secondary phases as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MoS}_{2}$</tex> at the back surface of the CZTS layer are also key factors limiting device efficiency, thus a comparative analysis of various p-type semiconductors is conducted. As a result, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex> are successfully identified as suitable BSF layers, with high efficiencies of 28.47 % and 28.85 %. By reviewing simulation records of recent literature and analyzing temperature effect, the feasibility of the proposed configuration (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{2} \mathrm{O} / \text{CZTS} / \text{ZrS}_{2}$</tex>) is confirmed.

title: Plant Disease Detection Using Dynamic Knowledge Distillation and Attention Mechanism
authors: Mohammad Ghasemi Arian, Mohammad Hossein Yaghmaee Moghaddam
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: One of the key aspects of modern agriculture is the detection of plant diseases. With the significant advancement of technology, one of the simplest and most cost-effective methods for assessing plant health is through image-based data. A common approach for analyzing such data involves the use of deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs). However, due to the computationally intensive nature of these networks, deploying them on edge devices is often challenging and costly. In this work, we propose a dynamic knowledge distillation framework that transfers knowledge from a powerful teacher model based on ResNet-50 to a compact student model built upon ResNet-18. This framework adaptively regulates the strength of knowledge distillation based on simulated noise levels during training, improving robustness under diverse conditions without requiring explicit noise estimation at inference. Experiments conducted on the PlantDoc dataset demonstrate that our method improves the student model’s accuracy from 61.86% to 65.25%, which is 2.11% higher than the teacher model’s accuracy, while reducing the student model's size by 47.2 MB compared to the teacher. The proposed approach provides a practical solution for real-time and on-device plant disease diagnosis.

title: Graphite: Automated Development of Hybrid Graphical-Textual DSL Editors
authors: Ionut Predoaia, Dimitris Kolovos, Antonio García-Domínguez
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Hybrid graphical-textual domain-specific languages can deliver the best of both worlds of graphical and textual modelling, by providing a graphical syntax for some parts of the language and a textual syntax for others. Graphite is a tool that facilitates the automated development of hybrid graphical-textual model editors for domain-specific languages. This paper outlines the capabilities of the hybrid editors generated by Graphite: smart textual editors, textual-graphical cross-referencing, integrated refactoring, consistency enforcement, tolerance of temporary inconsistencies, integrated abstract syntax graph, uniform error reporting, and conditional storage of derived model elements. Furthermore, the language engineering process employed by Graphite is demonstrated.

title: Towards Ontology-Driven User Experience Assessment of Collaborative Modeling Tools
authors: Marko Mijalkovic, Vicheka Oeun, Istvan David, Sadaf Mustafiz
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Collaborative Modeling (CM) tools increasingly offer advanced editing features, such as live co-editing, embedded chat, and automated reasoning. Yet, the impact of these features on the user experience (UX) of modeling is less understood. In this paper, we explore the relationship between CM and UX by developing a mapping between existing CM and UX ontologies. We propose CMUX Explorer, an ontology-driven assessment tool that enables tool builders to identify CM features with UX impact. The conversational front-end allows for natural-language interactions, which CMUX Explorer translates to SPARQL queries, executes them against the ontology, and returns ranked, interpretable recommendations to guide design decisions. Importantly, our approach supports continuous, semi-automated improvement of the ontology, leading to more precise recommendations over time. Through this work, we pave a path towards computer-aided design of UX-aware collaborative modeling tools.

title: Impact of Oversampling Methods on Imbalanced Dataset for Software Fault Prediction
authors: Alireza Abiri, Alireza Tajary, Mansoor Fateh
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: In today's world, marked by swift technological progress and the growing use and scale of software systems both in terms of data volume and number of users, the occurrence of software faults has become inevitable. Consequently, software fault prediction has gained significant importance for the early identification of faulty modules during the software development process. However, one of the key challenges in this domain is the class imbalance problem, where the number of faulty and non-faulty instances in software datasets is highly unequal. To address this issue, data oversampling techniques are commonly employed to balance the datasets. In this study, we investigate and compare the performance of three data oversampling methods on the BugHunter software fault dataset. The results indicate that using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for data generation and oversampling is a more effective approach for addressing class imbalance, achieving better performance compared to alternative methods.

title: Wireless Signal Generation via Modulation-Aware GANs for Low-Data AI
authors: Ubaid Iftikhar, Hassam Ahmed Tahir, Hamna Tahir, Azwan Mahmud
abstract: AI performance in wireless systems is limited by data scarcity and dynamic channel conditions. This paper introduces Modulation-Aware GANs (MA-GANs), a framework that synthesizes wireless signals by embedding modulation-specific constraints and modeling stochastic channel effects like Rayleigh fading and phase noise. Our design integrates domain-informed layers such as differentiable pulse shaping and spectral normalization to ensure physical-layer realism. We propose a hybrid training strategy that combines synthetic pre-training with minimal real-data fine-tuning, evaluated using wireless-centric metrics: Modulation Fidelity Score (MFS) and Spectral Compliance Index (SCI). MA-GAN narrows the sim-to-real gap to 1.8%, reduces EVM by 4.1×, and maintains BER below 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup> under dynamic conditions. With only 20% real data, it outperforms fully real-data-trained baselines by 1.6%, cutting data costs by 80%. This work enables reliable AI-driven wireless systems for 5G, 6G, and IoT applications.

title: Building Trust in Healthcare with Privacy Techniques: Blockchain in the Cloud
authors: Ferhat Ozgur Catak, Chunming Rong, Øyvind Meinich-Bache, Sara Brunner, Kjersti Engan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: This study introduces a cutting-edge architecture developed for the NewbornTime project, which uses advanced AI to analyze video data at birth and during newborn resuscitation, with the aim of improving newborn care. The proposed architecture addresses the crucial issues of patient consent, data security, and investing trust in healthcare by integrating Ethereum blockchain with cloud computing. Our blockchain-based consent application simplifies patient consent’s secure and transparent management. We explain the smart contract mechanisms and privacy measures employed, ensuring data protection while permitting controlled data sharing among authorized parties. This work demonstrates the potential of combining blockchain and cloud technologies in healthcare, emphasizing their role in maintaining data integrity, with implications for computer science and healthcare innovation.

title: Optimizing ARIMA-XGBoost Hybrid Model Performance through HPC Integration for Scalable Financial Forecasting
authors: Nandhitha B, Christopher Columbus C
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient time series forecasting framework that integrates High-Performance Computing (HPC) techniques with a hybrid ARIMA-XGBoost model to address the computational challenges of large-scale predictive analytics. The hybrid approach leverages the strengths of both models: ARIMA effectively captures linear patterns and seasonality, while XGBoost models the complex nonlinear residuals, resulting in a highly accurate and adaptive prediction pipeline. To enhance performance, the system incorporates parallel processing and distributed computing strategies for data preprocessing, model training, and inference. These optimizations substantially reduce execution time on multi-core systems, making the framework well-suited for high-volume and time-sensitive forecasting tasks. Experimental evaluations highlight the performance gains of the HPC-enabled implementation over standard sequential processing, demonstrating its scalability and effectiveness in real-world scenarios. The proposed solution addresses key computational bottlenecks in time series analysis and provides a robust foundation for applying hybrid forecasting models to complex, data-intensive environments.

title: A High-Efficiency, Size-Optimized 4×4 Butler Matrix with Via-Hole for 5G Communications
authors: Noorlindawaty Md Jizat, Nurul Huda Abd Rahman, Samir Salem Al-Bawri, Farid Zubir, Yusnita Rahayu, Yoshihide Yamada
abstract: The increasing demand for higher frequencies in 5G is driven by congestion at lower bands. Higher frequencies provide faster communication and greater bandwidth, which are essential for supporting the growing number of wireless devices. Efficient and compact beamforming networks are essential, and the Butler Matrix is particularly notable for its energy efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and strong interference suppression, making it an ideal choice for 5G. However, the conventional series-fed Butler Matrix results in a bulky design that’s difficult to scale for large 5G networks. Although some multi-layer designs achieve compactness by eliminating branch-line couplers, crossovers, or phase shifters, these often suffer from transmission inconsistencies and phase errors. To address this challenge, this paper presents a novel design that utilizes via-holes to compensate for the absence of crossovers and phase shifters and incorporates a back-to-back folding technique to maintain signal integrity while significantly reducing size. To ensure a fair and consistent performance comparison, both the proposed and conventional structures are fabricated on an NPC-F220A substrate with a thickness of 0.254 mm, a dielectric constant of 2.2, and a loss tangent of 0.007.

title: Replacement Index: A Techno-Economic Criterion for Replacing Copper Networks with Arial Bundled Cable in Low-Voltage Distribution Networks
authors: Saeed Resali Ahadi, Tahereh Bagherzadeh, Ramin Horri
abstract: Due to their critical role in energy supply and economic development, electrical distribution networks continuously need infrastructure upgrades and modernization. Replacing aging copper conductors with aerial bundled cable (ABC) has emerged as an effective strategy for reducing energy losses, enhancing reliability, and preventing conductor theft. This article examines the challenges associated with copper networks, such as equipment degradation, high theft rates, and maintenance costs. It introduces a numerical metric called the "Replacement Index (RI)," which facilitates the prioritization of low-voltage feeders based on technical and economic criteria. This index considers factors such as network lifespan, voltage profile, theft statistics, revenue from copper recycling, and the costs of installing ABCs. Initially, technical and economic analyses for each feeder are performed based on GIS information and actual operator data, and feeders in need of replacement are ranked according to the computed index. To assess the validity of the proposed method, one feeder from the Khodajou city distribution network was modeled using DIgSILENT Power Factory software. The results demonstrate that replacing the copper network with ABCs significantly reduces power losses, improves voltage profile, and enhances reliability.

title: Damping Enhancement Strategy in Microgrids Using High-Pass Filter-Based Virtual Synchronous Generator
authors: Shahram Akhtari, Mohammadali Narooie Dehchil, Ali Akhtari
abstract: Ensuring frequency stability in low-inertia microgrids with a substantial integration of renewable energy sources (RES) presents a considerable challenge. To address this issue, the utilization of virtual synchronous generators (VSGs) has been proposed. VSGs provide inertial and damping responses by emulating the operation of conventional synchronous generators, thus earning their name. This paper presents an updated structure of the virtual synchronous generator that replicates the behavior of a conventional synchronous generator equipped with automatic voltage regulator (AVR) and power system stabilizer (PSS) control loops. Furthermore, an optimal high-pass filter for improved transient damping is integrated into the control methodology to enhance the dynamic performance of the microgrid. This approach is employed to improve microgrid dynamic stability and performance against transient disturbances. To assess the effectiveness of the proposed method, comparative simulations are conducted in the MATLAB/Simulink environment, and the obtained results demonstrate an enhanced damping response through the proposed communication-less control strategy.

title: Evaluation of AI Models for Rain Rate Prediction to Support Communication Networks in Malaysia
authors: Nurhayati Hasan, Hafiz Basarudin, Chung Boon Kuan, Ling Lloyd, Mohd Azlan Abu, Nur Auni Izzati Aminudin, Aizat Faiz Ramli, Noor Hidayah Mohd Yunus
abstract: High-frequency wireless communication systems, including emerging 5G networks, are highly susceptible to rain-induced signal attenuation, particularly in tropical regions such as Malaysia. Accurate and timely rain rate forecasting is therefore critical for mitigating link degradation, optimizing resource allocation, and ensuring network reliability. This study presents a comparative evaluation of four artificial intelligence (AI) models; Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Transformer, and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) for forecasting hourly rain rates. A 14-year dataset (2009-2022) obtained from NOAA's Hydro-Estimator was processed using MATLAB and Python, with model training performed via sliding window sequences and hyperparameters optimized using the Optuna framework. Model performance was assessed using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), cross-correlation analysis, and rainrate exceedance probability curves. While LSTM demonstrated strong short-term alignment, the GRU and Transformer models achieved better performance across a wider range of rainrate intensities, especially in representing moderate to heavy rainfall. XGBoost performed reasonably well for light to moderate rain but overestimated extremes. These findings highlight the potential of sequence-based deep learning models, particularly GRU and Transformer, for improving weather-aware communication network planning in tropical climates.

title: Life Cycle Assessment of GIS and AIS Substations: A Comparative Environmental Impact Study
authors: Hussein Faisal Alsalehi, Istiyak Amin Santo, Siow Chun Lim
abstract: The electricity system’s environmental impact has become a cause for concern due to the recent increase in Global Warming Potential rates. Substations, which are widely distributed, are an integral part of the electricity system. Gas Insulated Substations (GIS) and Air Insulated Substations (AIS) are the two technologies used in substations. The purpose of this study is to investigate the environmental impact of these two technologies at medium voltage level using Life Cycle Assessment (LCA). The analysis focuses on four environmental indicators: Global Warming Potential, Damage to Human Health, Damage to Ecosystem, and Damage to Resources. The study found that the GIS substation has a slightly lower environmental impact than the AIS substation by 45% on Global Warming Potential and Human Health indicators due to electricity losses. However, the GIS and AIS have almost the same impact on Damage to Ecosystem and Damage to Resources indicators.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Microgrid Energy Optimization: Integrating Renewable Energy Sources with Demand-Side Management
authors: Kasra Shafiei, Ali Seifi, Mehrdad Tarafdar Hagh
abstract: One potential strategy for meeting future energy needs is the integration of renewable energy sources (RESs) into microgrids (MGs). RESs include photovoltaic (PV) systems, wind turbines (WT), and battery energy storage systems (BESS). Power production and system dependability are both jeopardized by these sources' inherent volatility. Microgrid operation optimization is the focus of this article, which offers an in-depth examination of energy management strategies (EnMS) and demand-side management (DSM) approaches. Through the optimization method, the paper investigates strategies to balance power generation from RESs and storage systems while minimizing operational costs and environmental impact. The proposed framework emphasizes the importance of advanced energy storage solutions, hybrid renewable systems, and demand response (DR) programs in achieving efficient and reliable energy distribution. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating multiple energy sources, highlighting the potential for improved grid stability and reduced energy costs. The findings underscore the role of intelligent energy management in facilitating the sustainable operation of future electrical distribution systems.

title: A Hybrid Architecture to Optimize Persian FAQ Retrieval using Semantic Similarity Search
authors: Seyed Amir Mohammad Hosseini, Fatemeh Dehbashi, Setare Kahnemuee, Mohsen Kahani, Morteza Fardin
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Traditional FAQ-based Question Answering (QA) systems, which rely on lexical matching, often fail to comprehend the semantic nuances of morphologically rich languages like Persian. Furthermore, their performance is typically measured by rigid metrics that underestimate a model's true capabilities. This paper addresses these challenges by proposing a novel, two-stage Hybrid Clustering-Based Search architecture designed to improve both the accuracy and efficiency of semantic retrieval. We introduce an iterative "Hierarchical DBSCAN" method to cluster a real-world Persian knowledge base, allowing for a focused, coarse-to-fine search pipeline. To robustly evaluate our system, we created a new multi-faceted dataset containing formal, informal, and challenging queries. Our experiments show that the proposed hybrid architecture, achieves a Top-1 accuracy of 79% and a Top-3 accuracy of 86% and also answering delay of only 0.115 seconds. This represents an improvement in both accuracy and speed compared to the optimal E5-Base model in the standard Direct Semantic Search baseline. Our work provides an efficient and validated blueprint for developing practical semantic QA systems for the Persian language.

title: Implementation of a Low-Overhead 2-Bit Parity-Preserving Reversible Vedic Multiplier for Quantum Architectures
authors: Shekoofeh Moghimi, Negin Mashayekhi, Mohammad Reza Reshadinezhad
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Reversible logic, by enabling computations without loss of information, offers a promising approach to significantly reducing energy dissipation, making it a key technology for low-power and quantum computing systems. Parity-preserving reversible circuits further enhance reliability, enabling fault detection in nanoscale systems. Multiplication, a fundamental operation in computing and signal processing, benefits significantly from efficient reversible designs. However, existing reversible Vedic multipliers often suffer from excessive Quantum Cost (QC), Garbage Outputs (GO), and Constant Inputs (CI). This paper proposes two new 2-bit parity-preserving reversible quantum Vedic multipliers, serving as the foundational block for scalable n-bit multipliers, that are enhanced to reduce quantum metrics without compromising performance. The proposed circuits are simulated using the Quirk tool to test their correct functionality. Comparative analysis shows that the best proposed design outperforms existing architectures on average by 34%, 53%, and 9% in constant inputs, garbage outputs, and quantum cost, respectively, providing a fault-tolerant, cost-efficient, and scalable solution for next-generation quantum computing systems.

title: Hybrid Adam-SGD Optimization for Enhanced Solar Irradiance Forecasting Using Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Nitipon Pongphaw, Keerati Maneesai, Prommin Buaphan, Pantong Sanonok, Mune Sukumaradat, Puntachok Numchokprasert, Athist Prasertsincharoen, Patiphan Khaokrachang
abstract: Accurate solar irradiance forecasting is crucial for integrating solar energy into power systems, given its variability and intermittency. Recurrent neural networks (RNN) effectively capture nonlinear and temporal patterns in solar radiation data. Optimizer choice significantly affects model convergence, generalization, and accuracy. While Adam adapts learning rates for noisy data and SGD ensures stable convergence, most studies use either alone or hybridize with metaheuristic algorithms, rarely combining Adam and SGD directly. This study proposes a hybrid Adam+SGD framework for RNN-based models (LSTM, GRU, SimpleRNN, Bidirectional LSTM, using Adam for initial convergence and SGD for fine-tuning to reduce bias. Evaluated on the Goa, India weather dataset with MAE, RMSE, MBE, and MASE, results show the hybrid optimizer consistently lowers forecasting errors and bias, especially for LSTM and GRU, highlighting its practical value for reliable solar forecasts.

title: Overcoming exe Execution Challenges in Robot Framework on Linux Using Wine
authors: Tushar Gupta, K. K. Sharma, Devchand Gadhiya
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: The automotive industry is using Robot Framework for integration testing of embedded software as it has open source nature, human-friendly and versatile keyword based syntax, extensibility through Python, Java and many other programming languages, easy to integrate with any third party tools without additional licensing fees, a rich ecosystem of third party libraries. Since it is also cross-platform, it allows you to scale up test automation. While many organizations move from Windows to Linux environments in order to get the most out of open-source, one big problem occurs: Robot Framework is able to execute binaries but there is still no native way on a Linux system to run .exe files. Wine enables to execute Windows software on Linux, but there are specialized issues and restrictions of Wine usage with Robot Framework workflows. This paper addresses these integration problems and provides a straight forward, but novel fix to launch and automate .exe files with Robot Framework on Linux via wine. This means that the automotive industry can apply fully open-source environments and still maintain the benefits of existing, executing legacy code by using such a solution to address seamless cross-platform test automation compatibility.

title: Inventory Management Using A2C Reinforcement Learning: Performance Comparison with Heuristic and Bandit Methods
authors: Tanmay Richhariya, Sunil Agrawal, Ashish Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) offers a promising approach to optimize inventory management by adaptively balancing stock levels against shortage, holding, and wastage costs. This paper presents an Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C) based inventory control strategy and compares its performance to a heuristic policy and an Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) algorithm baseline. Our results show that A2C significantly outperforms both baselines in terms of total cost (negative reward). The A2C agent achieves a substantially higher total reward (mean –4170.18 ± 210.18) compared to the heuristic and UCB strategies (approximately –5430.59 and –5396.43, respectively). This translates to a ~22–23% reduction in overall costs. Statistical significance tests (independent t-test and Mann-Whitney U) yield p-values of 0.0000 in all comparisons, indicating that the improvements are highly significant. These results underscore the effectiveness of the A2C-based approach in reducing inventory costs through intelligent and adaptive ordering decisions.

title: Design of Deployable Canister Mechanism for the Spaceborne Inflatable Planar Membrane Reflector Antenna
authors: Swapnil D. Shinde, Priyank Kumar Patel, Sanjay H. Upadhyay
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: The growing demand for large-aperture spaceborne antennas necessitates innovative structural solutions that are lightweight, compact, and capable of reliable deployment in orbit. This study presents the design and development of a deployable canister mechanism for an inflatable planar membrane reflector antenna intended for small satellite platforms. The proposed system integrates a two-step configuration for the canister deployment. The canister mechanism employs a flexural based deployment method to achieve position of the stowed configuration of inflatable antenna. Structural design considerations, such as material selection, packaging efficiency, and deployment behavior, are analyzed using finite element modeling and validated through ground-based deployment experiments. The proposed mechanism demonstrates ease of integration with standard spacecraft buses, offering a scalable and adaptable solution for next-generation deployable antenna systems.

title: Comparative Study of Natural Polymer Electrolytes in Organic Electrochemical Transistors: Electrical Performance
authors: Bo Sun, Mohd Fakhrul Zamani Bin Abdul Kadir, Yasmin Abdul Wahab, Cheng-Yao Lo, Shixun Zheng, Sharifah Fatmadiana Wan Muhamad Hatta
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This study investigates the use of three solid-state natural polymer electrolytes—chitosan, methylcellulose, and fish gelatin—in organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs), using PEDOT:PSS as the channel material. The electrical performance of these devices was systematically compared to a conventional aqueous NaCl-based OECT. Key transistor parameters, including threshold voltage (V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf>), on/off current ratio (I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</inf>/I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</inf>), and transconductance (g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>), were measured and analyzed. Among the tested materials, the chitosan-based OECT demonstrated the most balanced performance, with the lowest V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> of −0.71 V, a high I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</inf>/I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</inf> ratio of ~4.37 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and a strong g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf> of ~4.75 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">–6</sup> S. Notably, it exhibited comparable performance to the aqueous NaCl-based device, highlighting its potential as a sustainable and efficient electrolyte for future applications in flexible, wearable, and neuromorphic electronics.

title: Controlling Agglomeration in Silver Nanoparticle Synthesis: The Role of Polyvinylpyrrolidone as a Capping Agent
authors: Nur Atiqah Azman, Nor Shahanim Mohamad Hadis, Aida Zulia Zulhanip, Anis Diyana Rosli, Zurita Zulkifli, Mohamad Faizal Abd Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This study investigates the effect of trisodium citrate (TSC) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) concentrations on the morphology, elemental composition and optical properties of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) using a modified Turkevich method. Eight samples were prepared by varying the volumes of 34 mM TSC (1.5 mL, 2.0 mL and 2.5 mL) and 0.3 mM PVP (1.5mL, 2.0 mL and 2.5 mL) to explore their roles as reducing and capping agents, respectively. The resulting AgNPs were characterized using Ultra-High Resolution Scanning Electron Microscopy (UHRSEM), Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX), and UV-Visible spectroscopy (UV-VIS). UHRSEM analysis revealed that PVP significantly improved nanoparticle dispersion and uniformity, with the best morphology observed in samples synthesized with moderate amounts of both TSC and PVP. EDX results showed that optimal silver retention occurred when PVP volume was sufficiently high to stabilize the nanoparticles, while excessive TSC without adequate capping led to agglomeration and reduced surface silver content. UV-VIS spectroscopy further supported these findings, with distinct surface plasmon resonance peaks shifting in response to particle size and dispersion. The results emphasize the critical interplay between reducing and capping agents in controlling AgNPs growth, providing essential insights for the future fabrication of GQDs/AgNP-based sensors for heavy metal detection.

title: Annealing Effect on the Thermal Performance of XLPE from Retired High-Voltage Cables
authors: Chen Yi, Dehui Zhong, Xin Zhou
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: The thermal effects from the cable in operation brought great effect on the changes in morphology of cable insulation layer, which is the dominate factor in judging the insulation performance of the cable. A 110 kV XLPE (crosslinking polyethylene) insulated cable with seven-year service was selected, the outer sheath was removed and the XLPE insulation layer was peeled. Firstly, they were thermally aged at 105° C as long as 180 days. Then, they were heat-treated at six discrete temperatures of 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, and 115° C for 24 hours, respectively: ranges from the standard operation temperature to the melting point of XLPE. The differential-scanning-calorimetry, gel content, and conduction current were done, to check the changes in thermal, molecular, and electrical performance. The results show that 60 and 120-day-aged samples present enhanced thermal and electrical performance with higher crystallinity and lower conductivity; but the 180-day-aged sample shows a slight degradation. After annealing, the melting point and crystallinity in all sheets increased following the increment of annealing temperature, and the conductivity gave the opposite changes. The optimum annealing point, which corresponds to the highest melting point and crystallinity, appears at 105, 105, 100, and 100 °C for the fresh, 60, 120, and 180-day-aged samples. At the same time, the damage in molecular structure results in the optimum point for conductivity appearing at a lower temperature of 105, 105,100, and 100° C, corresponding to the four periodical aged samples. Finally, we can get that the thermal-electrical performance for a seven-year serviced cable could be enhanced, if they were thermally annealed at proper temperatures above the limited temperature during the cable in long-term temperature, even if the XLPE insulation suffered a further thermal aging test.

title: Impact of Molar Ratio and Temperature on Gold Nanoparticle Colloidal Stability and Size Distribution : A Zeta Sizer Analysis
authors: Anis Diyana Rosli, Nor Shahanim Mohamad Hadis, Khairul Adib Ishak, Aida Zulia Zulhanip, Nur Atiqah Azman
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: This study investigates the effects of citrate-to-gold molar ratio (MR) and synthesis temperature on the size distribution and colloidal stability of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) synthesized via the Turkevich method. Twelve distinct solutions were synthesized by systematically varying molar ratios (2.3, 2.5, 2.8, and 3.0) and temperatures (90°C, 95°C, and 100°C). Polydispersity index (PDI) analysis revealed that molar ratio had a significant impact on size distribution, with a 45% variation across different ratios. MR 2.8 consistently yielded the narrowest size distributions across all temperatures. While temperature had minimal impact on PDI, with less than 5% variation for two molar ratios, a synergistic effect between molar ratio and temperature was observed at MR 2.8, where the most monodisperse particles were obtained at 95°C (PDI = 0.336). Zeta potential measurements showed good colloidal stability across all conditions, ranging from -33.4 to -38.8 mV, with lower citrate-to-gold ratios (particularly MR 2.3) demonstrating enhanced stability. The effect of molar ratio on zeta potential was minimal, with less than 11.1% variation, while temperature changes resulted in less than 11.4% variation in zeta potential for each molar ratio. Notably, the conditions yielding the most monodisperse particles did not coincide with those providing maximum colloidal stability, highlighting the need to balance these properties based on application requirements.

title: Flow-Based Bayesian Updating for Finite Element Models in Digital Twins
authors: Shengxing Wei, Cheng Qian, Wenjuan Li, Yi Ren, Dongming Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium - Europe (RAMS-Europe)
abstract: SUMMARY & CONCLUSIONSThis paper introduces a flow-based Bayesian updating framework for finite element (FE) models in digital twin (DT) applications, addressing the challenges of real-time parameter updating and uncertainty quantification. By integrating conditional normalizing flows (CNFs) with Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) sampling, the proposed method eliminates the need for explicit likelihood derivation, significantly reducing computational costs while maintaining robust Bayesian inference. A case study on a fork component demonstrated the framework's effectiveness, achieving mean absolute percentage errors (MAPEs) below 4% for density and elastic modulus predictions. Elastic modulus exhibited higher accuracy and more reliable posterior distributions due to its stronger influence on system responses.Key findings highlight the importance of parameter sensitivity and prior selection in prediction accuracy, with uniform priors showing reduced efficiency when true parameters deviate from the prior mean. The methodology provides an efficient and scalable solution for real-time FE model calibration, offering broad applicability in engineering domains requiring dynamic parameter updates. Future work will focus on extending the framework to handle time-varying parameters and improving prior selection strategies to enhance robustness.

title: A Brief Discussion on the Technical Route for Enabling Substation Reclosing on 10kV All-Cable Lines
authors: Benhuang Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This article analyses the operation and maintenance status of a 10kV all-cable line in the Meizhou region over a three-year period and draws the following conclusions: in cable line tripping faults, non-permanent faults account for a much higher proportion than permanent faults, and among the non-permanent faults in cable lines, many are caused by outdoor platforms or line equipment that are not part of the cable equipment. Based on the above conclusions, the article outlines several technical approaches for enabling or disabling automatic reclosing on all-cable lines under different conditions.

title: Photovoltaic Module Parameter Extraction Based on Artificial Protozoa Optimizer
authors: Wenhao Lai, Duoduo Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: To effectively address the parameter extraction problem of photovoltaic (PV) cells, the high-performance Artificial Protozoa Optimizer (APO) is used for PV modules based on the Single Diode Model. Simulation experiments are conducted using the I–V characteristics of the polycrystalline STP6-120/36 module, with comparative analyses against several published algorithms, including ESO, NRBO, and WCA. The experimental results demonstrate that in dealing with the PV module parameter extraction problem, APO can obtain a minimum RMSE value comparable to the current optimal results and significantly outperform the others in terms of stability, as evidenced by its notably lower standard deviation. These findings affirm both the accuracy and robustness of APO in extracting PV module parameters.

title: Pulsed coherent laser wind measurement technology based on an improved multi-signal classification algorithm
authors: Hu Hong, Li Hong, Wen Libin, Xi Jinji, Tang Jingguang, Luo Yuying
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Pulsed coherent laser anemometry (PCLA), a remote sensing technique based on the Doppler effect, faces challenges in complex wind fields, including low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) sensitivity, multipath interference, and signal distortion. This study proposes an enhanced PCLA method using an improved Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) algorithm to address these limitations. A four-element circular pulsed LiDAR array is designed to encode wind speed and direction into time-delay differences, enabling spatiotemporal parameter identification. A Peak Matching Likelihood (PML) method extracts Doppler frequency shifts (DFS) with high precision. The MUSIC algorithm is further improved via wavelet threshold denoising and covariance matrix reconstruction to suppress noise and improve spatial resolution. Experimental validation in wind tunnels simulating airport runway turbulence (5–25 m/s wind speeds, 0°–360° directions, -10–20 dB SNR) demonstrates superior performance: wind speed errors are stabilized below 0.2 m/s, DFS extraction mean error is 0.6 at 20 dB SNR (95.6% lower standard deviation than conventional methods), and direction errors are <1° for low-level winds and ≤2° for high-level winds in double-layer cross fields. These results validate the method’s high precision, low-SNR robustness, and adaptability to complex wind fields, meeting GB/T 31163-2014 meteorological standards.

title: Semi-Supervised Seafloor Habitat Classification: A Pseudo-Labeling Framework
authors: Yani He, Shahrokh Heidari, Tegan Evans, Simon Thrush, Patrice Delmas
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Seafloor habitat classification plays an important role in marine ecology research, but manual labeling of underwater images is costly and time-consuming. This study explores the feasibility of applying semi-supervised learning using the pseudo-labeling strategy to improve classification performance under limited labeled seafloor data. The supervised stage begins with training on a small labeled dataset. The pseudo-labeling method is then applied using class-specific confidence thresholds. A class-balanced top- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> selection strategy is employed to iteratively expand the training set with high-confidence unlabeled samples. Our findings show that the proposed semi-supervised framework effectively leverages unlabeled data to improve classification performance, even when applied to a combined dataset of imagery from two geographically distinct regions.

title: Optimal Planning of Energy Hubs for Electrical Distribution Networks with Renewable Integration and Storage Systems: Analysis of Battery Degradation Costs and System Uncertainties
authors: Hossein Kiani, Mohammad Hassan Nazari, Seyed Hossein Hosseinian
abstract: Multi-carrier energy systems (MCES) integrate various energy carriers, such as electricity and natural gas, to provide a flexible and efficient framework for sustainable energy supply. In this regard, the energy hub (EH) has emerged as an innovative solution for optimizing resource management and enhancing energy efficiency. This paper presents a management framework for the efficient scheduling of an EH, which comprises three main components: (1) distributed generation (DG) units, including combined heat and power (CHP) systems, wind turbines (WTs), and photovoltaic-thermal (PVT) systems ; (2) electrical energy storage (EES); and (3) heating and Cooling systems, including heat pumps ) HPs) and absorption chillers (A.CHIL) . The suggested model is structured as a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem and is solved utilizing GAMS software. It determines the optimal operating points of energy assets to minimize costs and improve economic efficiency. Furthermore, the impact of battery degradation cost is incorporated into the economic analysis. The simulation results demonstrate that a well-structured optimization strategy for both storage units and generation assets not only reduces operational expenses but simultaneously improving the overall effectiveness of the EH while ensuring compliance with system constraints.

title: Design Space Exploration of FPGA-Based Spiking Neural Networks for Angle of Arrival Detection
authors: Cristina Bermúdez-Martín, Samuel López-Asunción, Pablo Ituero
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive design-space exploration of Spiking Neural Network (SNN) architectures for Angle-of-Arrival (AoA) estimation, a key challenge in Radio-Frequency (RF) signal processing. While traditional algorithms and conventional Artificial Neural Network (ANN) have been successfully implemented on hardware accelerators, the potential of SNN remains largely untapped. By implementing and testing various compact network architectures on reconfigurable hardware, we analyze the trade-offs between estimation accuracy, resource consumption, performance, and energy efficiency. Our findings reveal that even small-scale SNNs can deliver competitive precision, positioning them as promising candidates for lowpower, real-time embedded applications. This work highlights the advantages of adopting neuromorphic computing paradigms in RF systems and opens new avenues for further research.

title: Non-Invasive Near-Infrared (NIR) Spectroscopy Glucose Level Monitoring with ANN
authors: Ian Ting Chun Ing, Maximillian Fam Khiung Vui, Mohd Azhar Abdul Razak, Eileen Su Lee Ming, Fatin Hamimi Hamat Mustafa, Yeong Che Fai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Diabetes is an incurable disease at present. Patients with diabetes are frequently pressure to check their blood glucose level (BGL) to prevent complications associated with hyperglycemia. The traditional measure BGL methods are invasive, uncomfortable and time-consuming. The goal of this study is to provide a method for measuring BGL which is accurate and user-friendly. This is possible with application of near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy with a cloud-based Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model. The overall system structure consisted of three NIR LEDs which are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$940 ~\text{nm}, 1300 ~\text{nm}$</tex> and 1500 nm that activated sequentially by a microcontroller as these wavelengths can easily absorbed by glucose molecules. The intensity of the absorbed light was interpreted by a photodiode as analogy signals, which were filtered and sampled and then used to deduce the glucose concentration in the blood. Sensor data was then sent to Microsoft Azure Cloud Services via Wi-Fi using a NodeMCU ESP32. A single hidden layer backpropagation ANN regression model processes the sensor data and predicts BGL levels. Then the model was trained on glucose range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-20 \text{mmol} / \mathrm{L}$</tex>. The performance of the prediction result was evaluated with the coefficient of determination, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>, and Clarke's Error Grid Analysis. The proposed system gave <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 2 7 8}$</tex>. For Clarke's Error Grid Analysis, out of 10 validation samples, there was only 1 data point in region <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$D$</tex>, 2 data points in region <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B$</tex>, and 7 data points in region A.

title: Unified Granularity Controller for Interactive Segmentation
authors: Yian Zhao, Kehan Li, Pengchong Qiao, Chang Liu, Rongrong Ji, Jie Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Interactive Segmentation (IS) segments specific objects or parts by deducing human intent from sparse input prompts. However, the sparse-to-dense mapping is ambiguous, making it challenging for users to obtain segmentations at the desired granularity and causing them to engage in trial-and-error cycles. Although existing multi-granularity IS models (e.g., SAM) alleviate the ambiguity of single-granularity methods by predicting multiple masks simultaneously, this approach has limited scalability and produces redundant results. To address this issue, we introduce a creative granularity-controllable IS paradigm that resolves ambiguity by enabling users to precisely control the segmentation granularity. Specifically, we propose a Unified Granularity Controller (UniGraCo) that supports multi-type optional granularity control signals to pursue unified control over diverse segmentation requirements, effectively overcoming the limitation of single-type control in adapting to different needs, thus boosting the system efficiency and practicality. To mitigate the excessive cost of annotating the multi-granularity masks and the corresponding granularity control signals for training UniGraCo, we construct an automated data engine capable of generating high-quality and granularity-abundant mask-granularity data pairs at low cost. To enable UniGraCo to learn unified granularity controllability in an efficient and stable manner, we further design a granularity-controllable learning strategy. This strategy leverages the generated data pairs to incrementally equip the pre-trained IS model with granularity controllability while preserving its segmentation capability. Extensive experiments on intricate scenarios at both instance and part level demonstrate that our UniGraCo has significant advantages over previous methods, highlighting its potential as a practical interactive tool. Code and model weights are available at https://github.com/Zhao-Yian/UniGraCo.

title: Consumer-Centric Decentralized Federated Reinforcement Learning for Energy Scheduling in Community Integrated Energy System
authors: Hao Yang, Fanghong Guo, Xinwen Zhu, Lei Wang, Zhengguang Wu
abstract: This paper presents a consumer-centric decentralized federated reinforcement learning (DFRL)-based energy scheduling strategy for community integrated energy systems (CIES). In this strategy, each region assigns one agent that can independently manage the CIES by training its own local network. Different from both the multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm, which relies on a shared experience pool, and the traditional federated learning reinforcement learning method, where a central server (CS) is required for parameter aggregation, our proposed DFRL algorithm allows the local agent only to share and update network parameters in a round-robin sequence without the need for a CS. This leads to simple algorithm design and easy implementation, and privacy is also preserved, as no agent has access to the local data of other agents, while still enabling cooperative optimization among the CIESs. In addition, as no CS is required, the single-point failure risk can be avoided. Experimental evaluations on a 4-region 5-equipment CIES show that RR-DFRL achieves a total operating cost of $201,250.39, which is within 8.46% of the Gurobi optimum ($185,556.65), and requires 0.636 s online computing time versus 6.37 s for Gurobi. The total communication overhead in training is 42.50 MiB, lower than CFRL (85.00 MiB) and far below MADDPG (2404.74 MiB), all while maintaining data privacy.
