title: Cloud property retrieval based on DISAMAR using Oxygen-A and Oxygen-B band measurements by TROPOMI on Sentinel-5P
authors: Xiaoyun Zhang, Ping Wang, Piet Stammes, Maarten Sneep, Tao Xie, Feng Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: DISAMAR (Determining Instrument Specifications and Analyzing Methods for Atmospheric Retrieval) is a radiative transfer model developed to simulate retrievals of atmospheric components and surface properties. This paper evaluates the performance of the DISAMAR retrieval algorithm using TROPOMI spectral measurements of the O₂-A (757-770 nm) and O₂-B (685-691 nm) bands for cloud-free scenes and fully cloudy scenes. For fully cloudy scenes, cloud pressure and cloud optical thickness are retrieved and compared with FRESCO-S, ROCINN and VIIRS cloud products. For cloud-free scenes, the surface pressure and surface albedo are fitted, the results are compared with ERA5 surface pressure and TROPOMI DLER datasets respectively. Several parameters in DISAMAR retrieval settings are tested, including the stray light settings, the fitting wavelength windows, the a-priori values of the fitting parameters, and the performance of oxygen cross-section datasets (JPL2008, HITRAN 2008/2012/2020). As expected, DISAMAR retrieves cloud mid-level pressure values closely matching FRESCO-S and ROCINN, especially when fitting the O₂-A band. Cloud optical thickness (COT) and cloud top pressure show better correlation with VIIRS data when fitting the O₂-A band than O₂-B band. For thick clouds, fitting stray light is not advisable, and a specific a-priori value of COT is unnecessary. Using the HITRAN2020 dataset provides more accurate spectral simulations. Fitting the O₂-A band yields results closer to both FRESCO-S and VIIRS, while the O₂-B band yields results closer to ROCINN and serves as a useful supplement. Excluding high-residual wavelengths in the fitting window further improves retrievals.

title: Innovative Three and Four-Output-Port Bridge (TOPB and FOPB) for Series and Parallel Multilevel Inverters: Graph-Theoretic Analysis, Modulation Techniques, and Their Application
authors: Omid Zolfagharian, Mohsin Jamil, Hafiz Furqan Ahmed
abstract: This article presents a novel three-output-port bridge (TOPB) for multilevel inverters (MLIs), designed to optimize the interaction between input sources in both series and parallel configurations. Unlike conventional multilevel converters, which feature two output ports supporting only series interactions, the proposed TOPB includes three output ports, two of which interface with conventional MLIs or a power switch to enable parallel interactions alongside series connections. A four-output-port bridge (FOPB) serves as an intersection cell for two TOPBs, facilitating the extension to a higher number of voltage levels. A rigorous mathematical analysis compares the structural properties of the cascaded TOPB (CTOPB) and cascaded H-bridge (CHB) topologies. By modeling both configurations as graphs, we evaluate connectivity metrics, including adjacency matrices, Laplacian matrices, and algebraic connectivity. The results demonstrate that CTOPB-MLI exhibits superior connectivity, attributed to its three-output-port architecture. This freedom offers valuable insights for single-source, multisource multilevel converters, and store-and-forward energy MLI. Furthermore, a one-dimensional space vector modulation (OD-SVM) technique is introduced to efficiently control modular converters using predefined switching tables. This approach enhances performance and addresses challenges associated with conventional modulation techniques, particularly in managing noncomplementary switching signals. The CTOPB topology’s performance is validated through comprehensive simulation and experimental results.

title: Dynamic Phasor Modeling and Virtual Impedance Control of Two Paralleled Grid-Forming Converters
authors: Wenjia Si, Jingyang Fang
abstract: Grid-forming converters (GFMCs) have evolved into the enabler of modern power systems. When equipped with energy storage, they can act as either generators or loads. However, the modeling and control of paralleled GFMCs, including the GFMC operating as the generator and load, have not been fully explored. To fill in the research gap, this article proposes a dynamic phasor model of two paralleled GFMCs. The proposed GFMC model comprehensively encompasses crucial elements. In particular, transmission line dynamics are excluded from existing models yet proven to have a noticeable effect on system stability and hence should be modeled. Building on the proposed model, this article further performs stability analysis and derives stable boundaries, which verify that the proposed model achieves a 50% accuracy improvement as compared with the state-of-the-art model. Through analyses, it is revealed that a large line inductance or a low R/X ratio can translate into better stability in the low-frequency region, while an excessively low R/X ratio unavoidably amplifies the high-frequency oscillations caused by transmission line dynamics. Subsequently, such findings allow an optimal design of virtual impedance control. Experimental results validate the improved accuracy of the proposed dynamic phasor model and the effectiveness of virtual impedance control.

title: Wearable FBG Sensing System based on Optoelectronic Oscillator for High-resolution Vital-sign Detection
authors: Tongtong Xie, Wenzhao Liu, Mengyuan Wu, Zhiyi Li, Liangcheng Lin, Hao Chen, Hongyan Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Fiber optic sensors (FOS) have garnered significant attention as ideal tools for remote health monitoring and disease diagnosis, owing to their compact dimensions, resilience to electromagnetic interference, and seamless integration into communication networks. Here, we present a high-precision and wearable fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensing system based on an optoelectronic oscillator (OEO) for monitoring vital signs. The sensor head is a commercial FBG embedded within a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrate, which can achieve an elastic modulus akin to human skin. In contrast to traditional demodulation methods that employ costly and bulky FBG demodulation equipment, we utilize OEO for demodulation, which has garnered adjustable sensitivity, rapid demodulation speed, and ultra-high instrument-limited resolution (approximately several orders of magnitude higher than optical-domain demodulation methods). By employing a mixer to down-convert the detection frequency to below 100 kHz, we achieve a sensitivity similar to high-frequency detection, thus significantly reducing the overall detection cost. Compared to intensity-based demodulation methods, our scheme, which employs frequency-based demodulation, offers greater resistance to interference. Furthermore, we have demonstrated the capability of the system for monitoring vital signs such as respiration rate, wrist pulse, limb movements, and facial muscle activity. This study establishes a new technical foundation for high-resolution and wearable vital signs monitoring technology, aiming to meet the future demands of remote disease diagnosis and health monitoring.

title: Extracting the Single-Dispersion Fractional Cole-Cole Bioimpedance Model based on Low-pass Filter Technique
authors: Pipat Prommee, Jirat Chimnoy, Natapong Wongprommoon, Khunanon Karawanich
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents a simple approach to extracting the parameters of the single-dispersion Cole-Cole bioimpedance model. The main advantage of the proposed technique is that it is low-cost but accurate in identifying the bioimpedance models. The Cole-Cole model is simplified as a fractional low-pass filter (LPF) using a few electronic components. Based on a low-component count, the circuit can be realized using only a single operational amplifier (OPAMP), two resistors, and two potentiometers (POTs). The proposed technique can achieve a minimal error compared to the theory, ensuring accuracy. The Cole-Cole model parameter values can be extracted by measuring the filter magnitude and phase responses. The LPF topology inherently provides a low-noise output signal. Experimental results using different fruits are carried out to verify the method and compared with measurements from a commercial impedance analyzer to confirm the accuracy of the results, with the maximum errors of R0, R∞, α, and Cα being 0.94%, 2.41%, 0.85%, and 1.52%, respectively. The proposed new efficient technique provides excellent results in extracting the Cole-Cole parameters and agrees with the theoretical expectations.

title: A Federated Multi-scale Diagnostic Strategy for Bearing Compound Faults with Dynamic Privacy Preservation
authors: Cunsong Wang, Jiangle Yu, Mingyu Xu, Moshu Qian, Senlin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: As critical components of rotating machinery, bearings play a vital role in mechanical systems, making their health management and maintenance highly significant. However, current data-driven fault diagnosis techniques for bearings face three major challenges: difficulty in extracting fault features under variable-speed conditions, challenges in isolating compound fault characteristics, and insufficient data protection mechanisms. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Secure Federated Learning framework integrating a Dual-channel Convolutional Neural Network with a Transformer (SFLDFormer), which enables effective extraction of compound fault features under variable speeds and achieves accurate fault diagnosis. In terms of data protection, a noise-injection-based secure aggregation mechanism is introduced to effectively defend against data reconstruction attacks during the early stages of federated learning, ensuring the privacy and security of rotating component fault data throughout the distributed modeling process. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method maintains high diagnostic accuracy for compound faults under both constant and variable speed conditions. This work paves a feasible path toward building a secure and trustworthy cross-enterprise collaborative diagnostic system.

title: Cell-Free Distributed Precoding without Iterations on Unreliable Fronthaul by Quadratic Team Learning
authors: Ziyao Hong, Junli Xue, Xinjiang Xia, Ting Li, Shu Xu, Chunguo Li, Dongming Wang, Xiaohu You
abstract: Cell-free massive multi-input-multi-output (CF-mMIMO) provides significant improvement owing to the distributed architecture. However, it suffers from the constraints including information constraints, and computation resources constraints. In this paper, we propose 4 ranks of available information in CF-mMIMO and aim to find a distributed precoding exploiting randomly accessible side information, which is one-step without iterations and robust against the unreliable fronthaul between distributed central processing units. Quadratic team learning (QTL) is devised which is derived from team theory to handle the distributed underdetermined quadratic programming. The extensive 1440 experiments validate the superiority of QTL and we believe QTL is a definitely excellent choice for CF-mMIMO distributed precoding. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work utilizing team theory to help the design of artificial intelligence architecture for wireless communications. To prompt the development of QTL, we have open-sourced the implementation code on https://github.com/hzy238221seu/QTL4CF-Precoding.git.

title: A Rotary mmWave Radar for All-directional Pedestrian Trajectory Tracking
authors: Danke Jiang, Yingjie Ye, Zibin Wang, Zhishang Cheng, Zhenyu Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The limited Field of View (FOV) of a single millimeter-Wave (mmWave) radar represents a instrumentation constraint for continuous pedestrian trajectory tracking. To address this challenge, this study proposes an all-directional pedestrian tracking method using a rotary mmWave radar platform. The designed electro-mechanical system leverages Spatio-Temporal Multiplexing (STM) measurement scheme, enabling a single radar to function as multiple virtual radars to achieve all-directional continuous tracking measurement application. Furthermore, the Multiple Virtual Radars Tracking (MVRT) model is introduced to divide the generated virtual radar array form the elector-mechanical system into multiple independent all-directional tracking subsystems, thereby reducing detection error by fusing data from these subsystems. Additionally, the varying initial orientations of the subsystems create different relative angles for the pedestrian’s position, which introduces inter-subsystem heterogeneity. To address this, the Dynamic Weight Particle Filter (DWPF) is proposed, a specialized method that dynamically adjusts the weighting coefficients for each tracking subsystem based on the pedestrian’s predicted position. Experimental results validate the method’s all-directional pedestrian tracking capability, achieving a mean position error of 0.10 m in U-shaped paths. The system demonstrates robust performance across various motion trajectories and numbers of pedestrians, even in challenging scenarios involving obstacles and multi-pedestrian intersections.

title: Endo-DFD: Deep Flow-to-Depth in Endoscopy with Uncertainty-Driven Recurrent Refinement
authors: Yongming Yang, Peng Wang, Shuwei Shao, Ziliang Song, Hesheng Wang, Hao Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Dense depth estimation from monocular video frames provides accurate intraoperative 3D point clouds for augmented reality surgical navigation. However, multi-frame depth estimation within the endoscopic scene suffers from the inaccurate matching of geometric relationships under subtle camera movements. To address this challenge, we propose a novel deep flow-to-depth method with uncertainty-driven recurrent refinement. Specifically, a pixel-wise uncertainty-driven optimizer is proposed to iteratively refine depth predictions instead of the traditional cost volume, effectively reducing depth errors caused by low textures and illumination variations. Furthermore, a two-view geometry with motion simulator is employed to augment the optical flow network’s ability to explore temporal correlations under subtle camera movements. Extensive cross-datasets experiments demonstrate the superior accuracy and generalization of our method, achieving RMSE values of 6.566 on C3VD, 7.972 on EndoSLAM, and 16.697 on ColonDepth datasets. Qualitative evaluation conducted on clinical dataset demonstrates the promising ability of our method to accurately estimate realistic anatomical structures in real-world scenarios. The code will be accessible at the following link: https://github. com/ILSR-SIA/Endo-DFD.

title: Comparison of Conventional Machine Learning and Convolutional Deep Learning models for Seagrass Mapping using Satellite Imagery
authors: A. Mederos-Barrera, L. Albors, F. Marques, J. Marcello, G. Martinez, F. Eugenio
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Benthic communities, such as seagrass meadows, play a crucial environmental role in marine ecosystems and provide socio-economic benefits. Satellite remote sensing is currently used for their monitoring, and Deep Learning (DL) techniques offer improvements in mapping quality compared to traditional Machine Learning (ML). This study compares conventional ML and convolutional DL models for mapping Cymodocea nodosa meadows in El Río, Canary Islands, using WorldView-2 satellite imagery. An in-situ measurement campaign was conducted to generate an open dataset for segmentation. Evaluated models include Decision Trees, Gaussian Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines, K-Nearest Neighbors, Subspace KNN, Feedforward Neural Networks, U-Net, Attention U-Net, and Pix2Pix models. Results show that DL models significantly outperform conventional ML models in detecting Cymodocea nodosa. The best model (U-net) achieved an Intersection over Union (IoU) of 83% overall and 74% for Cymodocea nodosa, while the best ML model (FNN) only reached 62% and 23%, respectively. IoU was highlighted for its sensitivity to minor mapping changes. Additionally, a temporal analysis revealed a dramatic 96% reduction in Cymodocea nodosa coverage over 21 years, from 245.32 ha in 2001 to 9.31 ha in 2022. This study not only compares conventional ML and convolutional DL techniques for benthic habitat mapping but also provides a valuable methodology and dataset for future marine ecosystem monitoring research.

title: Robust Traffic Forecasting With Disentangled Spatiotemporal Graph Neural Networks
authors: Ting Wang, Rui Luo, Daqian Shi, Hao Deng, Shengjie Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Traffic prediction is a cornerstone of intelligent transportation systems (ITSs). The effectiveness of existing spatiotemporal graph neural networks (STGNNs) heavily relies on the independent identically distributed (i.i.d.) assumption of traffic data, which is frequently violated in practice because of distribution shifts owing to exogenous factors. While learning features that remain stable across all environments is promising for modeling robust frameworks, the fundamental challenge involves the decomposition of invariant features from the dynamic nature of spatiotemporal dependencies. In this article, we propose the disentangled spatiotemporal (DIST) graph neural networks, a novel framework for robust traffic forecasting considering distribution shifts. In DIST, latent invariant variables are explicitly decoupled from dynamically evolving spatiotemporal dependencies, enabling the learning of topology-agnostic representations resilient to distribution shifts. Specifically, we formulate a causality-driven learning objective that guides the separation of invariant variables from various exogenous factors. We then propose a spatiotemporal graph modeling module that can adaptively capture spatiotemporal dependencies in evolving traffic systems. Furthermore, we present a graph perturbation module to simulate topology variations during training, thereby encouraging the model to identify perturbation-sensitive dependencies and infer invariant and variant features for prediction and intervention tasks. The prediction risk and its variance on multiple interventional distributions are minimized in our learning strategy, allowing the model to identify invariant features, thus improving its robustness. The results of comprehensive real-world experiments demonstrate the superiority of our approach. The source code is available: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/tingwang25/DIST</uri>

title: Demonstration of Nitrogen-Polar InGaN-based Red Light Emitting Diodes
authors: Yusen Wang, JingKai Zhao, Changcai Zuo, Yuliang Liu, Haozhe Gao, Gaoqiang Deng, Tianpeng Yang, Yuantao Zhang
abstract: Red light-emitting diodes (LEDs) are at the forefront of current research in III-nitride semiconductors. The researches have shown that nitrogen-polar (N-polar) InGaN material facilitates the incorporation of indium, and N-polar InGaN-based LEDs are more conducive to carrier injection and confinement. This confers significant application potential for N-polar InGaN in red LEDs. In this work, we developed a novel metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) growth process for N-polar InGaN/GaN quantum wells (QWs) and successfully fabricated N-polar red LEDs. We achieved a significant red shift in the emission wavelength of the N-polar QWs by increasing the growth pressure of the well layer and reducing the V/III ratio, as well as modulating the stress of GaN template layer. Compared to metal-polar QWs, N-polar QWs fabricated using the new growth process exhibited a wavelength red shift exceeding 100 nm at the same growth temperature. Utilizing the new growth process, the efficiency of N-polar green LEDs increases by 1.5 times compared to previous results. Further, we fabricated N-polar red LEDs with an emission wavelength of 615 nm. This work demonstrates the feasibility and advantages of using N-polar InGaN for red LEDs fabrication, contributing to the advancement of nitride-based red LEDs.

title: Advanced Cooling Optimization for 5G Base Station via a Three-Stage Hybrid Learning Approach
authors: Yaping Liu, Jiang Wu, Zhanbo Xu, Di Wang, Xiaohong Guan
abstract: As data traffic and information services surge, 5G base stations (BSs) have become primary energy consumers in wireless networks, with cooling accounting for 40% of BS power use and driving high operational expenditure. This underscores the need for energy-efficient optimization of cooling control. However, existing model-based and AI-driven optimization methods face critical limitations in real-world deployments, including limited generalizability across heterogeneous BSs resulting from their high scenario dependence, the inherent tradeoff between control stability and dynamic adaptability under complex operating conditions, and high deployment costs due to computational demands. To address these challenges, this article develops a three-stage hybrid learning (TSHL) approach that integrates imitation learning, ensemble learning, and deep reinforcement learning into a three-stage offline-to-online architecture, enabling expert knowledge transfer from data-rich BSs to generate high-quality initial policies for data-scarce ones, while online learning ensures continuous adaptation to local dynamics. In addition, we propose a cost-efficient deployment mechanism that leverages only existing monitoring data without additional hardware costs, employs hybrid experience policy updates within a deep Dyna-Q-based architecture to enhance learning efficiency, and incorporates a safety-constrained exploration to enhance policy reliability. Extensive evaluations on both a simulation testbed and a real-world 5G BS demonstrate that TSHL achieves over 18.36% cooling energy savings and outperforms baseline methods in cold-start effectiveness, online adaptability, operational reliability, and overall cost-efficiency. These results highlight TSHL as a practical solution for sustainable 5G BS operations, especially for data-scarce BSs, such as retrofitted or newly established sites, offering a scalable pathway to network-wide energy savings.

title: Adaptive Topological Similarity Learning for Incomplete Multi-view Unsupervised Feature Selection
authors: Lin Xu, Ke Li, Dongjie Wang, Fanyin Zhou, Fengmao Lv, Tianrui Li, Yanyong Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Although multi-view unsupervised feature selection is a promising technique for dimensionality reduction on unlabeled multi-view data, existing methods cannot directly address incomplete data, where certain samples are missing in specific views. These methods typically begin by imputing missing data using predetermined values, followed by performing feature selection on the completed dataset. However, the separation of imputation and feature selection processes fails to exploit their inherent synergy, as local structural information obtained from feature selection could guide the imputation process and, in turn, improve the overall effectiveness of feature selection. In addition, previous methods rely on similarity graphs based on Euclidean distance to preserve the local manifold structure but overlook the topological relationships within the data, thereby hindering accurate capture of intrinsic structures. In this paper, we propose an adaptive topological similarity learning for incomplete multi-view unsupervised feature selection method (ATSL-IMUFS) to address the aforementioned issues. ATSL-IMUFS first integrates multi-view feature selection and missing data imputation into a unified learning framework. Then, it adaptively learns similarity graphs for each view while simultaneously capturing the consensus topological relationship across views, effectively characterizing the local manifold structure. Extensive experiments conducted on real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of ATSL-IMUFS compared to competing methods.

title: Transformer Driven Visual Servoing for Fabric Texture Matching Using Dual-Arm Manipulator
authors: Fuyuki Tokuda, Akira Seino, Akinari Kobayashi, Kai Tang, Kazuhiro Kosuge
abstract: In this paper, we propose a method to align and place a fabric piece on top of another using a dual-arm manipulator and a grayscale camera, so that their surface textures are accurately matched. We propose a novel control scheme that combines Transformer-driven visual servoing with dual-arm impedance control. This approach enables the system to simultaneously control the pose of the fabric piece and place it onto the underlying one while applying tension to keep the fabric piece flat. Our transformer-based network incorporates pre-trained backbones and a newly introduced Difference Extraction Attention Module (DEAM), which significantly enhances pose difference prediction accuracy. Trained entirely on synthetic images generated using rendering software, the network enables zero-shot deployment in real-world scenarios without requiring prior training on specific fabric textures. Real-world experiments demonstrate that the proposed system accurately aligns fabric pieces with different textures.

title: Improving Gecko Adhesive Performance in Robotic Systems through Trajectory Optimization
authors: Dror Kobo, Goren Gordon, Bat-El Pinchasik
abstract: Gecko-inspired adhesives have attracted considerable attention due to their unique combination of strong, yet reversible adhesion to diverse surfaces. However, their integration into robotic systems remains limited due to sensitivity to contact alignment, typically requiring near-perpendicular engagement. Yet, many robotic tasks involve varying approach and detachment angles, highlighting the need for adhesion that operates reliably across different orientations and loading conditions. This study addresses two key questions: Can the adhesion strength of gecko-inspired adhesives, integrated into robotic systems, be optimized using trajectory optimization? And is this optimization surface-dependent? A gecko-inspired adhesive was integrated on a robotic arm's end-effector, which attached to and detached from surfaces along various trajectories. The arm's energy expenditure for each attachment-detachment cycle, along with the corresponding adhesion strength, were measured. Online particle swarm optimization algorithm was applied to identify conditions that improve adhesion strength and facilitate detachment. Results show that trajectory optimization significantly improves both adhesion strength and detachment efficiency up to 17-fold, with surface-specific effectiveness. These findings underscore the importance of considering both the forces generated by gecko-inspired adhesives and the energy required by the robot to attach and detach from surfaces at various angles and positions. Using optimization, this study helps overcome current limitations in the use of gecko-inspired adhesives for robotic applications, including grippers and climbers.

title: Towards Understanding the Tradeoff between Privacy Preservation and Byzantine-Robustness in Decentralized Learning_supp1-3642292.pdf
authors: Qing Ling
abstract: This paper jointly investigates privacy preservation and Byzantine-robustness in decentralized learning. In a decentralized network, honest-but-curious agents faithfully follow the prescribed algorithm, but expect to infer their neighbors' private data from messages received during the learning process, while dishonest-and-Byzantine agents disobey the prescribed algorithm, and deliberately disseminate wrong messages to their neighbors for the sake of biasing the learning process. For this novel setting, we investigate a generic privacy-preserving and Byzantine-robust decentralized stochastic gradient descent (SGD) framework, in which Gaussian noise is injected to preserve privacy and robust aggregation rules are adopted to counteract Byzantine attacks. We analyze its learning error and privacy guarantee, discovering an essential tradeoff between privacy preservation and Byzantine-robustness in decentralized learning – the learning error caused by defending against Byzantine attacks is exacerbated by the Gaussian noise added to preserve privacy. For a class of state-of-the-art robust aggregation rules, we give unified analysis of their “mixing abilities”. Building upon this analysis, we reveal how the “mixing abilities” affect the tradeoff between privacy preservation and Byzantine-robustness. The theoretical results provide guidelines for achieving a favorable tradeoff with proper design of robust aggregation rules. Numerical experiments are conducted and corroborate our theoretical findings.

title: A pipeline to obtain a dynamic 3D-Brain Model using the fastsurfer deep learning model from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
authors: Eduardo Ignacio Castellón Castillo, Josué Daniel Rivera Fernández, Karen Roa Tort, Rodrigo Mercado Pimentel, Diego Adrián Fabila Bustos, Macaria Hernández Chávez
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: Three-Dimensional (3D) anatomical modeling plays a critical role in medical education and training, benefiting medical students, residents, specialists, and biologists by enabling both, physical and digital visualization of human and animal anatomy. In the context of neurology and neurosurgery, such models facilitate the comprehension of brain structures and their morphological characteristics. However, commercially available models are typically derived from generic templates, resulting in limited anatomical accuracy.This work presents a computational pipeline for generating anatomically accurate 3D brain models from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data, leveraging FastSurfer, a deep learning framework based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The segmentation process exemplifies the application of modern neural network architectures and machine learning techniques in the biomedical domain. This approach supports the study of the brain as a complex system and lays groundwork for future integration with network-based models of neural connectivity.

title: An Open-Source, Biomimetic, Anthropomorphic Robotic and Prosthetic Hand Testbed for the Execution of Dexterous Manipulation Tasks
authors: Masahiro Kobayashi, Mahonri Owen, Minas Liarokapis
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: The human hand is an extraordinary example of evolution, capable of performing a wide range of tasks from intricate manipulation tasks to powerful grasps. Replicating such versatility and dexterity in both robotic and prosthetic hands is a longstanding engineering challenge. Despite paramount efforts from academia and industry, robotic and prosthetic hands still fall behind their human counterparts in many aspects, including dexterity. Closing this gap is essential for robotic and prosthetic hand applications such as general humanoids, prostheses, service robotics, and human-robot interaction, in which the need for human-like capabilities is of high significance. This paper presents the design of a highly actuated, 24-DoF, tendon-driven anthropomorphic robotic hand testbed for dexterous manipulation tasks. The hand is designed to be lightweight, affordable, and accessible with readily available components. A series of experiments is conducted to evaluate the hand's design and performance. Results show that the hand possesses a comparable workspace to the Shadow Hand and high repeatability in finger movements, essential for accurate sim2real transfer.

title: Performance evaluation of a novel hybrid system integrating LAES with Brayton Cycle for LNG cold energy recovery
authors: H. Si, Q. Hong, L. Jiang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Liquid air energy storage (LAES) is a promising large-scale technology for low-carbon grid balancing, yet standalone systems discard a significant share of compression heat. Simultaneously, high-grade cold exergy released during liquefied natural gas (LNG) regasification is largely wasted. To valorise both energy streams, this paper proposes a novel LAES-Brayton integration in which an intermediate closed Brayton cycle simultaneously harvests the excess heat from LAES discharge stage and the cryogenic exergy from LNG regasification. Thermodynamic modelling reveals that the integrated system attains an LNG cold energy utilization efficiency of 58.18 %, higher than the standalone LAES, and an exergy efficiency of 60.16%. These figures position the LAES-Brayton configuration among the most efficient large-scale storage options while offering additional operational flexibility for both the power grid and LNG terminals.

title: Deep Learning-Based Ripeness Classification of Mangosteen Under Natural Imaging Conditions
authors: Mintra Boondach, Parkpoom Chaisiriprasert
abstract: Mangosteen is one of Thailand's most valuable tropical fruits, with ripeness levels significantly influencing its taste, texture, market value, and export quality. Conventional ripeness assessment relies on manual visual inspection, which is subjective and unsuitable for large-scale operations. To address this limitation, this study proposes an automated image-based ripeness classification system. A dataset of 2,478 mangosteen images, categorized into five ripeness stages and captured under varied natural conditions, was used for training and evaluation. The methodology begins with preprocessing steps, including color balance and Retinex, hueguided enhancement, and CLAHE combined with sharpening, to improve image quality and emphasize key ripeness features. Feature extraction is then performed using a CSPDarknet backbone, a PAN-FPN neck, and a decoupled detection head to capture both low- and high-level visual cues. The extracted features are subsequently evaluated with three models: YOLOv12, Faster R-CNN, and EfficientNetV2-B0. Experimental results show that YOLOv12 achieved the best performance with an average <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5$</tex> of 74.0 %, surpassing Faster R-CNN (41.0 %) and EfficientNetV2-B0 (52.0%), confirming the effectiveness of the proposed system as a robust, non-invasive solution for smart agriculture and post-harvest quality control.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Classification Using KNN and MLP Probability Aggregation
authors: Somnuek Surathong, Chakkraphop Maisen
abstract: This research investigates the classification performance of various modeling approaches, including single classifiers, ensemble techniques, and a novel hybrid framework that integrates K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) with a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP). The proposed method, referred to as KNN(k)MLP Probability Aggregation (KMA), employs the KNN algorithm to identify the k nearest neighbors of a given instance. These neighbors are subsequently processed through a pre-trained MLP, which outputs class probabilities. The aggregated probabilities are then used to determine the final classification outcome. The evaluation was conducted using four benchmark datasets from the UCI Machine Learning Repository: Haberman, Heart, Sonar, and Pima. Experimental results indicate that the KMA model consistently outperforms conventional single classifiers and established ensemble methods in terms of both classification accuracy and Fl-score. The integration of KNN's spatial locality with MLP's pattern learning capability enables the hybrid model to effectively address the complexities inherent in real-world datasets. These findings underscore the potential of hybrid learning architectures to enhance classification performance across diverse application domains.

title: MRI Compatible Focused Ultrasound Phantom for Breast Targets
authors: Christakis Damianou, Antria Filippou
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: The proposed study focuses on an agar-based tissue mimicking phantom with an embedded tumor mimic that can be used to test therapeutic protocols for Focused Ultrasound (FUS) systems for breast. The material around the tumor consists of agar and water, whereas the tumor mimic includes water, agar, and silicon dioxide. This difference in the silicon dioxide content resulted in excellent contrast between the tumor and surrounding normal tissue in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Ultrasonic ablation was performed within the phantom using a single element transducer which is attached to an MRI compatible robotic system under Magnetic Resonance (MR) thermometry guidance in a 3 T MRI scanner. Based on MRI images it was possible to move the ultrasonic beam within the phantom very accurately. MR thermometry monitoring within the tumor revealed ablative temperatures as a result of sonications. Post-ablation MRI images acquired in a plane parallel to the beam revealed lesion deflection at the tumor boundaries. Overall, the developed tumor phantom model was proven a very reliable tool to assess ultrasonic protocols, and provides a high contrast tool for tumor identification.

title: 3D Point Cloud Snow Removal Technology based on Graph-Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Zixue Liu, Yulin Zhou, Libing Bai, Kun She
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Intelligent Technology and Embedded Systems (ICITES)
abstract: Due to its ability to generate high-quality 3D point cloud data, lidar sensors are widely used in many fields, especially in unmanned driving. However, in bad weather conditions, such as fog, snow, and so on, the sensor is easy to produce large noise, which affects the quality of 3D point cloud data. At present, there are statistical methods, such as SOR, and ROR, and methods based on deep learning, such as WeatherNet, which have more or less their defects. In this study, a 3D point cloud data snow removal technology based on Graph Convolutional Neural Network (GCN) is proposed. Compared with ordinary deep learning, this study does feature extraction in the data preprocessing step. It introduces an attention mechanism into the GCN network for optimization, to remove noise points more effectively. We do a large number of experiments on the real WADS dataset to verify that our snow removal method significantly outperforms the baseline methods, which proves that our method achieves good results in point cloud denoising. The proposed method is designed with embedded and cyber-physical systems (CPS) in mind, offering the potential for real-time deployment in autonomous driving platforms. By integrating multi-scale graph aggregation strategies with hardware-aware optimizations, the method establishes a new paradigm for resource-constrained cyber-physical systems.

title: Enhancing Wide-Angle VR Video Transmission Using Human Perception
authors: Anastasia Mozhaeva, Igor Vlasuyk, Aleksei Potashnikov, Noor Alani, Steven J. Rogers, Lee Streeter
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Limited radio transmission bandwidth seriously limits the ability to use wide-angle video in technology. This problem is caused by video compression techniques currently being substantially sub-optimal for large field-of-view, leading to video transmission not being fast enough. While modern video compression leverages spatial redundancy to minimise data from the visual periphery, it often neglects temporal redundancy. Our research focuses on wide-angle video processing, considering spatial-temporal human visual models, and demonstrates that incorporating temporal knowledge of human visual perception into video transmission could reduce up to 60 % of bitrate without loss in quality. To enable optimal video transmission, we developed a new method for processing spatio-temporal information. Its performance was validated through a human perceptual quality study that employed established 2D virtual reality datasets alongside a newly obtained dataset using our approach. We believe our research will open users ' eyes to see in real-time through VR headsets.

title: Multi-Branch Vision Transformer for Early Skin Cancer Detection
authors: Jirachat Rujiwan, Khachonkit Chuiad, Parkpoom Chaisiriprasert
abstract: Early detection of skin cancer is vital, with timely diagnosis preventing up to 99% of melanoma-related deaths; however, severe dermatologist shortages in developing regions (ratios as high as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1: 200,000$</tex>) lead to life-threatening delays. Existing CNN-based systems show limitations, including inadequate global pattern recognition, lack of interpretability, and poor performance on rare conditions. This study proposes a multi-branch Vision Transformer (ViT) that integrates classical computer vision with deep learning for automated dermoscopic analysis. The framework combines Sobel edge detection to align with ABCDE clinical criteria, Local Binary Patterns for micro-texture representation, and pretrained ViT embeddings for semantic extraction. Multi-branch patch embedding enables attention-based feature weighting across modalities. Validation on 8,318 dermoscopic images covering seven lesion categories achieved 92.0 % accuracy and 89.5 % macro-F1. Importantly, the model reached 94.0 % recall in melanoma detection and maintained <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 2. 0 \%}$</tex> precision for rare Dermatofibroma, demonstrating robustness, interpretability, and potential for deployment in resource-limited clinical settings.

title: Advance Control Scheme for Precise Temperature Regulation of Peltier Module
authors: Samruddhi Meena Sidmul, Amruta Deshpande, Nikunj Mahajan
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: This paper illustrates the design and development of advance control scheme for precise temperature regulation of a Peltier module. Peltier modules are widely used for thermal management in various applications, but achieving precise temperature control remains a challenge due to nonlinearities and uncertainties in the system. To address these challenges, advanced control strategies, including On-Off control, PID control, and Sliding Mode Controller (SMC) are designed and implemented. Simulation and experimental studies evaluate the effectiveness of each control algorithm, demonstrating significant improvements in temperature regulation accuracy, response time, and robustness. The results validate the efficacy of the proposed advanced control scheme for practical applications requiring precise temperature control.

title: Performance Evaluation of Deep Learning for Tree Branch Segmentation in Autonomous Forestry Systems
authors: Yida Lin, Bing Xue, Mengjie Zhang, Sam Schofield, Richard Green
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: UAV-based autonomous forestry operations require rapid and precise tree branch segmentation for safe navigation and automated pruning across varying pixel resolutions and operational conditions. We evaluate different deep learning methods at three resolutions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(256 \times 256,512 \times 512,1024 \times 1024)$</tex> using the Urban Street Tree Dataset, employing standard metrics (IoU, Dice) and specialized measures including Thin Structure IoU (TSIoU) and Connectivity Preservation Rate (CPR). Among 22 configurations tested, U-Net with MiT-B4 backbone achieves strong performance at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \times 256$</tex>. At <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$512 \times 512$</tex>, MiT-B4 leads in IoU, Dice, TS-IoU, and Boundary-F1. At <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1024 \times 1024$</tex>, U-Net+MiT-B3 shows the best validation performance for IoU/Dice and precision, while U-Net++ excels in boundary quality. PSPNet provides the most efficient option (2.36/9.43/37.74 GFLOPs) with 25.7/19.6/11.8 percentage point IoU reductions compared to top performers at respective resolutions. These results establish multi-resolution benchmarks for accuracy-efficiency trade-offs in embedded forestry systems. Implementation is available at https://github.com/BennyLinntu/Performance_Tree_Branch_Segmentation.

title: Exploring Multi-Angle Imaging for Food Safety and Security Through Computer Vision
authors: Norazrai Daniel Afiq Razali, Nik Mohd Zarifie Hashim, Muhammad Nur Amir Che Hamid, Mahmud Dwi Sulistiyo, Noor Ziela Abd Rahman, Salizawati Mohd Yusoff
abstract: Food safety and security represents a worldwide essential problem which needs advanced monitoring systems and quality assessment methods. The research investigates multi-angle imaging for food observation through computer vision methods to enhance both detection accuracy and reliability. The traditional food inspection methods conduct assessments from a single perspective which fail to detect vital defects that become invisible during viewing angles. The method provides better food property understanding through multiple-angle photography which enables precise identification of spoilage and foreign objects and texture modifications. The multi-angle imaging approach improves visibility through reduced occlusions and better feature extraction and surface detail detection which single-angle observations would miss. The proposed system combines machine learning models with computer vision algorithms to analyze multi-angle images which enhances the robustness of food quality assessment. Experimental data shows that different viewing perspectives boost classification accuracy while decreasing detection errors and enhancing real-time monitoring reliability. The research demonstrates that multi-angle imaging creates an automated system which provides detailed food safety evaluations. The research employs AI technologies to support global food security initiatives while improving food quality management standards and protecting consumer safety.

title: Portable Real-Time System for Disease and Pest Detection in Grapevine Leaves using Edge Computing
authors: Rafael Santos Silva, Octavian Adrian Postolache, Waslon Terllizzie A. Lopes
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Due to climate change and weather variability, the historically persistent challenges with diseases and pest infestations in vineyards are increasing, demanding more efficient detection and management solutions. This paper provides a portable IoT solution for on-site diagnosis of diseases and pests in grapevine leaves with immediate feedback communication. The system leverages an edge computing platform, Raspberry Pi 5, with a high-resolution camera, a pre-trained YOLOv8s model, and a touchscreen interface for data visualisation. The YOLOv8s model was pre-trained using a customised dataset, which included six different types of grapevine diseases and pests, achieving an accuracy of 0.92. The model was then validated in real-world field conditions, where it consistently detected and classified various symptoms of grapevine diseases and pests.

title: Y-LIChess: Live and Interactive Over-The-Board Chess Recognition and Play with Yolo
authors: Gibran Benitez-Garcia, Hiroki Takahashi
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Chess is widely played on computers, yet over-theboard (OTB) chess remains the official and preferred format for many players due to its tactile and immersive nature. Bridging digital and physical play requires accurate recognition of OTB positions. Prior research has explored modular pipelines for board localization, square occupancy, and piece classification, as well as single-stage detectors. While these approaches demonstrate strong accuracy in controlled conditions, they often accumulate errors across stages, face latency and robustness issues, and rarely support interactive play. Thus, in this work, we present Y-LIChess, a YOLO-based system for live, interactive OTB play with engines and online platforms. Y-LIChess employs semiautomatic calibration, event-triggered recognition, and legalityaware validation to ensure seamless, low-latency interaction. On our wood180 dataset, built with an active learning process to reduce manual annotation, Y-LIChess achieves 99.36 AP50 with only 0.21 % per-square error, reconstructs 100 % of boards within one mistake, and performs FEN reconstruction in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 7 ~\text{ms}$</tex> GPU, more than an order of magnitude faster than prior pipelines.

title: A Proof-Of-Concept ASIC RISC-V Based SoC for Industrial Applications
authors: Sara Alonso, Alejandro Arteaga, Leire Muguira, Carlos Cuadrado, Aitzol Zuloaga, Jaime Jiménez, Jesús Lázaro, José Ignacio Gárate, José Angel Araujo, Victor Martínez, Unai Bidarte, Armando Astarloa
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This work presents SoC4cris_p1, a proof-ofconcept ASIC implementation of a RISC-V-based System-on-Chip (SoC) tailored for Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) applications. Built on the neorv32 RISC-V HDL core, SoC4cris_p1 prioritizes execution safety and deterministic behavior. Key enhancements include a redesigned memory map for improved internal memory usage, an extended boot system, optimized peripherals, and integration of four experimental IPs from Basque Country research centers to support IIoT-specific functions. The paper covers architectural modifications, front-end FPGA prototyping, back-end ASIC design using 65nm UMC technology, and validation using a custom test board.

title: Maximizing the Efficiency of Energy Storage and Renewable Energy Source Integration in Power-Intensive Industrial Microgrids
authors: Kasra Shafiei, Ali Seifi, Mehrdad Tarafdar Hagh
abstract: This paper addresses the integration of Energy Storage Systems (ESS) into Energy-Intensive Industrial Microgrids (EIIMs) to optimize economic performance while promoting environmental sustainability. The study highlights the challenges posed by the intermittent nature of Renewable Energy Sources (RES) and the high peak demand of EIIMs, which strain grid frequency stability. By incorporating ESS, the research demonstrates significant financial gains and reduced grid stress through peak demand management and RES integration. The paper presents a comprehensive model of a Distributed Multi-Energy System (DMES) that includes photovoltaic (PV) systems, wind turbines (WT), and energy storage devices. The model optimizes the generation mix, considering conventional and renewable sources, and evaluates the economic and environmental impacts, including pollution costs. Simulation results show that integrating ESS with wind and solar power reduces generation oscillations and enhances reliability. The study also explores demand response (DR) programs to smooth load demand patterns during peak hours. The findings underscore the importance of co-optimizing economics and performance, providing a detailed analysis of generation types and the combined use of wind, solar, and storage to overcome the limitations of RES variability.

title: Adaptive Protection Scheme for Radial Microgrids Considering Generation Contingency
authors: Abdolreza Gholipour, Mahdi Akhbari, Mohammad Bayat Bidkorpe, Farzaneh Gholipour
abstract: Microgrids are the modern solutions to increase the reliability of electrical energy distribution systems and for optimum operation of Distributed Generations (DGs). Variable fault currents due to different modes of operation and intrinsic intermittency in renewable energy sources impose several and numerous constraints on relay coordination and settings. These factors can change the power flow direction as well as the short circuit current level. Therefore, unique protection coordination schemes may either degrade the relay’s sensitivity in the form of delayed fault clearance or result in the lack of operation for some faults. This paper presents an optimal and reliable adaptive protection algorithm for Microgrids considering generation contingency and develops suitable protection settings for all operating modes with optimized sensitivity and selectivity. Power flow and short circuit studies are performed in DIgSILENT power factory software, followed by obtaining the optimal settings of directional overcurrent relays (DORs) using GAMS software. The proposed approach is tested on IEEE 9-bus typical radial distribution system equipped with directly connected conventional synchronous generators (CSGs) and inverter-based distributed generators (IBDGs).

title: Matrix - Based Encryption: A Python-Driven Approach to Data protection
authors: Yuvarani Chandrasekaran, Ajitha Angusamy, Yasothei Suppiah
abstract: In everyday life, it is crucial to protect our data and communication. The necessity for secure message communication is not a novel concept. It has existed for a long time. Data security relies heavily on encryption methods. The advancement of message encryption technology has accelerated due to the utilization of networks and the online world. Cryptographic methods are deemed essential in instances of data theft or hacking involving private and sensitive messages. For secret communication, ciphers can be transformed into graphs. Graph theory is essential to a number of disciplines. Graph theory, in particular, is extensively utilized for encryption purposes because of its numerous properties and the fact that it can be easily represented as a matrix in computer systems. This paper presents the use of a self-invertible key matrix along with an adjacency matrix from a cycle graph for encrypting and decrypting messages, thereby creating a complex cipher. It is possible to decode the cipher without calculating the inverse of the key matrix, as it is a self-invertible matrix. Python is also utilized to create a schematic representation of the code for the provided input message, as well as to encrypt and decrypt it.

title: Evaluating CNN Depth for Multi-Class Bone Tumor Tissue Classification in Histopathology Images
authors: Jesmeen Mohd Zebaral Hoque, Nor Azlina Ab. Aziz, Azlan Abdul Aziz, Md. Jakir Hossen, Anith Khairunnisa Ghazali, Chy. Mohammed Tawsif Khan
abstract: Artificial intelligence algorithms like the convolutional neural network (CNN) allow automated medical image analysis. However, accurate classification of tumour tissues in histopathological images including bone tumour poses significant challenges due to the subtle variations of the different classes. In this paper the impact of CNN architecture depth on the classification performance is evaluated. Additionally, the effectiveness of preprocessing techniques such as contrast enhancement and data augmentation is also studied. One of the key challenges faced in this study is the need to balance model complexity with computational efficiency while preventing overfitting on small and imbalanced datasets. The model was trained using a bone or osteosarcoma tumour dataset consists of 536 non-tumour tiles, 263 necrotic tumour tiles, and 345 viable tumour tiles. Our results demonstrate that custom-designed, lightweight CNN models can achieve competitive performance, with the best model achieving a validation accuracy of 87.44% and a validation loss of 0.3594, often outperforming deeper, pretrained architectures. This research contributes valuable insights into effective CNN architecture choices for histopathological analysis, specifically offering a pathway toward more efficient and accurate bone tumour classification systems.

title: Towards Intelligent Crowd Monitoring during Hajj: A Novel Dataset for Density Estimation and Anomaly Detection in the Tawaf Area (2015-2019)
authors: Md Roman Bhuiyan, Junaidi Abdullah, Noramiza Hashim, Farshad Badie, Fahmid Al Farid, Duraisamy Balaganesh, Jia Uddin
abstract: This paper presents two novel datasets, Hajj-Crowd-2021, focused on crowd density and crowd anomalies during the Hajj pilgrimage. The datasets are derived from videos and images captured during the 2015-2019 Hajj and Umrah seasons, specifically in the Tawaf area surrounding the Kaaba. The crowd density dataset contains 30,000 images classified into five categories: very low, low, medium, high, and very high. The crowd anomaly dataset consists of 200 videos (100 normal and 100 anomalous) with a total of 60,000 frames. The datasets aim to address the lack of comprehensive and specific data for analyzing crowd behaviors during Hajj and Umrah. The paper describes the data collection and annotation process, as well as a comparison with existing state-of-the-art datasets. These datasets have the potential to support the development of crowd monitoring and management systems for large-scale religious gatherings.

title: Exploring the Barriers to Undergraduate Student Engagement with Research Papers: A Machine Learning and Statistical Analysis Approach
authors: Hasin Almas Sifat, Ashiqur Rahman Saron, Md. Mortuza Ahmmed, Md Saef Ullah Miah, Liew Tze Hui
abstract: University students often have significant obstacles to participating in research publications, motivated by characteristics such as language difficulties, approach problems, help from instructors, and content distribution options. This study discovered these characteristics and their influence on students' commitment to reading. A complete survey is done, concentrating on variables including text difficulty, accessibility problems, teacher encouragement, topic preferences, and study environment. To investigate the data, a multivariable linear regression model was applied to evaluate the connections between independent characteristics and student engagement. Preliminary studies have shown that the combination of these components has a significant impact on the participation decisions. Several advanced machine learning models such as Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM), Random Forest, and Support Vector Machines (SVM) were deployed. The Random Forest and GBM models achieved 95% accuracy in predicting student engagement. Machine Learning models were employed to identify and predict the key cognitive, motivational, and accessibility-related factors. This study emphasized the importance of solving these challenges to improve research skills, improve access, and establish a solid relationship between students and academic resources. In short, we can say that the results give practical advice to educational institutions to design a more effective approach to increase student interaction with research publications.

title: Stability-Oriented AC Filter Capacity Design for Hybrid DR-MMC HVDC System with Grid-Forming Offshore WTGs
authors: Yining Wang, Wang Xiang, Haobo Zhang, Jinyu Wen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The hybrid diode rectifier-modular multilevel converter (DR-MMC) HVDC system for WF integration has better operation performance and economic efficiency. However, the AC filter of 40% of the DR capacity is required due to the operation requirements of the system, which increases the volume and cost of the offshore platform. Therefore, grid-forming wind turbine generators (GFM WTGs) with the reactive power coordination and voltage control capability can be introduced to optimize the capacity of the AC filter. This paper considers the allocation of the GFM WTGs, and analyzes the influence of the AC filter and GFM WTG capacity on system stability based on small-signal model. Finally, the design requirements for AC filter capacity under different GFM proportions are identified to guide cost-effective configurations that meet stability and efficiency targets.

title: Design and Evaluation of Pedestrian Detection on Edge ML device for Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Puneeth Subramanya, Ramaseshan R, Manikandan J
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: The development of autonomous vehicles has placed the transportation industry at the forefront of a significant technology shift. These vehicles are revolutionizing transportation by operating on advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence and sensors to navigate roads and highways, efficiently avoiding road hazards without human intervention. Pedestrian detection is a crucial technology needed in autonomous vehicles to identify and locate pedestrians. In this paper, design and evaluation of pedestrian detection for autonomous vehicles is proposed. Three different models were evaluated for the proposed work. After the successful and satisfactory validation, the optimum model is deployed on Edge ML device for real-time testing on a mobile rover prototype and the results are reported. The proposed model yielded a maximum recognition accuracy of 99.50% with 970 ms time for pedestrian detection in the field of view.

title: Single-Phase Ground Fault Protection Algorithm for AC Microgrids Based on Fault Distance Identification
authors: Liuming Jing, Qinghua Liu, Jinxuan Guo, Yue Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: The operation of AC microgrids is complex, and the high proportion of distributed power sources significantly increases the electrical complexity of the system. The system's dynamic power flow is unpredictable, and fault current levels are low. These issues make protection design difficult. To address this, this paper utilizes differential equations constructed between the voltage and current at both ends of the line and line parameters during a single-phase ground fault on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Pi$</tex>-type equivalent circuit. It employs the recursive least squares method for fault distance parameter identification, proposing an AC microgrid protection method based on fault distance identification. The sliding window variance is used as the evaluation criterion for identification completion, and the fault distance is compared with the set distance as the protection action criterion. Finally, based on the AC microgrid model in PSCAD/EMTDC, the effectiveness of the proposed protection method was thoroughly verified. Simulation results show that this protection scheme can effectively, accurately, and quickly locate faults, thereby enhancing the reliability of DC grid operations.

title: Retention Aware of Low Power Techniques for Double Data Rate in High-Speed Memory System
authors: Khor Chun Shen, Shaharin Fadzli Abd Rahman, Ab Al-Hadi Ab Rahman
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Double Data Rate (DDR) memory has become the standard for high-speed memory solutions. However, the dynamic operations of DDR memory, such as high-speed data transfers, periodic refresh cycles, and precise timing requirements, result in substantial power consumption. The challenge is compounded by the increasing demand for higher memory capacities and speeds, which amplify energy usage and heat generation. The aim of this work is to leverage Unified Power Format (UPF) for DDR Memory System for development of retention-aware low power techniques. The work started with migrating and analyzing power performance an open-source DDR3 Controller design as a baseline. Then, UPF strategies such as defining power intent, partitioning power domains, implementing power gating, and specifying isolation cells were integrated to improve power efficiency. The UPF-driven enhancements reduced the total power consumption from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28.43 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13.1 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex>. This is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 3. 9}$</tex>% reduction in total power consumption.

title: Multi-Bird Biomimetic Controllers for UAV Flight Dynamics
authors: Ovi Kulkarni, Palvi Kulkarni, Hemant Kumar C., Arunkumar Bongale, Satish Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: The Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have become an essential equipment in diverse fields but the ability to stabilize and effectively fly in dynamic scenes is one of the major challenges. In this work two biomimetic flight controllers based on the avian species, Humming Bird and Owl, and Harpy Eagle controllers, are presented and compared with a conventional Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller. Using the maneuverability of Hummingbirds and the robustness of Owls and Harpy Eagles, these controllers adapt the gain tuning to flight patterns inspired by biology to enhance UAV behavior. These simulations are performed on a smaller 12 states model of a point-mass UAV in MATLAB.Trajectory, orientation stability, and energy efficiency have been evaluated. Evaluation illustrates that the HarpyEagle controller provides the most appropriate combination of robustness and efficiency being substantially better than both the PID and HummingOwl controllers. This paper spotlights the prospect of biomimicry in the further development of UAV control methods, particularly those involving missions where versatility and robustness are important concerns.
