title: Distributed Deep Learning for Medical Image Denoising with Data Obfuscation
authors: Sulaimon Oyeniyi Adebayo, Ayaz H. Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Medical image denoising enhances diagnostic quality while enabling privacy-aware training on sensitive clinical datasets. This study presents a distributed deep learning framework for denoising chest X-rays from the NIH ChestXray14 dataset, using additive Gaussian noise as a lightweight obfuscation technique. We implement and evaluate U-Net and U-Net++ architectures under three training setups: single-GPU, multi-GPU (DataParallel), and optimized multi-GPU using PyTorch's DistributedDataParallel (DDP) with Automatic Mixed Precision (AMP). Results show that U-Net++ consistently achieves superior structural fidelity (Peak Signal to Noise Ratio and Structured Similarity Index Measure) at higher noise levels (20% and 30%), while U-Net performs better in perceptual similarity (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity) at lower noise levels. Our optimized DDP+AMP pipeline reduces training time by over 60% compared to single-GPU and over 30% versus DataParallel, with minimal accuracy trade-off. This work demonstrates the practical viability of combining model design, noise-based obfuscation, and software-level acceleration to build scalable, privacy-conscious medical imaging pipelines. The full implementation is publicly available at: https://github.com/Suadey/medical-image-denoising-ddp.

title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Control via Filterless Least Squares Based on HOFA System Approach
authors: Peng Wang, Minrui Fei, Yonghui Chen, Dajun Du
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the challenge of achieving fast and robust control in systems with parametric uncertainties. A novel high-order fully actuated (HOFA) system-based filterless least-squares adaptive prescribed-time control framework enhanced is proposed by radial basis function neural networks (RBFNNs). Firstly, a HOFA system model is constructed to preserve the original high-order dynamics. Then, a filterless least-squares estimator is designed to identify parameters using only measurable signals, and an RBFNN-based compensator approximates unknown higher-order differential functions without prior knowledge. Lyapunov stability analysis proves the asymptotic convergence of the system state within the prescribed time. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in handling uncertainties, ensuring precise state convergence and robust parameter estimation.

title: A New Single-phase Common-ground Rectifier with Reduced DC-link Capacitance
authors: Mingyuan Ma, Xiaobin Mu, Weimin Wu, Yuhao Yuan, Mingsan Ouyang, Xiang Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The common-ground topology effectively suppresses common-mode leakage current, but current research primarily focuses on photovoltaic inverters. This paper introduces a novel single-phase power factor correction (PFC) common-ground rectifier for AC/DC microgrids, utilizing active power decoupling (APD) technology. By replacing traditional electrolytic capacitors with small-value film capacitors, we extend maintenance intervals and mitigate secondary ripple power in single-phase rectification. This topology accommodates a wide output voltage range and features a decoupling circuit that shares the active switch, minimizing volume. A detailed circuit analysis and control strategies under coupling conditions are presented, alongside a 312W experimental prototype demonstrating the solution's feasibility.

title: A Multi-Time-Scale AGC Frequency Regulation Optimal Scheduling Method for Virtual Power Plants Based on PPO Algorithm
authors: Jing Wang, Youshu Yang, Xiangyang Mao, Qiqi Zhang, Jie Shi, Youlin Ma, Jiaju Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the rapid development of distributed energy resources and electric vehicles, the virtual power plant (VPP) has attracted significant attention as an effective means to aggregate various distributed resources for grid scheduling. This paper focuses on a VPP consisting of multiple types of resources, including photovoltaic (PV), wind power, gas turbines, energy storage systems (ESS), and electric vehicles (EVs), and establishes a multi-time-scale AGC frequency regulation optimal scheduling model. The model fully considers the dynamic characteristics and complementarity of different resources, and achieves day-ahead economic optimization and intra-day frequency regulation performance enhancement through hierarchical rolling scheduling. To address the problems of traditional scheduling algorithms, such as being prone to local optima and difficulty in balancing economic efficiency and flexibility, this paper proposes an optimization approach based on the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively coordinates the outputs of all dispatchable resources, improves the comprehensive frequency regulation performance and operational benefits of the VPP, and provides strong support for building a secure and efficient power system with a high penetration of renewable energy.

title: Optimal Regulation of Integrated Energy Systems Based on Refined Modelling
authors: Huirong Zhao, Peixi Zhao, Daogang Peng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The integrated energy system(IES) involves energy conversion equipment, energy transmission equipment and so on. The nonlinear inverter operating characteristic curves of various types of equipment in the system are subdivided and linearized; in addition, the energy consumption of variable speed pump is increased, and pipeline flow balance constraints are added, and an optimal configuration model is established with the optimization objective of minimizing the daily operating cost. Taking an IES as an example, several schemes are designed for simulation verification, and the simulation results show that the consideration of the inverter operating characteristics of multiple units of the same type of equipment can effectively reduce the system operating cost, and the consideration of the pump inverter characteristics can further reduce the system operating cost.

title: Blockchain-based Secure Distributed Economic Dispatch for Microgrids
authors: Yurou Zhu, Xue Li, Zhe Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The proliferation of diverse distributed energy resources, combined with a surge in cross-node data exchanges, has considerably broadened the attack surface, rendering microgrid economic dispatch vulnerable to escalating cybersecurity threats such as data tampering and denial-of-service attacks. To tackle this challenge, this paper proposes a blockchain-based secure distributed economic dispatch strategy. An equal-incremental-cost model is first formulated for a portfolio comprising renewable generators, battery storage, flexible loads, and conventional units. The dispatch algorithm is then packaged as a smart contract and deployed on Hyperledger Fabric, whose decentralised, unalterable, and traceable features protect data integrity and resist attacks. Experiments show that the strategy achieves both economic optimality and enhanced system security, confirming its practicality for real-world microgrid operation.

title: LightGBM-based optical encoder error compensation system
authors: Zhang Jiahao, Li Zhibin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The photoelectric encoder detection system generates detection corner errors due to the effects of installation, data acquisition, and detection system errors. Therefore, an algorithm based on gradient boosting tree machine learning is designed to compensate the error of the reference photoelectric encoder. After compensation by this algorithm and the traditional error compensation and other algorithms compensation effect compared to the LightGBM machine learning compensation faster, better results. After the LightGBM machine learning algorithm compensation, the angle measurement error of the photoelectric encoder is effectively reduced, and the detection accuracy of the photoelectric encoder detection system is improved.

title: Improved Adaptive PSO for Spray Process Optimization
authors: Tian Zhang, Yan Bian
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: The increasing utilization of spray-painting robots in industrial applications has led to several challenges in the automated painting of aircraft wings, including inconsistent coating thickness, excessive paint waste, and inadequate robot path planning. In response to these issues, this study introduces an improved adaptive particle swarm optimization (IAPSO) algorithm. This algorithm integrates a nonlinear dynamic inertia weight strategy, an elite chaotic search mechanism, and a constraint-handling technique to effectively address the problems of premature convergence and parameter sensitivity that are often associated with traditional particle swarm optimization (PSO). To assess the efficacy of the proposed approach, comparative experiments were conducted against standard PSO and genetic algorithms. The findings indicate that the improved algorithm significantly decreases the standard deviation of coating thickness, enhances paint utilization, and increases convergence speed.

title: PSO-WOA Hybrid Algorithm Empowering Path Planning of Autonomous Mobile Robots in Complex Ground Environments
authors: BoQi Wu, Bao Jia, HaoNan Zhang, Zhengyan Dong, Sen Li, BingYi Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Path planning for autonomous mobile robots in complex ground environments remains challenging, as conventional metaheuristic algorithms struggle to balance global exploration and local exploitation. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) excels in global search but tends to fall into local optima in dense obstacle scenarios, while the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) offers strong local refinement yet suffers from inefficient initial exploration in large-scale spaces, leading to suboptimal path length, poor smoothness, and increased collision risks. To address these issues, this study proposes a hybrid PSOWOA algorithm. It adopts a two-stage strategy: initially, PSO's global search is enhanced via dynamic inertial weights integrated with WOA's nonlinear shrink-wrapping mechanism (control parameter a(t) decreasing from 2 to 0), ensuring early extensive exploration and late local focus. Subsequent local optimization by WOA incorporates a spiral disturbance mechanism, with a subset of particles undergoing spiral updates around the global best solution to escape local optima and improve smoothness. Parallel computing accelerates fitness evaluation (considering length, obstacle avoidance, and smoothness) in large-scale spaces. Experimental results show the PSO-WOA outperforms standalone PSO and WOA in complex environments, generating shorter paths (average reduction over 12% across) with superior smoothness and reduced collision risks. It exhibits strong stability, with minimal path cost fluctuations across 50 runs, validating robust adaptability in diverse complex ground environments.

title: Research on Electric Vehicle Cluster Scheduling Strategy Based on Multi-Time Scale Collaborative Optimization
authors: Hongwei Zhang, Jincheng Tang, Qiongwen Lou, Zheng Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of electric vehicles (EVs), their flexibility potential as a distributed energy storage resource needs to be explored urgently. In this paper, we propose an EV cluster scheduling model that integrates day-ahead and real-time two-stage optimization: in the day-ahead stage, the Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) is used to optimize the charging load curve to stabilize the peak-to-valley difference of the power grid. In the real-time stage, an improved Deep Q Network (DQN) is introduced to deal with the fluctuation of renewable energy output and the uncertainty of user behavior. The simulation results based on the IEEE 33-node system show that the proposed strategy can reduce the operating cost of the microgrid by 23.7 % and the load variance by 41.2 %, which verifies the effectiveness of the model.

title: Attitude Fusion Method for Multi-Head Star Sensors Based on Attitude Covariance Matrix
authors: Di Pan, Da Lian, Songhang Ye, Chang Han, Bing Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: To address the issues of insufficient dynamic compensation for installation matrix errors and poor adaptability in weight allocation during attitude fusion of multi-head star sensors, this paper proposes an adaptive weight attitude fusion method based on covariance matrices. Traditional star vectorlevel fusion methods, relying on empirical weight allocation strategies, struggle to suppress error propagation under extreme conditions such as vibrations and stray light. By constructing a geometric constraint-driven adaptive Kalman filter model, this paper establishes a coupling mechanism between filtering parameters and the installation matrix, enabling dynamic compensation of non-reference head Z-axis errors. Experimental results show that the proposed method reduces the $\mathbf{Z}$-axis error of fused attitude by over 50% under both steady-state and stray light conditions. Meanwhile, a quaternion-level attitude fusion framework is innovatively designed, which adaptively allocates head fusion weights based on attitude covariance matrices. This approach breaks through the limitations of traditional empirical thresholds, achieving a 28% improvement in X/Y-axis fusion accuracy when single-head errors double, with computational efficiency significantly superior to star vector-level methods. Night sky tests verify that the proposed method ensures high precision while reducing computational complexity through adaptive installation matrix filtering and adaptive weight allocation, effectively enhancing the robustness of multi-head star sensors under extreme on-orbit conditions. This work provides a new technical solution for spacecraft attitude determination systems.

title: Research on Photovoltaic Power Prediction Model Based on Improved Drosophila Optimization Algorithm
authors: Qiansheng Qiu, Honghou Zhang, Tingting Pan, Lingehao Xiao
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: This paper proposes a photovoltaic power prediction model based on the Improved Drosophila Optimization Agorithm (IDBO). It achieves high-precision photowoltaic power prediction by integrating Random Forest (RF), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM), and stacked ensemble learning methods. The experiment designs a complete data processing flow, including data collection, cleaning, feature selection, normalization, and dataset division. By analyzing the correlation between meteorological factors and photovoltaic power, the optimal feature selection threshold is determined, and prediction verification is conducted in the typical climate range of 2022. The results show that the stacked ensemble moded with a correlation coefficient threshold of 0.1 achieves the best performance. In different seasons, the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) ranges from 1.769 to 2.390, the Root Mean Square Error (RM1SE) ranges from 3.457 to 4.797, and the Coefficient of Determination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex>) ranges from 0.9501 to 0.9783. These verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed model under complex climate conditions, providing reliable decision support for the efficient operation of photowoltaic power stations and power grid dispatching.

title: Boosting Zero-Shot Semantic Segmentation Performance on Unseen Categories with Key and Value Selection (KVS)
authors: Yong Zhang, Mengze Li, Yuhua Zheng, Yuehua Li, Hongliang Ren, Jianjun Gu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Zero-shot semantic segmentation (ZSSS) aims to address the reliance of traditional semantic segmentation models on large-scale annotated data, enabling generalization to unseen categories. Recently, the CLIP model, known for its strong generalization capability, has been widely applied in ZSSS tasks and demonstrated effective performance improvements. However, existing studies primarily focus on feature alignment and overall performance optimization, while neglecting the refinement at the image token level, which is crucial for enhancing model generalization. To address this, we propose a combination of the Key and Value Selection (KVS) algorithm and a stochastic training strategy, which together enhance token-level learning by selecting image tokens relevant to text features. Our approach achieves a balance in the prediction performance between seen and unseen categories with relatively low computational overhead. Experiments on the Pascal VOC and Pascal Context datasets validate the effectiveness of the KVS algorithm in achieving this balance.

title: Joint Super-Resolution and Segmentation for Low-Resolution Brain MRI Analysis
authors: Muhammad Waleed Anwar, Muhammad Awais Maqsood, Aleena Amjad, Basim Azam
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Low-resolution brain MRI acquisitions compromise anatomical segmentation accuracy, limiting clinical utility in time-constrained imaging protocols. We present a unified framework integrating generative super-resolution with volumetric segmentation to enable precise tissue delineation from degraded inputs. Our architecture employs advanced generative modeling to reconstruct perceptually faithful high-resolution MRI while preserving anatomical fidelity. Segmentation labels are appropriately scaled through parallel processing, and a deep neural network with robust architectural backbone generates corresponding high-resolution segmentation maps. The framework coordinates both components through joint optimization, the super-resolution module prioritizes features critical for tissue boundary detection, while the segmentation network adapts to characteristics of synthetically enhanced images. The framework demonstrates particular efficacy for challenging anatomical regions typically obscured in low-resolution acquisitions. Our method enables quantitative analysis of rapid acquisition protocols previously considered inadequate for morphometric assessment, potentially expanding access to advanced neuroimaging capabilities across resource-limited settings.

title: A Framework for Automated CGRA Design Space Exploration with Genetic Algorithm Optimization
authors: Maryam Katebzadeh, Daniel Vazquez, Andres Otero, Alfonso Rodriguez
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of compute-intensive applications has created a pressing need for computing architectures that effectively balance flexibility, efficiency, and performance. While Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) offer a good level of flexibility, they suffer from high configuration overhead and energy consumption. Coarse-Grained Reconfigurable Architectures (CGRAs) provide a more energy-efficient alternative with lower configuration costs. They can be customized for domainspecific applications by modifying their coarse-grained processing elements to execute particular sequences of operations. In fact, their domain-specific nature can be used to further improve their energy efficiency and reduce their area overhead by exploiting computing fabric specialization. This can be achieved by replacing homogeneous processing elements with a subset of heterogeneous, more optimized ones that are specifically suited to the target application domain. However, achieving an optimal CGRA configuration requires extensive design space exploration (DSE), which involves evaluating many architectural possibilities. Existing CGRA frameworks struggle with slow and inefficient exploration due to long runtimes and constrained customization options. These issues make it hard to find the best configurations rapidly. To tackle these challenges, this paper presents Genetic Algorithm-based CGRA Generator (GA-CG), a framework that enhances DSE in the CGRA design process. GA-CG uses a genetic algorithm to discover an efficient structural configuration, thereby improving resource utilization and reducing power consumption.

title: Coronary Heart Disease Prediction Model Based on Machine Learning
authors: Pengzhou Xu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Biomedical Engineering and Bioinformatics for Health (ICBEBH)
abstract: This study develops three distinct machine learning algorithms—Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression—based on the Framingham Heart Research Dataset. and uses classification algorithms to assist in predicting the risk of coronary heart disease for individuals in the next ten years. To improve the accuracy and stability of the model, in this paper, missing value filling and continuous variable standardization processing were carried out on the original data, and the problem of sample category imbalance was solved through the SMOTE technique. The results show that the random forest performs the best among various indicators and has good predictive ability and robustness. In addition, through the analysis of the importance of characteristics, it was found that variables such as age, systolic blood pressure, BMI, and cholesterol are the main factors affecting the possibility of coronary heart disease. Overall, this study demonstrates the feasibility and practicability of a coronary heart disease risk assessment model powered by machine learning algorithms, providing data support and model reference for identifying high-risk populations

title: Adsorption Behavior of Humidity Molecules for Different Binding Site on Graphene and Graphene on Hexagonal Boron Nitride
authors: Ainun Khairiyah Taib, Zaharah Johari, Shaharin Fadzli Abd Rahman, Mohd Fairus Mohd Yusoff, Fatimah Khairiah Abd Hamid, Mastura Shafinaz Zainal Abidin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Advanced materials such as Graphene and boron nitride have been researched due to their potential applications in electronics. This study examines the sensing properties of humidity molecules, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex>, on Graphene and graphene/hexagonal boron nitride. Through simulation, different possible binding sites of humidity molecules, namely, top of carbon, hollow and bridge, are explored to see their impact on adsorption energy and sensitivity. Results obtained show a considerable energy band gap, e.g., that is opened in graphene/<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{hBN}_{(\mathrm{P})}$</tex> upon adsorption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex>. However, different adsorption sites of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex> on both Graphene and Graphene/hBN result in minimal changes in the energy band gap. The sensitivity of Graphene achieved is higher by 71.06% than that of Graphene/hBN when <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex> was positioned on top of a carbon atom. Evaluation of the adsorption energy, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{E}_{\text{ads }}$</tex> indicate that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex> molecules on Graphene are most stable on hollow sites with Eads of −0.2808 eV corresponding to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${1. 9 2} {\times} {1 0}^{-{1 7}} \mathrm{s}$</tex> recovery time. This is 75.39% stronger than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex> on Graphene/hBN positioned on a hollow site with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{E}_{\text{ads }}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${- 0. 0 6 9 1 } \text{eV}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6.90} \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{s}$</tex>. These results provide foundational insight into the interaction of humidity molecules with Graphene and Graphene/hBN for the development of high-performance nanosensors.

title: Overcoming Data Scarcity in Sugarcane Leaf Disease Classification with Prototypical Network
authors: Rifat Islam, Salahuddin Azad, Md. Rahat Hossain, Yufeng Lin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Plant and crop production plays a vital role in the overall development of any country. Sugarcane is one of the most produced crops in Australia. Sugarcane plants are vulnerable to various leaf diseases. Early leaf disease detection is crucial for agricultural productivity. Traditional machine learning often relies on handcrafted features, struggles with high-dimensional data, and has scalability issues. Deep learning models overcomes these problems, still there are some challenges, such as the overfitting issue, the need for a large dataset, and less adaptability to new classes. This research addresses the challenge of limited dataset availability of sugarcane leaf diseases by employing few shot learning (FSL) and episodic training. This research proposes a Prototypical Network (PN) based few-shot learning technique to classify sugarcane leaf diseases. The proposed technique uses pretrained deep learning models for feature extraction, such as MobileNet, ResNet, EfficientNet, and PN based FSL to learn from fewer training examples. The experimental results show that the PN with a backbone of ResNet achieved the highest test accuracy of 87 %. The analysis of the experimental results indicates that PN based few shot learning with deep learning models as backbone outperforms standalone pre-trained deep learning models while using limited number of sugarcane images.

title: A Hybrid Learning Framework for One-to-One Air Combat Based on Combining Imitation Learning and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Chaoran Jiang, Heng Wang, Hanchen Li, Qijia Liu, Bowen Duan, Jianliang Ai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid imitation and reinforcement learning framework to enhance air combat strategies for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in a one-to-one air combat environment. The proposed framework integrates generative adversarial imitation learning (GAIL) algorithm with reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm to improve the decision-making capabilities of UAVs. Initially, a one-to-one air combat simulation environment is established, incorporating a six-degree-of-freedom (6DoF) UAV model, states and actions design, rewards design, and termination logic design. The hybrid framework involves two phases: first, GAIL is used to align the agent’s policy with expert demonstrations, leveraging an expert database for decision support; second, the policy network derived from GAIL is utilized as the initial policy for RL, specifically employing a self-play proximal policy optimization (SP-PPO) algorithm for further training. The training process combines imitation learning and RL methods to address the limitations of reward function design. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid approach significantly enhances training efficiency and decision-making performance, outperforming traditional RL methods. The findings indicate that the integration of GAIL and RL provides an effective solution for autonomous maneuver decision-making in complex air combat scenarios.

title: Dielectrophoresis-Only Biosensing: Velocity and Cross-Over Frequency for Label-Free Bacterial Identification
authors: Muhammad Akmal Suhaimi, Arash Zulkarnain Rozaini, Noraziah Zin, Abdullah Abdulhameed, Noor Haza Hashim, Aminuddin Ahmad Kayani, Muhamad Ramdzan Buyong, Burhanuddin Yeop Majlis, Céline Elie Caille, Mimiwaty Mohd Noor
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: Dielectrophoresis (DEP) has emerged as a powerful tool in bacterial detection, with recent research focusing on hybrid approaches incorporating acoustic, magnetic, optical, and thermal forces to enhance sensitivity. However, the complexity of these hybrid systems presents challenges in maintaining consistent and precise control, especially in long-term biosensor development. This study explores a streamlined alternative by employing DEP as the sole detection mechanism. We demonstrate successful differentiation of Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus using two DEP-based parameters: cross-over frequency and movement velocity. E. coli and S. aureus exhibited distinct cross-over frequencies at 500–600 kHz and 1.0–1.5 MHz, respectively. Additionally, at 10 kHz, their movement velocities were measured at 0.00031 m/s and 0.00015 m/s, with the velocity curves showing strong resemblance to Clauscius-Mossotti Factor (CMF) profiles predicted by MyDEP simulations. These results not only validate the use of velocity as a complementary detection metric but also highlight the potential for developing simpler, cost-effective DEP biosensors. Expanding this approach to additional bacterial species may facilitate the creation of a comprehensive DEP-based detection database, supporting future applications in water quality monitoring and public health diagnostics.

title: Distributed Optimization Method for Distribution Networks Considering Multi-Type Loads in Smart Buildings
authors: Yiting Jin, Da Xu, Zhaoyan Wang, Zhenchong Wu, Shufeng Dong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: In light of the dual carbon goals, urban buildings are evolving from passive electricity consumers into active prosumers, highlighting the need for efficient energy scheduling strategies tailored to smart building systems. This paper addresses the coordinated optimization problem between multitype loads in smart buildings and the distribution network by developing a comprehensive model that incorporates building thermal dynamics, bidirectional charging/discharging of electric vehicles, and non-dispatchable loads. Furthermore, a cluster partitioning method based on electrical distance and power complementarity is proposed to form optimization units with regional autonomy. Finally, a distributed optimization framework based on an improved alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is implemented, and its effectiveness and engineering applicability are validated using the IEEE 69-bus network integrated with office buildings and photovoltaic units.

title: A Calculation Method for Maximum Transmission Power of Tie-Lines Considering Renewable Energy and HVDC Integration
authors: Ansi Wang, Gongwei Xi, Xuliang Wang, Yinglin Liu, Jiahui Han, Jingzhe Tu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Under high-penetration renewable energy integration and large-capacity multi-infeed HVDC systems, faults in certain grids can readily trigger cascading commutation failures of multiple DC lines, whose power impacts propagate through tie-lines to the interconnected grids, potentially causing chain reactions including renewable generation tripping and voltage collapse. Existing studies typically assess tie-line transmission limits by simplifying power systems as two-machine models, failing to adequately consider dynamic energy interactions between DC commutation failures and renewable energy units. To address this, this paper proposes a calculation method for tie-line maximum transmission power incorporating renewable energy and HVDC systems based on the energy function method. The simulation results show that this method can judge the power angle stability of the interconnected power grid at both ends of the transmission section and give the maximum transmission power of the transmission section.

title: Battery State of Health Prediction for Portable Intelligent Medical Devices Based on GRU-Attention
authors: Xiaodie Wu, Zihui Lin, Min Yang, Hongru Zhang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: To ensure the stable and reliable operation of portable intelligent medical devices, it is necessary to predict the battery state of health <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{SOH})$</tex> of the devices. Considering the limitations of hardware resources and insufficient computing power in portable intelligent medical devices, this study proposes a compact hybrid model, GRU-Attention. The study first extracts key health indicators from the CALCE dataset and inputs them into the proposed model to predict the battery state of health. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves higher prediction accuracy compared to standalone Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) and Attention models, indicating its superior performance and significant application value in portable intelligent medical devices and related fields.

title: Fusion Strategies for Breast Cancer Characterization Using Traditional and Deep Learning Models
authors: Pedro Vitor Lima, Jaime S. Cardoso, Hélder P. Oliveira
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Breast cancer remains one of the most prevalent and deadly cancers worldwide, making accurate evaluation of molecular markers important for effective disease management. Biomarkers such as ER, PR, and HER2 are typically assessed because they help inform prognosis and guide treatment decisions. Predicting these characteristics from imaging can support earlier clinical intervention, reduce reliance on invasive procedures, and contribute to more personalized care. While radiomics and deep learning approaches have demonstrated potential, comprehensive comparisons across these methods are still limited. This study evaluated handcrafted features, deep features, and end-to-end deep learning models for predicting ER, PR, and HER2 status from DCE-MRI. Each feature type was first assessed individually and then combined using early and late fusion. Handcrafted and deep features were processed through a pipeline that included resampling, dimensionality reduction, and model selection, while end-to-end models were trained using different initialization strategies and loss functions. The best models achieved AUCs of 0.659 for ER, 0.679 for PR, and 0.686 for HER2. Although late fusion generally improved performance, bias toward the majority classes persisted. Overall, the results suggest that combining different modeling strategies may enhance robustness in breast cancer characterization.

title: Research on Application of Controllable Line-Commutated Converters for UHVDC System
authors: Dezhen Zhang, Jun Li, Jianjun Ma, Chuliang Xue, Lei Lu, Haishan Xiao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The Ultra High Voltage Direct Current (UHVDC) transmission projects are predominantly based on Line commutated converter at present. Under this technical route, commutation failure leads to transient power deficits, posing a significant risk to grid stability, particularly in regions with multi-infeed HVDC areas. To address this issue, a novel Controllable Line Commutated Converter (CLCC) has been proposed. This topology utilizes fully controllable devices to transfer current and achieve rapid inter-arm commutation by turning off the current through devices, thereby effectively mitigating commutation failure.This technology is scheduled for its first practical application in the Gezhouba-Nanqiao HVDC project. However, it has not yet been deployed in ultra-high voltage direct current (UHVDC) systems. This study is based on the Xiangjiaba-Shanghai UHVDC project . It investigates the trial implementation and control strategies of controllable commutation technology in UHVDC systems. The transient, steady-state, and typical fault characteristics of the CLCC are analyzed.The CLCC technology is particularly well-suited for ultrahigh voltage direct current (UHVDC) projects, as it effectively addresses the issue of commutation failure, significantly enhancing grid security, operational stability, and the power hosting capability in multi-infeed DC areas. This study focuses on the engineering application of CLCC in UHVDC systems, proposes key parameter selection guidelines, and demonstrates its technical advantages.

title: Transformer-Gather, Fuzzy-Reconsider: A Scalable Hybrid Framework for Entity Resolution
authors: Mohammadreza Sharifi, Danial Ahmadzadeh
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Entity resolution plays a significant role in enterprise systems where data integrity must be rigorously maintained. Traditional methods often struggle with handling noisy data or semantic understanding, while modern methods suffer from computational costs or the excessive need for parallel computation. In this study, we introduce a scalable hybrid framework, which is designed to address several important problems, including scalability, noise robustness, and reliable results. We utilized a pre-trained language model to encode each structured data into corresponding semantic embedding vectors. Subsequently, after retrieving a semantically relevant subset of candidates, we apply a syntactic verification stage using fuzzy string matching techniques to refine classification on the unlabeled data. This approach was applied to a real-world entity resolution task, which exposed a linkage between a central user management database and numerous shared hosting server records. Compared to other methods, this approach exhibits an outstanding performance in terms of both processing time and robustness, making that a reliable solution for a server-side product. Crucially, this efficiency does not compromise results, as the system maintains a high retrieval recall of approximately 0.97. The scalability of the ’Transformer-Gather, Fuzzy-Reconsider’ framework makes it deployable on standard CPU-based infrastructure, offering a practical and effective solution for enterprise-level data integrity auditing.

title: Optimized Design of Hybrid Porcelain Post Insulator Spout Based on Finite Element Simulation
authors: Shimin Huang, Wei Peng, Riwen Zhou, Yunxuan Jiang, Qiang Wu, Yu Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: The injection process is crucial for the product quality of hybrid porcelain post insulators, and the selection of gate location is the key to the casting process. The article proposes three hybrid porcelain post insulator gate location schemes, which are analyzed by finite element simulation to compare the filling time, pressure at the injection position, pressure at the velocity/pressure switching, clamping force and volume expansion rate during molding. The results show that scheme III is the best: the pressure at the injection position is only 17.83 MPa, the pressure at velocity/pressure switching is 14.86 MPa, the clamping force is only 249.1 tons, and the volume expansion rate is only 3.277 %. The improvement effect of changing the number of gates shows obvious marginal diminishing phenomenon, considering the economy, the design of scheme II can also be considered.

title: Analysis of Electrode and Semiconductor Materials in Organic Field-Effect Transistors for Electronic Applications
authors: Meena Naga Raju, M. Durga Prakash
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive analysis of Bottom-Gate Top-Contact Organic Field-Effect Transistors (OFETs) by evaluating the influence of various materials used for source/drain electrodes, gate electrodes, and organic semiconductor layers. The devices were fabricated using gold (Au), platinum (Pt), aluminum (Al), and copper (Cu) as source and drain electrodes, while the gate electrodes included Al, indium tin oxide (ITO), calcium (Ca), and highly doped silicon (Si). The semiconducting materials investigated in this work comprised pentacene, poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), polyimide, and dinaphthothienothiophene (DNTT). Our experimental results reveal that while the source/drain electrode materials have a minimal effect on the V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">gs</inf>-I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> characteristics, the choice of gate electrode significantly influences device performance. Among the tested gate materials, highly doped silicon demonstrated the most favorable characteristics, contributing to enhanced current modulation and improved field-effect behavior. The study also emphasizes the impact of different organic semiconductors on device performance. DNTT-based OFETs exhibited the highest charge carrier mobility, outperforming pentacene, P3HT, and polyimide. Furthermore, the effect of semiconductor layer thickness was analyzed by varying the pentacene layer from 20 nm to 60 nm in 10 nm increments. Although minor, these variations resulted in observable changes in the electrical characteristics, underscoring the importance of precise thickness control in OFET fabrication. Overall, the findings of this work highlight the critical role of material selection and structural optimization in the design of high-performance OFETs. The insights gained offer valuable guidance for future advancements in organic electronics and the development of next-generation flexible and low-cost electronic devices.

title: Enhancing Software Defect Prediction Accuracy through Feature Selection-Driven Hybrid Intelligence
authors: Vanapalli Kiran Kumar, Balajee Maram, Shanker Chandre
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Foremost, predicting software defects is essential to enhance software quality, as well as to minimize development costs. There is no doubt that defect identification is vital to software quality. The authors of this paper propose a hybrid intelligent model which incorporates feature selection processes with algorithms to increase accuracy in defect prediction. Using publicly accessible datasets from the PROMISE repository, including NASA's MDP datasets, the model attained a mean accuracy of 92.4%, an increase of 11.3% relative to traditional models. The accuracy increase of 14% alongside model complexity reduction of 25% from RFE and Mutual Information based feature selection methods demonstrate the robustness of these feature selection techniques. Additional tests done on the hybrid model of random forest and support vector machines confirmed the model’s reliability in addition to the successful generalizability tests. The claim that the model is adept at identifying accurate and precise measurements of fault-prone modules is validated by the experimental results, reinforcing the confidence in the model’s adaptability and robustness with regard to automation in processes of software quality engineering.

title: Variable Load Study of a 600MW Swirl Opposed Firing Boiler based on CFD Numerical Simulation
authors: Xingyang Fu, Hao Lu, Dongge Huang, Jiaqi Li, Rui Ju
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: In the context of the rapid development of renewable energy sources, coal-fired units are transforming from auxiliary power sources, enabling their participation in the provision of deep peaking energy. This study employs computational fluid dynamics (CFD) numerical simulation to analyze the combustion characteristics and pollutant emissions of a counterflow boiler at 50%, 40%,30%, and 25% rated load by establishing a full-scale three-dimensional numerical model. The results demonstrate that, at varying loads, the flame filling the furnace chamber is elevated, resulting in enhanced combustion stability. The NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf> concentrations at the outlet of the furnace chamber are 373.78 mg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and 247.06 mg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> at 50% and 40% rated loads, respectively. Conversely, when only one burner layer is operated, the air classification ability is compromised, and the NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf> concentrations at the furnace outlet were 373.46 mg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and 323.6 mg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> at 30% and 25% rated loads, respectively, and the NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf> generation was higher at lower furnace temperatures.

title: A Generation Method for Diffuse Reflective Random Mesh and Its Potential in RCS Reduction
authors: Pang Xiaoyu, Fu Yixiang, Yang Zhen, Huang Minjie, Meng Xiangrui
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: This paper presents a method for generating random meshes by simulating the crystallization process of polycrystals. Through statistical analyses of multiple random mesh generation results, the correlation between the method's setting parameters and the characteristic parameters of the random meshes is established. This allows the mesh generation method to possess both randomness and design controllability. Furthermore, simulations and sample tests of the random mesh structure within the radar band have confirmed that the generated aperture type random meshes exhibit excellent diffuse reflection characteristics. As this type of random mesh does not need to meet specific phase conditions and has less stringent requirements for lateral scale, it has potential applications in reducing the monostatic RCS.

title: Machine Learning-Based Early Prediction and Classification of Obesity Levels Using Ensemble Models
authors: Vishwam Modi, Aarchi Shah, Janmay Panchal, Yogesh Kumar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Obesity is a major threat to physical health, increasing the risk of developing chronic illnesses such as diabetes, metabolic disorders, and cardiovascular diseases. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset comprising demographic, behavioural, and lifestyle attributes, the research classifies individuals into seven weight-based classification, ranging from underweight to severe obesity. A systematic testing of a variety of classification algorithms, starting with simpler models like logistic regression and moving to more complex ensemble techniques like Random Forest, LightGBM, and XGBoost was done. Among these, XGBoost reached the peak of prediction accuracy, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling excessive data and multifaceted feature relations. The study underscores the potential of AI-driven methods to enable timely and personalized obesity risk assessments, thereby enhancing public health interventions. The promising results of ensemble models highlight their potential to support data-driven decision-making in clinical and community health settings.

title: Self-Supervised Learning for Hyperspectral Image Classification: An overview
authors: Jignesh R. Patel, Kamal M. Captain, Ashok Parmar
abstract: Uyperspectral Image (USI) classification has been a focal point of exploration in recent times across various remote sensing domains. Although Deep Learning has garnered widespread attention for analysing hyperspectral data, its efficacy is often hindered by the requirement for large datasets, which are seldom available. In the field of US I, where acquiring a large annotated dataset is challenging, researchers have increasingly explored self-supervised learning. This paper provides a comprehensive review of self-supervised learning-based approaches for USI classification. We referenced literature utilizing a self-supervised approach, presenting noteworthy contributions that span diverse aspects and methodologies within the self-supervised learning framework. Finally, we aim to discuss practical chal-lenges that demand attention and explore potential opportunities.

title: Design of low-orbit navigation signals Based on Linear frequency modulation
authors: Minyan Geng, Zhibin Xiao, Honglei Lin, Gang Ou, Xiaomei Tang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Low-orbiting satellite systems have received much attention in recent years because of the advantages of low-orbiting satellites in enhancing the GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System). However, the Doppler shift of LEO satellite signals is large, which increases the reception complexity. In this paper, a combined signal design of LFM (Linear Frequency Modulation) and BPSK (Binary Phase Shift Keying) based on orthogonal modulation model is proposed to solve the problem of high dynamic signal reception in low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite navigation system. In this paper, the computational complexity, average acquisition time, and acquisition performance of this combined signal are analyzed. Simulation results show that the signal design improves the acquisition performance by 1dB compared with the traditional BPSK navigation signals while maintaining a low computational complexity, and is suitable for LEO high dynamic navigation applications.

title: Multi-time Scale Scheduling Strategy for Microgrid Considering Component Faults
authors: Xian Bao, Fan Chen, Hongqi Xu, Man Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The power fluctuations of wind energy and uncertainties such as component failures pose challenges to the secure operation of microgrids. Existing microgrid scheduling strategies have not fully considered the impact of component failures on scheduling. To address this issue, a multi-timescale scheduling method for microgrids considering component failures is proposed within a "day-ahead to intraday to fault scenario" scheduling framework. First, a day-ahead scheduling model is established based on day-ahead forecasts of generation and load. Then, using the grid power trading plan determined in the day-ahead stage and intraday forecasts, a rolling intraday optimization model is developed to mitigate the impact of wind power fluctuations on shorter timescales. Subsequently, an adaptive scheduling strategy under fault scenarios is formulated to dynamically adjust unit outputs, energy storage charging and discharging, and grid power transactions. Case study results show that the proposed multi-timescale scheduling method considering component failures can significantly reduce unplanned load shedding caused by faults and improve the economic efficiency and reliability of microgrid operations.

title: Profit Sharing Mechanism Design for Renewable and Storage Collaboration Across Multi-voltage Channels
authors: Chupeng Xiao, Yuan Lu, Kui Wang, Haijing Zhang, Jing Xu, Liangliang Zhu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Multi-voltage transmission channels play a crucial role in power supply from renewable energy-rich regions, and effective profit-sharing mechanisms can promote the synergistic development of renewable energy and energy storage systems. However, existing research lacks quantitative assessment methods for contribution evaluation across different voltage-level users. This paper proposes a market value contribution rate-based profit-sharing mechanism, establishing optimization models for independent and shared multi-voltage channel operations while analyzing shared mode's social welfare enhancement essence. By quantifying user contributions and allocating benefits proportionally, the mechanism ensures participation incentives in distributed energy-storage platforms. Case studies demonstrate that this method can effectively identify market participant values and improve energy storage utilization efficiency by 72.66%.

title: Enhancing Smart Microgrid Sustainability with Lyrebird-Based EV Charging Optimization
authors: P. Anandan, N. Anbuselvan, Siow Chun Lim
abstract: The increasing integration of electric vehicles (EVs) and renewable energy sources (RES) into contemporary micro-grid has resulted in a more complex situation for distribution system planners and operators. This change necessitates tackling complex operational and financial issues. Operators specifically need to handle the increased reliance on RES and the growing demand for EVs. The aim of this paper is to present an optimal planning methodology that uses the Lyrebird Optimisation Algorithm (LOA) to address issues related to the level of integration of Renewable Energy Sources (RES) and the strategic placement of EV charging stations. These difficulties include increased system costs, voltage fluctuations, thermal loading, and power loss. LOA is designed to be strategically placed in conjunction with the deployment of hybrid RES across several micro-grids, in order to accommodate EV charging stations with controllable charging capabilities. To validate the efficacy of the proposed algorithm, the simulation results are compared with various optimisation techniques. The results show that using LOA instead of other optimisation algorithms reduces voltage deviation by 66.45%, cumulative energy undelivered by 49.63%, and total cost by 32.90%. This planning methodology includes an innovative charging strategy that lowers overall system costs while improving power quality significantly.

title: Zero-Trust Architectures for SecOps in ServiceNow: Enabling Scalable Security in Enterprise Platforms
authors: Kamran Ayub, Roushdy AlShawa
abstract: Zero-trust architecture is becoming very popular in IT security field these days. Many companies are now leaving traditional security methods and trying new approaches that focus more on risk assessment and sustainable frameworks. The main concept of zero-trust security is quite straightforward: you should not trust anything automatically, no matter if it is inside or outside of your network. This is a big change from old" castle and moat" thinking, where everything inside company firewall was considered as safe. But zero-trust is different-it treats every user, device, and application as potentially dangerous until they prove they are safe. This method works very good for today’s business environment where everything is distributed. Since employees are working from remote locations and companies are using cloud services heavily, the traditional network boundaries have basically vanished. Zero-trust architecture handles this situation by focusing on protecting individual resources instead of trying to secure one fixed network boundary. The framework makes security better by checking and authorizing access to company resources all the time. It works well across different parts of organization, giving same security policies whether someone is accessing systems from office, home, or any other place. What makes zero-trust really valuable is the way it spreads security intelligence through the whole technology platform. Every part-whether it is user, device, application, or data source-gets checked based on current risk levels and business situation. This creates many layers of protection that can adjust in real-time when conditions change. The system keeps detailed policies for different trust areas, making sure that access controls match how sensitive the protected resources are. These policies work through APIs and other connection points, so security decisions can be made fast and automatically. When organizations implement zero-trust architecture, they can get better security coverage for their entire technology system. It supports both centralized security management and local operational requirements, giving IT teams the flexibility they need while keeping strong security standards.

title: Blended Control Latent Diffusion Model for Text-Guided Image Inpainting
authors: Jiajing Yi, You Wu, Hewei Wang, Haoyang Zhang, Jie Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: With the introduction of text information, object inpainting techniques have made significant progress in semantic guidance and content generation. However, existing methods still have problems such as changes in undamaged areas and mismatch between text prompts and images, mainly due to insufficient spatial guidance and limited text-conditioned expression capabilities. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Blended Control Latent Diffusion Model (BCLDM). BCLDM mainly consists of two parts: the forward process provides an efficient denoising foundation based on a pretrained Latent Diffusion Model (LDM), and the denoising process generates multi-scale control signals through a trainable control module to enhance spatial guidance, and combines a mask blending strategy to optimize restoration quality. Experiments on the MSCOCO-2017 dataset (5000 images) show that BCLDM performs excellently in text-guided inpainting.

title: Optimized Neural Network Compression for Efficient Corrosion Detection in Metal Surfaces
authors: Pramath Parashar
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Corrosion detection in metal surfaces is crucial for infrastructure safety and maintenance. This study introduces a novel approach to lightweight deep learning models for corrosion segmentation by leveraging neural network pruning techniques. By applying three distinct pruning strategies—linear, automated gradual, and movement pruning—on five segmentation models, we achieve significant model compression while maintaining high accuracy. Experimental results on two corrosion image datasets demonstrate that models can be pruned up to 90% sparsity with minimal performance loss. This research paves the way for deploying efficient models on resource-constrained edge devices for real-time corrosion monitoring.

title: Comparative CFD Study of LNG and Ammonia Vapor Cloud Hazards for Marine Alternative Fuel Safety
authors: Li Yang
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: The adoption of alternative fuels such as liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquid ammonia <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{NH}_{3}\right)$</tex> is crucial for decarbonizing maritime transport, but leakage during ship-toship (STS) bunkering poses significant safety and environmental risks. This study presents a comparative computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis of LNG and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> leakage and vapor cloud dispersion under identical small-aperture leakage scenarios. An Eulerian-Eulerian multiphase model coupled with phasechange and species transport models was implemented in ANSYS Fluent to simulate evaporation, plume formation, and downwind dispersion. Results indicate that LNG forms narrow, rapidly rising flammable plumes, whereas <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> generates broader, ground-hugging toxic clouds with prolonged exposure risks [1]. The findings provide guidance for energy safety management in marine fuel operations, including emergency buffer design, detector placement, and risk zoning, contributing to safe implementation of alternative fuels in the maritime sector.

title: Harnessing Machine Learning for Intelligent Control of Shape Memory Alloy Actuators in Versatile Environments_supp1-3640241.docx
authors: JOO YONG SIM
abstract: Shape memory alloy (SMA) actuators, known for their high force output despite being lightweight and compact, are increasingly attracting attention in fields such as robotics, medical devices, and wearable devices. Due to these advantages, many studies have been conducted on SMA actuators driven by Joule heating under static air conditions. However, ensuring precise and responsive control of these actuators in diverse and dynamic environmental conditions remains a significant challenge. In particular, the implementation of efficient cooling mechanisms—such as fan-based or liquid-based cooling—for rapid operation is critical for practical applications but still underexplored. Herein, we introduce a durable and adaptive SMA actuation system that operates under randomly generated current conditions. This system enables reliable prediction of SMA output force using machine learning models, even as environmental conditions change. A Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network is trained to predict the output force of SMA coils using time-series inputs of current, electrical resistance, and environmental temperature. This model is validated under both static air and flowing water conditions with varying temperatures and flow rates. Furthermore, we demonstrate a closed-loop feedback control strategy for the SMA actuator, highlighting its potential for precise and robust operation across diverse environments.

title: DFA-Net: A Domain Flow Adaptation Network for Diverse Hazy-Image Generation
authors: Trung-Hieu Le, Shih-Chia Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Large and diverse image datasets have facilitated the recent advances in deep-learning-based computer vision applications. Whereas datasets with images depicting normal-weather scenes are plentiful, datasets with images depicting inclement weather conditions, such as haze, remain scarce due to collection difficulties. In response to this problem, we present a novel domain flow adaptation network (DFA-Net) that can control the haze density and facilitate the generation of realistic and diverse hazy images. DFA-Net employs a density variable to direct the network to learn and yield the desired images and is composed of four modules: a semantic extraction (SE) module, a haze extraction (HE) module, an image production (IP) module, and an image assessment (IS) module. The SE and HE modules are used to capture the semantic structure and style representation of clear and hazy images, respectively, and provide them to the IP module for refining the output images. The IP module is adopted to yield hazy images in a coarse-to-fine fashion, while the IS module is responsible for examining the realism of the synthesized results. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets confirm the effectiveness of the proposed DFA-Net, which outperforms competing approaches by achieving improvements of up to 147% in quality, 237% in fidelity, and 354% in the diversity of generated images.

title: Photothermal Detection of Trace Acetylene for Transformer DGA Monitoring Using an Adiabatically Tapered Optical Fiber
authors: Daiyuan Yang, Houxian Du, Xueman Hou, Yukun Wang, Xunbo Gao, Yuan Wang, Guoming Ma
abstract: In the field of optical sensing of characteristic defect gas in transformers, hollow-core photonic crystal fiber (HC-PCF) gas cells suffer from high fabrication costs and complex manufacturing processes. Meanwhile, fabricating non-adiabatic tapered fiber gas cells requires precise control of geometric parameters, such as the length of the transition region and the waist diameter. Moreover, these structures inherently exhibit common-path interference, making them susceptible to environmental noise and limiting detection sensitivity. To address these issues, we proposed a low-cost and easily fabricated adiabatic tapered fiber gas cell, fabricated from standard single-mode fiber using a flame-brushing tapering technique. We fabricated the adiabatic tapered fibers with a waist diameter of 2.2 μm by optimizing the stretching speed and distance of the stepper motors, effectively avoiding the common-path interference caused by mode coupling in non-adiabatic tapered fibers. This process is simple and achieves a production cost that is only 1% of HC-PCF gas cells. Additionally, we developed a heterodyne Mach–Zehnder interferometric (MZI) sensing system for hydrocarbon detection. We moved the beat frequency carrier signal to 100 MHz by introducing an acousto-optic modulator (AOM) to shift the reference light frequency, significantly reducing low-frequency environmental noise disturbances on both the sensing and reference arms. Based on this system, we achieved a detection limit of 0.6 ppm for acetylene gas, with a linear correlation coefficient (R²) of 0.996 for the sensor response. This sensing approach provides a highly sensitive and low-cost technical solution for the real-time, online monitoring of acetylene gas in power transformers.

title: Bridging Theory and Practice in Reconfigurable Fluid Antenna Systems
authors: Halvin Yang, Yizhe Zhao, Kai-Kit Wong, Hsiao-Hwa Chen, Chan-Byoung Chae
abstract: Fluid antennas, including those based on liquid, mechanical, and pixel-based technologies, are poised to significantly enhance next-generation wireless systems by adaptively optimizing their radiation characteristics. Many theoretical analyses assumed near-instant reconfiguration, perfect channel knowledge, static or slowly varying propagation environments, and ideal material properties that rarely hold in practice. In this article, we dissect these common assumptions and contrast them with the realities of finite actuation time, limited and imperfect channel state information, rapidly changing fading conditions, electromagnetic coupling, and mechanical constraints. Through illustrative examples and simulations, we demonstrate how ignoring these factors can lead to overestimated gains in capacity, coverage, etc. We then propose modeling refinements, experimental validation methods, and emerging control algorithms that better account for real-world constraints. Our findings highlight that, while reconfigurable antennas remain highly promising for B5G/6G and Internet of things (IoT) applications, their full potential can only be realized by incorporating practical considerations into system design and performance evaluation.

title: The Internet of Nature Things (IoNT): Pioneering a New Frontier in Environmental Monitoring and Sustainable Ecosystem Management
authors: Inam Ullah, Hazrat Bilal, Amin Sharafian, Mesfin Leranso Betalo, Stephen Arockia Samy, Xiaoshan Bai
abstract: The Internet of Natural Things (IoNT) is the extension of the Internet of Things (IoT) concept to natural environments, with the ability to monitor the environment in real-time using integrated sensor networks, Artificial Intelligence (AI), and remote sensing. IoNT can offer solutions to the ecological crisis that is facing the world today, such as climate change, loss of biodiversity, and depletion of resources. The survey addresses the technology behind the IoNT and its different applications in disaster management, forest conservation, biodiversity monitoring, and agriculture, among others. IoNT has been successfully applied to monitor the quality of water in remote river ecosystems and to irrigate precision agriculture. Furthermore, pilot projects have demonstrated that IoNT can be used to make decisions based on real-time data analytics so that it is possible to manage resources sustainably. The other aspect discussed in the survey is the consistency between the IoNT sensors and the commercial sensors, according to some case studies presented in the literature. In those works, it is also identified that the processes are experimental in sensor testing, data synchronization, and the functioning of standard metrics, which ensure the reliability and strength of IoNT sensor systems. Despite the fact that the IoNT has great strengths, it is still possible to encounter issues concerning data security, energy efficiency, and interoperability. The survey addresses these issues and identifies new trends, such as blockchain and autonomous systems, that can make IoNT applications more scalable and efficient to manage the sustainable ecosystem.

title: Calculation of Photocarrier Generation from Optical Absorption for Time-domain Simulation of Optoelectronic Devices
authors: Liang Chen, Ming Dong, Ran Zhao, Hakan Bagci
publish: IEEE Journal on Multiscale and Multiphysics Computational Techniques
abstract: Photocarrier generation rate in optoelectronic materials is often calculated using the Poynting vector in the frequency domain. However, this approach is not accurate in time-domain simulations of photoconductive devices because the instantaneous Poynting vector does not distinguish between power flux densities of optical and low-frequency electromagnetic fields. The latter is generated by photocurrents and is not supposed to contribute to the photocarrier generation since the corresponding photon energy is smaller than the bandgap energy of the optoelectronic material. This work proposes an optical absorption-based model to accurately calculate the generation rate in time-domain simulations. The proposed approach considers the material dispersion near the optical frequency corresponding to the bandgap energy of the optoelectronic material and calculates the instantaneous optical absorption from the polarization current density associated with this dispersion model. Numerical examples show that the proposed method is more accurate than the Poynting vector-based approach in calculating the instantaneous optical absorption. The method is further validated against experimental results via simulations of a photoconductive device, where the Poynting vector-based approach results in divergent carrier densities when the low-frequency fields are strong.

title: Energy-based Kinematic Analysis on Magnetic Soft Continuum Robot with Asymmetric Magnetization
authors: Junyeong Lee, Joowon Park, Sukho Park
abstract: Magnetically actuated soft continuum robots (MSCRs), which offer remote and wireless control via external magnetic fields along with high flexibility, have recently emerged as a promising technology for minimally invasive surgery (MIS). However, the magnetic actuation forces of MSCRs are generally limited, resulting in inherent workspace constraints. To overcome these limitations, various design strategies have been explored, including the development of an asymmetric magnetized soft continuum robot (AMSCR). Although AMSCRs have demonstrated a significantly larger workspace than conventional MSCRs, a quantitative relationship between the magnetization patterns of embedded magnetic particles and the resulting workspace has not yet been fully clarified. In this study, an energy based kinematic analysis of AMSCR was conducted to address this issue. Specifically, the equilibrium posture of the AMSCR was determined by minimizing the total potential energy, considering different combinations of external magnetic field directions and internal magnetization patterns. Based on the resulting potential energy graph, the workspace of the AMSCR was quantitatively analyzed, and an optimal linear asymmetric magnetization pattern was identified. Furthermore, the proposed energy-based kinematic model was validated through finite element analysis (FEA) conducted using COMSOL Multi-physics, as well as through experiments performed on a fabricated AMSCR prototype. As a result, an optimal magnetization design method for linearly asymmetric AMSCRs was proposed and experimentally confirmed. The proposed approach is expected to be further applicable to the kinematic performance evaluation and design optimization of AMSCRs with various other magnetization patterns.
