title: Multimodal Carotid Risk Stratification with Large Vision-Language Models: Benchmarking, Fine-Tuning, and Clinical Insights
authors: Daphne Tsolissou, Theofanis Ganitidis, Konstantinos Mitsis, Stergios Christodoulidis, Maria Vakalopoulou, Konstantina Nikita
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Reliable risk assessment for carotid atheromatous disease requires integrating diverse clinical and imaging information in a transparent and interpretable manner. This study investigates state-of-the-art large vision-language models (LVLMs) for multimodal carotid plaque assessment by integrating ultrasound imaging with structured clinical, demographic, laboratory, and biomarker data. A framework that simulates realistic diagnostic scenarios through interview-style question sequences is proposed, comparing open-source LVLMs including general-purpose and medically tuned models. Zero-shot experiments reveal that while most LVLMs accurately identify imaging modality and anatomy, all perform poorly in risk stratification. To address this, LLaVa-NeXT-Vicuna is adapted using low-rank adaptation (LoRA), achieving substantial improvements in stroke risk stratification. Integrating multimodal tabular data as text further enhances specificity and balanced accuracy, yielding competitive performance compared to prior CNN baselines. Our findings highlight both promise and limitations of LVLMs in ultrasound-based cardiovascular risk prediction, underscoring the importance of multimodal integration, domain adaptation, and model calibration for clinical translation.

title: Optimizing UAV Station Placement for Pharmaceutical Transfers between Hospitals
authors: Anastasios Biblias, Emmanouil S. Rigas, Antonios Billis, Panagiotis D. Bamidis
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or simply drones are a fast growing technology with many applications in several sectors, one of them being the transportation of pharmaceuticals. In this work, we study the use of UAVs for transporting pharmaceuticals between hospitals, and we solve the specific problem of the placement of the stations where the UAVs will be based and controlled. The aim of this work is to calculate the minimum number of drone stations required, as well as their locations, to connect a set of hospitals. To achieve this, we consider both the range of the drones and the operational range of the stations, which is defined by the distance over which a drone can be controlled. We initially identify and exclude hospitals that cannot be served because they are beyond the range of drones or stations. Then, we apply a heuristic algorithm to generate an initial set of potential locations for the stations. This solution is given as input to a metaheuristic algorithm that is an adaptation of the well-known Tabu search algorithm. This algorithm improves the initial solution through an iterative process. We evaluated our algorithm through both numerical experiments and a realistic case study, confirming its efficiency and applicability to the task at hand.

title: Control Strategy for Photovoltaic Output Based on Grey Wolf Guided Incremental Method
authors: Lu Shuaiyv, Gao Xin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) power generation is a renewable energy technology that directly converts solar energy into electricity. In recent years, advancements in device technology have significantly improved the efficiency and reduced the cost of PV generation, making it a core direction in the global energy transition. This paper proposes improvements to the Incremental Conductance (INC) method used in Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT). Traditional INC is susceptible to shading effects and exhibits slow response. To address these limitations, we integrate the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) algorithm with the INC method. First, the output characteristics of PV arrays are analyzed to establish an INC model. Second, GWO is incorporated into INC to enhance its global search capability and local optimization. Simulation models of PV systems are built in MATLAB/Simulink, comparing traditional INC, variable-step INC, and the proposed GWO-INC method. Results under varying irradiance conditions demonstrate that GWO-INC accelerates convergence to the Maximum Power Point (MPP), stabilizes output waveforms, and reduces response time compared to the other two methods.

title: Development and Design of Energy Management and Control Platform for Enterprise Microgrid
authors: Tong Liu, Fang Gao, Xiaoxu Jiang, Zhihe Li, Jinxi Hu, Songtao Han
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Due to the low level of informatization in existing enterprise parks, most of them have not realized the automatic reading, storage and query of data such as electricity meters. In addition, there are problems such as poor precision of data analysis statistics and inability to mine and analyze useful information in large-scale data. Based on the Spring Boot architecture, an enterprise microgrid energy management and control platform based on artificial intelligence is proposed. The platform adopts a layered architecture to integrate data from different systems such as photovoltaics, energy storage, distribution networks, and charging piles into the enterprise microgrid management and control platform for analysis, thereby solving the problem of information islands caused by different system data types and transmission methods. Secondly, the virtual measurement points method uses logical operation rules instead of hardware equipment to calculate energy consumption such as electricity and water, so as to solve the problems of high energy consumption, high capital consumption, complex equipment distribution, and inability to directly measure the installed hardware equipment. On this basis, intelligent monitoring is carried out on key areas such as factories, production workshops, and distribution rooms to detect suspicious personnel and issue warnings in a timely manner. Finally, a carbon footprint analysis and calculation model is introduced into the energy management and control platform to monitor the main energy consumption in the park and analyze and calculate the carbon footprint. By comprehensively dispatching various energy sources such as photovoltaic, energy storage, wind power, etc. in the park, the park can generate electricity and use it for its own needs. The solution can effectively reduce carbon emissions, provide carbon reduction measures, optimize energy use strategies, and help companies achieve green transformation.

title: Research on Multi-Energy Coupling Collection Based on Fully Covered Piezoelectric Structure
authors: Yuxuan Liu, Yixuan Meng, Hanxi Lin, Wenshuo Zhang, Mingxi Jia, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Currently, the global energy revolution is advancing rapidly. As critical carriers in clean energy systems, fluid energy sources have made energy coupling mechanisms pivotal for enhancing harvesting efficiency. Through numerical simulations, theoretical analysis, and experimental verification, our team validated the feasibility of PVDF thin-film piezoelectric generators. We developed and optimized an intelligent energy harvesting system integrating PVDF piezoelectric units with a BQ25570 power management module. Combined with tunnel acoustic energy harvesting, this system demonstrates potential for deep fluid energy utilization.

title: zkConsensus: A Zero Knowledge Proof Implementation for Consensus Sequence Generation
authors: Marxel S. Abogado, Worasait Suwannik, Geoffrey A. Solano, Somchoke Ruengittinun
abstract: Consensus sequences are reconstructed representations of original DNA strands, generated by aligning and combining multiple fragmented reads. This paper presents zkConsensus, a privacy-preserving system that verifies the generation of consensus sequences without revealing sensitive genetic information with the use of Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs). Implemented in Circom language, the circuit validates three validation parts: the consistency between original and aligned reads, the correctness of alignment scores across all read pairs, and the support for the consensus bases through majority voting. The system takes as public inputs the original reads, their lengths, and an expected score, while treating the alignments, reverse complement indications, start positions, and final consensus as private.

title: From Detection to Evidence: A Unified System for Automated Email Phishing Analysis and Forensic Logging
authors: Siti Husna Abdul Rahman, Kirtanah Manalan, Nur Haifa Mohd Fathil, Ahmad Anwar Zainuddin
abstract: Phishing attacks continue to bypass traditional defenses and burden non-technical users with manual, errorprone investigations. Existing tools are largely detectioncentric and rarely preserve evidence in a structured, reusable form, leaving a gap between threat identification and postincident analysis. We present a unified web-based system that automates email ingestion, multi-engine scanning, and forensic logging within a single interface. Implemented as a full-stack Python (Flask) application with MongoDB, the system programmatically acquires emails (or user-uploaded. eml), submits artifacts to VirusTotal, and parses headers to extract and geolocate sender IPs, maintaining user-scoped, audit-ready records. A dashboard provides real-time status, verdict visualization, and access to detailed reports and header forensics. In evaluation with 20 emails (10 phishing, 10 benign), the system achieved 95% accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geqslant 90 \%$</tex> target), while soak testing demonstrated stable operation over extended runtime. By coupling automated detection with structured, user-specific forensic records, the system reduces technical barriers and strengthens incident response, making email threat analysis more accessible to both non-technical users and security teams.

title: Tool-Assisted Annotation of Seafloor Sediment-Linked Features Using Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation
authors: Shahrokh Heidari, Mitchell Rogers, Jiaxuan Wang, David Arturo Soriano Valdez, Stefano Schenone, Gemma Cunnington, Patrice Delmas, Simon Thrush
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Pixel-wise labeling of seafloor imagery is highly time-consuming, limiting the scalability of benthic habitat monitoring. While existing underwater computer vision research has largely focused on visually prominent habitats, sediment-linked benthic features remain underexplored and lack annotated datasets. To address this gap, we propose a tool-assisted annotation framework based on weakly supervised semantic segmentation. The framework follows a three-phase pipeline: feature-based pseudo-mask generation, binary classspecific segmentation, and iterative multiclass segmentation with pseudo-mask expansion and affinity-field regularization. Applied to six ecologically important sediment features, the approach progressively improves pseudo-label quality while reducing reliance on dense expert annotations, providing a scalable solution that can accelerate the annotation of seafloor sediment features. Code is available at: https://github.com/shahrokh1106/seafloor-sediment-segmentation

title: Design of a CMOS Transmitter Chain for Satellite on the Move Communications
authors: Uxua Esteban-Eraso, Gesler Ramos, Santiago Celma, Francisco José Torcal-Milla, Carlos Sánchez-Azqueta
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: One of the main features that are expected for 6G networks will be their ability to have a three-dimensional (3D) extension. In contrast with current communications networks, in which the transimission of the signals is carried out at the surface level, this will allow true global coverage including oceans and vast unpopulated areas. 3D global coverage has become a strategic goal and efforts are being put into its implementation with the current deployment of 5G networks and in satellite communications (SATCOM). This requires minimizing the energy losses experienced by electromagnetic waves in the GHz bands. To achieve this goal, the most promising solution is the use of active antenna arrays incorporating smart beamforming techniques to achieve directionality in signal transmission. This work presents the design and simulation of the transmitter path of an active antenna array operating within the European downlink frequency band for SATCOM on the move (SOTM) applications (17.7 to 21.2 GHz). It incorporates a compact phase shifter based on a vector-sum architecture and a power amplifier based on the concatenation of neutralized differential common-source pairs. The transmitter has been designed in a 65nm CMOS MM/RF process. It achieves a phase resolution of 11.25° over the 360° range, with a gain of approximately 22.5 dB using a 5-bit control word while consuming 30mW.

title: An Impedance-Based Method for Online Preventive Control Generation Against Wide-Band Oscillation
authors: Wang Tu, Feng Luo, Haitao Liu, Jian Zhang, Naishuang Li, Qi Pan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the rapid increase in wind power penetration, wide-band oscillation issues caused by interactions between the fast flexible control characteristics of power electronic devices and the grid have become prominent. This paper proposes an online preventive control method against wide-band oscillation. First, oscillation-vulnerable areas are identified based on real-time grid conditions, and the full-frequency impedance of the grid-connected wind power system and grid side is calculated to assess wide-band oscillation risks online. Then, the impact factors of individual wind farm clusters on the equivalent resistance and reactance of the wind power integration system at oscillation frequencies are computed. Finally, a preventive control optimization model is formulated with the objective of minimizing post-control active power losses while ensuring system security and stability constraints, generating online preventive control measures against wide-band oscillations. Simulation cases on a practical system validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, providing technical support for enhancing renewable energy integration.

title: Adaptive Federated Meta-Reinforcement Learning for Personalized Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Mingchun Ma, Kedong Yan, Chanying Huang, Rui Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Intelligent Technology and Embedded Systems (ICITES)
abstract: In the field of intelligent embedded systems, the demand for multi-agent collaboration and personalized task processing without compromising user data is rapidly growing. To accommodate this need, we propose an Adaptive Federated Meta Reinforcement Learning method, named AFedMeta-RL, which combines the privacy protection of federated learning and the strong generalization ability of meta-learning. It can address the issue of insufficient adaptability of reinforcement learning in personalized tasks caused by differences in client environments while protecting privacy. The algorithm first implements a two-stage optimization strategy of meta-learning on the client side, fine-tuning the policy in the local environment to quickly adapt to specific tasks. It then further enhances the policy’s generalization ability through an adaptive validation phase. Meanwhile, AFedMeta-RL introduces a dynamic exploration rate mechanism that can adaptively adjust the balance between exploration and exploitation based on the agent’s learning progress and environmental feedback. On the server side, the algorithm employs a weighted aggregation protocol based on two metrics, training stability and task performance, to optimize the global model. Experimental results show that AFedMeta-RL achieves significantly higher average rewards than traditional methods and personalized federated reinforcement learning baselines in multiple test environments. Moreover, the proposed method demonstrates a significant advantage in the cold start scenario of new clients, requiring only a few steps of training to quickly transfer the policy, thereby verifying its adaptability to new tasks.

title: Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance Planning for Unmanned Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yubao Li, Meng Yu, Liangliang Han, Linxuan Gu
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Safe autonomous UAV planning in dynamic environment remains critical for low-altitude economy development, where conventional reinforcement learning methods with continuous velocity-control action spaces suffer from inefficient exploration and complex reward function design. To this end, this study proposes a deep reinforcement learning framework that formulates UAV path planning as a two-point boundary value problem, constructing the action space via a generalized Zero-Effort-Miss/Zero-Effort-Velocity means to derive velocity commands through an adaptive gain optimization algorithm; the state space integrates proprioceptive UAV states and obstacle features extracted from three-frame LiDAR sequences, while a concisely designed sparse-dense reward function circumvents complex reward structures. The proposed approach is validated in AirSim simulation environment, it achieves $34 \%$ faster convergence compared with traditional deep reinforcement learning based methods, in the meanwhile, it also reduces the total path length by $13.1 \%$ and transit times by $8.5 \%$ even without velocity/smoothing reward setting, which strategically resolving DRL planning challenges of exploration inefficiency and reward complexity in dynamic settings.

title: Simulation Calculation of Positive-Sequence Parameters for High-Voltage Single-Core Cables Based on Detection of Power-Frequency and Different-Frequency Methods
authors: Jie Zhou, Sujuan Xie, Kangni Wei, Yu Chen, Ke Yang, Yijia Zhu, Yifan Zhu, Wanhua Guo, Haiming Yang, Bin Zhang, Xinhua Guo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: To explore the equivalence between the differentfrequency methods and the power frequency methods in terms of positive-sequence impedance parameters of high-voltage cables, this study employs the finite element simulation method to construct a model of high-voltage single-core cables, aiming to explore the influences and differences of various grounding methods on the parameter measurement of high-voltage cables. Within the framework of physical field-circuit coupling, the equivalence between the different-frequency method and the power-frequency method in measuring the positive-sequence impedance parameters of high-voltage cables is verified. Additionally, for different frequency points, the measurement errors of cable parameters with different lengths are analyzed. The results indicate that the different-frequency method is effective in the field of measuring positive-sequence impedance parameters of high-voltage cables, which provides a reliable technical reference and theoretical basis for the measurement of positive-sequence impedance of high-voltage cables.

title: Optimized Cyber-Attack Detection and Localization in Smart Grids via Autoencoder-Based Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Amirreza Taherinia, Mahsan Tavakoli Kakhki, Turaj Amraee
abstract: Cyber-attack detection and localization are becoming increasingly critical, with AI methods significantly enhancing their effectiveness. This study utilizes Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), specifically ResNet-18 and LeNet, along with an Autoencoder for unsupervised feature extraction from unlabeled data. To enrich the dataset and improve model generalization, the L2 Penalty Regularization method is applied to generate synthetic data. The detection process consists of two stages: first, the Autoencoder processes unlabeled data, extracting latent features to improve accuracy in unstructured scenarios. In the second stage, these extracted features are fed into ResNet-18 and LeNet, which act as classifiers for effective cyber-attack detection. By combining pre-trained CNNs with deep transfer learning and Autoencoder-extracted features, the model achieves a 10% improvement in accuracy, primarily due to enhanced attack localization, feature extraction, and pattern recognition. The dataset, developed by Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), consists of three subsets representing normal, disturbance, control, and cyberattack behaviors in the electric transmission system. The integration of Autoencoder-extracted features with CNN classifiers, along with the use of simplified CNN architectures, significantly enhances model generalization and accuracy across various attack scenarios.

title: Comparative Study of DINOv2, I-JEPA, and ViT Embeddings for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection
authors: Jean-Marc Spat, Houda Chabbi-Drissi
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: This paper presents a unified, unsupervised framework for Visual Anomaly Detection (VAD) in dynamic, fixed-view scenes, leveraging modern Vision Transformers (ViTs) without additional fine-tuning. We investigate whether embeddings from backbones like a generic ViT, DINOv2, and I-JEPA, combined with a simple clustering approach, are sufficient for identifying anomalies. Our methodology extracts both global (CLS token) and local (patch-level) embeddings, applies clustering (k-Means, HDBSCAN) to model the distribution of normal scenes, and uses a scalable vector database (ChromaDB) for efficient similarity search. The three backbones delivered comparable performance, with the generic ViT showing a small but consistent advantage in balanced accuracy. Although local embeddings provided a 3 % gain in balanced accuracy, their sequential processing time is considerably higher. This limitation could be mitigated through parallelization, potentially bringing their efficiency closer to that of global embeddings. In contrast, global embeddings deliver comparable performance while being approximately 256 times faster, enabling near real-time batch processing of 15 s video segments. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{k}$</tex>-Means clustering and the proposed retrieval strategy proved most effective, achieving a practical operational trade-off with a balanced accuracy of 82 %. These results suggest that ViT embeddings are effective for separating normal and anomalous patterns. Local embeddings appear to capture complementary and pertinent information, and we expect that with modest adjustments in the detection strategy, they could be further leveraged to improve anomaly detection performance.

title: DanceAgent: Dance Movement Refinement with LLM Agent
authors: Cheng Shang, Xingyu Chen, Liang An, Jiajun Zhang, Yuxiang Zhang, Yebin Liu, Xubo Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Recent research on motion generation and text-to motion synthesis focus on coarse-grained motion descriptions, neglecting fine-grained motion details and motion quality refinement. Additionally, current text-to-motion models, such as MotionGPT, lack multi-turn interaction capabilities, relying on single-turn and single-modality transformations, which limit their ability to integrate information from different modalities across interaction stages. These gaps leave critical questions, such as “Howwell is the motion performed” and “How can it be refined?” largely unaddressed. To address these issues, first, we introduce two fine-grained dance datasets—one focusing on jazz dance and the other on folk dance, which we have independently collected. Second, considering that dance motions are inherently complex and consist of long sequential actions, we introduce both global and local optimization during the motion encoding phase and employ Hidden Markov Model (HMM) temporal modeling to capture differential features between correct and incorrect movements, thereby optimizing the training process. Finally, we propose a multi-turn historical dialogue framework that enables three stages generation—motion assess, text instructions, and motion refinement—for input videos. This framework assists dance beginners by providing feedback on their movements, offering textual instructions, and delivering motion-based refinement. Experimental results on the jazz dance and folk dance datasets demonstrate that our method surpasses existing approaches in both quantitative and qualitative metrics, establishing a new benchmark for motion-text generation in the field of dance training.

title: Face De-Identification: State-of-the-Art Methods and Comparative Studies
authors: Jingyi Cao, Bo Liu, Xiangyi Chen, Ming Ding, Rong Xie, Li Song, Zhu Li, Wenjun Zhang, Yiyan Wu
abstract: The widespread use of image acquisition technologies in broadcasting and multimedia services, together with advances in facial recognition, has raised serious privacy concerns. In live news or streaming interviews, audiences may legitimately view participants, yet automated systems can capture and recognize their identities without consent, creating significant legal and ethical risks. Face de-identification, which refers to the process of concealing or replacing personal identifiers, has therefore emerged as an effective means to protect the privacy of facial images. A significant number of methods for face de-identification have been proposed in recent years. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive review of state-of-the-art face de-identification methods, categorized into three levels: pixel-level, representation-level, and semantic-level techniques. We systematically evaluate these methods based on two key criteria, the effectiveness of privacy protection and preservation of image utility, highlighting their advantages and limitations. Our analysis includes qualitative and quantitative comparisons of the main algorithms, demonstrating that deep learning-based approaches, particularly those using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and diffusion models, have achieved significant advancements in balancing privacy and utility. Experimental results reveal that while recent methods demonstrate strong privacy protection, trade-offs remain in visual fidelity and computational complexity. This survey not only summarizes the current landscape but also identifies key challenges and future research directions in face de-identification.

title: Fine-Tuning and Deploying Large Language Models Over Edges: Issues and Approaches
authors: Yanjie Dong, Haijun Zhang, Chengming Li, Song Guo, Victor C. M. Leung, Xiping Hu
abstract: Since the release of GPT2-1.5B in 2019, the large language models (LLMs) have evolved from specialized deep models to versatile foundation models. While demonstrating remarkable zero-shot ability, the LLMs still require fine-tuning on local datasets and substantial memory for deployment over the network edges. Traditional first-order fine-tuning techniques require significant GPU memory that exceeds the capacity of mainstream hardware. Besides, the LLMs have been expanded beyond text generation to create images, audio, video, and multi-modal content, necessitating careful investigation of efficient deployment strategies for large-scale foundation models. In response to these challenges, model fine-tuning and model-compression techniques have been developed to support the sustainable growth of LLMs by reducing both operational and capital expenditures. In this work, we provide a comprehensive overview of prevalent memory-efficient fine-tuning methods for deployment at the network edge. We also review state-of-the-art literature on model compression, offering insights into the deployment of LLMs at network edges.

title: Multilevel joint regularizations meet dual self-representations: An innovative deep subspace clustering framework for Hyperspectral Images
authors: Han Zhai, Jun Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Hyperspectral image Clustering is a long-standing difficulty due to the huge spectral variability and significant nonlinearity. Deep subspace clustering (DSC) has presented incomparable advantages over traditional subspace clustering by learning robust features and nonlinear affinities. However, due to the neglection of hierarchical complementarity by solely using the deepest features and insufficient exploration of pixel relationships through single self-representation, the existing DSC methods suffered from degraded performance. To address these issues, this paper proposed an innovative clustering framework named dual self-representation based deep subspace clustering with multilevel joint regularizations (DDSC-MJR) for hyperspectral images. On the one hand, a dual self-representation module was developed to fully excavate the intrinsic affinities between pixels by consecutive self-expressions and affinity learning. On the other hand, both deep-seated and shallow features induced by a well-designed convolutional autoencoder were exploited in dual self-expressions, with multilevel joint regularizations utilized to promote their coefficient matrices to share a similar structural pattern. To fully leverage the advantages of multilevel self-expressions, a weighted residual fusion module was developed to adaptively fuse the learned coefficient matrices to create a more indicative and clustering-friendly adjacency matrix. Ultimately, a multifaceted joint loss involving data reconstruction, dual self-representations, multilevel joint regularizations, and graph regularization were put forward to simultaneously constrain each part of the network in the training process. The extensive experimental results on three public HSI datasets clearly demonstrate the large superiority of DDSC-MJR to the other state-of-the-art arts and indicate that it can be a promising tool for real applications.

title: AI-Based Pest Detection and Monitoring in Paddy Fields for Optimized Pesticide Management and Yield Enhancement
authors: Shridevi Bhat, Sanjana Shenoy, Navaneeth Bhaskar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Technologies for Humanity and Smart World (HSWTech)
abstract: Pest attacks in paddy fields usually result in major crop losses and lead to the excessive use of dangerous pesticides. To solve this problem, this paper presents an automated pest detection and monitoring system using a smart trap. The trap attracts major pests like yellow stem borer, leaf folder, and brown planthopper using a combination of UV light, pheromones, and insect wingbeat sounds. After catching the pests, images are captured and analyzed using the You Only Look Once-version 8 (YOLOv8) deep learning model. The system showed detection accuracy of 97.4%, precision of 96.8%, recall of 97.9%, F1-score of 97.3%, and mean average precision (mAP@0.5) of 98.1%, showing strong and consistent performance. The average inference time is just 18.7 milliseconds per image, which is practical for real-time updates. The solar-powered system is simple to install, needs very little maintenance, and is therefore suitable for use in distant farmlands. Pest data is shared through a simple web interface, helping farmers take quick action and prevent excessive pesticide application. This solution supports cost-effective, ecofriendly, and smarter paddy farming by allowing early pest detection and better decision-making.

title: Embedded Flexible Circumferential Sensing for Real-Time Intraoperative Environmental Perception in Continuum Robots
authors: Peiyu Luo, Shilong Yao, Yuhan Chen, Max Q.-H. Meng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Continuum robots have been widely adopted in robot-assisted minimally invasive surgery (RMIS) because of their compact size and high flexibility. However, their proprioceptive capabilities remain limited, particularly in narrow lumens, where lack of environmental awareness can lead to unintended tissue contact and surgical risks. To address this challenge, this work proposes a flexible annular sensor structure integrated around the disks of continuum robots. The proposed design enables real-time environmental mapping by estimating the distance between the robotic disks and the surrounding tissue, thereby facilitating safer operation through advanced control strategies. The experiment has proven that its accuracy in obstacle detection can reach 0.20mm. Fabricated using flexible printed circuit (FPC) technology, the sensor demonstrates a modular and cost-effective design with compact dimensions and low noise interference. Its adaptable parameters allow compatibility with various continuum robot architectures, offering a promising solution for enhancing intraoperative perception and control in surgical robotics.

title: STMixer: Spatial-Temporal Mixer for Continuous Sign Language Recognition
authors: Nguyen Tu Nam, Hiroki Takahashi
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Continuous Sign Language Recognition (CSLR) aims to bridge communication gaps by translating continuous sign language videos into sequences of glosses. A major challenge lies in modeling complex spatio-temporal dynamics under weak supervision, where precise frame-level sign boundaries are unavailable. While deep learning models have advanced CSLR performance, many rely on 2D CNNs that struggle to capture inter-frame motion, or require auxiliary modalities such as optical flow or pose estimation, thereby increasing complexity. To address these limitations, we propose the Spatio-Temporal Mixer (STMixer), a novel module that explicitly factorizes spatio-temporal learning into three sequential stages: temporal mixing, spatial mixing, and channel mixing. This disentangled design enables efficient and effective modeling of motion patterns and structural features directly from RGB video input. Integrated into a standard ResNet-based CSLR framework, STMixer enhances spatio-temporal reasoning without requiring additional modalities or complex preprocessing. We evaluate our method on the PHOENIX14 and PHOENIX14-T benchmarks, achieving competitive performance with a Word Error Rate (WER) of 18.6 % and 19.0 % on the Test set, respectively. Notably, our model outperforms existing methods using similar backbones and matches the performance of more complex, multi-modal approaches, demonstrating that explicit spatio-temporal factorization offers a powerful and efficient paradigm for CSLR.

title: Efficient Medical Image Classification in Model-Heterogeneous Federated Learning
authors: Madhuri Wakode, Geetanjali Kale
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Healthcare centers use artificial intelligence to detect thoracic diseases from chest X-ray images. However, they often lack the huge amounts of data required to build efficient models. Multiple hospitals can contribute their data to create large data pools to train learning models. In the absence of trust and data privacy guarantees, hospitals may be reluctant to share sensitive data due to healthcare privacy protection guidelines, standards, and legal issues. Federated Learning (FL) enables multi-hospital collaboration to jointly build intelligent models without sharing sensitive data with each other. The participating hospitals often exhibit varying compute, storage, and dataset capabilities and tend to build customized models as per their requirements. Participants with different model architectures is one of the most pressing issues in FL environments. Classical FL aggregation algorithms do not support the co-existence of different model architectures in the system. To address this issue, we use a Knowledge Distillation (KD)-Based FL Algorithm (KDBFA) for efficiently detecting multiple diseases in Chest X-ray (CXR) images in heterogeneous setup. We perform an in-depth analysis of homogeneous against heterogeneous models in the FL setup with Densenet121, ResNet50, and EfficientNet models on the CheXpert Plus dataset. Our proposed algorithm achieves 86.04% accuracy in detecting multiple diseases using CXR images under heterogeneous model scenario. Performance of the proposed KDBFA is comparable to the homogeneous setup, with an accuracy of 85.91% with EfficientNet.

title: Secure and Efficient E-Voting Using Parallelized RSA-Based Digital Signatures
authors: T. Venkata Sai Shirisha, Christopher Columbus C
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: Ensuring the integrity and security of electronic voting (e-voting) systems is crucial for maintaining fair and transparent democratic processes. This paper proposes a secure and efficient e-voting architecture that integrates Parallelized RSA-based Digital Signatures to enhance both voter authentication and vote verification. In the proposed system, each vote is signed using the voter’s private key and verified using the election authority’s public key, thereby ensuring authenticity, non-repudiation, and tamper resistance. To address performance concerns, the RSA-based signature verification process is parallelized using OpenMP, significantly reducing computational time compared to sequential implementations. Experimental results demonstrate notable speedup gains with increasing thread counts, though diminishing returns are observed at higher levels due to parallelization overhead. Despite this, the system maintains scalability and remains practical for large-scale elections. By combining robust cryptographic mechanisms with parallel computing, this framework offers a secure, efficient, and scalable e-voting solution well-suited for modern digital electoral environments.

title: Good Practices in Information Technology Auditing
authors: Pacharapon Sattayapong, Nalinpat Bhumpenpein
abstract: This study aims to investigate key factors influencing the success of Information Technology (IT) auditing and to propose good practice guidelines for IT audit processes in Thailand. A qualitative research method was employed, utilizing in-depth interviews with six experts who possess 2 to 15 years of experience in IT auditing. The findings reveal that the primary success factors include auditor independence, technical expertise, risk analysis capability, knowledge of auditing standards and regulations, and executive support. Regarding good practices, the study proposes an IT audit model consisting of five core stages, i.e., risk analysis, audit planning, audit execution, reporting, and post-audit follow-up. Notably, the risk analysis and follow-up phases are identified as critical to enhancing audit effectiveness in rapidly changing environments. Furthermore, continuous training and skill development for auditors are recognized as essential to improving audit accuracy and credibility. This research not only offers practical guidelines for conducting IT audits but also provides valuable insights for enhancing organizational audit processes to effectively address digital risks in a timely and appropriate manner.

title: Ecovoyage: An AI-Based System for Personalized and Sustainable Travel Planning
authors: Akira Kunoon, Napatsawan Meephol, Onjira Sitthisak
abstract: While tourism supports economic growth, it can also cause environmental problems. This paper presents Ecovoyage, an AI-based system for creating personalized and eco-friendly travel plans. The system uses two machine learning methods: K-Means Clustering to group activities into categories and a Decision Tree to suggest destinations based on user preferences. A Greedy Algorithm is applied to choose travel routes that are efficient and better for the environment. The system also recommends Green Leaf-certified hotels, nature-based attractions, and low-carbon transportation options. A pilot study with 17 participants tested the system in the Bangkok Metropolitan Region. The results showed that Ecovoyage can produce travel plans that match user preferences while supporting sustainable tourism. Its modular design allows for easy scaling to other provinces in Thailand and, in the future, to international destinations with local datasets and emission models.

title: Research on UAV swarm effectiveness evaluation method based on deep learning
authors: Hengyuan Chi, Lizhi Wang, Ruyue Li, Hui Tang, Minze Xu, Zhongzheng Cao, Lingfei You
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: UAV swarms have shown significant advantages in complex scenarios such as fire rescue due to their flexibility and collaboration capabilities, but their effectiveness evaluation still faces challenges such as dynamics, nonlinearity and real-time performance. In this study, a method of UAV cluster effectiveness evaluation based on deep learning is proposed. The evaluation system covering six indicators such as flight speed, task completion time and cluster coverage is constructed by analytic hierarchy process. The multi-dimensional task data is generated by NetLogo simulation platform, and the Z-score standardization and Min-Max normalization strategy are used for preprocessing. A deep learning model is constructed based on fully connected neural network (DNN), and L2 regularization and Dropout technology are introduced to suppress overfitting. Experiments show that the mean absolute error (MAE) of the model in the test set is 5.32 %, and the prediction error of the task completion time is less than 0.5 %, which verifies its robustness in dynamic scenarios. This study provides a quantifiable theoretical framework for the effectiveness evaluation of UAV swarm, and provides a reference for the design of intelligent decision support system in complex environment.

title: Research on the Interactive Influence of Multi-Layer Nested Sections on the Power Delivery Capability of New Energy Aggregation Systems
authors: Dehai Zhang, Xuanyuan Wang, Haitao Liu, Haibo Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The present study sets out to address the challenge of static voltage security assessment for multi-level sections in large-scale new energy aggregation systems. The study reveals the voltage–power flow coupling mechanism and the interaction law of security limits. Conventional methods encounter challenges in characterizing the spatial distribution characteristics of voltage trajectories under practical operating conditions. This deficiency leads to an inadequate level of accuracy in evaluating the static stability limits of sections with nested causal relationships. The present study proposes a multi-temporal–spatial scale assessment framework for the analysis of the characteristics of voltage oscillatory instability under fault-free conditions. Firstly, the coupling influence of wind–solar resource fluctuations and the upper–lower section control on operating limits is quantified. Subsequently, a voltage trajectory prediction model that takes into account future power flow growth directions is established to analyze the dynamic correlation between spatial voltage distribution and power flow variation. It is evident that the interactive mechanism of static security limits for each section is clarified, provided that the constraint of voltage oscillations is considered. The results provide a foundation for the theoretical underpinnings of precise delineation of static voltage stability regions within high-penetration new energy power systems, with relevance to delivery scenarios characterized by intricate causal chains.

title: Electro-Thermo-Mechanical Design and Development of a Reusable Spring-Actuated Separation Mechanism for ORUs
authors: Wenbo Bai, Xuhui Yang, Ning Zhang, Wenlai Ma, Peng Tian, Qiang Zhang, Xiaosong Zhang, Qiaodong Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: Traditional pyrotechnic separation mechanisms for Orbital Replacement Units (ORUs) suffer from high shock and non-reusability. This study presents a reusable, spring-actuated separation mechanism featuring integrated electro-thermo-mechanical design. A dynamics model incorporating both translation and rotation analyzed the impact of centroid offsets on separation velocity and collision risk. Simulations across eight offset scenarios and varying host masses confirmed the mechanism achieves the target $1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ separation velocity even under a 20 mm X-axis offset, with no collision, and stability when the host exceeds 300 kg. Structurally, a dual-flange interface and differentiated materials (aluminum alloy, carbon-fiber composite) balance lightweight and strength. The electrical subsystem integrates sensing and actuation within a unified low-shock connector. Thermally, polyimide pads and MLI effectively suppress conductive/radiative coupling. The study establishes practical thresholds for centroid offsets and mass matching, providing key engineering guidelines for reusable ORU interfaces in modular spacecraft on-orbit servicing, reducing costs and extending mission life.

title: Improved HVRT Control of PMSG-based Wind Turbine Considering Current Operation Region
authors: Zhichao Yang, Jiaxing Lei, Bingtuan Gao, Lingzhi Zhu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: During high voltage ride through (HVRT) period, permanent magnet synchronous generator-based (PMSG-based) wind turbine would experience DC-link overvoltage or AC-side overcurrent issue, which can lead to trip-off accident. This paper investigates the typical structure and fault characteristics of PMSG-based wind turbine in HVRT state. Considering the GSC capacity, pre-fault power, and grid code constraints of grid-side converter (GSC), the visualized current operation region is built to depict the transient current limit of PMSG-based wind turbine. Furthermore, a current operation region-based HVRT control method is proposed for enhancing the transient performance of PMSG-based wind turbine. Simulation results in PSCAD verifies the effectiveness of the proposed HVRT method.

title: Comparative Study of Hedonic Motivation, Shopping Lifestyle, and Trust on Impulse Buying in Social Commerce Platforms
authors: Kanyapa Phromsing, Nitthanet Natthakunlanan, Parkpoom Chaisiriprasert
abstract: In social commerce, lifestyle and psychological factors influence impulsive purchases in intricate, non-linear ways. This study analyzes survey data from Shopee Indonesia <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n=138)$</tex> and TikTok Vietnam (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=361$</tex>) using machine learning with stratified cross-validation, calibration, and SHAP-based explainability. Five classifiers were trained and evaluated with PR-AUC, ROC-AUC, and F1-score. Shopee models yielded stable performance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1 \approx 0.78$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R O C$</tex>-AUC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.92$</tex>), while TikTok models achieved high accuracy (F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.99$</tex>, ROC-AUC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.94$</tex>) but showed signs of overfitting. SHAP analysis confirmed that hedonic motivation was the strongest predictor across both platforms, with demographic variables more influential on Shopee and trust and scarcity more impactful on TikTok. These findings provide cross-cultural insights into impulsive buying behavior and practical guidance for platform-specific marketing strategies. Limitations include the smaller Shopee dataset and reliance on self-reported surveys, suggesting that future work should incorporate larger behavioral logs, causal inference, and deep learning approaches

title: A Fitting-Based Modeling Method of TCLs for Power System Demand Response
authors: Yu Zhou, Yibao Jiang, Haoran Zhao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: Demand-side response (DSR) has gradually become an important means of regulating power balance in electric power systems. As a primary target of DSR, Thermostatically Controlled Loads (TCLs) present challenges for accurate modeling due to large variations in building structures, unknown physical parameters, and diverse operating conditions. This paper proposes a data-driven modeling approach based on Vector Fitting (VF). The method requires no prior physical parameters and relies solely on historical indoor temperature and TCL power data. Time-domain data are converted into frequency-domain responses using the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), and the VF algorithm iteratively solves for the transfer function’s poles and residues to construct a compact linear time-invariant model. The method is validated using measured data from the NEST building complex in Switzerland from 2019 to 2022, with 10th- and 20th-order building models. The proposed approach achieves predictions that match the actual measurements perfectly.

title: Carbon-Based 2D Composites as Thermal Interface Materials for Thermal Management of Power Devices
authors: Tan Gim Kam, Iskandar Yahya, Avinash Kumaresan, Seri Mastura Mustaza, Norazreen Abd Aziz, Huda Abdullah
publish: 2025 IEEE Regional Symposium on Micro and Nanoelectronics (RSM)
abstract: Thermal interface materials (TIMs) based on two-dimensional (2D) carbon composites offer a pathway to reduce interfacial thermal resistance (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">int</inf>) in high-power electronics. This study evaluates graphene (Gr), carbon nanotube (CNT), and titanium dioxide (TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) hybrid composites as thermal interface materials (TIMs) for power devices using advanced simulation techniques in ANSYS Icepak. A novel aspect of the work is the incorporation of surface roughness modeling using the Greenwood-Williamson theory in a simulation environment. The results demonstrate that specific hybrid stack configurations able to minimize interface thermal resistance and provide optimized thermal performance, even under varying surface roughness conditions with ΔT/Δx as low as 0.00862 °C/μm. We replicated a published experimental setup to compute and normalize R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf> from both simulation and experiment to enable direct comparison and linking. Surface roughness values reported in the literature were mapped to effective contact areas (A<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</inf>) in simulation through Greenwood–Williamson theory, and it is revealing a near-two-fold increase in normalized R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf> as A<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</inf> decreased from 100% to 4%. The combined architectural and roughness correlation model provides predictive design guidelines for low-resistance TIMs in compact and high-reliability devices during the simulation phase of the project.

title: Predefined-Time Cooperative Guidance Law for Multiple Missiles with Terminal Angle Constraint
authors: Zhe Hu, Wenjun Yi, Weichen Qian, Hongqiao Yin
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Aerospace Engineering and Systems (ISAES)
abstract: In addressing the problem of coordinated attacks on maneuvering targets in three-dimensional space by multiple missiles, this study proposes a prescribed-time cooperative guidance law incorporating impact time and terminal angle constraints. The proposed guidance law consists of two main components. Firstly, a novel predefined-time multi-missile consensus protocol is developed. Building upon this, a predefinedtime cooperative guidance law for the line-of-sight (LOS) direction is designed to ensure simultaneous target engagement by all missiles. For the terminal angle constraint problem, a terminal sliding mode surface designed by introducing a time-to-go term. Based on this, a guidance law for the LOS normal direction is constructed, effectively smoothing the guidance commands while ensuring terminal angle constraints. Finally, numerical simulation results demonstrate that the proposed predefined-time cooperative guidance law successfully hits the target without causing saturation in control commands.

title: LiteXGNN: A Lightweight Explainable Graph Neural Network for Malware Detection with Control Flow Graph Explainability
authors: Kaung Khant Wai Yan, Jakapan Suaboot, Maneenate Puongmanee, Warodom Werapun
abstract: Current malware detection systems prioritize classification accuracy while neglecting behavioral analysis, limiting their utility for security analysts. This paper presents LiteXGNN, a lightweight explainable graph neural network framework that simultaneously performs malware detection and provides interpretable explanations through Control Flow Graph (CFG) analysis. Our approach combines supervised GraphSAGE-based learning with unsupervised GNNExplainer for both local and global interpretability without requiring labeled explanation data. The key innovation involves training the explanation component on benign CFGs to extract pure malware subgraphs by removing benign noise, clarifying decision boundaries, and enhancing analytical precision. LiteXGNN addresses critical limitations including high computational costs, lack of explainability, and inability to isolate malicious patterns. The framework generates comprehensive analysis reports that contain behavioral indicators, API categorizations, and structural statistics to support the forensic investigation. The preliminary implementation demonstrates the feasibility of integrating explainable AI into malware detection while maintaining competitive performance, offering significant potential to improve analysis efficiency through actionable insights into malicious behaviors.

title: Weakness Identification in Integrated Energy Systems Based on Volume Scaling Ratio Factor
authors: Yingqi Tie, Changzheng Shao, Bo Hu, Wei Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Energy Power and Automation Engineering (ICEPAE)
abstract: Integrated energy systems (IES), which involve multiple types of energy conversion and storage, offer significant flexibility, playing a vital role in enhancing energy efficiency and facilitating the integration of renewable energy. However, ensuring the safe and stable operation of IES requires effective identification of system vulnerabilities. Identifying the weak components within the system is crucial for improving its reliability and enabling efficient operation. In this paper, a weakness identification method based on a volume scaling ratio factor is proposed, considering the uncertainty in load. A load interval model is constructed, and a new system load-shedding risk metric is introduced, along with its analytical expression, which reduces the computational burden. Additionally, a risk responsibility allocation criterion is established, enhancing the fairness and accuracy of weak link identification. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through case studies.

title: Enhancing Thai Text Clustering for Performing Arts Through Domain-Specific NLP and Clustering Algorithms
authors: Pichaya Dumnil, Utharn Buranasaksee
abstract: This study aims to enhance the accuracy of Thai text clustering. It focuses specifically on text related to Thai performing arts. The objective is to improve information retrieval and support the preservation of cultural heritage. The research focuses on improving text preprocessing, embedding techniques, and clustering algorithms. The preprocessing pipeline includes word segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, stopword removal, and noun extraction, with domain-specific dictionaries incorporated for improved accuracy. Various embedding methods, including FastText, bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERT), WangchanBERTa, and BGE-M3, were evaluated. Dimensionality reduction techniques, such as principal component analysis (PCA) and uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP), were employed to optimize clustering performance. Among the clustering methods tested—k-means, DBSCAN, hierarchical clustering, spectral clustering, and gaussian mixture models (GMM)—k-means with UMAP achieved the highest Silhouette score (0.7115), indicating well-defined clusters. Additional evaluation using Davies-bouldin index (0.3948) and Calinskiharabasz index (2297.5827) confirmed the effectiveness of this approach. The resulting clusters were semantically coherent and thematically distinguishable, comprising groups related to folk performance, rituals and cultural practices; identity, symbolism and social values; mythology, royal traditions and sacred narratives; and deities, warriors and legendary figures. Expert validation further ensured the semantic coherence of clustered terms. These findings contribute to the advancement of natural language processing (NLP) methodologies for Thai text and can be applied in AI-driven recommendation systems and digital cultural heritage preservation.

title: Effects of Primary’s Oblateness on Satellite’s Relative Motion
authors: Qian Wang, Qingmu Ai, Yuzhi Wang, Shunli Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: This study presents the transformation between differential orbital elements and relative Cartesian states in near-circular orbits perturbed by J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and compares the influence of mean and modified mean elements on relative motion accuracy. The state transition matrices of the mean elements are obtained by performing a Taylor expansion of the averaging theory. Considering the difference in the accuracy of the relative motion derived for the mean and osculating elements, the mean elements of the chief are modified based on the osculating elements, determined by numerical methods. The initial values obtained from the C-W equation result in a drift along the track, which can be negated by correcting the initial values to obtain a bounded relative motion. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through numerical simulations and comparisons with a high-fidelity numerical method

title: Research on Green Hydrogen Capacity Planning Considering Grid-Side Voltage Security Margin Based on Artificial Intelligence Algorithms
authors: Zhihong Wu, Wei Dang, Qiang Hu, Yang Shen, Qinqin Xu, Xu Yang, Quan Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: This paper presents a green hydrogen capacity planning approach incorporating grid-side voltage stability margin using the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO). Continuous power flow parameters are introduced as constraints to ensure voltage security under varying operating conditions. By embedding a penalty function into GWO, multiple planning constraints—including electrolyzer capacity limits, node voltage bounds, and power flow security margins—are effectively handled. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves optimal hydrogen capacity allocation while maintaining grid voltage stability, offering a practical tool for integrated energy system planning.

title: A Deadbeat Model Predictive Current Control for Phase-Shifted Full-Bridge Converters with Fast Dynamic Response
authors: Yu Liang, Hui Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: Phase-shifted full-bridge (PSFB) converters are widely used in high-power Direct Current to Direct Current (DCDC) systems due to their high efficiency and power density. However, conventional linear controllers like ProportionalIntegra (PI) controllers show limited dynamic response and robustness during input voltage/load transients. To address this, this paper proposes a discrete-time deadbeat model predictive current (DMPC) control strategy for PSFB converters. Based on a discrete-time output stage model, the DMPC strategy predicts inductor current at the next sampling instant and calculates the optimal phase-shift ratio online, achieving rapid current tracking. Validated via MATLAB/Simulink simulations, the DMPC controller demonstrates ultra-fast dynamic response with minimal overshoot under transients. Compared to conventional methods, it significantly enhances disturbance rejection and dynamic accuracy, proving its suitability for high-performance power systems.

title: Width-Dependent Quantum Conductance and Transmission in AA-Stacked Armchair Bilayer Graphene Nanoribbons
authors: Yuki Wong, Nurul Ezaila Alias, Suhana Mohamed Sultan, Choon Min Cheong, Tian Swee Tan, Michael Loong Peng Tan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: This study investigates the quantum transport properties of AA-stacked armchair bilayer graphene nanoribbons (AA-ABGNRs) under width variations, with a focus on quantum conductance and transmission coefficients. Employing the nearest-neighbour tight-binding (NNTB) model and non-equilibrium Green's function (NEGF) formalism, the results reveal that wider ribbons exhibit a linear increase in quantum conductance due to the proportional rise in the number of conduction channels. Metallic ribbons with larger widths support more conducting channels, enhancing their effectiveness for electronic applications. The transmission spectra demonstrate that broader ribbons feature denser and more prominent transmission peaks, indicative of additional subbands contributing to electronic transport. These findings underscore the critical role of width variations in modulating the electronic properties of AA-ABGNRs, providing a pathway for their optimization in advanced nanoelectronic devices such as transistors and energy-selective filtering systems. This work contributes to the understanding of quantum confinement effects and their influence on the tunability of electronic transport mechanisms in bilayer graphene nanoribbons.

title: Automated Grade Classification of Ankle Osteoarthritis Using Advanced Neural Network Classifier
authors: Kottaimalai Ramaraj, Pallikonda Rajasekaran Murugan, Wai Kit Wong, MD. Jakir Hossen, Arunprasath Thiyagarajan
abstract: Ankle Osteoarthritis (AOA) is a form of joint degeneration that affects movement and overall quality of daily life, but it is more uncommon compared to knee or hip OA. Ankles joint is composed of three major bones: the tibia (shinbone), fibula (calf bone), and talus (ankle bone). As a result of the disorders' increasing cartilage deterioration, there is bone-on-bone friction and constriction of the joint space, which ultimately results in discomfort and decreased mobility. Prompt detection and classification of AOA using clinical imaging techniques, such as MRI and X-rays, is important for timely treatment and effective therapy. Precisely classifying the different grades of AOA is vital for timely identification and effective therapy selection. Traditional grading schemes depend on radiologists' subjective, inter-reader variability-prone subjective evaluation. The current research suggests a semi-automated method for assessing and rating AOA using MATLAB and Joint Space Width (JSW) assessment. Recognition of edges is used to emphasize bone edges after the raw X-ray picture has been preprocessed employing contrast enhancement and noise reduction procedures. The Euclidean distance within the talus, fibula, and tibia margins can subsequently be measured by individuals by choosing many pairs of points across the intersection region. These measurements are linked to predetermined OA severity classifications conforming to medical norms and normalized to millimeters applying an established metric. In addition, the method estimates the overall OA grade and calculates the average JSW. This method helps radiologists make increasingly precise and predictable findings while also increasing uniformity and lowering variability.

title: Automated Activity Monitoring of Cryptic Species in a Zoo Environment
authors: Mitchell Rogers, Junhong Zhao, Simon Eyre, Bing Xue, Mengjie Zhang
publish: 2025 40th International Conference on Image and Vision Computing New Zealand (IVCNZ)
abstract: Automated monitoring of cryptic species in a zoo environment provides a valuable opportunity to study behaviours and ecological patterns to inform conservation efforts that would otherwise remain poorly documented. In this study, we explore the problem of monitoring a population of endangered Whitaker's Skink (Oligosoma whitakeri), a cryptic species that hides under leaf litter for most of the day, held in captivity at Te Nukuao Wellington Zoo, New Zealand. We propose a lightweight pipeline based on the Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) between frames sampled from videos and identify time points where the skinks are active in their habitats. We benchmark our pipeline against a deep learning approach based on the MegaDetector model, explore the influence of both the sampling rate and choice of difference metric on detection performance, and discuss the challenges of implementing our pipeline. The proposed method provides scalable, interpretable, and low-cost monitoring of skink activity and can be integrated with existing zoo camera systems to reduce the daily workload of keepers without requiring intensive computing resources.

title: CMOS SPDT Switch Topologies in the Frequency Range of 6 to 20 GHz
authors: F. Bonfiglio-Buendía, Natalia-Abel Fernández-García, P. López, V.M. Brea, Diego Cabello
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This work builds on a recent contribution from the literature to improve isolation on single-pole single-throw switches by introducing an additional transistor at the gate of the series devices in a series-shunt architecture implemented in an FDSOI process. This paper explores the effects of this extra transistor when used in single-pole double-throw switches implemented with RF CMOS transistors in a 130 nm SiGe technology over the 6-20 GHz range. The insights drawn from the post-layout simulations confirm improved isolation, albeit at the cost of higher area consumption, lower output power handling, and higher insertion loss. The overall performance is evaluated using a figure of merit that combines these parameters, showing that the series-shunt configuration offers the best trade-off, while the analyzed approach may be advantageous in applications with area-constrained designs or very high isolation requirements.

title: Engineering Fit-for-Implementation Digital Twins Across the Total Product Lifecycle of Next-Generation Dental Restorative Materials: A Translational Intelligence Strategy for Real-World Impact
authors: Orlando Lopez, Jeff Buchsbaum, Elena Sizikova, Noffisat Oki, Sepideh Mazrouee, Julia Berzhanskaya, Siddharth Shenoy
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: A Digital Twin (DT) is a set of virtual information constructs that mimics the structure, context, and behavior of a natural, engineered, or system-of-systems. It is dynamically updated with data from its physical twin, possesses predictive capabilities and supports decision-making processes that garner value. Bidirectional interaction between the virtual and the physical systems is central to functionalizing a digital twin. Recently, Biomedical Digital Twins (BDTs) are poised to revolutionize biomedical innovation by enabling predictive, realtime modeling of complex biological and engineered systems. However, despite their potential, most BDTs fail to reach deployment due to a fundamental misalignment with clinical workflows, regulatory structures, usability requirements, and systems-level constraints. This paper introduces a new class of digital twins, termed Fit-for-Implementation Digital Twins (FiDTs), designed to address the translational gap through an engineering-informed, stakeholder-driven, and lifecycle-integrated strategy. The primary audience for this article includes biomedical digital twin innovators and clinical stakeholders (e.g. physicians, caregivers, and patient advocates). We present a novel translational framework that embeds three foundational constructs into the engineering of BDTs: Fit-for-Purpose for scientific and mechanobiological validation, Fit-for-Implementation for realworld deployment readiness, and Technology- and EngineeringReadiness for structured decision-making and maturity assessment across the Total Product Lifecycle. FiDTs evolve digital twins into dynamic, regulatory-aware, and context-sensitive ecosystems, capable of simulating system-to-system interactions, accelerating preclinical validation, informing adaptive trial design, and integrating with electronic health record infrastructure. To reliably maintain and sustain these biomedical DTs, we propose a Multi-Participatory Twin Engineering Model to anchor stakeholder co-development from ideation to implementation to ensure co-development with clinicians, regulators, payers, caregivers and patients from the outset. This paper outlines a scalable, modular approach that harmonizes simulation fidelity with deployment feasibility. It includes actionable tools for risk mitigation, accessibility modeling, and global context adaptability, enabling DT systems that are not only predictive, but also trusted, scalable, and ethically grounded. Furthermore, we present the application of the proposed framework for FiDTs to accelerate critical milestones in the end-to-end translation of next-generation dental restorative materials (e.g., composite resins, ceramics, smart materials, sealants) as a representative case study of BDTs in biomedical innovation. In advancing the FiDT concept for dental health, we offer a visionary yet pragmatic foundation for next-generation BDT engineering. This foundation supports translational science mandates, anticipates regulatory evaluation, and accelerates the delivery of accessible, sustainable innovations in oral health and beyond.

title: Color Space Channel Evaluation for Clahe-Enhanced Retinal Vessel Segmentation With Attention U-Net
authors: Patrycja Kwiek, Małgorzata Jakubowska
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of retinal blood vessels plays a crucial role in the early diagnosis and monitoring of systemic and ophthalmological diseases, such as diabetic retinopathy and hypertension. While many existing approaches rely on grayscale or RGB image representations, this work explores the impact of color space transformations on segmentation performance using an optimized Attention U-Net architecture. The study evaluates 19 input variations: grayscale and individual channels from six color space models-RGB, YUV, HSV, HLS, CIELab, and YCrCb. All images were preprocessed using the CLAHE algorithm to enhance local contrast and suppress background noise, particularly beneficial for medical images with low illumination and poor vessel visibility. A key innovation lies in identifying the most informative channel from each color space and comparing segmentation outcomes across them. The Attention U-Net was trained on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 6} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{2 5 6}$</tex> retinal image patches derived from the DRIVE dataset, using a composite loss function combining Binary Cross-Entropy (BCE) and Dice loss (weighted 0.2 and 0.8 respectively). Among all tested channels, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Y$</tex> component from the YUV color space achieved the best performance, with a mean DICE coefficient of 0.879 on test patches and a maximum of 0.922. Full-resolution image evaluations further validated these results, reaching DICE scores up to 0.912 and pixel-level accuracy above 0.979. Statistical significance was rigorously assessed. A paired ttest confirmed that CLAHE preprocessing significantly improved segmentation accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.0001$</tex>). Additionally, a Wilcoxon signed-rank test demonstrated that models trained with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{Y}$</tex> channel from YUV significantly outperformed grayscale-based models (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.0001$</tex>), with consistent improvement across all samples. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{Y}$</tex> channel also exhibited the lowest variance among all tested channels, indicating strong robustness and generalization capability. This research underscores the importance of color channel selection in medical image segmentation and shows that combining optimized input representations with attention mechanisms and hybrid loss functions can yield clinically meaningful improvements. The findings provide a practical foundation for the development of more reliable, color-aware computer-aided diagnostic tools in ophthalmology and related fields.

title: DTChecker: A Real-Time Signal Monitoring and Property Specification Tool for Digital Twins
authors: Abdelhamid Rouatbi, Eugene Syriani, Bentley Oakes
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Specifying and monitoring temporal requirements in Digital Twin (DT) systems is challenging, as writing formal specifications in temporal logic is often complex and inaccessible to domain experts. This typically necessitates close collaboration with software engineers, introducing communication overhead and slowing development. We present DTChecker, a reusable selfcontained monitoring tool for DT systems built on RabbitMQbased architectures. The tool enables domain experts to write temporal specifications in a browser-based editor with language server support. These specifications are automatically translated into Signal Temporal Logic (STL) formulas and evaluated in real-time on data streams from sensors or services. Robustness scores are streamed to a front-end dashboard to visualize how well the system satisfies the specified requirements over time. This enables domain experts to write and verify temporal properties easily, thereby improving the real-time monitoring of the DT. We demonstrate the tool through integration with an open-source incubator DT case study. Video demonstration: https://youtu.be/elyhSOiGuc4?si=V2TTsXgRcYaAU2X

title: Comparing High- and Low-Level Model Representations for Evolutionary Algorithms
authors: Henrik Eckhardt, Jens Kosiol
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Model-driven optimization promises the availability of meta-heuristic approaches, such as evolutionary algorithms, for optimization problems to domain experts, without requiring deeper knowledge of the underlying technologies. Models directly serve as the problem specification, while model transformations form the evolutionary operators for exploring the search space. Evolutionary algorithms, however, are usually designed to operate on low-level representations (or encodings) such as bit strings or vectors of integers or real numbers. As models generally consist of multiple high-level constructs and are much more complex than the usual low-level encodings, a performance penalty is to be expected when operating directly on such models. On the other hand, models provide additional domain knowledge and, as such, allow for the design of more sophisticated evolutionary operators. In this work we compare the performance of evolutionary algorithms operating on high- and low-level representations of solutions on two problems, the class responsibility assignment problem as well as the multi-objective knapsack problem. The results show a clear advantage of high-level model representations in terms of solution quality, producing higher-quality results for all evaluated instances, which generally come at the cost of a higher total duration. The extent of the differences and their reasons are found to greatly depend on the complexity of the model and its instances.
