title: Modeling the Full Stack: Frontend and Backend Generation with Extended Domain Models
authors: Gagandeep Singh, Gunter Mussbacher
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: In model-driven engineering courses, students are often asked to implement complete applications from domain models with code generation following architectures such as Model-View-Controller. However, much of the implementa-tion-both backend logic and user interface still involves substantial manual effort. FeatureLanguage is a lightweight domainspecific language built on top of domain models and introduced to enable code generation from high-level feature specifications in such educational settings. In this work, we extend FeatureLanguage to also support User Interface (UI) generation. This extension enables automatic generation of frontend alongside backend components, all from a user-defined domain model, layout related constructs, and UI annotations, which are all expressed in an extended class diagram. The result is a more complete transformation pipeline that reduces the implementation burden on students and instructors. According to a comparison of the generated UI screens against the manually crafted UI implementation over four course projects, on average $83 \%$ of required UI elements per screen are automatically generated.

title: Consistent Modeling of Agility: Applications of Flexible Multi-Level Modeling
authors: Razieh Dehghani, Anne Koziolek
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Agile system development emphasizes minimizing unfinished work by focusing on the most prioritized tasks. While this approach improves efficiency, it can also lead to challenges in coordinating efforts, often resulting in inconsistencies. These issues become even more pronounced in interdisciplinary projects, where conceptual misalignment between domains are common. To address this, a modeling shared development approach can help reduce inconsistencies and foster alignment across disciplines. However, the modeling approach must be flexible, as concepts may exist at different levels of granularity and dynamicity. Flexible Multi-Level Modeling (FMMLx) supports this need by enabling adaptable representations while also offering mechanisms to control and constrain flexibility. This research proposes a mapping between these adapting mechanisms and the corresponding challenges in agile development. The resulting models and controls can be used to support a shared understanding of agile practices and manage variability. This paper presents the strengths of FMMLx to model prescriptions for agile methodologies in comparison to the existing strict two-level models. The results demonstrate FMMLx’s flexibility and applicability in supporting agile practice modeling.

title: Bridging Expertise Gaps in the WEF Nexus through Participatory Modeling: Insights from Oyo State, Southwest Nigeria
authors: Foluke Olatoye, Cynthia Odili, Jafaru Musa Egieya
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: This study presents insights from a participatory modeling initiative undertaken during the 2025 SustainFood Collaborative Learning School (CLS) in Oyo State, Nigeria. The initiative engaged early-career researchers, smallholder farmers, and policy actors to collaboratively address challenges within the Water-Energy-Food (WEF) Nexus. Using tools such as Causal Loop Diagrams (CLDs), Political Economy Analysis (PEA), and actor-factor mapping, the team co-developed a model centered on Interest-Free Credit Cooperatives (IFCs) to enhance rural resilience. The participatory process empowered non-technical stakeholders to engage in systems thinking, visualize complex feedback loops, and design sustainable, community-driven interventions. The resulting model positioned IFCs not only as financial mechanisms but also as platforms for capacity building, climate adaptation, and collective resource management. Key preconditions for success included multilingual facilitation in English and Yoruba, cultural sensitivity, and institutional collaboration. Despite challenges such as limited systems-thinking exposure and time constraints, the approach fostered shared ownership and conceptual clarity. A WEF-IFC Toolkit was proposed to scale the intervention, supported by participatory Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) systems. The study contributes to the discourse on inclusive systems modeling and demonstrates how participatory approaches can localize sustainability solutions and inform bottom-up policy integration in resource-constrained contexts.

title: Control and Coordination of DC Collection Systems for Large-Scale Offshore Wind Integration
authors: Yijing Chen, Jianbo Su, Xiaojiang Guo, Chunhua Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: As there are currently no operational medium-voltage DC (MVDC) collection system projects for offshore wind power, this paper proposes a referential parallel-type MVDC collection system engineering implementation scheme for offshore wind power. Addressing issues such as complex control and difficulties in self-starting of the system, a coordinated startup control strategy with black-start capability is proposed. Stable MVDC collection voltage is first established by the offshore DC wind turbines (ODCWTs). Subsequently, the centralized offshore substation completes the uncontrolled charging and active charging processes using this voltage. After startup completion, the system enters the power transmission stage. The machine-side converter (WTVSC) of the ODCWT adopts active power control. The grid-side converter (GSVSC) generates the AC voltage reference through low-voltage DC (LVDC) link voltage control and then performs voltage/frequency control. Meanwhile, the centralized offshore substation switches to MVDC collection voltage control to achieve stable system operation. Finally, a simulation model is established in PSCAD/EMTDC to verify the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed strategy.

title: On-Demand Cardiac Digital Twins: A Case Study on DevOps workflows for Digital Twin Platforms
authors: Pranjay Yelkotwar, Rohit Raj, Aryan Pingle, Prasad Talasila, Neena Goveas
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE 28th International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems Companion (MODELS-C)
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs), when integrated with physical systems and their virtual representations, can support real-time analysis, simulations, and decision-making. A major barrier to creating DTs is the effort required to put together the techniques and technologies developed by subject experts. The Digital Twin as a Service (DTaaS) is a DT platform that helps in DT development by creating collaborative environments in which users can develop, use, and share DTs. While experts can create and customize DTs to their needs, non-expert users benefit from automated solutions for on-demand deployment and execution of DTs. Modern software engineering practices such as Development and Operations (DevOps) have produced architectural solutions for a scalable deployment of software products. In this work, we present our contribution to the integration of DevOps workflows with the DTaaS platform. We develop a cardiac DT for ECGbased preventive diagnostics of the human heart. The same DT is used to demonstrate an implementation of DevOps workflows on the DTaaS platform. We find that our proposed solution is suitable for time-sensitive applications and flexible enough to be used with other DT platforms.

title: Optimizing Magnetic Sensory Configuration for Gesture Recognition in Bionic Hands
authors: Mehdi Alimohammadi, Arman Abasian, Mohammad-R. Akbarzadeh-T.
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Computer and Knowledge Engineering (ICCKE)
abstract: Achieving accurate and reliable performance in bionic hands is crucial for implanted magnets, which are used for tracking the muscle movements of amputee patients. Increasing the number of magnets is the first trivial action. However, there are two main challenges: (I) implementing many magnetic sensors is hard in surgeries for both the amputee and the doctor, and (II) increasing the number of magnets increases their interference, resulting in reduced performance. To find fewer needed magnetic sensors, this study suggests using Binary Particle Swarm Optimization (BPSO) for feature selection. In particular, we propose an error margin added to the cost function, which acts as a hyperparameter to select the best sensors. Compared to using a total set of 16 sensors, using only 8 sensors achieves an accuracy of 96.98% in predicting three hand gestures—wrist, fist, and thumb—in the second day actual experiment. This accuracy can easily increase if the data is obtained only from the 8 sensors in the identified locations because of the elimination of interference from other sensors, which the current dataset includes. These findings validate the proposed sensor configuration’s robustness and effectiveness in accurately distinguishing between hand gestures. This result also holds the potential for future experiments, implanting only 8 sensors to remove the interference from 16 sensors.

title: Brain Tumor Classifiers Under Attack: Robustness of ResNet Variants Against Transferable FGSM and PGD Attacks
authors: Ryan Deem, Garrett Goodman, Waqas Majeed, Md Abdullah Al Hafiz Khan, Michail S. Alexiou
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Conference on Bioinformatics and Bioengineering (BIBE)
abstract: Adversarial robustness in deep learning models for brain tumor classification remains an underexplored yet critical challenge, particularly for clinical deployment scenarios involving MRI data. In this work, we investigate the susceptibility and resilience of several ResNet-based architectures, referred to as BrainNet, BrainNeXt and DilationNet, against gradient-based adversarial attacks, namely FGSM and PGD. These models, based on ResNet, ResNeXt, and dilated ResNet variants respectively, are evaluated across three preprocessing configurations (i) full-sized augmented, (ii) shrunk augmented and (iii) shrunk non-augmented MRI datasets. Our experiments reveal that BrainNeXt models exhibit the highest robustness to black-box attacks, likely due to their increased cardinality, though they produce weaker transferable adversarial samples. In contrast, BrainNet and Dilation models are more vulnerable to attacks from each other, especially under PGD with higher iteration steps and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> values. Notably, shrunk and non-augmented data significantly reduce model resilience, even when the untampered test accuracy remains high, highlighting a key trade-off between input resolution and adversarial vulnerability. These results underscore the importance of jointly evaluating classification performance and adversarial robustness for reliable real-world deployment in brain MRI analysis.

title: Parameter Identification of a Perturbed Servo System via ESO-PSO and RoLS-VFF algorithms
authors: Abraham Rivera, Antonio Herrera, Rubén Garrido, Ricardo Cortez
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This work shows a comparative study of two novel parameter identification algorithms applied to a servo system affected by a bounded disturbance. The first algorithm corresponds to an offline Particle Swarm Optimization algorithm relying on an Extended State Observer (ESO-PSO), and the second algorithm is an online Robust Least Squares with Variable Forgetting Factor (RoLS-VFF). The performance of these methods is evaluated through real-time experiments on a laboratory prototype, and a detailed analysis is conducted by comparing the parameter estimates obtained using each method with previously identified values. This comparison provides insight into the accuracy, robustness, and adaptability of the proposed algorithms under real-world conditions. The results highlight that each algorithm has its strengths and weaknesses. Moreover, this study provides a practical perspective on the trade-offs involved in selecting identification algorithms for real-time control applications.

title: Decision–Feedback Equalization Over Doubly Selective Channels via Adaptive Hard-Thresholding Delay–Doppler Estimation
authors: Fei-Yun Wu, Peng-Kun Wang, Quan Sun
abstract: Reliable high-rate underwater acoustic (UWA) communication is challenged by the doubly selective nature of the channel, where multipath propagation induces delay spread and platform or boundary motion generates Doppler dispersion. This article develops a delay–Doppler (DD) domain framework that jointly models and compensates these impairments. First, we introduce an adaptive hard-thresholding (AHT) estimator tailored for sparse DD spreading functions, combining curvature-aware step-size control with hard thresholding and least-squares debiasing to enhance support recovery and reduce bias. Second, building on this estimate, we design a 2-D decision–feedback equalizer (delay-Doppler-domain equalizer (DDE)–decision-feedback equalizer (DFE)) that incorporates a windowed minimum-mean-square error feedforward stage and a successive interference cancellation feedback stage, thereby mitigating both delay spread and multiple Doppler components. Numerical experiments on a quadrature phase-shift keying image-transmission task confirm that the proposed AHT–DDE–DFE achieves superior image quality, lower bit error rates, and tighter symbol constellations compared with conventional greedy and global baselines, while maintaining competitive computational cost. These results demonstrate that sparse DD modeling combined with DD-domain equalization provides an effective and practical solution for wide-Doppler UWA links.

title: LoRA Patching: Exposing the Fragility of Proactive Defenses against Deepfakes
authors: Zuomin Qu, Yimao Guo, Qianyue Hu, Wei Lu
abstract: Deepfakes pose significant societal risks, motivating the development of proactive defenses that embed adversarial perturbations in facial images to prevent manipulation. However, in this paper, we show that these preemptive defenses often lack robustness and reliability. We propose a novel approach, Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) patching, which injects a plug and-play LoRA patch into Deepfake generators to bypass state of-the-art defenses. A learnable gating mechanism adaptively controls the effect of the LoRA patch and prevents gradient explosions during fine-tuning. We also introduce a Multi-Modal Feature Alignment (MMFA) loss, encouraging the features of adversarial outputs to align with those of the desired outputs at the semantic level. Beyond bypassing, we present defensive LoRA patching, embedding visible warnings in the outputs as a complementary solution to mitigate this newly identified security vulnerability. With only 1,000 facial examples and a single epoch of fine-tuning, LoRA patching successfully defeats multiple proactive defenses. These results reveal a critical weakness in current paradigms and underscore the need for more robust Deepfake defense strategies. Our code is available at https://github.com/ZOMIN28/LoRA-Patching

title: Real-time Velocity Profile Optimization for Time-Optimal Maneuvering with Generic Acceleration Constraints
authors: Mattia Piazza, Mattia Piccinini, Sebastiano Taddei, Francesco Biral, Enrico Berolazzi
abstract: The computation of time-optimal velocity profiles along prescribed paths, subject to generic acceleration constraints, is a crucial problem in robot trajectory planning, with particular relevance to autonomous racing. However, the existing methods either support arbitrary acceleration constraints at high computational cost or use conservative box constraints for computational efficiency. We propose FBGA, a new <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">F</u>orward-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">B</u>ackward algorithm with <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G</u>eneric <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>cceleration constraints, which achieves both high accuracy and low computation time. FBGA operates forward and backward passes to maximize the velocity profile in short, discretized path segments, while satisfying user-defined performance limits. Tested on five racetracks and two vehicle classes, FBGA handles complex, non-convex acceleration constraints with custom formulations. Its maneuvers and lap times closely match optimal control baselines (within <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.11\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.36\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>), while being up to three orders of magnitude faster. FBGA maintains high accuracy even with coarse discretization, making it well-suited for online multi-query trajectory planning. Our open-source <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C++</monospace> implementation is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/DRIVEWISE/FBGA</uri>.

title: Patch-wise Analysis and Reconstruction of Large-scale Floorplan for Digital Twin Modeling
authors: Seunghan Paek, Wonyoung Cho, Juyong Jeong, Jong-Il Park
abstract: Transforming 2D floorplans into 3D models is a crucial step toward building digital twin environments. However, existing methods designed for residential floorplans often suffer fromwall thickness scaling errors when applied to large layouts and rely on strict orthogonality assumptions, limiting their applicability to complex designs. To overcome these limitations, we propose a patch-wise analysis framework that handles both residential and commercial layouts. Our approach leverages a modular segmentation-and-vectorization pipeline, enabling robust and accurate reconstruction of detailed 3D geometry. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance compared to existing techniques, effectively generalizing from residential to complex large-scale floorplans. Our framework thus provides a scalable solution for creating digital twins of diverse real-world environments.

title: Modeling, Analysis, and Optimization of Omega-shaped Magnetic Field Energy Harvester for Self-Powered Three-Core Cable Sensors
authors: Yonghong Zhou, Yong Li, Shunpan Liu, Jiefeng Hu, Zhengyou He
abstract: In non-uniform magnetic field environments around three-core power cables, conventional magnetic field energy harvesters (MFEHs) typically suffer from low power density due to the mutual cancellation of three-phase magnetic fluxes. To address this limitation, this paper proposes an omega-shaped magnetic field energy harvester (OS-MFEH) based on the amplitude and phase characteristics of the surrounding magnetic flux density. The proposed structure enhances the induced voltage and mitigates output degradation caused by flux cancellation, while also reducing demagnetization effects. A mathematical model of the harvester's output power is developed, incorporating the influence of the magnetic field generated by the harvester coil. Guided by this model, the core dimensions and material properties are systematically optimized to achieve improved performance. The resulting design not only achieves improved power density but also prevents magnetic core saturation—an issue commonly overlooked when coil-induced magnetic fields are neglected. The experiment verified the effectiveness of proposed omega-shaped MFEH structure and the optimization method. The experimental prototype volume is 45.8 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and can achieve an output power of 12.86 mW to 84.2 mW within 100 A<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RMS</sub> to 250 A<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RMS</sub>. Within a three-phase current imbalance of 10%, OS-MFEH can still supply power to the load.

title: Variable Mode Bidirectional LLC Resonant Converter With Dual Resonant Branches
authors: Qinglin Zhao, Zhouzhou Wu, Shixiang Gao, Jing Yuan, Deyu Wang, Hao Ding
abstract: This paper proposes a variable-mode bidirectional LLC resonant converter equipped with two resonant branches, which enables wide-range output voltage regulation within a limited switching frequency range. By regulating the driving signals of the switches, the converter can switch between two operating modes during forward operation: dual half-bridge (DHB) mode and full-bridge plus half-bridge (FHB) mode. Correspondingly, during reverse operation, it operates in dual-path voltage-doubling (DV) mode and single-path voltage-doubling (SV) mode. Frequency modulation is adopted in all operating modes, and synchronous rectification technology is also integrated. Throughout all operational phases, zero voltage switching (ZVS) is implemented for every active switching device, effectively minimizing switching losses and optimizing the overall energy conversion efficiency of the system. A 2.5 kW experimental platform has been built: in forward operation, the DC bus voltage on the primary side is maintained at 400 V, while the battery voltage on the secondary side can be adjusted within the range of 250–450 V, thereby achieving wide output voltage regulation; in reverse operation, the battery terminal voltage ranges from 250 V to 450 V, enabling wide input voltage regulation.

title: Bidirectional Isolated DC-DC Converter with Power Active Allocation Strategy for Single-cell BESS
authors: Jiahao Wang, Dongyuan Qiu, Yangbin Zeng, Bo Zhang, Yukun Chen
abstract: This paper proposes a low-voltage-side parallel high voltage-side series isolated bidirectional DC-DC converter for single-cell battery energy storage systems (BESSs), addressing the critical challenges of high voltage gain requirements and low voltage/high-current operation. Two parallel staggered shunt boost units are used on the low-voltage side to reduce the current ripple and the current stress. The voltage gain is further increased by applying an isolation capacitor on the high-voltage side, which enables the converter to accomplish high-gain boosting without a high transformer turns ratio. Since switches with different performance are used in the two parallel branches to achieve cost efficiency, this paper further proposes a power active allocation strategy for the proposed converter. Despite the mixed use of switches with different conduction and switching characteristics, the proposed strategy dynamically optimizes the branch current allocation through duty cycle control while regulating the output voltage, thus improving the overall system efficiency, particularly enhancing efficiency under light-load conditions. Finally, a 250W prototype with 3.2V/48V is built to verify the working principle of the proposed converter, and the overall efficiency is improved by an average of 1.22% after adopting the power active allocation strategy.

title: A Deep Dive into MediaPipe Pose for Postural Assessment: A Comparative Investigation
authors: Claudia Ferraris, Gianluca Amprimo, Serena Cerfoglio, Luca Vismara, Veronica Cimolin
abstract: Markerless pose estimation is an accessible alternative to marker-based methods. Although Google MediaPipe Pose is a promising RGB-only solution, a comprehensive performance investigation of its 2D and 3D models for postural assessment is lacking. This study systematically evaluated the accuracy, reliability, and symmetry preservation of MediaPipe models at varying complexities, and compared them against a marker-based gold standard and a markerless RGB-D reference system based on Azure Kinect. Twenty-four healthy subjects performed static 40-second postural tasks, from which five categories of angular and linear measures were computed from frontal recordings to compare model’ behaviors. One of the primary findings was the counterintuitive degradation in 3D MediaPipe reconstruction performance with increasing model complexity. Indeed, the high-complexity model introduced severe distortions and asymmetries, which we demonstrated to originate from the 3D-uplifting process rather than robust 2D tracking. All 2D models showed excellent performance in frontal plane analysis, albeit with some limitations for specific angular measurements. This study revealed a clear trade-off between the precision of RGB-D systems and the accessibility of RGB-only models. In addition, the analysis provided detailed recommendations for selecting the most suitable model for specific applications of postural assessment. Overall, the findings suggest that current 3D MediaPipe Pose models should be used with caution for quantitative postural assessment, especially at higher complexities, whereas 2D models represent an effective and practical choice for many lightweight front-view applications.

title: Multimodal Knowledge-Infused VLM for Respiratory Disease Prediction and Clinical Report Generation
authors: Mukhlis Raza, Saied Salem, Hyunwook Kwon, Jamil Hussain, Yeong Hyeon Gu, Mugahed A. Al-Antari
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate and interpretable computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) for respiratory diseases remains a significant challenge due to the complex multimodal nature of medical data. Existing systems often fall short by focusing on unimodal retrieval analysis or lack sophisticated retrieval strategies, which limit both diagnostic reliability and interpretability. To address this, we propose a novel end-to-end CAD framework that employs a large language model (LLM) with advanced retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) techniques, leveraging multimodal retrieval and structured radiology report generation. The framework employs a dedicated vision encoder for binary identifying view types (frontal anterior-posterior (AP), Lateral View (LV)) and multi-label classification for 14 disease categories, with Grad-CAM providing visual interpretability. Concurrently, an advanced text encoder processes unstructured medical reports, enabling the generation of structured zero-shot reports. We propose three novel RAG approaches to enhance retrieval accuracy and reduce LLM hallucination by improving contextual alignment for medical report generation: (1) Caption-Augmented Fusion (CAF), (2) CLIP-Aligned Fusion (CLAF), and (3) Domain-Grounded Fusion (DGF). The performance of our radiology report generation (RRG) is rigorously evaluated using a comprehensive suite of lexical, semantic, and clinical metrics, including METEOR, ROUGE-L, BERTScore, and CheXpert Labeler. The clinical relevance and diagnostic accuracy are further validated by a panel of expert radiologists, establishing a gold standard. Our proposed CAD system can accurately diagnose respiratory conditions and generate structured radiology reports within 21.39 seconds. This rapid and accurate system holds considerable promise for real-world clinical applications and is well-suited to meet the demands of modern medical practice.

title: Towards Defect Detection of Transmission Line Insulator: A Dataset, Benchmarks and Challenges
authors: Zhedong Hu, Yongjie Zhai, Zhenbing Zhao, Qianming Wang, Bangchao Zhai, Ke Yang, Peiyao Hu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: The Insulator is essential for high-voltage transmission systems, offering mechanical support and vital electrical insulation between energized conductors and grounded structures. In recent years, deep learning–based object detection has emerged as a promising approach for identifying defects in transmission line insulators. The performance of these methods largely depends on the availability of diverse, high-quality, and accurately annotated datasets. However, existing public datasets remain limited in scale and diversity, particularly in terms of defect morphology, which poses a significant obstacle to advancing intelligent transmission line insulator inspection technologies. In this study, we present the Transmission Line Insulation Defect (TLID) dataset, specifically designed to meet the requirements of practical insulator defect detection tasks. The TLID dataset comprises 712 raw images and 816 annotated bounding boxes, covering insulator defect samples across three material types (ceramic, composite, and glass), seven background scenarios (e.g., paddy fields, snowy landscapes, deserts), and two distinct viewpoints (close-range with large-scale features, and long-distance with small-scale features). We conduct a comprehensive evaluation of state-of-the-art object detection algorithms on the proposed public datasets and provide an in-depth analysis of the results. Finally, we discuss the key challenges in insulator defect detection for transmission lines and outline potential directions for future research.

title: Smart Distribution Grid Operation Simulation for Efficient Accommodation of Distributed Renewable Energy
authors: Yuanchao Zhang, Youjia Tian, Yongyue Han, Xinyu Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges posed by the integration of distributed renewable energy (DRE) into distribution grids. A simulation model is developed based on the "source-grid-load" framework. Comprehensive simulations are conducted to analyze the operational impacts of DRE under varying conditions, including different locations, power factors, penetration rates, and centralized versus decentralized integration modes. The findings provide decision-making support for the construction, management, and operation of smart distribution grids, facilitating the efficient accommodation of distributed energy resources.

title: Development and Evaluation of Reflection Promoting System Using Knowledge Maps
authors: Mizuto Fujimoto, Masanori Takagi
abstract: Reflection is a vital component of learning, yet it often faces the challenge of fragmentation, where individual learning experiences become disconnected, making it difficult for learners to see their relationships to past and future learning. This research seeks to deepen reflection qualitatively by allowing learners to structurally comprehend their own learning and connect it with new knowledge. Here, qualitative deepening of reflection refers to transforming descriptions from simple enumerations of learned content into more specific and exploratory accounts. To achieve this, we propose a system that leverages Generative AI to dynamically generate and visualize personalized “learning maps” from learners' reflective descriptions. This system serves as a scaffold for structuring (visualizing interplays between concepts) and contextualizing (positioning within related knowledge) the content of their descriptions. Findings from a demonstration experiment with first-year university students propose that employing these maps helps learners make their reflective descriptions more concrete and encourages exploratory activities that extend their interests toward more specialized concepts. While the preliminary study revealed technical and usability challenges that limited engagement for some participants, in this research, we present the architecture and effectiveness of the proposed system and argue that visualizing dynamic knowledge maps derived from learners' own descriptions is an effective approach to fostering the qualitative deepening of reflection.

title: Smart Waste Management System in Cities Using LoRa Technology
authors: Ponglert Sangkaphet, Nawara Chansiri, Chanidapa Boonprasom, Buppawan Chaleamwong, Pheerasap Wonglamai
abstract: Ubon Ratchathani Municipality is confronted with the issue of insufficient waste receptacles and frequent overflow, a situation exacerbated by the continuous increase in waste volume and resulting in incomplete garbage collection coverage. In this study, a smart waste management system designed to monitor waste levels and track the location of trash bins in real time is proposed. The system employs LoRa technology to transmit data from the trash bins to nodes connected to the internet, and the data are subsequently forwarded to a web server. Additionally, a web-based platform for bin management is developed. The experimental results indicate that the system is capable of accurately measuring waste levels within the bins and effectively supports long-distance data transmission. An evaluation conducted by subject matter experts and waste collection staff determined that the system's performance is at a high level, with an average satisfaction score of 3.96.

title: Performance Analysis of Convolution Function for IA Edge Computing Acceleration Using a 32-bit RISC-V CPU Implementation
authors: David Cantero, Alexander Ugena, Laura Sanz, Alejandro Arteaga, Armando Astarloa
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This work presents a Convolution IP coprocessor (CIP) for RISC-V CPUs to accelerate convolution operation between the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> kernel and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> portion of the input layer. This processing is the basis of many artificial vision algorithms required in the industry. Thanks to the RISC-V open instruction set and flexible architecture, it is feasible to explore different ways to accelerate heavy computations that nowadays impose relevant drawbacks to deploying some advanced vision processing on resourceconstrained semiconductor devices widely used in industrial applications. The CIP has been included in a custom SoC RISC-V-based prototype named SoC4cris, which is implemented on FPGA and 65 nm UDSM technologies. The CIP is connected to the CPU via the AXI4-Lite external bus interface in the SoC. It has been implemented using fully combinational logic to achieve the maximum computing power throughput. The CIP performance is compared to the CPU performance in terms of the number of clock cycles needed to fulfill a complete convolution layer computation task. The same test is executed with and without enabling specific RISC-V extensions for integer and floating point arithmetic to analyze the performance versus hardware resource trade-off. The results of our performance analysis demonstrate the exceptional efficiency of the CIP coprocessor. It significantly improves computation performance by a factor of six, all while introducing no considerable overhead in terms of hardware resources. This underscores the robustness and reliability of our design.

title: Large Language Models-based Software Test Input Generation
authors: Seda Akin Akman, Berkay Ertem, Cagatay Catal
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: Test input generation is a critical aspect of software testing, ensuring the quality and reliability of software systems. In recent years, Large Language Models (LLMs) have gained significant attention for their potential to automate and enhance this process. While several studies have explored the use of LLMs in test input generation, a systematic overview of the state of the art in LLM-based test input generation is lacking. Therefore, this systematic literature review (SLR) examines the current state of LLMs in test input generation. A search across multiple databases identified 113 relevant papers, of which 17 specifically focused on test input generation and were selected for in-depth analysis. The study evaluates LLMs based on their applicability, challenges, and limitations. The findings indicate that while LLMs effectively automate and diversify test input generation, challenges remain in scalability and domain-specific adaptability. This study provides insights into the current capabilities of LLMs and their future potential in test input generation.

title: Real-World Evaluation of Driver Cognitive Load Across Traffic Conditions Using Biometric Signals
authors: Alicia Nava, Ilse Cervantes, Amadeo Arguelles, Mauricio Cruz-Acevedo, Marco A. Hernandez-Nochebuena
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This study investigates how physiological signals respond to real-world traffic complexity, aiming to support the development of intelligent systems for driver state recognition. A total of eight participants were monitored using synchronized Electroencephalography (EEG) and Electrocardiography (ECG) recordings while driving along an urban route segmented into low, medium, and high traffic conditions. Time-domain Heart Rate Variability (HRV) metrics Root Mean Square of Successive Differences (RMSSD), and standard deviation of NN intervals (SDNN) and EEG spectral power (theta, alpha, beta bands) were extracted and analyzed per traffic segment. The results show significant and consistent physiological changes across traffic conditions. RMSSD and SDNN values decreased by 22.8% and 18.4%, respectively, under high traffic load, indicating increased sympathetic activation. Simultaneously, frontal theta power increased by 31.6%, suggesting elevated cognitive demand. These effects were observed in 4 out of 8 participants and exhibited region-specific patterns, particularly in frontal and temporal lobes. From a computational intelligence perspective, this work contributes (i) a well-structured, manually labeled dataset combining EEG and ECG in real traffic, (ii) evidence of feature separability across traffic conditions, and (iii) a methodological basis for developing data-driven models for stress and workload detection. The extracted features and synchronized multimodal structure are suitable for training classification models, enabling future implementation of personalized and context-aware cognitive state monitoring in intelligent transportation systems.

title: Genetic Projective Discriminant Analysis
authors: Víctor David García Medina, Héctor Gabriel Acosta Mesa, Adriana Laura López Lobato, Efrén Mezura Montes
publish: 2025 IEEE Latin American Conference on Computational Intelligence (LA-CCI)
abstract: This paper presents Genetic Projective Discriminant Analysis (GPDA), a novel dimensionality reduction method that integrates principles from Fisher’s Linear Discriminant Analysis with evolutionary computation. GPDA addresses the Small Sample Size (SSS) problem by formulating the projection search as a combinatorial optimization task. A genetic algorithm evolves orthonormal projection matrices that maximize the silhouette index, promoting class separability in reduced spaces. The method is evaluated across several benchmark datasets and compared against PCA+LDA and Genetic LDA (GLDA). Results demonstrate that GPDA consistently outperforms traditional techniques in challenging scenarios, providing robust and interpretable low-dimensional representations even when scatter matrices are singular or ill-conditioned. These findings highlight GPDA’s effectiveness in preserving structure and enhancing class discrimination where classical methods fail.

title: Research on the Central Measurement Device of Programmable High-precision Hydraulic Turbine Generator Sets
authors: Jihong Kong, Jiahao Xiao, Yisong Lv, Xi Luo, Guanbao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of strong subjectivity, low efficiency and significant environmental interference in the traditional measurement method of fixed parts of hydro turbine units, a programme-controlled measurement device based on single-chip microcomputer control is proposed. The device replaces manual listening judgement by detecting the on-waveform characteristics of the measurement loop (long <2.4ms at high levels and no burrs) to achieve objective and accurate measurement. The practical application shows that the size of the device is only 48×26×16mm, which supports the power supply of rechargeable lithium batteries, can complete data reading in a single instance in a noisy environment, and the measurement efficiency is better than traditional method, providing reliable technical support for the installation and maintenance of the unit.

title: Congestion Management Mechanism for Inter-Regional Multi-Channel Transactions among Electricity Markets
authors: Xudong Jia, Xiaodong Chen, Zhe Xu, Jiang Wang, Yuxuan Wang, Changyun Wang, Tiance Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: With the deepening of electricity market reform, the transmission congestion management is critical for ensuring efficient market operations. Traditional transmission congestion management methods (e.g., proportional curtailment, price-based priority, and first-come-first-served) cannot accurately reflect the actual social welfare differences arising from different transactions, often leading to increased congestion costs and large fluctuations in locational marginal prices (LMPs). To address these issues, this paper proposes an improved model based on the social welfare congestion factor (SWCF). By quantitatively evaluating the economic benefit and network interaction strength of each transaction unit, the proposed approach seeks to maximize overall system social welfare under congested conditions. Simulations conducted on the IEEE 30-bus system demonstrate that compared to conventional approaches, our model can enhance social welfare by 3.8%–13.6%, reduce congestion costs by approximately 18%, and suppress LMP volatility by 25% in different congestion scenarios. Therefore, our study presents a novel perspective for congestion management of multi-channel transactions between regional electricity markets.

title: Study on Pilot-Stage Hydraulic Bridge with Piezoelectrically-Driven Restrictor of Spool Valve
authors: Bin Wang, Zhibo Liu, Simin Wang, Hongcheng Zhang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE)
abstract: Turbine engines need guide vane mechanism to have the performances of fast response and high reliability, so it is of great significance for the spool valve used in the mechanism. The article presents a new spool valve with hydraulic restrictor bridge as a pilot-stage, which consists of piezoelectrically-driven variable restrictor and fixed restrictor. Principles of four types of half bridge are introduced, and the flow gain and pressure gain of a particular half bridge are modeled and simulated. Characteristics of three types of full bridge, are analyzed and the pressure-flow characteristic of a particular full bridge for the spool valve are examined through AMESim simulation. Influences of main parameters in the restrictor bridge on response ability of the valve are analyzed. The results show that, the half bridge features a fixed restrictor at the oil inlet and a variable restrictor has larger gain and enough stability margin. The full bridge including three fixed restrictors and a variable restrictor has fewer fixed restrictors and higher resolution, and exhibits better displacement and speed response of the spool valve under different diameters of the restrictor. 1.5 mm diameter fixed restrictor can provide the best response for the spool valve. It can be recommended as a scheme solution for pilot-stage bridge in guide vane mechanism.

title: Improving Pedestrian Detection in Infrared Images Using CBAM and Faster R-CNN for Autonomous Vehicle Application
authors: Muhammad Habibullah Abdulfattah, Usman Ullah Sheikh, Mohd Afzan Othman, Nurulaqilla Khamis, Fatima Aliyu Shugaba, Mohd Norzali Mohd
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Infrared imagery is essential for pedestrian detection in autonomous vehicles, especially in low-light and occluded environments where conventional RGB-based methods fall short. This research enhances pedestrian detection by incorporating the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) within a ResNet-50 backbone coupled with the Faster R-CNN model. CBAM improves the model's ability to concentrate on crucial spatial and channel features, which is particularly useful under challenging conditions like occlusions. Experiments conducted on the FLIR dataset reveal that the CBAM-enhanced Faster R-CNN achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) improvement from 0.8505 to 0.8717, reflecting an approximate 2.5% gain. Moreover, the model demonstrated stronger robustness under occluded pedestrian scenarios. These findings suggest that integrating CBAM significantly enhances the reliability of pedestrian detection systems in real-world applications. The results highlight a promising standalone infrared solution that eliminates reliance on RGB fusion, thereby offering a simpler, cost-effective, and more consistent alternative. This improvement supports safer and more dependable autonomous vehicle performance across variable environmental conditions.

title: A 300 mA Fully-Integrated Inverter-Based LDO with Enhanced Supply Insensitivity for Smart Edge AI Applications
authors: M. Clara Simões, Floriberto Lima, Marcelino Santos, Fábio Passos
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: A capacitor-less low-dropout (LDO) regulator with nanosecond-transient response for modern smart edge AI processors is presented. The LDO employs an operational transconductance amplifier (OTA) as the error amplifier and an inverter-based amplifier that provides a high DC gain. The proposed LDO was designed in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$65-\text{nm}$</tex> complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS), allowing for an output range of 0.4-1.6 V from an 1.8 V input and a maximum 300 mA load current. The simulated output undershoot is 60 mV with a load current step from 10 to 300 mA and a 20 ns edge-time. The proposed LDO consumes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$243 \mu \mathrm{A}$</tex> and has a transient response time of 9.97 ns with steps of 10 to 300 mA and 37.2 ns with steps of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 0}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 m A}$</tex>.

title: Character Recognition Application of a Neural Circuit Including Lateral Inhibitory Mechanisms
authors: Dídac Llobet, Ioannis K. Chatzipaschalis, Antonio Calomarde, Antonio Rubio
publish: 2025 40th Conference on Design of Circuits and Integrated Systems (DCIS)
abstract: This article presents the hardware simulation of neurons using memristive devices as synapses. To model the neuronal behavior of a nerve, that is, a coherent set of neurons, we introduce two well-known mechanisms from biology: lateral inhibition and threshold adaptation to repetitive excitations. We present circuit simulations and a high-level model that demonstrate scalable behavior. This network demonstrates the ability to learn and recognize characters, using lateral inhibition as a key dynamizing element.

title: A LightGBM-Augmented Convolutional Transformer with Adaptive Feature Recalibration for EEG Motor Imagery Classification
authors: Md.Wajed Ali, Kawsar Ahmed Refat, Md Golam Sadeque, Dipon Roy, Md Tanjil Sarkar, Gobbi Ramasamy
abstract: Interpreting motor imagery (MI) tasks in brain-computer interface (BCI) systems remains a significant challenge in both neuroscience research and clinical applications. One of the challenges in MI classification tasks is finding an easily handled Electroencephalogram (EEG) representation method that can preserve both temporal and spatial features. In this study, we suggest a compact Convolutional Transformer to combine global and local characteristics into a single EEG classification system. This architecture starts with the feature extraction module-based Convolution block and adaptive feature recalibration (AFR). In particular, throughout the one-dimensional temporal and spatial convolution layers, the convolution module picks up low-level local characteristics, and the AFR can improve the quality of the extracted features by modeling the inter-dependencies between the features. The global correlation within the local temporal features is extracted by simply connecting the self-attention module. Subsequently, the LightGBM classifier module is used to predict the categories for EEG data trained on the extracted features. Finally, we have carried out comprehensive tests to evaluate our approach on the publicly available BCI Competition IV 2a dataset in EEG-based motor imagery and emotion identification procedures. The experimental results indicate the potential of this approach for advancing BCI systems, achieving an accuracy of 74.73%, which outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Traffic Sign Classification Across Borders: Evaluating DenseNet201 on Belgium and Bangladesh Signs
authors: Fahmid Al Farid, Hezerul Abdul Karim, Md Roman Bhuiyan, Farshad Badie, Duraisamy Balaganesh, Md. Mahbubur Rahman Tusher
abstract: Traffic Sign Recognition (TSR) is essential for autonomous vehicles and intelligent transportation systems. This study compares deep learning-based TSR models trained on two datasets: Belgium Traffic Sign Classification (BTSC) with 62 classes, and Bangladesh Traffic Sign Recognition (BDTSR) with 48 classes. Using a DenseNet201 backbone pre-trained on ImageNet, we applied transfer learning with a custom classification head, data augmentation, and fine-tuning. The model achieved 95.34% validation accuracy on BTSC and 99.17% on BDTSR. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of transfer learning across regions, even with differing signage styles and environ- mental conditions. This highlights the importance of localized training data for building accurate TSR systems, helping improve road safety and autonomous navigation in diverse environments.

title: Benchmarking Few-Shot Anomaly Detection in Image Classification With Low-Rank Adaptation
authors: Hoiman Sum, An Wang, Jiewen Lai, Hongliang Ren
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Recently, numerous advanced zero-shot and few-shot algorithms have been developed; however, their performance varies significantly across different environments. The lack of a standardized benchmark impedes the development and practical application of image anomaly detection (IAD) methods in real-world scenarios. Furthermore, without a uniform benchmark, researchers encounter difficulties conducting effective analyses of these algorithms. Consequently, this paper aims to establish a comprehensive benchmark for image anomaly detection, evaluating zero-shot and few-shot image classification models. This benchmark illustrates anomaly classification performance across varying threshold values for different models, tested on major datasets, utilizing consistent metrics and conditions. Additionally, this paper explores new methods to improve model performance. Specifically, we propose integrating Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) into conventional models. LoRA facilitates the adaptation of large and complex machine learning models for specific applications by introducing lightweight components to the original architecture, rather than necessitating a complete overhaul of the model. In the 8-shot setting on the MVTec-AD dataset, the CLIP-LoRA model achieves an AUROC of 79.9% and an F1-max of 85.5%, while the DINOv2-LoRA model attains an AUROC of 79.3% and an F1-max of 88.5%. These results demonstrate proximity to state-of-the-art performance.

title: An Underactuated Gripper with Grasshopper-Inspired Linkages and Delay Triggering for Pinching and Adaptive Grasping*
authors: Haokai Ding, Yizhe Chen, Dongjun Jia, Wenzeng Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information and Automation (ICIA)
abstract: Traditional parallel grippers require the adjustment of their position by a robotic arm when grasping objects on a table, which undoubtedly increases the difficulty of grasping planar objects of varying sizes. This challenge primarily arises from the circular trajectory exhibited by the fingertips during parallel grasping. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel design for an adaptive gripper that combines both linear parallel grasping and adaptive grasping functions. Specifically, on the one hand, the characteristics of a locust linkage mechanism are utilized to achieve linear motion of the fingertips. On the other hand, a two-stage parallel four-bar linkage mechanism is applied to the gripper to ensure a fixed posture of the terminal finger segments. Additionally, an idle stroke transmission mechanism with delayed triggering is employed to achieve an adaptive grasping effect. Both theoretical and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed robotic hand exhibits excellent grasping performance and is suitable for industrial grasping applications.

title: Water Quality Assessment Via Ensemble Machine Learning
authors: Poornima Ediga, Ponnada Naga Aasritha, Besam Sri Kanya, Ganta Sowmya, Heba Abdul-Jaleel Al-Asady, P Gopalakrishna
publish: 2025 Third International Conference on Industry 4.0 Technology (I4Tech)
abstract: The lack of clean drinking water is hurting a lot of people nowadays across various regions of the globe. Thus, there is a necessity of measuring the water quality. The goal of the paper is to create a machine learning water quality model. It is a data cleaning step followed by a feature selection process based on a Random Forest (RF) classifier and performance optimization through grid search and K-fold cross-validation. The overall goal is to predict the water quality correctly using the necessary characteristics like pH, Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), Carbonate (CO3), Bicarbonate (HCO3), Chloride (Cl), and Fluoride (F). The integrity- and consistency-based process of water quality compilation and recording comes first. The RF classifier is used to select the most important attributes that affect water quality and to select them. Then, the chosen features are trained to the RF model and hyperparameters are optimized by the grid search technique. In order to make the system user-friendly and accessible, a web application that allows the users to input the parameters and get real-time classification results is created. Although the model is very accurate, there are issues with it, including possible bias due to missing value imputation, seasonal water quality fluctuations, and noise in measurements. These we will address in subsequent work with more advanced imputation, temporal modeling, and noise-handling techniques to put greater emphasis on reliability. The model proposed can be put to use in monitoring and control of water quality by environmental scientists, water quality managers and ordinary people.

title: Resistive Switching of Stencil-Printed Graphene Electrode on Oxidized Copper Clad Substrate
authors: Wan Muhammad Haikal Wan Mohamad Zaidi, Shaharin Fadzli Abd Rahman, Asser Sherif Ahmed Abdelnaby, Suhana Mohamed Sultan, Zaharah Johari
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Memristor is a nonvolatile memory structure that can be utilized in various applications such large-scale memory system and analog computing. By incorporating material that sensitive to external stimuli, the functionality of the memristor can be enhanced for realization of low-power smart sensor. Graphene has been extensively investigated as sensor material. In this work, a memristor structure with graphene as top electrode was considered. The memristor device was fabricated on an inexpensive copper clad substrate. The formation of copper oxide as the insulator layer was achieved by thermal oxidation on hot plate or oxidation in sodium hydroxide solutions. The graphene top electrode was formed by stencil printing. The oxidation process using sodium hydroxide produced darker surface, which indicates the formation of tenorite layer. Higher resistance value reflects the formation of insulator layer. Furthermore, oxidation using sodium hydroxide is suitable for the common copper clad as the process can be done at lower temperature. Based on current-voltage characteristics, the high-resistance state (HRS) and lowresistance state (LRS) could be observed. HRS-to-LRS ratio was calculated to be 1.15. The resistive switching of the fabricated device was also verified through observation of device resistance switching after DC biasing. Although the HRS-to-LRS ratio is relatively low, the obtained results demonstrated the functionality of the fabricated memristor.

title: Inconsistency Detection in Requirement Boilerplates Ontology Using Reasoner and SPARQL
authors: Audyva Irefilevitasari Alifia, Tri Astoto Kurniawan, Bayu Priyambadha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic and Computer Engineering (ECE)
abstract: Requirement validation in software requirement engineering is a stage to check whether the specified system requirements are in accordance with customer needs. The consistency check of software requirements is one of the key activities during the requirement validation stage. This activity is generally performed manually by analysts, but it can now be automated using various approaches. However, several issues remain in consistency check activity such as: 1) many inconsistency detection studies remain at the syntactic level; 2) the use of static ontologies that cause limitations in handling system change dynamics; and 3) there has been no research on inconsistency detection of software requirements in requirement boilerplates pattern. Therefore, automation of inconsistency detection in requirement boilerplates dynamic ontology offers a promising solution to facilitate consistency checking. This study solves these problems by building a dynamic ontology-based requirement inconsistency detection software by detecting ontology inconsistencies using the HermiT reasoner and matches ontology components with requirement sentences using SPARQL queries. The test results show a precision of 1.00 and a recall of 0.92, based on reasoning and SPARQL querying over a pre-built dynamic requirement boilerplates ontology. By automating this method through a proof-of-concept software implementation, the process of detecting inconsistencies in requirement boilerplates sentences is expected to become more efficient and accurate.

title: High-Purity Molybdenum Powder for High-End Electrical Applications: Trace Detection and Evaluation of Twenty-Four Crucial Impurities
authors: Zhongling Li, Lan Ma, Yuxin Zhai, Zhaoyong Tian, Weijie Lian, Shuang Li
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Energy Materials and Electrical Engineering (ICEMEE)
abstract: High-purity molybdenum powder is a key material in the electrical industry, and its impurity content directly affects the performance and service life of devices. Therefore, it is crucial to determine its impurity element content efficiently and accurately. In this study, we developed an impurity analysis method based on direct current glow discharge mass spectrometry for high-purity molybdenum powder samples. Using high-purity indium sheets as conductive media, we prepared samples by pressing high-purity Mo powder onto indium substrates. By selecting appropriate isotopes and resolutions to minimize mass spectrometric interferences, we established a DC-GDMS method for determining 24 impurity elements (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Na}, \text{Mg}, \text{Al}, \text{Ca}$</tex> and V, etc.) in high-purity molybdenum powder. The optimized experimental parameters were as follows: discharge current 1.8 mA, discharge voltage 1200 V, gas flow rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$400 \text{mL} / \min$</tex>, pre-sputtering time 35 min, and sample layer diameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 m m}$</tex>. Elements <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ca}, \text{Ni}, \text{Se}, \text{Cd}, \text{Sn}$</tex>, Te, and Ta were analyzed at high resolution, whereas the others were analyzed at medium resolution. Experimental results showed that for impurity elements <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>1 \mu \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{g}$</tex>, the RSD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{n}=4)$</tex> ranged between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5. 7 4 8 \%} \boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{3 3. 9 3 5 \%}$</tex>; for elements <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<1 \mu \mathbf{g} / \mathbf{g}$</tex>, the RSD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{n}=\mathbf{4})$</tex> varied from 3.733 % to 48.528 %. Comparative analysis using ICP-MS on representative impurities indicated largely consistent results between the two methods, except for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ca}, \text{Co}, \text{Ni}$</tex>, As, and Cd. The reliability of the established DC-GDMS detection method in ensuring the quality of high-purity molybdenum powder and meeting electrical application requirements has been confirmed.

title: A Novel Transformerless Single-Stage Single-Inductor Buck-Boost Inverter with Leakage Current Suppression Capability
authors: Zhehao Wu, Weimin Wu, Houqing Wang, Mingsan Ouyang, Frede Blaabjerg, Liang Yuan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Power and Renewable Energy (ICPRE)
abstract: This paper proposes a single-stage single-inductor Buck-Boost inverter (SIBBI) with leakage current suppression capability. By controlling the DC-side electrolytic capacitor voltage to remain balanced, common-mode leakage current can be eliminated. Compared to traditional half-bridge Buck-Boost inverters, the SIBBI uses only one inductor for energy regulation, thereby improving the utilisation rate of the inductor during both positive and negative half-cycles, reducing losses and costs, and further enhancing power density. The SIBBI employs a multi-modal control algorithm based on dead-beat control (DBC), ensuring that only one switch is in the high-frequency state at any given time, thereby reducing switching losses. Additionally, when the capacitance of the electrolytic capacitor decreases, the SIBBI can operate in pure Buck-Boost mode, thereby extending the lifespan of the electrolytic capacitor. This makes it suitable for photovoltaic inverter applications.

title: A Classification Algorithm for Epithelial Carcinoma Based on an Attention-Mechanism Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Yifei Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Biomedical Engineering and Bioinformatics for Health (ICBEBH)
abstract: Deep learning has rapidly advanced within the field of artificial intelligence and has been applied across a wide range of domains. Recently, significant progress has been achieved in computer vision and image processing through deep learning techniques, leading to new breakthroughs in the medical field. By leveraging deep learning model architectures, it is now possible to address cancer staging diagnosis for diseases such as lung cancer. This study proposes an improved DenseNet algorithm that integrates the DenseNet architecture with the SE attention mechanism to enhance feature extraction capabilities, thereby improving patient identification and assessment. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits robust lung cancer diagnostic performance, achieving an accuracy of 92.12 % and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex> score of 92.12 %. Compared to the baseline model, this paper's approach improves accuracy by 6.01 % and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score by 6.09 %. Moreover, the integration of the SE mechanism significantly enriches feature representation, which is pivotal for early and precise diagnosis. These findings underscore the potential for further clinical applications, paving the way for more efficient, automated, and reliable diagnostic tools that could ultimately enhance patient care

title: Recent Progress of Capacitor-less IGZO DRAM technology
authors: Xuanming Zhang, Guanhua Yang, Nianduan Lu, Ling Li, Ming Liu
abstract: Traditional Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) technology faces significant scaling challenges as device dimensions approach fundamental physical constraints. Indium-gallium-zinc-oxide (IGZO) has emerged as a potential solution to these scaling limitations, offering advantageous characteristics such as ultra-low leakage currents and compatibility with low-temperature fabrication processes. This paper reviews recent advancements in Two-Transistor Zero-Capacitor (2T0C) DRAM technology that utilize IGZO materials, with a focus on innovations in device architecture and system-level integration.

title: Generative AI-Driven Healthcare: Bridging Technology and Patient-Centric Care
authors: Revuri Jaswanth, S Rakesh Kumar, N Gayathri, Saikat Gochhait, Mohammed Alandoli
abstract: GenAI is emerging as a game changer in the field of medicine and healthcare. New avenues that promise significant improvements in patient care, aggressive conventional medical procedures, and accelerated scientific discoveries pop up due to GenAI. Forensic research offers a meaningful extension of the current trends in GenAI usage, advantages, and challenges in the medical field. From diagnostics, drug discovery, and virtual health assistants to clinical decision support, GenAI has shown the potential to enhance accuracy in diagnosis, personalized treatment, and overall efficiency in daily effective practices in a clinical setup. Also, the paper discusses important challenges that were associated with large-scale application: these include inequities in data provision, privacy concerns, algorithm bias, regulatory issues, and independent validation mechanisms that might ease its adoption. The review synthesizes current findings of the conference papers and journal articles while providing insights into the future directions of GenAI in healthcare, simultaneously marking the place of a co-developed principle behind the responsible evolutionary use of these technologies. The transformative prospect of GenAI for healthcare mostly comes out in this analysis, alongside a call for cooperation between researchers’ clinicians, and legislators for a solid basis and successful intervention for ethical use.

title: DWT-based Image Steganography using CNN-Generated Heatmaps
authors: Jantana Panyayarapom, Paramate Horkaew
abstract: This paper presents a novel steganographic method that integrates a convolutional neural network (CNN) with discrete wavelet transform (DWT). By exploiting the high-frequency sub-bands in the DWT domain, the proposed method embeds a color cover image with a binary secret image. A CNN was used to create a spatial heatmap of the cover image to identify regions that are less sensitive to light. This spatial function is similar to a soft threshold or mask that adjusts the embedding strength as necessary. During the extraction stage, the hidden secret is reassembled using the differences between the stego and cover wavelet coefficients. In the experiments, our method outperformed the DWT method in terms of produced stego image quality (PSNR > 44 dB, SSIM > 0.98), as well as of successfully extracting the hidden image (NC > 0.94, BER < 7%). The proposed system is found to be more robust and secure than traditional approaches, thanks to efficient heatmap generation. This makes it particularly suitable for image-based secure communication.

title: Text-to-Image Generation for Consumer Electronics via Region-Aware Diffusion Transformer
authors: Yimin Zhou, Chengzong Peng, Jie Luo, Juelin Liu, Gengcheng Xu
abstract: Text-to-image generation has advanced rapidly with diffusion models. However, generating realistic and coherent images of consumer electronics remains challenging. Product images must capture fine details, maintain global structural consistency, and align accurately with textual descriptions. To address these needs, we propose RADT (Region-Aware Diffusion Transformer), a diffusion framework tailored for consumer electronics image generation. RADT integrates a Region-Aware Attention (RAA) mechanism into the denoising process. It introduces a dynamic neighborhood window that adjusts to feature complexity, allowing better preservation of local details in electronic products. In addition, RADT employs multi-scale feature aggregation, enabling information sharing across different resolutions and strengthening global structural fidelity. The optimization process is further improved with a dynamically weighted MSE objective, which balances the importance of denoising steps, focusing on structural recovery at early stages and detail refinement at later stages. Together, these innovations make RADT an effective solution for text-guided consumer electronics image generation, providing both methodological contributions and practical value for product design, visualization, and marketing. Experimental results show that RADT can generate images of consumer electronics with superior fidelity, semantic alignment, and structural realism.

title: A Rapid Linear Localization Method for Multiple Magnetic Dipole Sources
authors: Xuning Chen, Jianying Zheng, Yong Cui, Qinglei Hu, Huafu Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper addresses the simultaneous localization problem of multiple magnetic dipole sources distributed at varying heights in space. To overcome the limitations of traditional optimization-based methods, which are time-consuming and prone to local optima, we propose a fast multi-dipole linear localization (MDLL) method. After performing 2D grid measurements, the MDLL method first determines the number of magnetic sources, their initial positions, and magnetic moments by calculating the magnetic gradient tensor and tilt angle. It then filters effective measurement points for each source using the Voronoi diagram and iteratively refines the results through a single-source linear localization scheme to approach the true values. The simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the MDLL method significantly outperforms the benchmark one-step localization (OSL) and differential evolution (DE) methods in both localization accuracy and computational efficiency. In noise-free simulations, the localization error of MDLL is reduced by over 99% compared to OSL and DE, and its computation speed is more than 20,000 times faster than DE in the scenario with 30 magnetic sources, with the advantage becoming more evident as the number of sources increases. In experiment, the average localization error of MDLL are only 4.55% and 36.94% of that of OSL and DE methods, respectively, and its computation time remains significantly shorter than that of the DE method.
